title: Study clawdbot Telegram connector implementation
description: Research and document the existing clawdbot Telegram connector implementation. Identify patterns for long polling, Bot API usage, message handling, inline keyboards, and error recovery. Document learnings and anti-patterns. Use findings to inform fcp.telegram improvements.
close_reason: DUPLICATE: Merged with flywheel_connectors-w1g which has more detailed study plan.

title: fcp.docusign: Track Signature Status
description:
# fcp.docusign: Track Signature Status (FCP2)

## Goal
Allow agents to track envelope progress:
- delivered/signed/completed/declined/voided
- recipient-level status (without leaking PII)

## Scope
- Get envelope status.
- List envelopes with filters (date range, status).
- Optional: ingest Connect webhooks for real-time status updates.

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `docusign.envelopes.read`
- `docusign.webhook.ingest` (optional)

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- NetworkConstraints pinned.
- PII hygiene:
  - recipient names/emails are sensitive
  - logs include only envelope_id + status + timestamps

## Deliverables
- Operation schemas:
  - `docusign.envelope.status.get`
  - `docusign.envelope.list`
  - Optional: `docusign.webhook.ingest`

## Test strategy (MUST)
- Mock-only tests for:
  - status parsing
  - webhook replay/idempotency (if enabled)

## Acceptance criteria
- Envelope status tracking is reliable and safe for automation.

title: fcp.salesforce: Enterprise SSO integration
close_reason: CONSOLIDATED: All Salesforce sub-features merged into comprehensive parent connector bead flywheel_connectors-4m0 (fcp.salesforce: Salesforce CRM Platform Connector)

title: fcp.docusign: Add Recipients and Fields
description:
# fcp.docusign: Add Recipients and Fields (FCP2)

## Goal
Configure envelope recipients and signature fields (tabs) in a safe, typed way.

## Scope
- Add recipients (signer/CC/etc) with routing order.
- Add tabs/fields:
  - signature
  - initials
  - date signed
  - text fields
  - checkbox
- Support both:
  - coordinate-based placement
  - anchor-tag placement (preferred when possible)

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `docusign.envelopes.write`
- `docusign.envelopes.tabs.write`

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- NetworkConstraints pinned.
- PII hygiene:
  - recipient emails/names are sensitive; never log
- Deterministic field placement:
  - stable IDs for recipient roles/tabs

## Deliverables
- Operation schemas:
  - `docusign.envelope.add_recipient`
  - `docusign.envelope.update_recipient`
  - `docusign.envelope.add_tabs`

## Test strategy (MUST)
- Mock-only tests for:
  - recipient routing rules
  - anchor-tag placement
  - redaction

## Acceptance criteria
- Envelopes can be configured reproducibly without leaking recipient PII.

title: fcp.linkedin: Professional Networking Platform Connector
description:
# fcp.linkedin - Professional Networking Platform Connector


## Goal
Provide an FCP2-compliant LinkedIn connector for controlled access to profile/company content and posting workflows under strict policy.

## External surface (NetworkConstraints)
Default deny.
- Network egress MUST be restricted per-operation via manifest `NetworkConstraints` (defined in the connector’s manifest/cap map bead if present).
- Allow only the configured service host(s); HTTPS-only where applicable; deny redirects by default.
- Bound timeouts + response sizes; treat all remote responses as untrusted input; never leak secrets/PII in logs or errors.

## Manifest archetypes (closed set)

- `operational`
- `streaming`

> Interaction patterns (non-archetype): Request/Response + (optional) Webhook/Streaming

## Overview
Comprehensive LinkedIn integration supporting professional profiles, connections, job search, company intelligence, and messaging for recruiting, networking, and business development workflows.

## Value Assessment
- **Value Score**: 72/100 (Tier 4)
- **Use Cases**: Job market intelligence, professional networking, recruiting automation, company research, lead generation
- **Strategic Value**: Access to the world's largest professional network with 900M+ members

## Archetype
**Request-Response**
- LinkedIn APIs are strictly request-response based
- No native streaming or webhook support
- Polling required for real-time-like updates

## API Access Tiers
LinkedIn has multiple API tiers with different access levels:

### Consumer API (Basic)
- Profile read (authenticated user only)
- Share content to user feed
- Limited company page access

### Marketing API (Requires Partnership)
- Ad campaign management
- Audience insights
- Conversion tracking
- Lead gen forms

### Sales Navigator API (Premium)
- Advanced people search
- Lead recommendations
- Account insights
- InMail automation

### Recruiter API (Enterprise)
- Candidate search
- Job posting management
- Applicant tracking integration
- Recruiter InMail

### LinkedIn Learning API
- Course catalog access
- Learning progress tracking
- Skill assessments

## Key Operations

### Profile Operations (Consumer API)
- `linkedin.profile.me` - Get authenticated user profile
- `linkedin.profile.get` - Get profile by URN (limited fields)
- `linkedin.profile.picture.get` - Get profile picture
- `linkedin.profile.email.get` - Get primary email (requires r_emailaddress)

### Connection Operations
- `linkedin.connections.list` - List first-degree connections
- `linkedin.connections.count` - Get connection count
- `linkedin.connections.mutual` - Get mutual connections with user

### Sharing Operations
- `linkedin.share.create` - Create share/post on feed
- `linkedin.share.delete` - Delete owned share
- `linkedin.ugc.create` - Create user-generated content
- `linkedin.ugc.get` - Get UGC post details
- `linkedin.media.upload` - Upload images/videos for posts
- `linkedin.reactions.get` - Get reactions on content
- `linkedin.comments.list` - List comments on post
- `linkedin.comments.create` - Comment on post

### Company Operations
- `linkedin.company.get` - Get company page by ID
- `linkedin.company.lookup` - Lookup by vanity name/domain
- `linkedin.company.posts.list` - Get company updates
- `linkedin.company.followers.count` - Follower statistics
- `linkedin.company.admin.posts.create` - Post as company (admin only)

### Job Operations (Jobs API)
- `linkedin.jobs.search` - Search job listings
- `linkedin.jobs.get` - Get job details by ID
- `linkedin.jobs.recommended` - Get recommended jobs for user
- `linkedin.jobs.saved.list` - List saved jobs
- `linkedin.jobs.saved.add/remove` - Manage saved jobs
- `linkedin.jobs.apply.start` - Initiate Easy Apply flow

### Job Posting Operations (Recruiter API)
- `linkedin.jobs.post.create` - Create job posting
- `linkedin.jobs.post.update` - Update job posting
- `linkedin.jobs.post.close` - Close job posting
- `linkedin.jobs.applicants.list` - List applicants

### Messaging Operations (Messaging API)
- `linkedin.messaging.conversations.list` - List conversations
- `linkedin.messaging.messages.list` - Get messages in conversation
- `linkedin.messaging.messages.send` - Send message
- `linkedin.messaging.inmail.send` - Send InMail (Premium)

### Search Operations (Sales Navigator/Recruiter)
- `linkedin.search.people` - Advanced people search
- `linkedin.search.companies` - Company search
- `linkedin.search.jobs` - Job search with filters
- `linkedin.search.content` - Content/post search

### Marketing Operations (Marketing API)
- `linkedin.ads.accounts.list` - List ad accounts
- `linkedin.ads.campaigns.list/create/update` - Campaign management
- `linkedin.ads.creatives.list/create` - Ad creative management
- `linkedin.ads.analytics.get` - Campaign analytics
- `linkedin.leads.forms.list` - List lead gen forms
- `linkedin.leads.submissions.list` - Get form submissions

## Authentication
- **OAuth 2.0 (3-legged)**: Primary authentication method
- **Scopes**:
  - `r_liteprofile` - Basic profile (deprecated)
  - `r_basicprofile` - Basic profile data
  - `r_emailaddress` - Primary email
  - `r_organization_admin` - Company page admin
  - `r_organization_social` - Company social features
  - `w_member_social` - Post on behalf of member
  - `w_organization_social` - Post as organization
  - `rw_ads` - Advertising APIs
  - `r_marketing_leadgen_automation` - Lead gen access
  - `rw_organization_admin` - Full company admin
- **Token Refresh**: 60-day refresh token validity

## Rate Limiting
LinkedIn has aggressive rate limiting:
- **Daily call limit**: 100,000 calls/day per app
- **Per-member limit**: Varies by endpoint
- **Rate limit headers**: `X-RateLimit-Limit`, `X-RateLimit-Remaining`
- **Throttling**: 429 responses with retry-after
- **Rolling window**: Most limits use 24-hour rolling window

### Rate Limit Strategy
- Implement call budget tracking per day
- Per-user rate limit isolation
- Exponential backoff on 429
- Request queuing with priority
- Cache aggressively (profiles change infrequently)

## Zone Architecture

<!-- fcp2-single-zone-note -->
**FCP2 single-zone binding note:** A connector instance binds to exactly one `ZoneId` for its entire lifetime.
The *"zones"* described in this section are a **recommended deployment pattern** (run separate connector instances in separate zones with different capability grants/policies) and/or conceptual risk tiers.
The connector MUST NOT multiplex multiple zones internally.

```
Zone 0 (Public):     Public company pages, job listings
Zone 1 (Authorized): Own profile, connections list
Zone 2 (Private):    Messages, InMail content, saved jobs
Zone 3 (Sensitive):  OAuth tokens, ad account credentials
```

## API Quirks and Limitations
1. **URN-based identifiers**: All entities use `urn:li:*` format
2. **Projection fields**: Must explicitly request fields via projection parameter
3. **API versioning**: Uses dated versioning (e.g., `202401`)
4. **Strict TOS**: Many use cases require partnership approval
5. **Scraping prohibited**: Strict enforcement against unauthorized access
6. **No bulk operations**: Single-entity requests only
7. **Limited historical data**: Most APIs return recent data only

## Error Handling
- `401 Unauthorized`: Token expired or invalid
- `403 Forbidden`: Missing scope or TOS violation
- `429 Too Many Requests`: Rate limit exceeded
- `451 Unavailable For Legal Reasons`: Regional restrictions

## Dependencies
- `fcp-core`: Base connector traits, zone management
- `fcp-oauth`: OAuth 2.0 flow handling
- `fcp-ratelimit`: Daily/per-user rate limiting
- `fcp-telemetry`: API call metrics and monitoring

## Integration Considerations
- LinkedIn API access requires app review for most scopes
- Marketing/Sales Navigator APIs need partnership agreements
- Consider implementing profile caching layer
- URN resolution/mapping utilities needed
- Support both v1 and v2 API formats

## Implementation Priority
1. OAuth flow with proper scope management
2. Profile operations (me, basic get)
3. Sharing/posting operations
4. Company information retrieval
5. Job search and listings
6. Messaging (requires additional approval)
7. Marketing APIs (partnership dependent)

## Compliance Notes
- GDPR data export support required
- User consent for data access must be clear
- Respect user privacy settings
- LinkedIn Professional Community Guidelines apply

## Acceptance Criteria
- The functionality described in this bead is implemented with typed schemas + validation (no unstructured “stringly” interfaces).
- Errors map to the FCP error taxonomy with correct retry semantics and no secret/PII leakage.
- Mock-only unit/integration tests cover success paths and common failures and emit structured JSON logs per `flywheel_connectors-1n78.35`.

title: fcp.linkedin: Manifest + Capability Map (FCP2)
description:
## Goal
Produce the full FCP2 manifest and capability map for this connector.

This bead is where we translate the connector’s functional surface (operations) into a **mechanically checkable** contract:
- operation schemas + schema IDs
- capability families per operation
- per-operation NetworkConstraints (default deny)
- sandbox profile requirements
- declared state model (stateless / singleton_writer / crdt)

## Required content (must be explicit)
- Operation list is exhaustive and stable for the current phase.
- Capability IDs DO NOT encode hostnames/ports.
- NetworkConstraints are minimal and per-operation.
- Risk tier for each operation (Safe / Dangerous).
- Explicit bounds: timeouts, max response sizes, pagination limits.

## Tests
- Add good/bad manifest examples for the compliance runner.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Passes static checks in `flywheel_connectors-1n78.21.5`.
- Default-deny is enforced by manifest + capability requirements.

title: fcp.linkedin: Provisioning Automation
description:
## Goal
Automate provisioning and configuration with minimal human steps.

This bead owns:
- auth setup (OAuth / API keys / webhook secrets) via `CredentialObject`/`CredentialId` (egress proxy injection preferred)
- endpoint configuration
- `fcp doctor` readiness checks
- deterministic, mockable provisioning flows

## FCP2 requirements
- Secrets never touch disk.
- Provisioning is deterministic and testable.
- Error messages are actionable and do not leak secrets/PII.

## Acceptance Criteria
- No real external calls in unit tests.
- Provisioning emits structured logs per `flywheel_connectors-1n78.35`.

title: TEST: fcp.linkedin Unit/Integration Tests (mock-only)
description:
## Goal
Mock-only unit/integration tests for this connector.

## Required coverage
- schema validation (inputs + outputs)
- error taxonomy mapping (retry semantics)
- pagination and bounds
- rate limit behavior
- redaction (no token/secret/PII leakage)
- idempotency + receipts for Dangerous operations

## Logging
All tests emit structured JSON logs per `flywheel_connectors-1n78.35`.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Deterministic tests; no live external calls.
- Includes adversarial cases (timeouts, malformed responses, partial failures).

title: E2E: fcp.linkedin Connector Compliance Run
description:
## Goal
Run the shared connector compliance runner and capture an evidence bundle.

## Must validate
- handshake + introspection correctness
- default deny (no CapabilityToken → deny + DecisionReceipt)
- NetworkConstraints enforcement
- receipts/audit for Dangerous operations
- structured logs

## Acceptance Criteria
- E2E run is deterministic and produces a stable artifact bundle.

title: fcp.postgresql: PostgreSQL Database Connector
description:
# fcp.postgresql - PostgreSQL Database Connector


## Goal
Provide an FCP2-compliant PostgreSQL connector for safe SQL query/transaction execution and optional LISTEN/NOTIFY streaming.

## External surface (NetworkConstraints)
Default deny.
- Network egress MUST be restricted per-operation via manifest `NetworkConstraints` (defined in the connector’s manifest/cap map bead if present).
- Allow only the configured service host(s); HTTPS-only where applicable; deny redirects by default.
- Bound timeouts + response sizes; treat all remote responses as untrusted input; never leak secrets/PII in logs or errors.
- For DB connectors, constrain raw TCP connects to explicit host:port (or unix socket path) only; deny private ranges unless explicitly allowed by policy.

## Overview
PostgreSQL database connector for SQL queries, transactions, and connection pooling.

## Manifest archetypes (closed set)
- `storage`
- `operational`
- `streaming`

> Interaction patterns (non-archetype): Database access (SQL) + (optional) LISTEN/NOTIFY streaming

## Key Operations

### Query Operations
- `pg.query` - Execute parameterized SQL query
- `pg.execute` - Execute non-returning statement
- `pg.batch` - Execute multiple statements
- `pg.prepared` - Execute prepared statement
- `pg.explain` - Explain query plan

### Transaction Operations
- `pg.transaction.begin` - Start transaction
- `pg.transaction.commit` - Commit transaction
- `pg.transaction.rollback` - Rollback transaction
- `pg.transaction.savepoint` - Create savepoint
- Isolation levels: READ COMMITTED, REPEATABLE READ, SERIALIZABLE

### Schema Operations
- `pg.schema.tables` - List tables
- `pg.schema.columns` - Get column info
- `pg.schema.indexes` - List indexes
- `pg.schema.constraints` - Get constraints

### Advanced Features
- COPY protocol for bulk load/unload
- LISTEN/NOTIFY for event handling
- Row streaming for large results
- JSON/JSONB operations
- Full-text search support
- PostGIS spatial queries

### Connection Pool
- Configurable pool size
- Connection health checks
- Statement timeout
- Query logging

## Authentication
- Password authentication
- SSL/TLS connections
- Certificate authentication
- AWS IAM (RDS)
- Cloud SQL IAM (GCP)

## Providers Supported
- PostgreSQL (self-hosted)
- AWS RDS/Aurora
- Google Cloud SQL
- Azure Database
- Supabase
- Neon
- CockroachDB (compatible)

## Zone Architecture

<!-- fcp2-single-zone-note -->
**FCP2 single-zone binding note:** A connector instance binds to exactly one `ZoneId` for its entire lifetime.
The *"zones"* described in this section are a **recommended deployment pattern** (run separate connector instances in separate zones with different capability grants/policies) and/or conceptual risk tiers.
The connector MUST NOT multiplex multiple zones internally.

\`\`\`
Zone 0 (Public):     Schema metadata
Zone 1 (Authorized): Read queries
Zone 2 (Private):    Write operations
Zone 3 (Sensitive):  DDL, admin operations
\`\`\`

## Security
- Parameterized queries (no SQL injection)
- Query whitelisting option
- Statement timeout enforcement
- Connection limit enforcement

## Dependencies
- fcp-core, fcp-config, fcp-testkit, fcp-telemetry

## Acceptance Criteria
- The functionality described in this bead is implemented with typed schemas + validation (no unstructured “stringly” interfaces).
- Errors map to the FCP error taxonomy with correct retry semantics and no secret/PII leakage.
- Mock-only unit/integration tests cover success paths and common failures and emit structured JSON logs per `flywheel_connectors-1n78.35`.

title: fcp-security: Security Testing and Audit Framework
description:
# fcp-security: Security Testing and Audit Framework

## Overview
Security-focused library providing capability validation, input sanitization, audit logging, and security testing utilities for FCP connectors.

## Capability Token Validation
- Ed25519 signature verification
- Token expiration validation
- Issuer/audience verification
- Capability scope enforcement
- Resource constraint checking
- Constant-time comparison

## Zone Security
- Zone boundary enforcement
- Trust level validation
- Cross-zone access prevention
- Zone hierarchy traversal
- Provenance tracking

## Input Validation
- SQL injection detection
- XSS pattern detection
- Command injection patterns
- Path traversal detection
- SSRF prevention helpers
- Content-Type validation

## Audit Logging
- Security event capture
- Structured audit records
- Tamper-evident logging
- Correlation ID tracking
- PII redaction
- Retention policy support

## Security Testing
- Fuzzing helpers
- Property-based testing utilities
- Security assertion macros
- Vulnerability pattern matchers

## Cryptographic Utilities
- Secure random generation
- Key derivation functions
- Constant-time operations
- Secure memory handling (zeroize)

## Dependencies
- ed25519-dalek, sha2, hmac
- zeroize, rand
- regex (for pattern detection)
- fcp-core
close_reason: Superseded by FCP2 crypto primitives (1n78.5) and capabilities (1n78.7). The security framework functionality is now distributed across the FCP V2 architecture.

title: [FCP2] MVP: Mesh-Native Core Platform (Rust)
description:
# [FCP2] MVP: Mesh-Native Core Platform (Rust)


## Goal
Build the FCP2 (V2-only) Rust reference implementation: mesh-native, symbol-first, zone-isolated, capability-gated core platform with conformance suite and performance budgets.

## Why this exists
We are building the **FCP V2-only** reference implementation in Rust: a mesh-native, symbol-first, zone-isolated, capability-gated connector platform. The deliverable is the **system described by the FCP V2 specification + README + connector model guide**, implemented as a set of Rust crates and CLIs that can power a library of production connectors.

This epic is the parent for the concrete subsystem issues that implement the MVP conformance target.

## Non-negotiable project constraints
- **NO backwards compatibility:** We do **not** support FCP1/JSON-RPC compatibility modes, translators, or hybrid shims. If migrating from anything older, do a clean cutover.
- **No unsafe Rust:** `#![forbid(unsafe_code)]` everywhere.
- **Ultra-optimized defaults:** low latency, low allocation churn, bounded memory spikes, predictable performance.
- **Security is mechanical:** enforcement must not depend on agent prompts.

## The three axioms (what everything must preserve)
1. **Universal Fungibility:** Every durable thing is a content-addressed object that is symbol-addressable (RaptorQ). Even when transported via a control-plane stream, it must still have a canonical object form.
2. **Authenticated Mesh:** Tailscale is transport and identity (node IDs, ACL tags). FCP must assume the tailnet is authenticated but still enforce crypto + policy.
3. **Explicit Authority:** No ambient authority. All authority chains back to the owner root key via verifiable signatures.

## MVP conformance target (ship this first)
This epic is complete when we have a V2-only platform that supports, at minimum:
- **Canonical object format**: deterministic CBOR with schema-hash prefix; stable schema IDs/hashes.
- **Security object addressing**: keyed ObjectId derivation bound to zone + schema for security-relevant objects.
- **Zone crypto**: ZoneKeyManifest distribution (HPKE sealed boxes) and rotation.
- **Capability system**: COSE_Sign1 (CWT) CapabilityTokens with grant_object_ids verification; aud_binary binding for risky ops.
- **Revocation**: revocation objects + head/seq freshness semantics + policy (Strict/Warn/BestEffort).
- **Receipts**: OperationIntent + OperationReceipt for exactly-once semantics where required.
- **Audit**: AuditEvent chain + AuditHead + ZoneCheckpoint + DecisionReceipt for explainability.
- **Wire protocols**:
  - **FCPS** symbol-native data plane (frame format, per-symbol AEAD, per-session MACs).
  - **FCPC** control plane (ordered, backpressured framing of canonical control-plane objects).
- **RaptorQ + chunking**: symbol encoding/decoding for objects; ChunkedObjectManifest for large objects.
- **Stores**: object store + symbol store + placement policy + background repair loop + retention/GC roots.
- **MeshNode**: peer discovery via Tailscale, routing, admission control, and distributed coordination primitives (leases).
- **Sandbox + egress proxy**: enforce NetworkConstraints and deny-by-default egress.
- **Connector SDK + manifest**: connectors implement standard methods and embed a manifest; SDK makes this ergonomic.
- **Conformance harness**: golden vectors, fuzz targets, and mechanical compliance checks.

## Definition of Done (quality gates)
- `cargo check --all-targets`
- `cargo clippy --all-targets -- -D warnings`
- `cargo fmt --check`
- `cargo test` (including conformance tests)
- Fuzz targets exist for the spec-required surfaces (frame parsing, handshake transcripts, token verification, key manifests).
- Benchmarks exist for the hot paths (ObjectId, CBOR canonicalization, FCPS parse, RaptorQ decode).

## Work breakdown (child issues)
This epic is intentionally decomposed into subsystem issues (types/crypto/protocol/store/mesh/sandbox/sdk/conformance). Each child issue must be self-contained with:
- a crisp scope and non-goals
- concrete deliverables
- acceptance criteria and test strategy
- performance and security considerations

## Success Criteria
- The MVP system can execute a V2 connector end-to-end under zone/capability enforcement, producing receipts and audit events.
- Conformance suite is green (golden vectors + fuzz targets exist and run).
- No unsafe code; performance budgets are tracked and not regressing.

title: [FCP2] Requirements Index: Spec-to-Implementation Matrix (V2-only)
description:
# [FCP2] Requirements Index: Spec-to-Implementation Matrix (V2-only)


## Goal
Maintain a complete, V2-only mapping from spec/docs to owning implementation+test beads so the whole system can be built without re-reading the docs.

## Purpose
This bead is the **single source of truth** mapping from:
- `FCP_Specification_V2.md`
- `README.md`
- `docs/fcp_model_connectors_rust.md`

…to the **owning Beads** (implementation + tests).

If we keep this up to date, engineers should be able to implement FCP2 by following the Beads graph **without rereading the spec/docs**.

## How to Use This Bead
- Treat each entry as a **mechanical checklist** item.
- When you discover a missing requirement, update this matrix first, then:
  - create the missing owning bead(s), or
  - expand the owning bead’s scope/acceptance criteria/tests.

## Conformance Profiles (Spec §25)
- **MVP Profile:** must ship first and is the default target for the reference implementation.
- **Full Profile:** post-MVP hardening features (enabled by explicit configuration/policy).

This matrix labels some items as **MVP** or **Full**. Many are shared.

## V2-Only Clarifications (Spec §26)
- FCP2 makes **no backwards-compat guarantees** with FCP1.
- No hybrid translator layer.
- Clean cutover only.

## Pricing / Cost Tracking Clarification (Connector-facing)
- Connectors MUST emit **usage metrics**.
- We do **not** embed hard-coded pricing tables in connectors (pricing changes frequently).
- If cost estimates are supported, they are explicit and policy/ops-owned (e.g., `CostEstimate`).

---

# A) Spec Coverage Matrix — `FCP_Specification_V2.md`

Below, each chapter lists:
- **Owners**: implementation beads responsible for building it.
- **Primary Tests/Conformance**: golden vectors, fuzz, interop, E2E, compliance runner.
- **Notes / Key Requirements**: the “sharp edges” we must not forget.

## Spec: Conformance Language
Owners:
- `flywheel_connectors-1n78.21` (overall conformance)

Primary Tests/Conformance:
- `flywheel_connectors-1n78.21.1` (CDDL + golden vectors)

Notes / Key Requirements:
- RFC2119 language interpretation.
- Anything labeled NORMATIVE is part of the interop/security contract.

## Spec §1: Introduction (informative)
Owners:
- `flywheel_connectors-1n78.1` (this matrix)

Primary Tests/Conformance:
- n/a

Notes / Key Requirements:
- Establishes that FCP is object-native, mesh-authenticated, explicit authority.

## Spec §2: Foundational Axioms
Owners:
- `flywheel_connectors-1n78.3` (canonical serialization)
- `flywheel_connectors-1n78.4` (IDs + headers)
- `flywheel_connectors-1n78.11` (audit/checkpoints as roots)

Primary Tests/Conformance:
- `flywheel_connectors-1n78.21.1` (golden vectors + CDDL)

Notes / Key Requirements:
- Persisted/audited/mirrored things must be representable as canonical mesh objects.
- Mesh is authenticated; authority is explicit and provable.

## Spec §3: Foundational Primitives
Owners:
- `flywheel_connectors-1n78.4` (ObjectId/EpochId/ZoneId/Schemas/ObjectHeader)
- `flywheel_connectors-1n78.3` (canonical CBOR + schema hash)
- `flywheel_connectors-1n78.5` (crypto primitives)

Primary Tests/Conformance:
- `flywheel_connectors-1n78.21.1` (golden vectors + CDDL)
- `flywheel_connectors-1n78.21.2` (fuzz: parsers/decoders/verifiers)

Notes / Key Requirements:
- Canonical identifier formats; reject non-canonical forms (no silent normalization).
- ObjectHeader rules + retention semantics and root pointers.
- HPKE sealed box shape requirements (used by zone crypto).
- ZoneCheckpoint is the “root pointer” (GC/security).

## Spec §4: Symbol Layer
Owners:
- `flywheel_connectors-1n78.12` (FCPS framing + SymbolEnvelope AEAD)
- `flywheel_connectors-1n78.24` (session auth, key schedule, anti-replay)
- `flywheel_connectors-1n78.14` (RaptorQ + chunking)
- `flywheel_connectors-1n78.17.2` (multipath + transport priority)

Primary Tests/Conformance:
- `flywheel_connectors-1n78.21.1` (golden vectors)
- `flywheel_connectors-1n78.21.2` (fuzz)
- `flywheel_connectors-1n78.21.3` (interop)

Notes / Key Requirements:
- Session MACs required for throughput; Poly1305 key reuse rules.
- MTU safety and explicit frame size limits.
- Multipath delivery must respect ZoneTransportPolicy.

## Spec §5: Zone Architecture
Owners:
- `flywheel_connectors-1n78.26` (ZoneDefinition/ZonePolicy/roles/resource objects/reason codes)
- `flywheel_connectors-1n78.16` (Zone ↔ Tailscale tag mapping, port gating)

Maps all 27+ spec sections, README sections, and connector doc sections to owning implementation and test beads. title: WORKFLOW: Specification Refinement with APR (V2 docs)
description:
# WORKFLOW: Specification Refinement with APR (V2 docs)

## Goal
Capture the APR-based iterative spec refinement workflow in a fully self-contained Bead so we do not need to reread README.md to run refinement rounds.

## Context
The repo uses APR (Automated Plan Reviser Pro) + Oracle (browser automation) to run multi-round reviews of the FCP2 docs with GPT Pro.

This workflow is **for documents**, not for connector binaries or the runtime platform. It exists to continuously harden and clarify:
- `FCP_Specification_V2.md` (authoritative)
- `docs/fcp_model_connectors_rust.md` (connector authoring + implementation guidance)
- `README.md` (overview + ops/dev UX)

## Scope
In scope:
- How to install and run APR rounds.
- How to include the implementation doc periodically.
- How to run remotely (Oracle serve mode) when the dev box has no browser.
- How to integrate APR feedback back into the docs in a disciplined way.

Out of scope:
- Any “backwards compatibility” plan with FCP1. FCP2 is a clean cutover.
- Installing Node/npm tooling as a requirement for the shipped platform.

## Why this matters
The spec is large and security-sensitive. Iterative AI review is a force multiplier, but only if:
- we can repeat it reliably,
- we can reproduce what changed and why,
- and we integrate feedback in a way that preserves the spec’s internal consistency.

## Baseline assumptions
- You have a GPT Pro account available for Oracle/APR.
- You can authenticate in a browser for the initial APR run.
- You can run the workflow either locally or with Oracle serve mode over Tailscale.

## Workflow configuration
APR workflow file: `.apr/workflows/fcp.yaml`

Expected config (informational):
- Documents:
  - `readme`: `README.md`
  - `spec`: `FCP_Specification_V2.md`
  - `implementation`: `docs/fcp_model_connectors_rust.md`

## Setup (one-time)
Install APR:
```bash
curl -fsSL "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Dicklesworthstone/automated_plan_reviser_pro/main/install.sh" | bash
```

Install Oracle (browser automation):
```bash
npm install -g @steipete/oracle
```

Note: Oracle is tooling only; it is not part of the FCP2 runtime distribution.

## Running revision rounds
First round (requires manual ChatGPT login):
```bash
apr run 1 --login --wait
```

Subsequent rounds:
```bash
apr run 2
apr run 3 --include-impl  # include implementation doc every 3–4 rounds
```

Inspect status and output:
```bash
apr status
apr show 5
```

## Remote/SSH setup (Oracle “serve mode”)
Use this if your dev box is remote (SSH) and cannot open a local browser.

On your local machine (with browser):
```bash
oracle serve --port 9333 --token "your-secret-token"
```

On the remote server:
```bash
export ORACLE_REMOTE_HOST="100.x.x.x:9333"  # local machine’s Tailscale IP
export ORACLE_REMOTE_TOKEN="your-secret-token"

# test connection
oracle -p "test" -e browser -m "5.2 Thinking"

# now APR works normally
apr run 1
```

Important: use port `9333` (not `9222`) to avoid clashing with Chrome DevTools.

## Integration discipline (how to apply feedback)
When APR produces feedback for round N:

1) Prime the coding agent with full context (don’t assume partial memory):
- Read ALL of `AGENTS.md` and `README.md`.
- Read `FCP_Specification_V2.md` and `docs/fcp_model_connectors_rust.md`.

2) Integrate feedback carefully:
- Treat GPT output as suggestions; validate each claim against the spec’s goals.
- Prefer “mechanical enforcement” changes over editorial prose.
- Ensure changes do not introduce FCP1 compatibility shims.

3) Harmonize docs in this order:
- Update `README.md` first for the human-facing story.
- Update `docs/fcp_model_connectors_rust.md` to keep connector authoring aligned.
- Update `FCP_Specification_V2.md` last (authoritative) to ensure correctness.

4) Commit in logical groupings with clear messages.

## Useful APR commands
```bash
apr status          # check Oracle sessions
apr list            # list workflows
apr history         # show revision history
apr diff 4 5        # compare rounds 4 and 5
apr stats           # convergence analytics
apr integrate 5 -c  # copy integration prompt to clipboard
```

## Key files
- `FCP_Specification_V2.md` — main protocol specification
- `docs/fcp_model_connectors_rust.md` — Rust implementation guide
- `.apr/workflows/fcp.yaml` — workflow configuration
- `.apr/rounds/fcp/round_N.md` — GPT Pro output per round

## Acceptance Criteria
- A new contributor can run APR rounds without consulting README.md.
- The workflow notes explicitly keep FCP2 V2-only (no FCP1 compatibility work).
- The workflow documents remote mode and integration discipline.
close_reason: Created docs/WORKFLOW_APR_Specification_Refinement.md - comprehensive APR workflow documentation covering setup (APR + Oracle), running rounds, remote/SSH mode with Oracle serve, integration discipline (document update order, feedback validation), useful commands reference, and V2-only reminders. New contributors can now run APR spec refinement without consulting README.md.

title: [FCP2] Exactly-Once Semantics: OperationIntent + OperationReceipt + Idempotency
description:
# [FCP2] Exactly-Once Semantics: OperationIntent + OperationReceipt + Idempotency

## Goal
Provide exactly-once semantics for external side effects (where required) by combining:
- an idempotency key
- an OperationIntent pre-commit object
- an OperationReceipt object that is returned on retries

## Required behavior (spec-aligned)
- For Strict idempotency and for Risky/Dangerous operations:
  - MeshNode MUST store OperationIntent (Required retention) **before** executing external side effects.
  - OperationIntent SHOULD bind to the execution lease fencing token (`lease_seq`) when applicable.
  - OperationReceipt MUST reference the OperationIntent.
  - Retries with the same idempotency key must return the prior receipt without re-executing.

## Subtasks
- Define OperationIntent and OperationReceipt schemas (include refs/evidence fields; include optional upstream idempotency handle).
- Define storage/indexing model to look up receipts by idempotency key.
- Integrate with audit: emitting audit events on intent and receipt.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Unit tests: retry returns same receipt without re-execution.
- Fault injection tests: crash between intent and receipt is handled safely (detect and reconcile incomplete intents).
close_reason: Implemented OperationIntent and OperationReceipt schemas with IdempotencyEntry for exactly-once semantics. Includes validation functions, orphan detection, and comprehensive tests. Fixed lease.rs tests that were broken from previous struct changes.

title: [FCP2] Wire Protocol (Control Plane): FCPC Frames + Canonical ControlPlaneObject Retention
description:
# [FCP2] Wire Protocol (Control Plane): FCPC Frames + Canonical ControlPlaneObject Retention

## Goal
Implement reliable, ordered, backpressured control-plane framing for canonical objects (invoke/response/receipts/approvals/audit/etc).

FCPC exists to make small control-plane messages fast and reliable without forcing everything through RaptorQ.

## Normative transport requirements
- Implementations **MUST** support FCPC over **QUIC streams** inside the tailnet.
- Implementations **MAY** support FCPC over TCP as a fallback.

## Security requirements (NORMATIVE)
- FCPC messages MUST be bound to an authenticated MeshSession.
- FCPC payloads MUST be authenticated using `k_ctx` derived from the MeshSession key schedule.
- Implementations SHOULD encrypt FCPC payloads (AEAD) using `k_ctx`.

## Control-plane object model (NORMATIVE)
All control-plane message types MUST have a canonical CBOR object representation with SchemaId/ObjectId.

### ControlPlaneObject
- `ObjectHeader`
- `body` = canonical payload bytes (`schema_hash || canonical_cbor`)

### Retention classes (NORMATIVE)
Some control-plane objects MUST be stored (auditable/replayable), others MAY be ephemeral.

Examples:
- **Required**: invoke/response, receipts, approvals, secret access, revocations, audit events/heads
- **Ephemeral**: health, handshake objects, decode_status, symbol_ack, introspect, configure, simulate

## FCPC frame format (NORMATIVE)
Conceptual frame:

```
magic = "FCPC"
version = u16
session_id = [16]
seq = u64 (per-direction monotonic)
flags = u16
len = u32
ciphertext[len] (AEAD under k_ctx)
tag = [16]
```

AEAD rules:
- Nonce derived deterministically from `seq` (direction-specific).
- AAD includes at minimum `session_id || seq || flags`.

Replay protection:
- Receivers MUST enforce a bounded replay/reorder window (same scale as SessionReplayPolicy.max_reorder_window).
- `seq` MUST be strictly increasing per direction for an authenticated session.

## Transport options (spec surface)
The spec describes multiple ways to transport control-plane objects:
1. **FCPC (required)**: QUIC stream framing using `k_ctx`
2. **Direct local (optional)**: canonical bytes over local connector transport (may reuse FCPC framing)
3. **Mesh fallback (optional but important)**: encode canonical ControlPlaneObjects to symbols and send inside FCPS frames with `FrameFlags::CONTROL_PLANE` set

This issue owns (1) and a reusable framing library. (3) is implemented/owned by MeshNode because it couples to routing, stores, and repair.

## Deliverables
- `FcpcFrame` encoder/decoder with strict bounds checks and no unbounded allocation.
- Backpressure/flow control integration with QUIC stream semantics.
- Retention enforcement hooks: Required objects are stored; Ephemeral objects may be dropped after processing.

## Tests
- Unit tests:
  - seq ordering
  - replay window enforcement
  - backpressure behavior under slow consumers
- Fuzz target for FCPC frame parsing.

## Acceptance Criteria
- FCPC can carry InvokeRequest/Response + receipts end-to-end in the system harness.
- Conformance fuzz target runs without panics.

title: [FCP2] RaptorQ + Chunking: Symbol Encoding/Decoding, ChunkedObjectManifest, Decode DoS Mitigation
close_reason:
Implemented RaptorQ fountain code encoding/decoding and chunking policy in fcp-raptorq crate. All 58 tests passing. Includes:
- RaptorQConfig with spec-aligned defaults (symbol size, repair ratio, object limits, chunking thresholds)
- ChunkedObjectManifest for objects above max_chunk_threshold with BLAKE3 verification
- RawChunk with content-addressed IDs
- RaptorQEncoder for producing source and repair symbols
- RaptorQDecoder with timeout support

- DecodePermit RAII guard for resource tracking
- EncodingDecision for automatic direct vs chunked encoding

title: [FCP2] Stores: Object Store + Symbol Store + Placement Policy + Background Repair + Retention/GC
description:
# [FCP2] Stores: Object Store + Symbol Store + Placement Policy + Background Repair + Retention/GC

## Goal
Make offline resilience real by implementing:
- content-addressed object store (canonical objects)
- symbol store (partial availability)
- placement policies and measurable coverage
- periodic repair loop (targeted + rate-limited)
- retention classes and well-defined GC roots
- quarantine admission pipeline for untrusted/unreferenced objects

## Required behaviors (spec-aligned)
### Coverage is measurable
Nodes must quantify symbol/object availability using stable, interop-safe metrics (basis points):
- coverage ratio (bps)
- max concentration (avoid single-node dependency)
- distinct-node count

### Repair is bounded and convergent
- Repair loop must push coverage toward policy targets over time.
- Repair must be rate-limited and account for admission-control budgets.

### Retention + GC roots are explicit
- **Store retention** uses `RetentionClass` semantics for stored objects (Pinned | Lease{expires_at} | Ephemeral).
- **Control-plane retention** (Required vs Ephemeral) is a separate concept owned by FCPC/control-plane and maps to store retention by policy.
- GC roots include the zone’s pinned `ZoneCheckpoint` (and other pinned policy/config heads).

### Quarantine admission pipeline (NORMATIVE)
To prevent storage exhaustion from injected garbage ObjectIds:
- Unknown/unreferenced ObjectIds MUST be stored in a **bounded quarantine store** by default.
- Quarantined ObjectIds MUST NOT be inserted into global gossip filters/state until promoted.
- Promotion from quarantine → admitted is allowed only if:
  - object becomes reachable from the zone’s pinned `ZoneCheckpoint`, OR
  - object is explicitly requested by an authenticated peer via a bounded request, OR
  - object is explicitly pinned locally by user action/policy.
- Promotion MUST require successful reconstruction + schema verification (prevents admitting garbage as “real”).

## Subtasks
- Define ObjectPlacementPolicy and CoverageEvaluation (basis points for interop stability).
- Implement ObjectStore + SymbolStore interfaces with strict bounds.
- Implement RepairController run loop with rate limiting + targeted repair support.
- Define retention classes and GC roots.
- Implement quarantine store quotas (per-zone bytes/objects + TTL eviction) and promotion logic.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Unit tests for placement evaluation + retention semantics.
- Simulation tests for repair loop improving coverage.
- Adversarial tests for quarantine quotas + promotion rules.
- Benchmarks for symbol store operations.
close_reason: Completed: promotion validation, adversarial tests, symbol store benchmarks

title: TEST: Store/Placement/Repair Simulation + Bounds
description:
# TEST: Store/Placement/Repair Simulation + Bounds

## Goal
Make offline resilience measurable and bounded. Prove that the store layer maintains availability guarantees.

## Test Categories

### Object Store Tests
- [ ] Object write produces correct ObjectId (keyed derivation)
- [ ] Object read returns identical bytes
- [ ] Missing object returns appropriate error
- [ ] Object metadata (zone, schema, retention) is preserved
- [ ] Object reference counting works correctly
- [ ] Object deletion respects GC roots

### Symbol Store Tests
- [ ] Symbols stored with correct ESI mapping
- [ ] Symbol retrieval by ESI works
- [ ] Symbol availability tracking is accurate
- [ ] Symbol eviction respects retention class
- [ ] Quarantine zone isolation

### Placement Policy Tests
- [ ] Coverage evaluation correctness (basis points calculation)
- [ ] min_coverage threshold enforcement
- [ ] max_concentration limit enforcement (no single-source)
- [ ] Geographic diversity when node location available
- [ ] Placement decisions are deterministic (same inputs → same placement)

### Background Repair Loop Tests
- [ ] Repair loop improves coverage over time (measurable)
- [ ] Repair respects bandwidth budget
- [ ] Repair prioritizes objects below threshold
- [ ] Repair actions produce audit events
- [ ] Repair loop is idempotent (no duplicate work)

### Retention/GC Tests
- [ ] GC roots (ZoneCheckpoint) prevent premature eviction
- [ ] Retention class ordering: Required > Pinned > Cached > Ephemeral
- [ ] Ephemeral objects evicted first under pressure
- [ ] GC produces audit events
- [ ] No orphaned symbols after GC

### ChunkedObjectManifest Tests
- [ ] Large object → manifest + chunks
- [ ] Chunk placement distributed correctly
- [ ] Manifest references valid chunk ObjectIds
- [ ] Reassembly produces original object
- [ ] Partial chunk availability tracked correctly

### Quarantine Tests
- [ ] Quarantine eviction order matches policy (by age, by risk)
- [ ] Quarantined objects isolated from normal storage
- [ ] Quarantine entry produces audit event
- [ ] Quarantine promotion/demotion paths

## Simulation Framework
```rust
#[test]
fn test_repair_improves_coverage() {
    let harness = StoreSimulation::new()
        .with_nodes(5)
        .with_failure_rate(0.1);
    
    harness.store_object(test_object, min_coverage: 5000);
    harness.fail_node(2);
    
    assert!(harness.coverage() < 5000);
    harness.run_repair_loop(Duration::from_secs(10));
    assert!(harness.coverage() >= 5000);
}
```

## Golden Vectors
- Object storage: content → ObjectId mapping
- Placement decisions: node set → placement result
- Coverage calculation: symbol distribution → basis points

## Logging Requirements
All store tests MUST emit structured JSON:
```json
{
  "timestamp": "RFC3339",
  "test_name": "test_repair_improves_coverage",
  "module": "fcp-store",
  "phase": "execute|verify",
  "operation": "write|read|repair|gc|placement",
  "object_id": "...",
  "object_size": 12345,
  "symbol_count": 13,
  "coverage_bps": 7500,
  "nodes_holding": ["node-0", "node-2", "node-4"],
  "result": "pass|fail",
  "duration_us": 1234
}
```

### For Repair Actions
```json
{
  "repair_action": "replicate",
  "object_id": "...",
  "source_node": "node-0",
  "target_node": "node-3",
  "coverage_before_bps": 4000,
  "coverage_after_bps": 6000,
  "reason_code": "BELOW_THRESHOLD"
}
```

### For GC Events
```json
{
  "gc_action": "evict",
  "object_id": "...",
  "retention_class": "Ephemeral",
  "reason": "SPACE_PRESSURE",
  "gc_root_checked": true
}
```

## Determinism Requirements
- Simulation tests MUST use seeded RNG
- All tests MUST be reproducible from seed
- No flaky tests allowed

## Acceptance Criteria
- Simulation tests run deterministically
- Repair loop measurably improves coverage
- GC respects retention and roots
- All operations produce structured logs
- Performance bounds verified
close_reason: Added GC symbol pruning + test

title: [FCP2] Tailscale Integration: MeshIdentity, NodeKeyAttestation, Peer Discovery, ACL Tag Mapping
description:
# [FCP2] Tailscale Integration: MeshIdentity, NodeKeyAttestation, Peer Discovery, ACL Tag Mapping

## Goal
Abstract Tailscale as the authenticated mesh substrate.

## Required behaviors
### MeshIdentity model
MeshIdentity MUST include:
- tailscale node_id
- hostname
- IPs
- ACL tags
- owner_pubkey anchor
- node signing/encryption/issuance pubkeys + kids
- owner-signed NodeKeyAttestation binding `node_id ↔ keys ↔ tags` (and optional DevicePostureAttestation)

### Peer discovery
Provide peer discovery and a stable view of online peers (mockable for tests).

Implementation guidance (non-binding):
- use Tailscale LocalAPI (`/localapi/v0/status`, `/localapi/v0/whois`) behind an interface

### Zone ↔ tag mapping + ACL generation
- ZoneId maps to a Tailscale tag: `tag:fcp-<suffix>`.
- Port-gating ACL generation is a defense-in-depth feature:
  - zone members can reach only zone ports (symbol_port/control_port)
  - policy engine still enforces the true integrity/confidentiality lattice

## Acceptance Criteria
- Unit tests for tag<->zone mapping.
- Mockable interface so tests don't require a real tailnet.
close_reason: Closed

title: [FCP2] MeshNode: Routing, Gossip, Admission Control, Leases, Device-Aware Execution
description:
# [FCP2] MeshNode: Routing, Gossip, Admission Control, Leases, Device-Aware Execution

## Goal
Implement the core runtime node that turns the spec into behavior:
- peer discovery (via Tailscale abstraction)
- session establishment + replay policy
- symbol routing + multipath delivery
- gossip / announcements + reconciliation
- admission control + anti-amplification
- enforcement: zones/caps/taint/approvals/revocation/checkpoint/policy
- distributed coordination: leases
- connector state coordination hooks (singleton_writer)
- device-aware execution planner + delegation

## Why Users Care
MeshNode is where "mechanical security" becomes real:
- It is the enforcement boundary between untrusted inputs and privileged side effects.
- It produces DecisionReceipts and audit events, enabling `fcp explain` and incident response.
- It makes offline availability measurable (coverage) and repairable.

## Recommended Runtime Stack (2025-2026)

| Component | Crate | Version | Notes |
|-----------|-------|---------|-------|
| Async runtime | `tokio` | 1.44+ | io-uring on Linux |
| Networking | `quinn` | 0.12+ | QUIC transport |
| Gossip | `crdt-rs` / custom | - | CRDT-based state sync |
| Hash ring | `hashring` | 0.3+ | Consistent hashing |
| Timer wheel | `tokio-util` | 0.7+ | Efficient timeouts |
| Metrics | `metrics` | 0.24+ | Prometheus/OTEL |
| Tracing | `tracing` | 0.2+ | Distributed tracing |

## Normative Behaviors (Spec-Aligned)

### Default Deny Enforcement Spine
No operation executes unless it passes, in order:
1. canonical decode + schema validation
2. capability token verification (including checkpoint freshness + holder proof)
3. revocation freshness enforcement (per policy tier)
4. taint/approval enforcement (elevation/declassification)
5. zone policy ceilings + connector manifest constraints
6. (when required) execution lease acquisition/validation

Every denial MUST emit a DecisionReceipt with stable `reason_code` and evidence ObjectIds.

```rust
/// Enforcement result with full provenance
pub struct EnforcementResult {
    pub decision: Decision,
    pub reason_code: ReasonCode,
    pub evidence: Vec<ObjectId>,
    pub trace_id: TraceId,
    pub latency: Duration,
}

pub enum Decision {
    Allow { receipt: OperationReceipt },
    Deny { receipt: DecisionReceipt },
}
```

### Transport Priority + Multipath Delivery
Transport path selection is user-visible and policy-controlled.
- Priority order: Direct (LAN) → Mesh NAT traversal → DERP → Funnel
- ZoneTransportPolicy controls DERP/Funnel availability (deny-by-default for high-trust zones)
- Multipath symbol delivery MAY use multiple paths concurrently when allowed

```rust
/// Transport selection with locality scoring
pub struct TransportSelector {
    pub direct: Option<DirectPath>,
    pub mesh: Option<MeshPath>,
    pub derp: Option<DerpPath>,
    pub funnel: Option<FunnelPath>,
}

impl TransportSelector {
    pub fn best_path(&self, policy: &ZoneTransportPolicy) -> Option<&dyn Transport> {
        // Priority-ordered selection respecting policy
    }
}
```

### Admission Control + DoS Resistance (NORMATIVE)
MeshNodes MUST implement admission control for:
- per-peer inbound bytes/symbols
- failed decrypt/MAC counters
- bounded concurrent decodes + decode CPU budgets
- bounded gossip reconciliation work

```rust
/// Admission control state per peer
pub struct PeerAdmission {
    pub inbound_bytes: RateLimiter,      // Token bucket
    pub symbols_per_second: RateLimiter,
    pub failed_mac_count: AtomicU32,     // Quarantine trigger
    pub concurrent_decodes: Semaphore,
    pub quarantined_until: Option<Instant>,
}
```

Anti-amplification rule (NORMATIVE):
- do not send more than `N` symbols in response to a request unless the requester is authenticated AND presents bounded proof-of-need (e.g., missing-hint).

### Gossip Protocol (CRDT-Based)

```rust
/// Gossip message types
pub enum GossipMessage {
    /// Announce object availability (Bloom filter)
    ObjectAnnounce { filter: BloomFilter, version: u64 },
    /// Request reconciliation (XOR filter diff)
    SyncRequest { filter: XorFilter },
    /// CRDT state merge
    StateMerge { crdt: MeshStateCrdt },
}

/// CRDT for mesh state convergence
pub struct MeshStateCrdt {
    pub checkpoint_heads: LWWRegister<ZoneCheckpoint>,
    pub revocation_heads: LWWRegister<RevocationHead>,
    pub peer_liveness: GCounter,
}
```

### Control-Plane Fallback over FCPS (Spec Surface)
In degraded/offline sync scenarios, control-plane objects may be encoded to symbols and transported in FCPS frames with `FrameFlags::CONTROL_PLANE`.
MeshNode owns the semantics here (routing + reconstruction + retention enforcement).

### Execution Planner (Device-Aware)
MeshNode chooses where to execute operations based on:
- device profiles (cpu/mem/battery)
- connector availability + version requirements
- symbol locality scoring + DERP penalty
- (full profile) secret reconstruction cost

```rust
/// Device profile for execution planning
pub struct DeviceProfile {
    pub cpu_class: CpuClass,          // mobile | desktop | server
    pub memory_mb: u32,
    pub battery_powered: bool,
    pub battery_percent: Option<u8>,
    pub connector_versions: HashMap<ConnectorId, Version>,
    pub symbol_locality: f64,         // 0.0-1.0 (local availability)
}

pub enum ExecutionDecision {
    ExecuteLocal,
    DelegateToNode { node_id: NodeId, reason: String },
    WaitForSymbols { missing: Vec<SymbolId> },
    Reject { reason: ReasonCode },
}
```

## Performance Optimizations

### io_uring Integration (Linux)
```rust
#[cfg(target_os = "linux")]
pub async fn symbol_batch_read(store: &SymbolStore, ids: &[SymbolId]) -> Vec<Symbol> {
    // Use io_uring for batched reads when available
    tokio_uring::fs::read_batch(...)
}
```

### Zero-Copy Symbol Handling
```rust
/// Zero-copy symbol buffer
pub struct SymbolBuffer {
    data: bytes::Bytes,  // Reference-counted, zero-copy
    offset: usize,
}
```

## Observability

```rust
#[tracing::instrument(
    level = "info",
    skip(symbols),
    fields(
        operation = %operation_id,
        zone = %zone_id,
        peer = %peer_id,
        trace_id = %trace_context.trace_id,
    )
)]
async fn route_symbols(&self, symbols: Vec<Symbol>) -> Result<(), RoutingError> {
    metrics::counter\!("mesh.symbols.routed").increment(symbols.len() as u64);
    // ...
}
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- Integration tests (simulated mesh) for:
  - sessions + replay
  - routing + reconstruction
  - allow path (receipt + audit)
  - deny path (DecisionReceipt with evidence)
  - admission control rejecting floods
- Benchmarks for local invoke overhead
- CRDT gossip convergence under partition
- Device-aware execution delegation tests

## Notes
This issue is intentionally an umbrella; complex sub-behaviors are tracked as child beads (routing/multipath, admission+quarantine, gossip, execution planner, FCPS control-plane fallback).

title: TEST: MeshNode Integration Scenarios (Routing + Enforcement)
description:
# TEST: MeshNode Integration Scenarios (Routing + Enforcement)


## Goal
Validate MeshNode routing/enforcement end-to-end in tests (multi-node), including admission control, lease behavior, and policy gating, with structured logs.

## Scope
Integration tests for MeshNode routing, admission control, and policy enforcement.

## Test Categories

### Routing
- [ ] Symbol routing to correct nodes based on placement
- [ ] Control-plane message routing
- [ ] Multi-hop routing when direct path unavailable
- [ ] Routing table updates on topology changes
- [ ] Load balancing across equivalent paths

### Admission Control
- [ ] Valid requests admitted
- [ ] Requests without session rejected
- [ ] Rate-limited requests rejected with backpressure
- [ ] Quarantined nodes blocked
- [ ] Anti-amplification limits enforced

### Policy Enforcement
- [ ] Zone boundary enforcement in routing
- [ ] Capability verification before forwarding
- [ ] Revocation checks on forwarded requests
- [ ] Taint labels propagated correctly

### Gossip Integration
- [ ] Object availability propagates
- [ ] Reconciliation completes after partition
- [ ] Stale gossip is rejected
- [ ] Gossip rate limiting

### Lease Coordination
- [ ] Lease acquisition via HRW
- [ ] Lease renewal works
- [ ] Lease transfer on node failure
- [ ] Lease conflicts detected

## Golden Vectors
Location: `tests/vectors/mesh_node/`
- `routing_table.json` - Expected routing decisions
- `admission_scenarios.json` - Allow/deny test cases
- `gossip_messages.cbor` - Gossip message examples

## Test Infrastructure
- Deterministic mesh harness (3+ nodes)
- Network fault injection
- Clock control for timeouts
- Structured log collection

## Logging Requirements
All tests MUST emit structured JSON:
```json
{
  "timestamp": "RFC3339",
  "test_name": "test_symbol_routing",
  "module": "fcp-mesh",
  "phase": "execute",
  "correlation_id": "uuid",
  "nodes": ["node-0", "node-1", "node-2"],
  "source_node": "node-0",
  "target_node": "node-2",

  "result": "pass"
}
```

### For Admission Tests

```json
{
  "request_type": "invoke",
  "admission_decision": "allow|deny",
  "deny_reason": "FCP-4001",
  "rate_limit_remaining": 95
}
```

### For Gossip Tests
