Fuzz targets runnable via: cargo +nightly fuzz run <target_name>

title: [FCP2-CONF] Interop Test Suite (Handshake, Symbols, Tokens, Cross-Zone)
description:
# [FCP2-CONF] Interop Test Suite (Handshake, Symbols, Tokens, Cross-Zone)

## Goal
Verify that independent implementations can interoperate on the wire.

Even though the reference implementation is Rust, these tests should be structured so a second implementation (future Rust rewrite, Go/Python test client, etc.) can plug in.

## Scenarios (minimum)
### Sessions / handshake
- MeshSessionHello/Ack transcript verification:
  - deterministic transcript bytes
  - suite negotiation determinism
- HelloRetry cookie path:
  - responder issues cookie
  - initiator retries with cookie
- TransportLimits negotiation + enforcement:
  - max_datagram_bytes affects FCPS_DATAGRAM acceptance

### FCPS data plane
- FCPS_DATAGRAM envelope:
  - MAC computation and verification for Suite1 and Suite2
  - bounded replay window behavior
  - MTU enforcement
- Inner FCPS frame parsing:
  - header fields parsed exactly
  - symbol record parsing with strict bounds
- Per-symbol AEAD:
  - deterministic nonce derivation
  - AAD binding matches spec

### FCPC control plane
- FCPC frame parsing/ordering:
  - ordered delivery per direction
  - bounded replay window
  - k_ctx AEAD integrity (and confidentiality if enabled)

### Capability tokens + provable authority
- COSE_Sign1 encoding/verification
- grant_object_ids subset enforcement
- chk_id/chk_seq freshness binding
- holder_node + holder_proof verification

### Cross-zone enforcement
- deny cross-zone operations without required ApprovalToken
- allow with correct ApprovalToken evidence
- DecisionReceipt reason_code + evidence stability

## Acceptance Criteria
- Tests are deterministic and can run in CI without a real tailnet.
- The test harness can ingest golden vectors as inputs and validate byte-for-byte expectations.
close_reason: Implemented interop test suite with 37 tests: session handshake, FCPS data-plane, FCPC control-plane, capability tokens, cross-zone enforcement. All tests pass with clippy compliance.

title: [FCP2-CONF] System E2E Harness: Multi-Node Simulation + Structured Logs
description:
# [FCP2-CONF] System E2E Harness: Multi-Node Simulation + Structured Logs

## Goal
Provide end-to-end confidence that the platform works as a coherent system.

## Key idea
Run a multi-node simulation (in-process or multi-process) with deterministic identities and keys, so we can test:
- sessions
- symbol routing
- policy decisions
- receipts/audit
- repair loop behavior

## Deliverables
- A harness that can spin up N MeshNodes with deterministic keys.
- A "minimal connector" (or test connector) that exercises invoke + events.
- Scripts/tests that run the required E2E scenarios from STANDARD.

## Logging
- Every scenario emits structured JSON logs with correlation_id and phase.

## Acceptance Criteria
- CI can run the E2E harness with `--nocapture` and produce usable logs.

title: [FCP2-CONF] Mechanical Connector Compliance Runner (Static + Dynamic)
description:
# [FCP2-CONF] Mechanical Connector Compliance Runner (Static + Dynamic)

## Goal
Given a connector binary, mechanically verify it meets the FCP2 connector contract.

## Static checks
- `--manifest` output parses and validates strictly.
- Manifest versioning fields are present and sane:
  - `schema_version`, `min_mesh_version`, `min_protocol`, `interface_hash`
- Canonical IDs and schema versions.
- Capability declarations are explicit (required/optional/forbidden).
- Zone constraints (`home`, allowed_sources/targets, forbidden) are present.
- Sandbox profile + network constraints are within zone ceilings.

## Dynamic checks
Run the connector under the host/SDK harness and probe:
- standard methods (handshake/describe/introspect/capabilities/configure/invoke/health/shutdown)
- **optional** preflight: if connector exposes `simulate`, probe simulate for at least one operation and verify:
  - response is well-formed and deterministic
  - no side effects are observed in the harness (no receipts/intents, no state mutation beyond caches)
- capability gating (default deny)
- DecisionReceipt production on denials (stable reason_code + evidence)
- event subscription/replay behavior (if declared)
- no secret leakage in logs

## Acceptance Criteria
- Compliance runner can be used in CI to accept/reject a connector artifact.


LABELS: conformance, connectors, fcp2, mvp

title: [FCP2-CONF] FZPF v0.1 JSON Schema Pack (Policy Authoring + Validation)
description:
# [FCP2-CONF] FZPF v0.1 JSON Schema Pack (Policy Authoring + Validation)

## Goal
Make policy authoring **mechanical and verifiable** by shipping the **FZPF v0.1 JSON Schema** (Spec Appendix A) as an explicit artifact, with tests.

Even though FCP2’s canonical objects are deterministic CBOR, users and tools still need a **human-authorable** representation for zone/policy definitions.

## Scope
- Define/ship `FZPF_v0.1.schema.json` (or equivalent) in-repo.
- Provide golden example documents that cover the important policy shapes.
- Validate that policy JSON inputs can be validated deterministically and fail-closed.

## Design Notes
- This is **V2-only**. Any older “hub” concepts are out of scope.
- FZPF should be aligned to the V2 policy object model:
  - ZoneDefinitionObject
  - ZonePolicyObject
  - RoleObject / RoleAssignment
  - ApprovalToken constraints (JSON Pointer only)
  - ZoneTransportPolicy and port-gating fields

## Deliverables
- JSON schema file for FZPF (v0.1).
- Example policy documents:
  - minimal zone definition + policy
  - role bundles + assignment + attenuation
  - transport restrictions (DERP/Funnel forbidden)
  - revocation/checkpoint freshness policy (Strict/Warn/BestEffort)
  - taint/approval constraints (elevation + declassification)
- Unit tests:
  - validate example docs against schema
  - negative tests for forbidden constructs (regex/JSONPath, unbounded globs, unknown fields)
  - deterministic ordering and stable validation errors (no non-deterministic maps)

## Acceptance Criteria
- Schema is present in the repo and referenced by conformance docs.
- Example docs validate and are comprehensive enough to exercise the sharp edges.
- Validation is fail-closed: unknown/extra fields are rejected.
close_reason: FZPF v0.1 JSON Schema pack complete: schema, 5 example docs, 33 unit tests passing

title: [FCP2] CLI: install/doctor/explain/bench/audit/repair
description:
# [FCP2] CLI: install/doctor/explain/bench/audit/repair

## Goal
Ship an operator/dev CLI that makes the system operable **without disabling security**.

Key principle: if you can't explain a denial or quantify offline availability, the system isn't finished.

## Command set (MVP)
### Safety + debugging
- `fcp doctor --zone <zone>`
  - report checkpoint freshness, revocation freshness, degraded-mode state
  - report transport policy state (DERP/Funnel allowed?)
- `fcp explain --request <objectid>`
  - render DecisionReceipt evidence and reason_code
  - include pointers to relevant objects (token, grants, checkpoint, approvals)

### Storage + availability
- `fcp repair status --zone <zone>`
  - report coverage metrics (bps), distinct nodes, max concentration
  - report pending/last repair actions
- `fcp audit tail --zone <zone>`
  - tail AuditEvent stream with trace correlation

### Install + verification
- `fcp install <connector>`
  - verify supply chain chain and policy requirements
  - install/mirror connector into mesh store

### Performance
- `fcp bench ...`
  - canonical CBOR encode/decode
  - ObjectId derivation
  - token verify
  - FCPS parse+verify
  - RaptorQ decode
  - invoke-local and invoke-mesh

## Output contracts
- All commands MUST support a machine-readable `--json` output mode.
- Errors MUST be stable FCP-XXXX codes with retry semantics.
- Commands MUST NOT print secrets (including auth headers, tokens, and raw secret material).

## Testing
- Snapshot tests for `--json` output schemas.
- E2E tests in the deterministic harness:
  - `fcp install` + invoke
  - `fcp explain` on a denial
  - `fcp doctor` showing stale/fresh transitions
  - `fcp repair status` showing coverage changes

## Acceptance Criteria
- CLI commands operate purely from mesh objects and verifiable receipts.
- A denial can be diagnosed from DecisionReceipt + CLI output alone.

## Implementation note
The concrete CLI implementation work is tracked in the child bead `flywheel_connectors-iqrb`.

title: [FCP2] Performance Budgets: Benchmarks, Profiles, Binary Size Targets
description:
# [FCP2] Performance Budgets: Benchmarks, Profiles, Binary Size Targets

## Goal
Make performance and binary size regressions **visible, measurable, and hard to ignore**.

The benchmark suite is part of the product: if we can’t measure cold start, invoke latency, decode costs, and offline-repair overhead, we can’t keep the system fast and reliable.

## Canonical Targets (README-aligned)
Track these as p50/p99 where applicable:
- **Cold start (connector activate):** p50 < 100ms / p99 < 500ms (stretch goal: p50 < 50ms)
- **Local invoke latency (same node):** p50 < 2ms / p99 < 10ms
- **Tailnet invoke latency (LAN/direct):** p50 < 20ms / p99 < 100ms
- **Tailnet invoke latency (DERP):** p50 < 150ms / p99 < 500ms
- **Symbol reconstruction (1MB):** p50 < 50ms / p99 < 250ms
- **Secret reconstruction (k-of-n):** p50 < 150ms / p99 < 750ms
- **Memory overhead:** < 10MB per connector (idle)
- **CPU overhead:** < 1% idle (event-driven)
- **Binary size:** < 20MB compressed (release profile: opt-level=z, lto, strip)

## Bench Suite Shape (CLI contract)
The reference implementation ships `fcp bench` with stable subcommands:
- `fcp bench connector-activate`
- `fcp bench invoke-local`
- `fcp bench invoke-mesh --path=direct`
- `fcp bench invoke-mesh --path=derp`
- `fcp bench raptorq --size=1mb`
- `fcp bench secrets --k=3 --n=5`

Additionally, we want microbenches for hot primitives:
- canonical CBOR encode/decode
- ObjectId derivation
- CapabilityToken verify
- FCPS parse + session MAC verify

## Output + Regression Tracking
- Emit machine-readable JSON results (with environment metadata + versions + commit hash).
- Provide deterministic bench fixtures where possible.
- CI policy can start as “report-only” and later move to strict thresholds once baselines stabilize.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Bench suite runs in CI (or as a gated job) and outputs machine-readable JSON.
- The CLI subcommand surface is stable enough to track regressions over time.
close_reason: Implemented fcp-cli bench command with CBOR microbenches, JSON output, and p50/p90/p99 statistical analysis

title: [FCP2] Sessions: MeshSessionHello/Ack, Suite Negotiation, Key Schedule, Anti-Replay
close_reason: Closed

title: TEST: Sessions Unit/Adversarial Tests (Handshake + Key Schedule)
description:
# TEST: Sessions Unit/Adversarial Tests (Handshake + Key Schedule)

## Goal
Make the session layer provably correct and resilient - no authentication bypasses, no key compromise paths.

## Test Categories

### MeshSessionHello Tests
- [ ] Valid Hello parses correctly
- [ ] Suite list parsing
- [ ] Supported suites only
- [ ] Suite preference ordering
- [ ] Random bytes present and non-zero
- [ ] Timestamp within acceptable skew
- [ ] NodeId format validation

### MeshSessionAck Tests
- [ ] Valid Ack parses correctly
- [ ] Chosen suite present in Hello list
- [ ] Cookie validation
- [ ] Random bytes present
- [ ] Signature verification

### Transcript Tests
- [ ] Transcript formation is stable (deterministic)
- [ ] Transcript includes all required fields
- [ ] Domain separation prefix included
- [ ] Hash is BLAKE3
- [ ] Transcript binding prevents MITM

### Signature Verification Tests
- [ ] Valid signature with valid NodeKeyAttestation passes
- [ ] Invalid signature rejected
- [ ] Expired attestation rejected
- [ ] Revoked attestation rejected
- [ ] Wrong node key rejected
- [ ] Malformed signature rejected

### Suite Negotiation Tests
- [ ] Negotiation is deterministic
- [ ] Server picks highest mutual preference
- [ ] No mutual suite → connection rejected
- [ ] Downgrade attack prevented (suite pinning)

### Key Derivation Tests
- [ ] Key schedule follows HKDF(transcript, ...) spec
- [ ] Derived keys match golden vectors
- [ ] Key roles are separated (encrypt/MAC/auth)
- [ ] Forward secrecy: session keys independent of long-term keys
- [ ] Key zeroization after use

### HelloRetry / Cookie Tests
- [ ] Missing cookie rejected when required
- [ ] Invalid cookie format rejected
- [ ] Expired cookie rejected
- [ ] Cookie from wrong server rejected
- [ ] Valid cookie accepted
- [ ] Cookie-key rotation grace period works
- [ ] Cookie replay rejected

### TransportLimits Tests
- [ ] max_datagram_bytes negotiation honored
- [ ] Frames exceeding limit rejected
- [ ] Limit applied symmetrically

### Anti-Replay Tests
- [ ] Exact replay rejected
- [ ] Duplicate sequence number rejected
- [ ] Stale timestamp rejected (beyond skew window)
- [ ] Sequence regression rejected (seq < last seen)
- [ ] Window-based replay detection works
- [ ] Out-of-order within window accepted

### Adversarial Handshake Tests
- [ ] Truncated Hello rejected
- [ ] Oversized Hello rejected
- [ ] Malformed CBOR rejected without panic
- [ ] Invalid suite ID rejected
- [ ] Future-dated timestamp rejected
- [ ] Ancient timestamp rejected
- [ ] Garbage after valid message rejected

## Golden Vectors
Location: `tests/vectors/sessions/`
- `hello.cbor` - Valid Hello message bytes
- `ack.cbor` - Valid Ack message bytes
- `transcript.hex` - Expected transcript hash
- `key_schedule.json` - Input → derived keys
- `bad_handshakes.json` - Invalid messages with expected rejection reason

## Fuzz Targets
- MeshSessionHello parsing
- MeshSessionAck parsing
- Cookie parsing
- Key schedule with random inputs

## Logging Requirements
All session tests MUST emit structured JSON:
```json
{
  "timestamp": "RFC3339",
  "test_name": "test_replay_rejected",
  "module": "fcp-session",
  "phase": "handshake|established|teardown",
  "session_id": "uuid",
  "peer_node_id": "...",
  "suite": "X25519_CHACHA20_BLAKE3",
  "operation": "hello|ack|verify|derive|replay_check",
  "result": "pass|fail",
  "reason_code": "FCP-3001"
}
```

### For Key Derivation Tests (NEVER log actual keys)
```json
{
  "operation": "key_derive",
  "transcript_hash": "...",
  "key_roles_derived": ["encrypt", "mac", "auth"],
  "golden_vector_match": true
}
```

### For Replay Tests
```json
{
  "operation": "replay_check",
  "sequence_received": 1234,
  "sequence_expected_min": 1230,
  "decision": "accept|reject",
  "reason": "IN_WINDOW|STALE|DUPLICATE"
}
```

## Security Invariants
- NEVER log keys, raw transcript bytes, or cookies
- Hash sensitive data if logging needed for debugging
- All rejections must have specific reason_code

## Acceptance Criteria
- All tests run under `--nocapture` with structured JSON logs
- Known-bad handshakes rejected for correct reason_code
- Golden vectors match exactly
- Fuzz targets find no panics
- Key material never appears in logs
close_reason: Completed all 72 session tests covering hello/ack parsing, suite negotiation, adversarial handshakes, signatures, transcripts, cookies, key derivation, anti-replay, transport limits, and session MACs

title: [FCP2] Trust/Quorum Model: n/f Assumptions, Threshold Rules, Degraded Mode Semantics
description:
# [FCP2] Trust/Quorum Model: n/f Assumptions, Threshold Rules, Degraded Mode Semantics

## Goal
Make quorum-signed objects and conflict behavior **well-defined and testable**.

Many FCP2 objects require multiple signatures (AuditHead, RevocationHead, ZoneCheckpoint, leases for risky ops). Without a crisp trust model, implementations drift and security becomes ambiguous.

## Core concepts
- `n`: eligible nodes for a zone (by membership)
- `f`: maximum Byzantine faults assumed for that zone
- Default thresholds (configurable per zone):
  - **CriticalWrite** (e.g., AuditHead, ZoneCheckpoint): require `n - f` signatures
  - **Dangerous ops** (leases): require `n - f` signatures
  - **Risky ops** (leases): require `f + 1` signatures
  - **Safe ops**: MAY allow coordinator-only signature

## Degraded mode (offline / partition behavior)
Define an explicit degraded mode policy:
- Which writes are allowed with reduced quorum?
- Which operations must fail closed?
- How we record degraded mode in audit/decision receipts.

## Determinism rules
- Quorum signatures must be sorted deterministically (by node_id) before hashing/encoding.
- When multiple valid candidates exist (e.g., overlapping leases), tie-breakers must be deterministic and audited.

## Deliverables
- A `QuorumPolicy` structure used by audit, revocation, checkpoints, and leases.
- A small library of deterministic helpers:
  - `required_quorum(n,f,purpose,risk_tier)`
  - signature set canonicalization + verification
  - degraded-mode reason codes

## Tests
- Property tests: signature sorting determinism.
- Unit tests: threshold computations across edge cases.
- Integration tests: simulated membership change updates required quorum.

## Acceptance Criteria
- All quorum-required objects share a single source of truth for threshold rules.
- Conformance suite can validate quorum semantics with golden vectors.
close_reason: Closed

title: [FCP2] Policy Engine: ZoneDefinition/ZonePolicy, Roles, ResourceObjects, Decision Reason Codes
description:
# [FCP2] Policy Engine: ZoneDefinition/ZonePolicy, Roles, ResourceObjects, Decision Reason Codes

## Goal
Implement the **policy objects + evaluation engine** that makes enforcement mechanical.

This is where we decide (with evidence) whether a request is allowed or denied.

## Why users care
- "Why was this denied?" becomes answerable via DecisionReceipt.
- Zones are not labels: policy binds capabilities, taint/approval, revocation/checkpoint freshness, and connector constraints.
- Prevents prompt injection from becoming a security incident.

## Policy objects (canonical CBOR + content-addressed)
### ZoneDefinitionObject (owner-signed)
The canonical, signed definition of a zone, including at least:
- `zone_id`, `name`
- `integrity_level`, `confidentiality_level`
- `symbol_port`, `control_port` (for Tailscale ACL port-gating defense-in-depth)
- `transport_policy` (ZoneTransportPolicy: DERP/Funnel/LAN broadcast allows)
- `policy_object_id` pointer to the current ZonePolicyObject
- optional `prev` for history/rollback

### ZonePolicyObject (owner-signed)
- principal/connector/capability allow/deny rules (glob-only; bounded patterns)
- capability ceilings: what can ever be granted in this zone
- audit policy (when to emit DecisionReceipts for allowed ops)
- revocation/checkpoint freshness policy per risk tier (Strict/Warn/BestEffort)
- retention rules and default storage policies
- execution/sandbox defaults (may be overridden per connector manifest within ceilings)
- **ZoneTransportPolicy** enforcement rules (DERP/Funnel controls)

### RoleObject + RoleAssignment (capability bundles)
- RoleObject: named bundle of capabilities, optional inheritance
- RoleAssignment: binds RoleObject to PrincipalId with optional attenuation
- Inheritance MUST be a DAG (no cycles) and is purely additive

### ResourceObject + Resource Visibility
- zone-bound handles to external resources
- classification (integrity/confidentiality + taint) for sinks/sources
- rules for declassification when writing to lower-confidentiality resources (including external sinks)

### ApprovalToken (unified)
ApprovalToken is a first-class mesh object used for:
- `Elevation` (integrity uphill)
- `Declassification` (confidentiality downgrade)
- `Execution` (scoped approval for a specific connector/method and optionally a specific request_object_id/input_hash)

Execution-scope approvals MUST use JSON Pointer (RFC 6901) input constraints only; JSONPath/regex are forbidden.

## Evaluation pipeline
Given an InvokeRequest (or other enforcement point):
1. Verify canonical IDs + schemas.
2. Verify token validity (signature + grants) and enforce checkpoint freshness (`chk_id/chk_seq`).
3. Verify revocation freshness for all authority inputs (issuer keys, grant objects, connector binary).
4. Verify taint + provenance (including sanitizer receipts and proof-carrying taint reductions).
5. Resolve roles/assignments into effective capabilities (bundle + attenuation).
6. Evaluate zone policy ceilings and connector manifest constraints (sandbox, network, zones, rate limits).
7. Enforce transport policy (if request implies mesh routing / DERP / funnel usage).
8. Decide Allow/Deny and emit:
   - DecisionReceipt (required on denied Risky/Dangerous; optional on allowed depending on audit_level)
   - audit events / receipts as required.

## Reason code taxonomy (must be stable)
Define stable, enumerable reason codes for denials (and optionally allows), e.g.:
- `capability.insufficient`
- `checkpoint.stale_frontier`
- `revocation.stale_frontier`
- `taint.public_input_dangerous`
- `zone_policy.connector_denied`
- `approval.missing_declassification`
- `transport.derp_forbidden`

This taxonomy is what powers `fcp explain`.

## Tests (must be exhaustive)
- Golden decision vectors:
  - allow + deny cases with evidence object IDs
  - cross-zone flows requiring approval
  - stale checkpoint / stale revocation denial
  - transport policy denial (DERP/Funnel forbidden)
  - taint reduction success/failure
  - execution-scope approval binding (request_object_id/input_hash/input_constraints)
- Property tests:
  - merge rule: integrity=min, confidentiality=max
  - role inheritance DAG enforcement
- Fuzz tests:
  - policy object parsing and evaluation safety

## Acceptance Criteria
- Policy engine can produce DecisionReceipts with correct evidence.
- `fcp explain` can render denials without guessing.
- No "ambient authority" paths exist (tests enforce).
notes: Ran cargo check and clippy (all-targets) OK. cargo fmt --check still fails due to pre-existing formatting diffs across connectors/fcp-manifest/etc; policy.rs formatting fixed (approval missing execution return). No new mail.
close_reason: Policy module + decision engine + golden vectors implemented; clippy/check OK; fmt --check failing due to unrelated formatting diffs elsewhere.

title: TEST: Policy Engine Golden Decision Vectors + Property Tests
description:
# TEST: Policy Engine Golden Decision Vectors + Property Tests

## Goal
Ensure policy decisions are deterministic, explainable, and cannot be bypassed - policy is the guardian.

## Test Categories

### Golden Decision Vectors (Core)
- [ ] Allow decision with full evidence chain
- [ ] Deny decision with specific reason_code
- [ ] Risk tier escalation triggers additional checks
- [ ] Zone boundary enforcement produces DecisionReceipt

### ApprovalToken Tests
- [ ] Elevation required when integrity flows up
- [ ] Declassification required when writing to lower-confidentiality sink
- [ ] Execution-scope approvals bind to request_object_id
- [ ] Execution-scope approvals bind to input_hash
- [ ] JSON Pointer constraints respected
- [ ] Missing approval → deny with FCP-2XXX code
- [ ] Expired approval → deny
- [ ] Wrong scope approval → deny

### Taint/Provenance Tests
- [ ] Tainted input to clean output → deny
- [ ] SanitizerReceipt reduces taint
- [ ] Sanitizer coverage check (all tainted inputs covered)
- [ ] Transitive taint propagation
- [ ] Taint merge rules: max(sources)
- [ ] Taint labels preserved in DecisionReceipt

### Revocation Freshness Tests
- [ ] Stale checkpoint → deny for Risky/Dangerous (Strict policy)
- [ ] Stale checkpoint → warn for Risky/Dangerous (Warn policy)
- [ ] Stale checkpoint → allow for Normal (BestEffort)
- [ ] Freshness window calculation is correct
- [ ] DecisionReceipt cites freshness state

### Transport Policy Tests
- [ ] DERP forbidden → stable reason_code
- [ ] Funnel forbidden → stable reason_code
- [ ] Transport constraints in ZonePolicy enforced
- [ ] Fallback transport only when permitted

### Zone Policy Tests
- [ ] ZoneDefinition fields parsed correctly
- [ ] ZonePolicy inherits from parent zones
- [ ] Override rules applied correctly
- [ ] Resource type → allowed operations mapping
- [ ] Role → capabilities resolution

### Role Resolution Tests
- [ ] Role inheritance DAG traversal
- [ ] Cycle detection in role inheritance
- [ ] Role capability aggregation
- [ ] Role attenuation (restrictions)
- [ ] RoleAssignment binding

### Reason Code Tests
- [ ] All reason codes are stable and enumerable
- [ ] Reason code includes denial category
- [ ] Reason code parseable by humans and machines
- [ ] Each denial path has unique reason code

## Property Tests
- [ ] Merge rule: integrity = min(sources)
- [ ] Merge rule: confidentiality = max(sources)
- [ ] No ambient authority: capability not granted → deny
- [ ] Attenuation can only restrict, never expand
- [ ] Decision determinism: same inputs → same decision

## Golden Vector Files
Location: `tests/vectors/policy/`
```
allow_simple.json       - Basic allow with evidence
deny_missing_cap.json   - Deny for missing capability
deny_tainted.json       - Deny for taint violation
deny_stale.json         - Deny for freshness violation
approval_elevation.json - Elevation approval required
approval_declass.json   - Declassification approval required
```

## Logging Requirements
All policy tests MUST emit structured JSON:
```json
{
  "timestamp": "RFC3339",
  "test_name": "test_deny_missing_capability",
  "module": "fcp-policy",
  "operation": "evaluate",
  "zone_id": "z:work",
  "principal_id": "...",
  "resource_type": "ConnectorOperation",
  "operation_id": "gmail.send_message",
  "risk_tier": "Risky",
  "decision": "allow|deny",
  "reason_code": "FCP-2001",
  "evidence_object_ids": ["..."],
  "result": "pass"
}
```

### For Approval Tests
```json
{
  "approval_type": "elevation|declassification|execution",
  "approval_token_id": "...",
  "scope_match": true,
  "constraints_satisfied": true
}
```

### For Taint Tests
```json
{
  "input_taint_labels": ["user_input", "external_api"],
  "output_confidentiality": "z:work",
  "sanitizer_receipts": ["..."],
  "taint_cleared": true
}
```

## DecisionReceipt Verification
Every denied Risky/Dangerous operation MUST produce a DecisionReceipt containing:
- decision (Deny)
- reason_code
- evidence_object_ids
- policy_snapshot_id
- timestamp

## Acceptance Criteria
- Golden vectors exist and run in CI
- All denied Risky/Dangerous produce DecisionReceipts
- Reason codes are stable across versions
- Property tests verify invariants
- Logging is complete and structured
close_reason: Completed: policy decision golden vectors + role DAG tests

title: [FCP2] Registry + Supply Chain: Install/Verify Manifests & Binaries, Mirroring, Attestations
description:
# [FCP2] Registry + Supply Chain: Install/Verify Manifests & Binaries, Mirroring, Attestations

## Goal
Make connector acquisition and execution **safe and offline-friendly**.

Registries are sources of signed manifests/binaries. The mesh can mirror/pin connectors as content-addressed objects so installs/updates work offline.

## Deliverables
### Verification chain (must be explicit)
Before execution, verify:
1. Manifest signature (registry or trusted publisher quorum)
2. Binary checksum matches manifest
3. Binary signature matches trusted key
4. Platform/arch match
5. Requested capabilities ⊆ zone ceilings (policy engine)
6. Optional (if policy requires): transparency log inclusion
7. Optional (if policy requires): in-toto/SLSA attestations and builder allowlist

### Distribution model
- Treat connector binaries as mesh objects (symbol-addressable) so they can be mirrored.
- Support pinning known-good versions in a high-trust zone.

### Rollback / incident response
- Support revoking a connector binary via RevocationObject scope `ConnectorBinary`.
- Policy can require transparency/attestations for high-risk zones.

## Tests
- Unit tests: signature and checksum failures reject.
- Integration tests: install from local mock registry; mirror into local object store.
- Adversarial tests: rollback/freeze attempts fail when policy requires transparency.

## Logging
- Emit audit events for install/update, including verified manifest/binary object IDs.
- Never log secrets or raw tokens.

## Acceptance Criteria
- A connector cannot execute without passing the verification chain.
- Policy can tighten requirements per zone without changing connector binaries.
notes: Registry crate now passes cargo check/test/clippy. Added const fn tweak in fcp-core provenance (TaintFlags::new) to satisfy clippy for registry build.
close_reason: Implemented fcp-registry verification + mirroring (trust policy, supply-chain checks, capability ceiling enforcement, audit report). Added unit tests incl. mirroring; cargo check/test/clippy for fcp-registry OK.

title: TEST: Registry/Supply Chain Verification + Mirroring Tests
description:
# TEST: Registry/Supply Chain Verification + Mirroring Tests

## Goal
Prevent executing unverified or downgraded connector artifacts - supply chain is the first gate.

## Test Categories

### Manifest Verification Tests
- [ ] Valid manifest signature passes
- [ ] Invalid signature rejected
- [ ] Expired signature rejected (if time-bound)
- [ ] Wrong signing key rejected
- [ ] Manifest CBOR malformed → rejection
- [ ] Required fields missing → rejection
- [ ] Schema version mismatch → rejection

### Binary Verification Tests
- [ ] Binary checksum matches manifest
- [ ] Checksum mismatch → reject installation
- [ ] Truncated binary → reject
- [ ] Extra bytes after binary → reject
- [ ] Zero-length binary → reject

### Platform/Architecture Tests
- [ ] Wrong platform (linux vs darwin) → reject
- [ ] Wrong architecture (amd64 vs arm64) → reject
- [ ] Platform in manifest matches runtime
- [ ] Fallback platform handling (if applicable)

### Policy Enforcement Tests
- [ ] Policy requires attestation → attestation verified
- [ ] Policy requires transparency log → log checked
- [ ] Policy requires specific signers → signer verified
- [ ] Missing required metadata → reject per policy
- [ ] Downgrade attempt detected → reject

### Attestation Tests (when required)
- [ ] Valid attestation chain verified
- [ ] Attestation covers binary content
- [ ] Attestation timestamp within window
- [ ] Attestation revocation checked

### Transparency Log Tests (when required)
- [ ] Entry exists in log
- [ ] Entry matches manifest hash
- [ ] Log consistency proof verified
- [ ] Log inclusion proof verified

### Mirroring Tests
- [ ] Mirror produces expected ObjectIds
- [ ] Mirrored symbols match original
- [ ] Symbol availability correct after mirror
- [ ] Partial mirror handles interruption
- [ ] Mirror respects placement policy

### Version Management Tests
- [ ] Newer version replaces older
- [ ] Downgrade blocked (unless forced)
- [ ] Version comparison is semver-correct
- [ ] Pre-release versions handled correctly

### Audit Event Tests
- [ ] Install produces audit event
- [ ] Update produces audit event
- [ ] Failed install produces audit event with reason
- [ ] Audit event includes manifest hash and signer

## Mock Registry Setup
```rust
let registry = MockRegistry::new()
    .with_connector("fcp.example", version: "1.0.0", signed: true)
    .with_invalid_signature("fcp.malicious")
    .with_checksum_mismatch("fcp.corrupted");
```

## Golden Vectors
Location: `tests/vectors/registry/`
```
valid_manifest.cbor     - Valid signed manifest
invalid_sig_manifest.cbor - Manifest with bad signature
checksum_mismatch/      - Binary that fails checksum
attestation_chain.json  - Valid attestation chain
```

## Logging Requirements
All registry tests MUST emit structured JSON:
```json
{
  "timestamp": "RFC3339",
  "test_name": "test_invalid_signature_rejected",
  "module": "fcp-registry",
  "operation": "verify|install|mirror",
  "connector_id": "fcp.example",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "manifest_hash": "...",
  "signer_key_id": "...",
  "verification_step": "signature|checksum|attestation|policy",
  "result": "pass|fail",
  "reason_code": "FCP-5001"
}
```

### For Install Events
```json
{
  "operation": "install",
  "connector_id": "fcp.example",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "manifest_hash": "...",
  "binary_size": 12345678,
  "platform": "linux",
  "arch": "amd64",
  "install_path": "...",
  "audit_event_id": "..."
}
```

### For Mirror Events
```json
{
  "operation": "mirror",
  "connector_id": "fcp.example",
  "source_registry": "https://registry.fcp.dev",
  "objects_mirrored": 42,
  "symbols_created": 1337,
  "total_bytes": 12345678,
  "duration_ms": 5000
}
```

## Offline Testing
- All tests use mock registry
- No network calls to real registries
- Mock responses are deterministic

## Acceptance Criteria
- Tests are fully offline with mock registry
- Audit events emitted for all install/update operations
- All rejection paths have specific reason codes
- Supply chain attacks are detected and blocked
- Logging is complete for forensics
close_reason: Added 16 comprehensive verification tests + MockRegistry. All 35 tests passing.

title: [FCP2] Registry Hardening (Optional): Transparency Log + TUF + Sigstore
description:
# [FCP2] Registry Hardening (Optional): Transparency Log + TUF + Sigstore

## Goal
Add optional-but-powerful supply-chain hardening layers that can be enforced by zone policy:
- transparency log inclusion
- TUF root pinning (anti-rollback / freeze / mix-and-match)
- Sigstore/cosign verification (builder provenance)

## Requirements
- These features are **policy-controlled**:
  - high-trust zones can require transparency + attestations
  - lower-trust zones can allow unsigned/less strict sources if explicitly configured

- If enabled by policy, verification must be mechanical:
  - fail closed when required artifacts are missing/invalid
  - produce DecisionReceipts/AuditEvents with evidence object IDs

## Deliverables
- Verification adapters:
  - transparency log inclusion proof verification
  - TUF metadata fetch/verify + root pinning
  - Sigstore bundle verification (publisher/builders)
- Clear reason codes:
  - `supply_chain.missing_transparency`
  - `supply_chain.tuf_root_mismatch`
  - `supply_chain.sigstore_invalid`

## Tests
- Mock transparency log server tests.
- Mock TUF repo tests (rollback/freeze/mix-and-match attempts).
- Sigstore verification tests with known bundles.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Policy can require these checks per zone without changing connector binaries.
close_reason: Added verification adapter traits (TransparencyLogVerifier, TufVerifier, SigstoreVerifier), mock implementations, error types, and 12 tests. Live implementations available via supply-chain-live feature.

title: [FCP2] Observability: Structured Logs, Metrics, TraceContext Propagation
description:
# [FCP2] Observability: Structured Logs, Metrics, TraceContext Propagation

## Goal
Make the system operable without disabling security. Provide first-class observability that enables debugging denied requests, tracing operations end-to-end, and monitoring system health.

## TraceContext (NORMATIVE)

W3C-compatible trace context for end-to-end request tracing:

```rust
/// W3C TraceContext (NORMATIVE when present)
///
/// Enables stitching mesh routing, connector execution, receipts, and audit together.
pub struct TraceContext {
    /// 16-byte trace ID (W3C traceparent format)
    pub trace_id: [u8; 16],
    /// 8-byte span ID (W3C traceparent format)
    pub span_id: [u8; 8],
    /// Trace flags (sampled, etc.)
    pub trace_flags: u8,
    /// Optional tracestate for vendor-specific context
    pub trace_state: Option<String>,
}
```

TraceContext MUST be propagated through:
- InvokeRequest → OperationReceipt → AuditEvent
- Cross-node symbol routing
- Connector execution spans
- DecisionReceipt evidence

## Structured Logs (JSON - NORMATIVE)

All components MUST log structured JSON with required fields:
- `timestamp` (RFC3339 with microsecond precision)
- `level` (trace, debug, info, warn, error)
- `correlation_id` (16-byte UUID; same as trace_id when available)
- `zone_id` (when applicable)
- `connector_id` + `operation_id` (when applicable)
- `decision` + `reason_code` for policy decisions
- `node_id` (local TailscaleNodeId)

### Redaction Guarantees (NORMATIVE)

MUST never log:
- Secret material (tokens, keys, passwords)
- PII (email addresses, phone numbers, IP addresses outside mesh)
- Request/response bodies containing sensitive data

MUST redact:
- Credential fields in audit logs
- Token payloads (log token JTI only)

## Required Metrics (NORMATIVE)

Implementations MUST expose:

### Request Metrics
- `fcp_request_total{connector, operation, risk_tier, status}` - Request counts
- `fcp_request_duration_seconds{connector, operation, risk_tier}` - Latency histogram
- `fcp_denial_total{reason_code, zone}` - Denial counts by reason

### Revocation/Checkpoint Metrics
- `fcp_revocation_freshness{zone}` - Gauge (0=stale, 1=ok)
- `fcp_checkpoint_seq{zone}` - Current checkpoint sequence
- `fcp_checkpoint_coverage{zone}` - Node coverage fraction

### Store Metrics
- `fcp_symbol_store_objects_total{zone}` - Total objects
- `fcp_symbol_coverage{zone}` - Coverage fraction
- `fcp_repair_actions_total{zone, type}` - Repair operations

### Admission Control Metrics
- `fcp_admission_rejected_total{peer, reason}` - Rejection counts
- `fcp_decode_budget_exhausted_total` - DoS mitigation triggers

### Rate Limiting Metrics
- `fcp_rate_limit_violations_total{connector, operation}` - Throttle events

## Audit Event Integration

All security-relevant decisions MUST be recorded in the audit chain (1n78.11):
- Secret access with SecretAccessToken
- High-risk capability invocations
- Approvals/elevations
- Zone transitions
- Security violations

AuditEvents MUST include TraceContext when present in the originating request.

## Tests

- Unit tests: log lines contain required keys (using a test subscriber)
- Unit tests: redaction works for known secret patterns
- E2E tests: trace_id can be followed across components (invoke → audit → explain)
- Integration tests: metrics are exposed and can be scraped

## Acceptance Criteria

- A denied request can be debugged from logs + DecisionReceipt without guessing
- TraceContext propagates end-to-end (verify via test harness)
- CI can fail if logging contracts regress (schema validation)
- Metrics enable SLO dashboards for availability and latency
close_reason: fcp-telemetry crate fully implemented with all FCP2 observability requirements: W3C TraceContext (16-byte trace_id, 8-byte span_id), structured JSON logging with redaction, full metrics suite (counters, gauges, histograms), TelemetryContext with all FCP2 fields (correlation_id, zone_id, connector_id, operation_id, decision, reason_code). 228 tests passing. Child bead (5un1 - tests) also closed.

title: [FCP2] Error Taxonomy: FCP-XXXX Codes, Retry Semantics, AI Recovery Hints
description:
# [FCP2] Error Taxonomy: FCP-XXXX Codes, Retry Semantics, AI Recovery Hints

## Goal
Provide stable, user-friendly, machine-actionable errors.

## Requirements
- Implement the FCP error code ranges (FCP-1000..9999).
- Errors must include:
  - `code` (stable string)
  - `message` (human)
  - `retryable` (bool)
  - `retry_after_ms` (optional)
  - `details` (optional structured data)
  - `ai_recovery_hint` (optional, but used heavily)

## Design principles
- Never include secrets in error messages.
- Prefer deterministic errors over ambiguous failures.
- Map internal errors to stable codes so clients can react.

## Tests
- Unit tests for each major subsystem mapping (protocol, auth, capability, zone, store).
- Golden vectors for a small set of representative errors.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Errors returned by SDK/host are stable and well-classified.
- `ai_recovery_hint` exists for the top 20 operational failure modes.
notes:
Completed Error Taxonomy implementation:

## Changes Made
- Added comprehensive AI recovery hints for ALL 26 error variants (100% coverage)
- Each hint is context-specific, including variable interpolation (capability names, zone IDs, retry delays)
- Added ErrorCategory enum for error classification (Protocol, Auth, Capability, Zone, Connector, Resource, External, Internal)
- Added category() method for programmatic error classification
- Added numeric_code() method for extracting the numeric code (e.g., 3001)
- Added error_code() method for the full FCP-XXXX string
- Added code_range() and name() methods to ErrorCategory

## New Tests Added
- 8 category tests (one per error category)
- 2 error code format/range tests
- 2 AI hint tests (coverage + actionability verification)
- 5 golden vector tests for representative errors
- 2 category code range validation tests

## Quality Gates
- cargo check/clippy/fmt/test: all pass (204 tests)

title: [FCP2] Canonical Serialization: SchemaId/SchemaHash + Deterministic CBOR + CDDL
close_reason: Implemented SchemaId/SchemaHash + deterministic canonical CBOR serializer (schema-hash-prefixed) in fcp-cbor with unit tests; remaining CDDL/golden/fuzz/signature work tracked in conformance/crypto beads.

comments.author: Dicklesworthstone
comments.text:
Progress update (2026-01-15):

- Implemented SchemaId/SchemaHash + SchemaHash-prefixed canonical CBOR serialization in crates/fcp-cbor/src/lib.rs.
- Canonical CBOR is produced by converting T -> ciborium::value::Value, recursively canonicalizing maps by RFC 8949 key ordering (sort by length then lexicographic of each key’s canonical CBOR bytes), rejecting duplicate keys, then encoding via ciborium::ser::into_writer.
- deserialize() enforces canonical bytes by re-encoding + byte-for-byte equality; also rejects missing schema prefix, schema mismatches, trailing bytes, and payloads > 64 MiB.
- Added unit tests covering roundtrip determinism, schema mismatch, non-canonical integer encoding rejection, and trailing bytes.
- Added workspace deps: ciborium 0.2.2, blake3 1.8.3, semver 1.0.27 (serde enabled).

Note: the spec/docs mention ciborium::ser::into_writer_canonical(), but ciborium 0.2.2 does not provide that API; current implementation provides equivalent canonicalization in fcp-cbor.
