title: TEST: Crypto Primitives Unit Tests (Ed25519, X25519, HPKE, AEAD, COSE)
description:
# TEST: Crypto Primitives Unit Tests


## Goal
Prove crypto primitives and encodings are correct via golden vectors + negative tests (Ed25519/X25519/HPKE/AEAD/COSE) without panics or side-channels in logs.

## Scope
Comprehensive unit tests for all cryptographic primitives used in FCP2.

## Test Categories

### Ed25519 Signatures
- [ ] Sign/verify roundtrip
- [ ] Verify with wrong key fails
- [ ] Verify with tampered message fails
- [ ] Signature malleability checks
- [ ] Test vectors from RFC 8032

### X25519 Key Exchange
- [ ] ECDH produces same shared secret both ways
- [ ] Reject low-order points
- [ ] Test vectors from RFC 7748

### HPKE Sealing (RFC 9180)
- [ ] Seal/unseal roundtrip
- [ ] Unseal with wrong key fails
- [ ] AAD binding is enforced
- [ ] Multiple recipients (sealed to multiple keys)
- [ ] Test vectors from RFC 9180

### HKDF-SHA256
- [ ] Extract/expand produces correct output
- [ ] Context/info binding changes output
- [ ] Test vectors from RFC 5869

### ChaCha20-Poly1305 AEAD
- [ ] Encrypt/decrypt roundtrip
- [ ] Tampered ciphertext fails authentication
- [ ] Tampered AAD fails authentication
- [ ] Nonce reuse detection (if stateful)
- [ ] Test vectors from RFC 8439

### XChaCha20-Poly1305 (if used)
- [ ] Extended nonce handling
- [ ] Same test matrix as ChaCha20-Poly1305

### BLAKE3 Hashing
- [ ] Hash produces expected output
- [ ] Keyed MAC mode
- [ ] Incremental hashing
- [ ] Test vectors from BLAKE3 spec

### COSE_Sign1 Helpers
- [ ] Create/verify COSE_Sign1 structure
- [ ] Protected headers in AAD
- [ ] KID extraction
- [ ] Invalid COSE structures rejected
- [ ] Test vectors from RFC 9052

### KID (Key ID) Generation
- [ ] KID format is stable
- [ ] Same key produces same KID
- [ ] Different keys produce different KIDs
- [ ] KID truncation is correct (8 bytes)

## Golden Vectors
Each category MUST have golden vectors:
- Input bytes (hex)
- Expected output bytes (hex)
- Source reference (RFC, test suite, etc.)

## Fuzz Targets
- COSE structure parsing
- HPKE unsealing (malformed inputs)
- Signature verification (malformed signatures)

## Logging Requirements
All tests emit structured JSON logs with:
- `test_name`
- `primitive` (ed25519, x25519, etc.)
- `operation` (sign, verify, seal, etc.)
- `result` (pass/fail)
- `vector_source` (RFC reference or "generated")

## Acceptance Criteria
- All crypto operations have test coverage
- Golden vectors exist and match
- Fuzz targets run without panics
- No secret material in test logs
close_reason: Completed comprehensive unit tests with RFC golden vectors for all fcp-crypto primitives: Ed25519 (RFC 8032), X25519 (RFC 7748), HKDF (RFC 5869), HPKE (edge cases + multi-recipient). All 109 tests passing, clippy clean.

title: fcp.zendesk: Analytics and Reporting
description:
# fcp.zendesk: Analytics and Reporting (FCP2)

## Goal
Expose Zendesk reporting surfaces so agents can:
- summarize support volume/trends
- compute response time and backlog metrics
- track CSAT/quality signals (if available)

## Scope
- Fetch aggregate metrics over time windows:
  - ticket volume by category
  - first response time
  - resolution time
  - backlog and queue depth
- Optional: agent workload metrics (aggregates; avoid raw agent identity exposure unless policy allows).

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `zendesk.analytics.read`

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- NetworkConstraints pinned.
- Prefer aggregates; avoid raw ticket bodies.

## Deliverables
- Operation schemas:
  - `zendesk.analytics.summary`
  - `zendesk.analytics.time_series`

## Test strategy (MUST)
- Mock-only tests for:
  - time window handling
  - unit correctness (ms vs seconds)

## Acceptance criteria
- Metrics are stable, correctly unit-labeled, and safe for logging.

title: [FCP2] InvokeRequest/InvokeResponse: Schema Validation, Holder Proof, Binding Rules
description:
# [FCP2] InvokeRequest/InvokeResponse: Schema Validation, Holder Proof, Binding Rules

## Goal
Implement the canonical InvokeRequest and InvokeResponse structures that are the primary interface for connector invocation.

## Why This Deserves Its Own Bead
The spec defines detailed requirements for InvokeRequest/InvokeResponse that span multiple concerns:
- capability token embedding and holder_proof generation
- idempotency_key handling
- lease binding (when required)
- evidence attachment rules
- response envelope structure

This complexity warrants focused implementation and testing.

## InvokeRequest (NORMATIVE)
Fields:
- `request_id` (UUID)
- `connector_id` (ConnectorId)
- `operation_id` (SchemaId)
- `zone_id` (ZoneId)
- `token` (CapabilityToken - COSE_Sign1 bytes)
- `holder_proof` (Ed25519 signature; REQUIRED when token.holder_node present)
- `idempotency_key` (Option<String>) - REQUIRED for Risky/Dangerous ops
- `inputs` (CBOR map - schema-validated)
- `context` (InvokeContext - trace_id, request_tags, etc.)
- `lease_seq` (Option<u64>) - REQUIRED for singleton_writer connectors

### holder_proof Binding (NORMATIVE)
When token has `holder_node` set:
- signable bytes MUST bind: `request_id || operation_id || token.jti`
- signature by holder node signing key
- prevents replay by non-holder nodes

### Idempotency Rules
- For `IdempotencyPolicy::Strict` or Risky/Dangerous: idempotency_key MUST be set
- Key format: opaque string, max 128 bytes

## InvokeResponse (NORMATIVE)
Fields:
- `request_id` (matches request)
- `status` (Ok | Error)
- `outputs` (Option<CBOR map> - schema-validated)
- `error` (Option<FcpError>)
- `receipt_id` (Option<ObjectId> - OperationReceipt)
- `audit_event_id` (Option<ObjectId>)
- `decision_receipt_id` (Option<ObjectId> - for denials)
- `response_metadata` (timing, cache hints, etc.)

## Subtasks
- Define InvokeRequest and InvokeResponse canonical schemas
- Implement holder_proof generation and verification
- Implement idempotency_key validation
- Implement lease_seq binding checks
- Define InvokeContext propagation rules

## Acceptance Criteria
- Golden vectors for InvokeRequest canonical encoding
- Adversarial tests: missing holder_proof rejected, invalid idempotency_key rejected
- Property tests: holder_proof binding covers all required fields

title: fcp.sentry: Performance monitoring data access
description:
# fcp.sentry: Performance monitoring data access (FCP2)

## Goal
Expose Sentry performance/trace surfaces so agents can:
- identify slow transactions and regressions
- correlate errors with performance degradation
- fetch trace/transaction summaries for RCA

## Scope
### Read operations
- Query transactions by project/environment/time range.
- Fetch a transaction/trace summary:
  - duration
  - spans breakdown
  - key tags
  - sample trace ids
- Fetch performance metrics trends (where available).

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `sentry.performance.read`

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- NetworkConstraints pinned.
- Performance data may include URLs, user agents, and other sensitive metadata:
  - treat as tainted
  - avoid logging raw payloads

## Deliverables
- Operation schemas:
  - `sentry.performance.transactions.query`
  - `sentry.performance.transaction.get`
  - `sentry.performance.trace.get_summary`
- Pagination helpers + time-window query helpers.

## Test strategy (MUST)
- Mock-only tests for:
  - query construction and pagination
  - normalization of key metrics
  - rate limiting + retry/backoff
  - taint propagation

## Acceptance criteria
- Agents can retrieve stable, comparable performance summaries for RCA.
- No secrets/PII leak through logs.

title: [FCP2] Offline Capability: Availability Tracking, OfflineAccess Metrics, Predictive Pre-staging
description:
# [FCP2] Offline Capability Tracking

## Goal
Implement the offline capability tracking from V2 spec section 21, enabling:
- Real-time availability tracking per object
- OfflineCapability/OfflineAccess metrics
- Predictive pre-staging based on user patterns
- Quantifiable offline resilience (SLO-ready)

## Normative Requirements (from FCP Specification V2 section 21)
- Nodes MUST track local symbol availability per object
- Nodes SHOULD support predictive pre-staging based on access patterns
- Offline resilience MUST be quantifiable (can_access, coverage ratio)

## Implementation Details

### OfflineCapability Schema
- accessible: HashMap<ObjectId, OfflineAccess>

### OfflineAccess Schema
- object_id: ObjectId
- local_symbols: usize (symbols held locally)
- k: usize (symbols needed for reconstruction)
- can_access(): bool (local_symbols >= k)
- coverage(): f64 (local_symbols / k)

### Predictive Pre-staging
- Track object access patterns per zone
- Pre-stage symbols for frequently accessed objects before needed
- Respect device storage constraints (DeviceProfile)
- Priority queue based on access frequency and recency

## Dependencies
- Requires Stores (1n78.15) for symbol tracking
- Requires DeviceProfile (wwq8) for storage constraints
- Integrates with Background Repair for coverage management

## Tests
- Unit tests: can_access(), coverage() calculations
- Integration tests: pre-staging triggers on access patterns
- E2E tests: offline read with reduced connectivity

## Acceptance Criteria
- Offline capability is queryable per object (can_access, coverage)
- Pre-staging improves offline availability for frequently accessed objects
- CLI reports offline readiness via fcp doctor --zone
close_reason: Implemented OfflineAccess, OfflineCapability, AccessPatternTracker with 21 tests

title: TEST: Revocation Unit/Adversarial Tests (Freshness, Chain Integrity, Scope Enforcement)
description:
# TEST: Revocation Unit/Adversarial Tests

## Goal
Prove that revocations are processed correctly and cannot be bypassed.

## Test Categories

### RevocationObject Parsing
- [ ] Valid revocation object parses
- [ ] Malformed CBOR rejected
- [ ] Missing required fields rejected
- [ ] Invalid scope rejected
- [ ] Owner signature verification succeeds/fails correctly

### Revocation Scopes
- [ ] Capability revocation: referenced capability becomes invalid
- [ ] IssuerKey revocation: tokens from that issuer become invalid
- [ ] NodeAttestation revocation: node operations become invalid
- [ ] ZoneKey revocation: triggers zone key rotation awareness
- [ ] ConnectorBinary revocation: connector cannot run

### RevocationEvent Chain
- [ ] Events hash-linked correctly (prev_hash binding)
- [ ] Monotonic seq enforced
- [ ] Duplicate seq rejected
- [ ] Gap in seq detected and flagged
- [ ] Out-of-order events handled correctly

### RevocationHead
- [ ] Quorum signatures required (n-f)
- [ ] Insufficient signatures rejected
- [ ] Signature from non-member rejected
- [ ] Signature set canonicalization (sorted by node_id)
- [ ] Multiple valid heads for same seq → fork detection

### Freshness Policy Enforcement
- [ ] Strict policy: stale revocation head → operation rejected
- [ ] Warn policy: stale head → operation allowed with degraded flag
- [ ] BestEffort policy: very stale head → operation allowed with audit
- [ ] max_age calculation correct
- [ ] Freshness check is O(1) (seq comparison, not chain traversal)

### RevocationRegistry
- [ ] Fast negative lookup (bloom filter or equivalent)
- [ ] False positives trigger full check
- [ ] True positive: revoked item correctly identified
- [ ] True negative: valid item passes quickly
- [ ] Registry update on new revocation event

### Attack Scenarios (Adversarial)
- [ ] Revocation withholding: node claims no revocations but others have them
- [ ] Revocation replay: old revocation re-submitted
- [ ] Revocation forgery: invalid owner signature rejected
- [ ] Stale frontier attack: verifier with very old revocation head
- [ ] Chain fork injection: two revocation heads for same seq detected

## Golden Vectors
- Valid revocation object bytes
- Valid revocation chain with multiple events
- RevocationHead with quorum signatures
- Bloom filter state after N revocations

## Fuzz Targets
- RevocationObject parsing
- RevocationEvent chain verification
- RevocationHead signature verification

## Logging Requirements
```json
{
  "test_name": "...",
  "revocation_scope": "Capability|IssuerKey|...",
  "target_id": "...",
  "chain_seq": 123,
  "result": "pass|fail",
  "reason_code": "...",
  "freshness_policy": "Strict|Warn|BestEffort"
}
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- All revocation scopes tested
- Chain integrity verified
- Attack scenarios blocked
- Freshness policies enforced correctly
close_reason:
Created comprehensive revocation_golden_vectors.rs with:
- Golden vectors for all 5 revocation scopes
- Chain integrity vectors (valid chain, gaps, duplicates, broken links)
- Freshness policy vectors for strict/warn/best_effort
- 7 adversarial attack tests (withholding, replay, stale frontier, fork injection, scope escalation, bloom bypass, flood)
- Chain integrity validation tests
- Quorum verification tests for RevocationHead
- Note: Tests compile but full verification blocked by pre-existing fcp-crypto rand_core version conflict

title: fcp.plaid - Banking & Financial Data Connector
description:
# fcp.plaid - Plaid Banking & Financial Data Connector (FCP2)

## Strategic Context

### Value Assessment
**Strategic Value Score: 94/100** — Critical Tier 1 connector (Financial Data family).

**Why Critical**: Plaid is **the dominant banking data aggregator**, enabling secure access to financial accounts, transactions, and identity verification. Essential for any financial automation, expense tracking, or accounting integration.

### Priority Matrix Position
- **Category**: Strategic Investment (High Value + Security Critical)
- **Build Phase**: Phase 1 Foundation (immediate)

---

## V2 Specification Compliance (NORMATIVE)

### ConnectorArchetype
```rust
archetypes: vec\![
    ConnectorArchetype::Operational,  // API operations
    ConnectorArchetype::Streaming,    // Webhook event ingestion
]
```
- **Operational**: Account linking, transaction sync, balance queries
- **Streaming**: Webhook events for transaction updates, errors

### ConnectorStateModel
```rust
state_model: ConnectorStateModel::SingletonWriter
```
- **SingletonWriter**: Transaction sync cursors per Item
- State tracked: `{ item_cursors: HashMap<ItemId, SyncCursor> }`
- Lease required for writer fencing

### ConnectorFormat
```rust
format: ConnectorFormat::Wasi
```
- **WASI MANDATORY**: Handles highly sensitive financial data
- Memory isolation for credentials
- Capability-gated hostcalls
- No raw credentials in connector memory

### NetworkConstraints (NORMATIVE)
```rust
NetworkConstraints {
    // Plaid API endpoints (environment-specific)
    host_allow: vec\![
        "sandbox.plaid.com".into(),     // Sandbox
        "development.plaid.com".into(), // Development
        "production.plaid.com".into(),  // Production
    ],
    port_allow: vec\![443],
    deny_localhost: true,
    deny_private_ranges: true,
    deny_tailnet_ranges: true,
    deny_ip_literals: true,
    require_sni: true,
    require_host_canonicalization: true,
}
```

### TaintFlags (NORMATIVE)
```rust
// Account data is highly sensitive but trusted from Plaid
account_data.provenance.taint = TaintFlags::NONE;

// Transaction descriptions may contain merchant names (external)
transaction.description.provenance.taint = TaintFlags::EXTERNAL_INPUT;

// User-provided institution selection
link_token_request.provenance.taint = TaintFlags::USER_SUPPLIED;
```

### SafetyTier per Operation
| Operation | SafetyTier | Rationale |
|-----------|------------|-----------|
| `plaid.accounts.read` | Risky | Sensitive financial data |
| `plaid.transactions.read` | Risky | Sensitive financial data |
| `plaid.balances.read` | Risky | Sensitive financial data |
| `plaid.link.create` | Risky | Initiates account linking |
| `plaid.identity.read` | Dangerous | PII (name, address, SSN) |
| `plaid.auth.read` | Dangerous | Account/routing numbers |
| `plaid.item.remove` | Dangerous | Breaks integration |
| `plaid.assets.manage` | Dangerous | Credit report access |

---

## Agent Capabilities (Concrete Use Cases)

### Account Management
- Link bank accounts via Plaid Link
- List connected accounts
- Get account balances
- Manage Items (connections)

### Transaction Access
- Sync transactions (incremental)
- Categorize transactions
- Search transaction history
- Detect recurring transactions

### Financial Data
- Account/routing numbers (ACH)
- Identity verification
- Investment holdings
- Liability information

### Examples of Agent Workflows
```
"Connect my bank account"
"Get my current balances"
"Show transactions from last month"
"Categorize my spending"
"Set up ACH transfer details"
"Verify my identity for compliance"
```

---

## Flywheel Ecosystem Synergies

### Stripe Integration
**Complete financial picture:**
- Plaid for bank data
- Stripe for payments
- Unified revenue + expense view

### HubSpot Integration
- Financial data for customer profiles
- Payment behavior analytics
- Revenue forecasting

### Airtable Integration
- Transaction export to tables
- Budget tracking dashboards
- Financial reporting

### Agent Mail Integration
- Balance alerts → agent threads
- Transaction anomaly notifications
- Financial status updates

---

## Technical Implementation Notes

### API Surface
- **Link API**: Account connection flow
- **Transactions API**: Transaction sync
- **Auth API**: Account/routing numbers
- **Identity API**: KYC verification

### Recommended Crates
- `reqwest` — HTTP client
- `serde_json` — JSON handling
- `chrono` — Date handling for transactions
- `secrecy` — Credential handling

### Environment Selection
| Environment | Use Case |
|-------------|----------|
| Sandbox | Testing with fake data |
| Development | Testing with real banks |
| Production | Live financial data |

### Rate Limits
```rust
RateLimits {
    requests_per_minute: 100,
    concurrent_requests: 10,
    // Per-endpoint limits vary
}
```

---

## Zone Architecture

### Recommended Zones
| Zone | Description | Capabilities |
|------|-------------|--------------|
| `z:private:plaid:full` | Full access | All operations |
| `z:private:plaid:readonly` | Read-only | Balances, transactions |
| `z:private:plaid:link` | Link only | Account connection |

### Security Considerations
- Financial data is PII/NPI
- Audit all data access
- Never log account numbers
- Environment isolation critical

---

## Manifest Archetypes (Closed Set)
- `operational` — API operations
- `streaming` — Webhook event ingestion

---

## External Surface

### NetworkConstraints
Default-deny; allow only:
- `{environment}.plaid.com:443`
- Environment selected at deployment

### Credential Injection
- client_id + secret via egress proxy
- access_token per Item via CredentialId
- Never persist raw credentials

---

## Capability Model

### Read Operations
- `plaid.accounts.read` — List accounts
- `plaid.balances.read` — Get balances
- `plaid.transactions.read` — Sync transactions
- `plaid.investments.read` — Holdings/securities

### Sensitive Read Operations
- `plaid.auth.read` — Account/routing numbers (Dangerous)
- `plaid.identity.read` — PII verification (Dangerous)

### Write Operations
- `plaid.link.create` — Create link token
- `plaid.link.exchange` — Exchange public token
- `plaid.item.remove` — Disconnect Item (Dangerous)

### Admin Operations
- `plaid.webhooks.manage` — Configure webhooks (Dangerous)
- `plaid.assets.manage` — Asset reports (Dangerous)

---

## Operations (Representative)

### Create Link Token
```json
POST /link/token/create
{
  "client_id": "{{injected}}",
  "secret": "{{injected}}",
  "user": {"client_user_id": "user_123"},
  "client_name": "My App",
  "products": ["transactions"],
  "country_codes": ["US"],
  "language": "en"
}
```

### Get Accounts
```json
POST /accounts/get
{
  "access_token": "{{injected}}"
}
```

### Sync Transactions
```json
POST /transactions/sync
{
  "access_token": "{{injected}}",
  "cursor": "{{last_cursor}}"
}
```

### Get Auth (Dangerous)
```json
POST /auth/get
{
  "access_token": "{{injected}}"
}
// Returns account + routing numbers
```

---

## Threat Model

### Hard Requirements
- Never log account/routing numbers
- Never log access tokens
- Never log transaction descriptions in full
- Secrets never touch disk
- Default deny for all operations

### Audit Requirements
- All data access logged
- All writes require AuditEvent
- Correlation IDs for tracing
- Retention policy compliance

---

## Tests

### Unit Tests (Mock-Only)
- Request construction
- Response parsing
- Cursor handling for sync
- Error responses
- Webhook signature validation

### Integration Tests
- Mock Plaid API responses
- Transaction sync simulation
- Link flow simulation
- Error handling

### E2E Compliance
- Validates NetworkConstraints (environment-specific)
- Dangerous operation approval flow
- Audit logging verification
- No credential leakage

---

## Acceptance Criteria
- Passes connector compliance runner (static + dynamic)
- No real Plaid API calls in unit tests
- Link token creation works
- Transaction sync functional
- Balance queries work
- Auth data requires approval
- Credential injection via egress proxy
- All V2 NORMATIVE requirements satisfied

title: fcp.jira: Dual Cloud and Server/DC API support
description:
# fcp.jira: Dual Cloud and Server/DC API support (FCP2)

## Goal
Support **Jira Cloud** and **Jira Server / Data Center** with a single connector binary, while preserving *mechanical* FCP2 guarantees (single-zone binding, default deny, sandbox + NetworkConstraints).

This bead exists because Cloud and Server/DC differ on:
- auth mechanisms
- REST base paths / API versions (v3 vs v2)
- response shapes / field availability
- rate-limit semantics

## Scope
Deliver an internal abstraction layer that makes higher-level Jira operations (issues, comments, attachments, sprints, workflows, JQL, etc.) **deployment-agnostic**.

### In scope
- `JiraDeployment = Cloud | ServerDc` configuration (manifest + provisioned config).
- A canonical `JiraBaseUrl` normalization + validation layer (used for NetworkConstraints pinning).
- Request construction differences:
  - Cloud: REST v3 endpoints where required
  - Server/DC: REST v2 endpoints where required
- Response parsing normalization:
  - unify common structs (Issue, Project, User, Comment, Attachment metadata)
  - feature-detect optional fields instead of assuming presence
- Auth strategy selection (mechanical, policy-gated):
  - Cloud: OAuth2 or API token via `CredentialId`
  - Server/DC: PAT or basic auth via `CredentialId`

### Explicitly out of scope
- Backwards compatibility with *any* legacy “FCP1” protocol or compatibility shim.
- Supporting multiple Jira instances from a single connector instance (still single-zone bound).

## FCP2 requirements to enforce
- **Single-zone binding**: deployment choice does not change ZoneId.
- **Capability IDs** MUST NOT encode hostnames or ports.
- **NetworkConstraints**:
  - allow only the configured Jira base hostname
  - forbid redirects to different hostnames by default
- **Secret hygiene**:
  - credentials are injected via `CredentialId` at invocation time
  - never log tokens, Authorization headers, cookies

## Deliverables
- `JiraHttp` facade with:
  - `send_json<TReq, TRes>(...)` with typed request/response
  - consistent error mapping to the SDK error taxonomy
  - explicit timeouts + bounded response size limits
- `JiraApiSurface` mapping table:
  - operation → (cloud endpoint, server endpoint) + method + required query params
- “Capability ↔ endpoint” mapping hooks for the manifest bead to reference.

## Test strategy (MUST)
### Unit/integration (mock-only)
- Two mock fixtures:
  1. Jira Cloud mock server
  2. Jira Server/DC mock server
- Golden request tests:
  - correct URL path + query params per deployment
  - correct auth header strategy selected
- Golden parse tests:
  - normalize issues/projects/users from both variants
  - handle missing fields gracefully

### Negative/security tests
- NetworkConstraints refusal when URL host differs (including redirects).
- Ensure no secrets appear in structured logs (log-scrub tests).

## Acceptance criteria
- Higher-level Jira feature beads can depend on a stable `JiraDeployment` abstraction.
- A single test suite can run the same operation tests against both mock variants.
- No FCP1/backwards-compat behaviors are introduced.

title: fcp.homeassistant: Service calls for device control
description:
# fcp.homeassistant: Service calls for device control (FCP2)

## Goal
Enable safe device control via Home Assistant service calls:
- lights, switches, climate, covers, media
- (policy-controlled) locks/alarms

Service calls are side effects and must be capability + (policy) approval gated.

## Scope
- List available services by domain.
- Call a service with a typed payload.
- Provide a constrained allowlist of domains/services by default.

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `ha.services.read`
- `ha.services.call` (dangerous-ish)
- `ha.security.call` (critical; locks/alarms)

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- NetworkConstraints pinned.
- Approval gating recommended for security-adjacent service calls.
- Receipts + audit events include:
  - service domain/name
  - entity_id targets (hashed)
  - correlation id

## Deliverables
- Operation schemas:
  - `ha.service.list`
  - `ha.service.call`
- Safety layer:
  - deny-by-default for dangerous domains
  - require explicit policy enablement

## Test strategy (MUST)
- Mock-only tests for:
  - allowlist enforcement
  - approval gating
  - audit/receipt emission

## Acceptance criteria
- Device control is safe-by-default and auditable.

title: fcp.redis: Redis Cache and Pub/Sub Connector
description:
# fcp.redis - Redis Cache and Pub/Sub Connector


## Goal
Provide an FCP2-compliant Redis connector for cache/storage, pub/sub, and stream operations with strict capability gating and bounded resource use.

## External surface (NetworkConstraints)
Default deny.
- Network egress MUST be restricted per-operation via manifest `NetworkConstraints` (defined in the connector’s manifest/cap map bead if present).
- Allow only the configured service host(s); HTTPS-only where applicable; deny redirects by default.
- Bound timeouts + response sizes; treat all remote responses as untrusted input; never leak secrets/PII in logs or errors.
- For DB/queue connectors, constrain raw TCP connects to explicit host:port only; deny private ranges unless explicitly allowed by policy.

## Overview
Redis connector for caching, key-value storage, pub/sub messaging, and data structure operations.

## Manifest archetypes (closed set)
- `storage`
- `operational`
- `bidirectional`

> Interaction patterns (non-archetype): Request/Response + Queue/Pub-Sub

## Key Operations

### String Operations
- `redis.get` - Get value
- `redis.set` - Set value (with TTL, NX/XX)
- `redis.mget/mset` - Multiple get/set
- `redis.incr/decr` - Atomic increment/decrement
- `redis.append` - Append to string
- `redis.getrange/setrange` - Substring operations

### Hash Operations
- `redis.hget/hset` - Single field get/set
- `redis.hmget/hmset` - Multiple fields
- `redis.hgetall` - Get all fields
- `redis.hdel` - Delete fields
- `redis.hincrby` - Increment field

### List Operations
- `redis.lpush/rpush` - Push to list
- `redis.lpop/rpop` - Pop from list
- `redis.lrange` - Get range
- `redis.llen` - List length
- `redis.lindex` - Get by index
- `redis.blpop/brpop` - Blocking pop

### Set Operations
- `redis.sadd/srem` - Add/remove members
- `redis.smembers` - Get all members
- `redis.sismember` - Check membership
- `redis.sinter/sunion/sdiff` - Set operations

### Sorted Set Operations
- `redis.zadd/zrem` - Add/remove members
- `redis.zrange/zrevrange` - Get by rank
- `redis.zscore` - Get score
- `redis.zrangebyscore` - Get by score range
- `redis.zincrby` - Increment score

### Pub/Sub Operations
- `redis.publish` - Publish message
- `redis.subscribe` - Subscribe to channels
- `redis.psubscribe` - Pattern subscribe
- `redis.unsubscribe` - Unsubscribe

### Stream Operations
- `redis.xadd` - Add to stream
- `redis.xread` - Read from stream
- `redis.xrange` - Read range
- `redis.xgroup` - Consumer groups
- `redis.xreadgroup` - Group read

### Key Operations
- `redis.del` - Delete keys
- `redis.exists` - Check existence
- `redis.expire/ttl` - TTL management
- `redis.keys/scan` - Key enumeration
- `redis.type` - Get key type

### Transaction Operations
- `redis.multi/exec` - Transactions
- `redis.watch` - Optimistic locking

## Providers Supported
- Redis OSS
- Redis Enterprise
- AWS ElastiCache
- Azure Cache for Redis
- Upstash
- Redis Cloud

## Connection Management
- Connection pooling
- Cluster mode support
- Sentinel support
- TLS connections

## Authentication
- Password authentication
- ACL users (Redis 6+)
- TLS client certificates

## Zone Architecture

<!-- fcp2-single-zone-note -->
**FCP2 single-zone binding note:** A connector instance binds to exactly one `ZoneId` for its entire lifetime.
The *"zones"* described in this section are a **recommended deployment pattern** (run separate connector instances in separate zones with different capability grants/policies) and/or conceptual risk tiers.
The connector MUST NOT multiplex multiple zones internally.

```
Zone 0 (Public):     N/A
Zone 1 (Authorized): Read operations
Zone 2 (Private):    Write operations
Zone 3 (Sensitive):  Admin operations, credentials
```

## Dependencies
- fcp-core, fcp-ratelimit, fcp-testkit, fcp-telemetry

## Acceptance Criteria
- The functionality described in this bead is implemented with typed schemas + validation (no unstructured “stringly” interfaces).
- Errors map to the FCP error taxonomy with correct retry semantics and no secret/PII leakage.
- Mock-only unit/integration tests cover success paths and common failures and emit structured JSON logs per `flywheel_connectors-1n78.35`.

title: fcp.twilio: Programmable Video API
description:
# fcp.twilio: Programmable Video API (FCP2)

## Goal
Provide a minimal, safe surface over Twilio Programmable Video:
- create/manage rooms
- list participants
- end rooms
- optionally fetch recordings

Video is high-cost and high-privacy. Treat most write operations as approval-gated.

## Scope
### Rooms
- Create room with constrained options (max participants, timeout).
- List rooms and get room status.
- End/complete a room.

### Participants
- List participants in a room.
- Optional: disconnect participant (dangerous).

### Recordings (optional; dangerous)
- List recordings for a room.
- Fetch recording metadata.

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `twilio.video.rooms.read`
- `twilio.video.rooms.write` (dangerous)
- `twilio.video.participants.read`
- `twilio.video.participants.write` (dangerous)
- `twilio.video.recordings.read` (dangerous)

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- NetworkConstraints pinned to Twilio API host(s).
- For any write:
  - require approval when policy dictates
  - emit receipts + audit events with room SID and action
- Strict privacy hygiene:
  - never log participant identities or media URLs

## Deliverables
- Operation schemas:
  - `twilio.video.room.create`
  - `twilio.video.room.get`
  - `twilio.video.room.list`
  - `twilio.video.room.end`
  - `twilio.video.room.participants`
  - Optional: `twilio.video.recording.list`

## Test strategy (MUST)
- Mock-only tests for:
  - room lifecycle
  - approval gating
  - error mapping
  - log redaction

## Acceptance criteria
- Video operations are safe-by-default and auditable.

title: fcp.spotify: Library Management
description:
# fcp.spotify: Library Management (FCP2)

## Goal
Enable safe access to the user’s library:
- list saved tracks/albums/shows
- save/unsave items

Library writes modify user state and must be auditable.

## Scope
- Get saved tracks/albums/shows/episodes (pagination).
- Save/unsave items.
- Check whether items are saved.

  - `spotify.library.shows.list/save/remove`

  - audit/receipt for writes

## Acceptance criteria

title: fcp.figma: Design token export (colors, typography, spacing)
description:
# fcp.figma: Design token export (colors, typography, spacing) (FCP2)

## Goal
Extract design tokens from Figma so agents can:

- CSS variables.

## Acceptance criteria

title: fcp.llm-router: Intelligent Model Selection Connector
description:
## Goal
Provide an FCP2-compliant LLM routing connector that selects among providers/models based on capabilities/latency/budgets while preserving mechanical policy, auditability, and strict sandboxing.

## External surface (NetworkConstraints)
Default deny.
- Network egress MUST be restricted per-operation via manifest `NetworkConstraints` (defined in the connector’s manifest/cap map bead if present).
- Allow only the configured service host(s); HTTPS-only where applicable; deny redirects by default.
- Bound timeouts + response sizes; treat all remote responses as untrusted input; never leak secrets/PII in logs or errors.

## Zone model (mechanical)

<!-- fcp2-single-zone-note -->
**FCP2 single-zone binding note:** A connector instance binds to exactly one `ZoneId` for its entire lifetime.
The connector MUST NOT multiplex multiple zones internally.

Recommended deployment pattern: run separate connector instances in separate zones with different capability grants/policies.

## Manifest archetypes (closed set)

- `operational`

> Interaction patterns (non-archetype): Request/Response

## Overview
Meta-connector for intelligent routing between multiple AI/LLM providers, optimizing for cost, latency, and capability while enforcing budgets and providing usage analytics.

## Core Capabilities

### Cost-Based Routing
- Usage-based routing using deterministic estimates (tokens/bytes/duration) and/or `Simulate` `CostEstimate` (NO pricing tables).
- Token estimation before routing
- Prefer the lowest *estimated* cost option within policy/budget constraints (no embedded price tables).
- Cost threshold triggers for model downgrade
- Batch request optimization for cost savings

### Latency-Based Routing
- Provider health monitoring
- Historical latency tracking per model
- Geographic routing optimization
- Time-of-day latency patterns
- Streaming vs batch latency considerations

### Capability-Based Routing
- Task classification (coding, writing, analysis, etc.)
- Model capability matrix maintenance
- Context window requirement matching
- Vision/multimodal capability detection
- Tool use capability routing
- Specialized model selection (code, math, etc.)

### Fallback Chains
- Primary/secondary/tertiary provider chains
- Automatic failover on errors
- Partial failure handling (retry vs fallback)
- Circuit breaker implementation
- Graceful degradation strategies
- Provider outage detection

### Budget Enforcement
- Per-user budget limits
- Per-project budget allocation
- Daily/weekly/monthly caps
- Real-time spend tracking
- Budget alert thresholds
- Hard vs soft limit modes

### Usage Tracking and Analytics
- Request logging with metadata
- Cost attribution by user/project/task
- Model performance comparison
- Success rate tracking
- Token usage patterns
- ROI analysis per model

## Supported Providers (Initial)
- Anthropic (Claude models)
- OpenAI (GPT models)
- Google (Gemini models)
- AWS Bedrock (multi-model)
- Azure OpenAI
- Local models (Ollama, vLLM)

## Implementation Notes
- Unified request/response format across providers
- Provider-specific adapters
- Async request handling
- Request queuing for rate limits
- Credential management per provider
- Caching layer for repeated queries

## Configuration
- YAML-based routing rules
- Dynamic rule updates without restart
- A/B testing support for routing strategies
- Custom routing logic plugins

## Testing Requirements
- Mock providers for unit tests
- Routing decision validation
- Budget enforcement tests
- Failover scenario tests
- Load testing for routing performance

## Acceptance Criteria
- The functionality described in this bead is implemented with typed schemas + validation (no unstructured “stringly” interfaces).
- Errors map to the FCP error taxonomy with correct retry semantics and no secret/PII leakage.
- Mock-only unit/integration tests cover success paths and common failures and emit structured JSON logs per `flywheel_connectors-1n78.35`.

title: fcp.llm-router: Manifest + Capability Map (FCP2)
description:
## Goal
Produce the full FCP2 manifest and capability map for this connector.

This bead is where we translate the connector’s functional surface (operations) into a **mechanically checkable** contract:
- operation schemas + schema IDs
- capability families per operation
- per-operation NetworkConstraints (default deny)
- sandbox profile requirements
- declared state model (stateless / singleton_writer / crdt)

## Required content (must be explicit)
- Operation list is exhaustive and stable for the current phase.
- Capability IDs DO NOT encode hostnames/ports.
- NetworkConstraints are minimal and per-operation.
- Risk tier for each operation (Safe / Dangerous).
- Explicit bounds: timeouts, max response sizes, pagination limits.

## Tests
- Add good/bad manifest examples for the compliance runner.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Passes static checks in `flywheel_connectors-1n78.21.5`.
- Default-deny is enforced by manifest + capability requirements.

title: fcp.llm-router: Provisioning Automation
description:
## Goal
Automate provisioning and configuration with minimal human steps.

This bead owns:
- auth setup (OAuth / API keys / webhook secrets) via `CredentialObject`/`CredentialId` (egress proxy injection preferred)
- endpoint configuration
- `fcp doctor` readiness checks
- deterministic, mockable provisioning flows

## FCP2 requirements
- Secrets never touch disk.
- Provisioning is deterministic and testable.
- Error messages are actionable and do not leak secrets/PII.

## Acceptance Criteria
- No real external calls in unit tests.
- Provisioning emits structured logs per `flywheel_connectors-1n78.35`.

title: TEST: fcp.llm-router Unit/Integration Tests (mock-only)
description:
## Goal
Mock-only unit/integration tests for this connector.

## Required coverage
- schema validation (inputs + outputs)
- error taxonomy mapping (retry semantics)
- pagination and bounds
- rate limit behavior
- redaction (no token/secret/PII leakage)
- idempotency + receipts for Dangerous operations

## Logging
All tests emit structured JSON logs per `flywheel_connectors-1n78.35`.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Deterministic tests; no live external calls.
- Includes adversarial cases (timeouts, malformed responses, partial failures).

title: E2E: fcp.llm-router Connector Compliance Run
description:

## Acceptance Criteria
- E2E run is deterministic and produces a stable artifact bundle.

title: TEST: fcp-streaming Unit Test Suite
description:
# TEST: fcp-streaming Unit Test Suite

## Scope
Comprehensive unit tests for streaming and SSE library.

## Test Categories

### Server-Sent Events (SSE)
- [ ] Event parsing (data, event, id, retry fields)
- [ ] Multi-line data handling
- [ ] Event ID tracking for reconnection
- [ ] Retry interval handling
- [ ] Connection keep-alive

### WebSocket Support
- [ ] Connection establishment
- [ ] Message framing (text, binary)
- [ ] Ping/pong handling
- [ ] Graceful close
- [ ] Reconnection with backoff

### Stream Processing
- [ ] Backpressure handling
- [ ] Buffer management
- [ ] Stream cancellation
- [ ] Timeout enforcement

### Error Recovery
- [ ] Network disconnection
- [ ] Partial message handling
- [ ] Reconnection with last-event-id
- [ ] Maximum reconnection attempts

### Performance
- [ ] Zero-copy parsing where possible
- [ ] Memory allocation limits
- [ ] Large message handling

## Mocking Strategy
- Mock SSE endpoints returning controlled event streams
- Mock WebSocket servers with programmable responses
- Inject network errors at specific points

## Coverage Target: >90%
close_reason: Streaming functionality is now part of FCP2 SDK (1n78.20.1). The SDK Streaming bead already covers EventEnvelope, replay, and acks.

title: fcp.bigquery: Google BigQuery data warehouse connector
description:
## Goal
Provide an FCP2-compliant BigQuery connector for querying and dataset/table management with strict NetworkConstraints and audit for writes.

## Manifest archetypes (closed set)

- `storage`
- `operational`

> Interaction patterns (non-archetype): Request/Response (SQL) + polling for long queries

## Overview
Google BigQuery data warehouse connector for the Flywheel Connector Platform. Provides comprehensive access to BigQuery's analytics and data warehouse capabilities.

## Value Assessment
- **Value Score**: 49/100 (Tier 4)
- **Archetype**: Request-Response
- **Primary Use Cases**: Analytics, data warehousing, business intelligence, large-scale data processing

## Operations

### Query Zone (read-only analytics)
- **query.execute**: Execute SQL queries with parameterized inputs
- **query.dry_run**: Validate queries and estimate costs without execution
- **query.results**: Fetch paginated query results
- **query.cancel**: Cancel running queries

### Data Modification Zone
- **streaming.insert**: Real-time streaming inserts to tables
- **table.create**: Create new tables with schema definition
- **table.delete**: Delete tables
- **table.update**: Update table metadata and schema
- **table.patch**: Partial table updates
- **table.copy**: Copy tables within/across datasets

### Dataset Management
- **dataset.list**: List datasets in project
- **dataset.get**: Get dataset metadata
- **dataset.create**: Create new datasets
- **dataset.delete**: Delete datasets
- **dataset.update**: Update dataset properties

### Schema Management
- **schema.get**: Retrieve table schema
- **schema.update**: Modify table schema (add columns, change descriptions)
- **schema.validate**: Validate schema compatibility

### Job Management
- **job.list**: List jobs with filtering
- **job.get**: Get job status and metadata
- **job.cancel**: Cancel running jobs
- **job.query**: Submit query jobs

### Admin Zone (restricted)
- **iam.get**: Get IAM policies
- **iam.set**: Set IAM policies (requires elevated permissions)
- **routine.create**: Create stored procedures/functions
- **routine.delete**: Delete routines

## Zone Architecture

<!-- fcp2-single-zone-note -->
**FCP2 single-zone binding note:** A connector instance binds to exactly one `ZoneId` for its entire lifetime.
The *"zones"* described in this section are a **recommended deployment pattern** (run separate connector instances in separate zones with different capability grants/policies) and/or conceptual risk tiers.
The connector MUST NOT multiplex multiple zones internally.


```
Zone 1 (Query - Read Only):
  - query.execute, query.dry_run, query.results
  - dataset.list, dataset.get
  - table.list, table.get
  - schema.get
  - job.list, job.get

Zone 2 (Data Modification):
  - streaming.insert
  - table.create, table.update, table.delete, table.copy
  - dataset.create, dataset.update
  - schema.update

Zone 3 (Admin - Restricted):
  - dataset.delete
  - iam.get, iam.set
  - routine.create, routine.delete
  - job.cancel
```

## Dependencies
- **fcp-core**: Base connector traits and types
- **fcp-oauth**: Google OAuth 2.0 authentication (service account, user credentials)
- **fcp-ratelimit**: Rate limiting for API quota management
- **fcp-telemetry**: Metrics, logging, and tracing

## Implementation Approach

### Authentication
- Service account JSON key files
- Application Default Credentials (ADC)
- User OAuth flow for interactive use
- Workload Identity for GKE deployments

### API Integration
- BigQuery REST API v2 (primary)
- Consider gcp-bigquery-client crate for Rust native bindings
- Support for both sync and async operations

### Rate Limiting
- Per-project quota management
- Concurrent query limits
- Streaming insert rate limits (rows/second, bytes/second)

### Error Handling
- Query timeout handling
- Quota exceeded errors with retry logic
- Job failure recovery
- Partial insert failure handling for streaming

## Configuration Schema

```toml
[connector.bigquery]
project_id = "my-gcp-project"
location = "US"  # or specific region

[connector.bigquery.auth]
method = "service_account"  # or "adc", "oauth"
service_account_credential_id = "cred:<service_account_json>"  # do not store service account JSON on disk

[connector.bigquery.defaults]
query_timeout_ms = 30000
max_results_per_page = 10000
use_legacy_sql = false

[connector.bigquery.streaming]
insert_batch_size = 500
insert_timeout_ms = 5000

[connector.bigquery.rate_limits]
queries_per_minute = 100
streaming_rows_per_second = 100000
```

## Testing Strategy
- Unit tests with mocked BigQuery responses
- Integration tests against BigQuery sandbox/emulator
- Cost estimation validation tests
- Schema compatibility tests

## Documentation Requirements
- Authentication setup guide (service account, ADC, OAuth)
- Query best practices (parameterization, cost control)
- Streaming insert patterns
- Error handling guide
- Rate limiting and quota management

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] All query zone operations implemented and tested
- [ ] Data modification operations with proper error handling
- [ ] Admin zone with appropriate permission checks
- [ ] OAuth and service account authentication working
- [ ] Rate limiting integrated with quota management
- [ ] Comprehensive test coverage (unit + integration)
- [ ] Documentation complete with examples

title: fcp.terraform: Drift detection between state and actual resources
description:
# fcp.terraform: Drift detection between state and actual resources (FCP2)

## Goal
Detect drift safely by comparing:
- recorded Terraform state
- actual provider-reported infrastructure

This may require provider API egress and must respect NetworkConstraints.

## Scope
- Run a refresh-only plan (no apply) and extract drift summary.
- Return a canonical `DriftReport`:
  - resources changed
  - attributes changed (hashed/summary)
  - severity estimation

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `terraform.drift.read` (sensitive)

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- NetworkConstraints default deny unless backend/providers are explicitly allowed.
- No mutations; drift detection must not apply changes.
- Audit state/provider access.

## Deliverables
- Operation schema:
  - `terraform.drift.detect`
- Canonical output type:
  - `DriftReport`

## Test strategy (MUST)
- Unit tests with a terraform shim for:
  - refresh-only invocation
  - parsing drift summaries
  - error mapping

## Acceptance criteria
- Drift reports are deterministic and safe-by-default.

title: fcp.airtable: Linked record resolution and management
description:
# fcp.airtable: Linked Record Resolution and Management

## Goal
Provide first-class support for Airtable relational features:
- linked record fields
- lookup/rollup-style derived values

## External surface (NetworkConstraints)
Default deny.
- Network egress MUST be restricted per-operation via manifest `NetworkConstraints`.
- Allow only the configured service host(s); HTTPS-only where applicable; deny redirects by default.
- Bound timeouts + response sizes; treat all remote responses as untrusted input; never leak secrets/PII in logs or errors.

## Zone model (mechanical)

<!-- fcp2-single-zone-note -->
**FCP2 single-zone binding note:** A connector instance binds to exactly one `ZoneId` for its entire lifetime.
The connector MUST NOT multiplex multiple zones internally.

Recommended deployment pattern: run separate connector instances in separate zones with different capability grants/policies.

## Scope
- Read/write “link to another record” fields (arrays of record ids).
- Resolve linked record chains for agent-friendly outputs (bounded joins).
- Support computed field read semantics (lookup/rollup) without pretending they are writable.

## Key requirements
- Capability gated (reads vs writes).
- Bounded traversal:
  - prevent unbounded graph walks / cycles
  - explicit depth/record count limits
- Deterministic output:
  - stable ordering when expanding linked records
  - explicit “partial” indicators when traversal is truncated by bounds

## Tests
- Linked graph traversal (including cycles).
- Bounded expansion behavior.
- Error mapping for missing/deleted linked records.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Linked record expansion is safe and predictable.
- Computed fields are exposed read-only with clear typing.

title: TEST: RaptorQ Unit Tests (Encode/Decode, Chunking, DoS Bounds)
description:
# TEST: RaptorQ Unit Tests


## Goal
Prove RaptorQ encode/decode correctness and enforce decode DoS bounds (size/time) with reproducible test vectors.

## Scope
Comprehensive unit tests for RaptorQ symbol encoding/decoding and chunking.

## Test Categories

### Basic Encoding/Decoding
- [ ] Encode small object (< symbol size) → decode from K symbols
- [ ] Encode medium object (multiple symbols) → decode from K symbols
- [ ] Encode large object → ChunkedObjectManifest path
- [ ] Decode with exactly K source symbols
- [ ] Decode with K + repair symbols (erasure recovery)
- [ ] Decode with subset of repair symbols only

### Symbol Parameters
- [ ] Default symbol size (1024 bytes) produces expected symbol count
- [ ] Custom symbol sizes work correctly
- [ ] K (source symbols) calculation is correct for object sizes
- [ ] Repair ratio produces expected number of repair symbols

### ChunkedObjectManifest
- [ ] Objects > threshold produce manifest + raw chunks
- [ ] Manifest references correct chunk ObjectIds
- [ ] Chunks reconstruct to original object
- [ ] Chunk ordering is deterministic

### Decode DoS Mitigation
- [ ] Reject decode attempts exceeding CPU budget
- [ ] Reject decode attempts exceeding memory budget
- [ ] Timeout on pathological decode patterns
- [ ] Reject impossibly large symbol counts
- [ ] Reject impossibly large object sizes in manifest

### Symbol Identity
- [ ] Same object always produces same symbols (deterministic)
- [ ] ESI (encoding symbol identifier) is unique per symbol
- [ ] Symbols are self-describing (include ESI, K)

### Partial Availability
- [ ] DecodeStatus correctly reports received vs needed
- [ ] SymbolAck correctly acknowledges specific ESIs
- [ ] Missing symbol requests are targeted (not full retransmit)

## Golden Vectors
- 1KB object → expected symbols (with specific bytes)
- 100KB object → expected manifest structure
- Known erasure pattern → successful decode

## Fuzz Targets
- Malformed symbol streams
- Invalid ESI values
- Oversized object claims
- Corrupt manifest structures

## Performance Benchmarks
- Encode 1MB object: target < 10ms
- Decode 1MB from K symbols: target < 20ms
- Decode 1MB with 10% erasure: target < 50ms

## Logging Requirements
All tests emit:
```json
{
  "test_name": "...",
  "object_size": 12345,
  "symbol_size": 1024,
  "k": 13,
  "repair_symbols": 3,
  "decode_symbols_used": 13,
  "result": "pass|fail",
  "duration_us": 1234
}
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- All encoding/decoding paths tested
- DoS mitigations verified
- Performance benchmarks pass
- Golden vectors match
close_reason:
Implemented comprehensive RaptorQ unit tests with 79 passing tests covering:
- Golden vector tests for 1KB, 10KB, 100KB, and 300KB objects
- Symbol count verification (K source + repair ratio)
- Encode/decode roundtrip for all sizes
- Erasure recovery tests (10% loss, repair-only decode)
- Symbol determinism tests (same payload = same symbols)
- ESI uniqueness verification
- DoS mitigation tests (oversized payloads, concurrent limits, timeouts, memory/symbol buffer limits)
- Decode status tracking tests
- Chunked manifest tests (ID determinism, ordering, hash verification)
All acceptance criteria met.

title: TEST: Exactly-Once Semantics Unit Tests (Intent/Receipt, Idempotency, Fault Injection)
description:
# TEST: Exactly-Once Semantics Unit Tests

## Goal
Comprehensive unit tests verifying exactly-once semantics for OperationIntent + OperationReceipt.

## Test Categories

### 1. OperationIntent/Receipt Schema Tests
- Verify schema ID and hash correctness
- Test all required fields are present (idempotency_key, lease_seq, lease_object_id, refs)
- Validate upstream idempotency handle handling (optional field)
- Golden vector tests for deterministic CBOR serialization

### 2. Idempotency Key Tests
- Same key returns same receipt without re-execution (core idempotency property)
- Different keys produce independent executions
- Key collision resistance (hash-based keys)
- Key expiry/TTL semantics (if applicable)

### 3. Lease Fencing Tests
- OperationIntent MUST bind to lease fencing token (`lease_seq`)
- Stale lease holder attempts to execute (MUST be rejected)
- Lease renewal does not break in-flight intents
- Receipt references correct lease object

### 4. Fault Injection Tests
- Crash between intent creation and receipt creation
- Detect and reconcile incomplete intents on recovery
- Network partition during execution
- Storage failure during receipt write
- Timeout during external side effect

### 5. Audit Integration Tests
- AuditEvent emitted on intent creation
- AuditEvent emitted on receipt creation
- Audit chain integrity preserved across retries
- Decision receipts reference correct operation receipts

### 6. Concurrency Tests
- Concurrent requests with same idempotency key (only one executes)
- Concurrent requests with different keys (all execute)
- Race between intent creation and lease expiry

## Logging Requirements
- All test cases MUST log structured JSON with:
  - `test_name`, `test_phase` (setup/execute/verify)
  - `idempotency_key`, `lease_seq`, `operation_id`
  - `expected_outcome`, `actual_outcome`
  - `timing_ms` for each phase
- Failures MUST include full context for reproduction

## Golden Vectors
- Provide golden vectors for:
  - OperationIntent canonical CBOR
  - OperationReceipt canonical CBOR
  - Idempotency key derivation

## Acceptance Criteria
- All tests pass with `cargo test`
- Fault injection tests use deterministic chaos (seeded RNG)
- No flaky tests (deterministic outcomes)
- Coverage of all code paths in exactly-once module
close_reason: Implemented 60 comprehensive tests for exactly-once semantics: CBOR golden vectors, idempotency, lease fencing, fault injection, concurrency, and edge cases

title: fcp.jira: Sprint and board management
description:
# fcp.jira: Sprint and board management (FCP2)

## Goal
Implement Jira Agile operations for **boards** and **sprints** so agents can manage sprint workflows safely under FCP2 capability + approval enforcement.

This bead is specifically about Jira Software (Agile) surfaces (boards, sprints, backlog), not generic issue CRUD.

## Scope
### Read operations (low risk)
- List boards visible to the principal.
- Get board configuration (type, filters, location).
- List sprints for a board; get sprint metadata.
- List issues in a sprint/backlog (pagination; stable ordering).

### Write operations (medium/high risk)
- Create sprint (board-scoped).
- Start / complete sprint.
- Move issues into/out of sprint and backlog.

### Constraints
- Must work in both Jira Cloud and Server/DC (via `flywheel_connectors-3a9`).
- Must respect project permissions and Jira Software license availability.

## Capability model (illustrative)
Capability IDs MUST NOT encode hosts/ports.
- `jira.boards.read`
- `jira.sprints.read`
- `jira.sprints.write` (create/start/complete)
- `jira.sprints.assign_issues` (move issues)

Danger/approval guidance:
- Starting/completing sprints should be **approval-gated** by policy in many orgs.
  - Emit DecisionReceipt reason codes that are specific (e.g., `JIRA_SPRINT_START_REQUIRES_APPROVAL`).

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- NetworkConstraints pinned to the Jira base hostname.
- For write ops: emit OperationReceipt + AuditEvent with:
  - board_id / sprint_id / issue_keys (IDs only; no secret data)
  - request correlation id

## Deliverables
- Operation schemas:
  - `jira.board.list`
  - `jira.board.get`
  - `jira.sprint.list`
  - `jira.sprint.get`
  - `jira.sprint.create`
  - `jira.sprint.start`
  - `jira.sprint.complete`
  - `jira.sprint.issues`
  - `jira.sprint.move_issues`
  - `jira.backlog.move_issues`
- Robust pagination helpers (bounded memory; streaming-friendly).
- Clear error mapping when Jira Software APIs are unavailable.

## Test strategy (MUST)
### Unit/integration (mock-only)
- Mock fixtures for Agile endpoints:
  - board listing and sprint listing
  - start/complete sprint happy paths
  - permission denied
  - missing Jira Software (feature not enabled)
  - rate-limit + retry/backoff

### Compliance
- Ensure capability-gating is enforced for each operation.
- Ensure write operations produce receipts/audit events.

## Acceptance criteria
- A mock-only test suite covers both Cloud and Server/DC variants.
- All write operations are capability + (policy-configurable) approval gated.
- No assumptions about “global boards”; all operations are explicitly scoped.

title: fcp.webhook-receiver: Inbound Event Gateway
description:
# Inbound Event Gateway Meta-Connector

**Force Multiplier:** Universal webhook receiver for external service integrations.

## Overview

Many services push events via webhooks (GitHub, Stripe, Discord, Slack, etc.). Instead of building separate webhook handlers for each service, this meta-connector provides a unified HTTP endpoint infrastructure with per-service configuration.

## Core Components

### 1. HTTP Endpoint Management
- Dynamic endpoint creation/deletion
- Unique URL per webhook source
- Support for path-based routing (`/webhooks/{service}/{id}`)
- Health check endpoints
- CORS and preflight handling
- Rate limiting per endpoint

### 2. Signature Verification (Per-Service)
- Pluggable verification strategies:
  - HMAC-SHA256 (GitHub, Stripe)
  - HMAC-SHA1 (legacy services)
  - Ed25519 (Discord)
  - API key header
  - Basic auth
  - Custom verification functions
- Timing-safe comparison
- Signature caching for replay prevention
- Failed verification alerting

### 3. Payload Transformation
- JSON schema validation
- Payload normalization to common event format
- Field mapping/extraction
- Nested payload unwrapping
- Binary payload handling (multipart)
- Compression support (gzip, deflate)

### 4. Event Routing to Zones
- Route events to appropriate FCP zones
- Support multiple destinations per event type
- Filter events based on payload content
- Priority-based routing
- Fan-out to multiple handlers

### 5. Retry/Dead-Letter Handling
- Configurable retry strategies:
  - Exponential backoff
  - Fixed interval
  - Fibonacci backoff
- Dead letter queue for failed events
- Manual retry interface
- Event replay capability
- TTL-based expiration

## Configuration Example

```toml
[[webhooks]]
name = "github-repo-events"
path = "/webhooks/github/main-repo"
signature_type = "hmac-sha256"
signature_header = "X-Hub-Signature-256"
secret = "${GITHUB_WEBHOOK_SECRET}"
route_to = "zone.github-automation"
event_type_header = "X-GitHub-Event"

[[webhooks]]
name = "stripe-payments"
path = "/webhooks/stripe/payments"
signature_type = "stripe"
secret = "${STRIPE_WEBHOOK_SECRET}"
route_to = "zone.billing"
retry_max = 5
retry_backoff = "exponential"

[[webhooks]]
name = "discord-interactions"
path = "/webhooks/discord/bot"
signature_type = "ed25519"
public_key = "${DISCORD_PUBLIC_KEY}"
route_to = "zone.discord-bot"
```

## Event Format (Normalized)

```json
{
  "id": "evt_abc123",
  "source": "github",
  "type": "push",
  "timestamp": "2024-01-15T10:30:00Z",
  "webhook_id": "github-repo-events",
  "payload": { ... },
  "metadata": {
    "delivery_id": "xyz789",
    "signature_valid": true,
    "received_at": "2024-01-15T10:30:00.123Z"
  }
}
```

## Success Criteria

- [ ] Support 10+ common webhook signature types
- [ ] Sub-50ms processing latency
- [ ] 99.9% uptime for webhook endpoints
- [ ] Complete audit trail for all received webhooks
- [ ] Zero data loss with dead-letter queue
- [ ] Hot-reload of webhook configurations

## Dependencies

- HTTP server framework (axum/actix-web)
- Persistent queue for dead-letter handling
- Zone routing system

## Security Considerations

- All secrets stored encrypted
- IP allowlisting per webhook (optional)
- Request size limits
- Timeout handling
- DDoS protection integration

title: fcp-config: Configuration Validation and Schema Framework
description:
# fcp-config: Configuration Validation and Schema Framework

## Overview
Type-safe configuration framework with JSON Schema validation, secret handling, and environment variable support for FCP connectors.

## Schema Validation
- JSON Schema Draft 7 validation
- Required field enforcement
- Type validation (string, number, bool, array, object)
- Format validation (uri, email, uuid, datetime)
- Custom validators
- Nested schema support

## Configuration Loading
- TOML file parsing
- JSON file parsing
- Environment variable expansion (${VAR})
- File path resolution
- Default value injection
- Configuration merging

## Secret Handling
- Secret placeholder syntax: ${secret:name}
- Environment variable secrets
- File-based secrets (Docker secrets)
- Vault integration (future)
- No secrets in logs/errors

## Validation Errors
- Human-readable error messages
- JSON path to invalid field
- Expected vs actual type
- Suggested fixes
- Multiple error aggregation

## Configuration Schema Definition
- Derive macros for Rust structs
- Automatic schema generation
- Documentation extraction

## Features
- Hot reload support
- Change detection
- Validation caching
- Cross-field validation

## Dependencies
- serde, serde_json, toml
- jsonschema, regex
- fcp-core
close_reason: Superseded by FCP2 Connector Manifest (1n78.19). Configuration validation is now part of manifest parsing/verification.

title: fcp.figma: Component extraction and inspection
description:
# fcp.figma: Component extraction and inspection (FCP2)

## Goal
Expose Figma component metadata so agents can:
- identify reusable components and variants
- inspect component properties (auto-layout, constraints)
- support design-to-code workflows

## Scope
- List components and component sets for a file or library.
- Fetch component details:
  - name
  - key/id
  - description
  - variant properties (for sets)
- Find component instances within a file (where supported).

## Performance constraints
- Figma files can be very large; component discovery must be:
  - paginated
  - bounded memory
  - avoid downloading full node trees unless explicitly requested

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `figma.components.read`
- `figma.files.read` (for node references)

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- NetworkConstraints pinned.
- Treat component names/descriptions as tainted.

## Deliverables
- Operation schemas:
  - `figma.component.list`
  - `figma.component.get`
  - `figma.component_set.list`
  - `figma.component.instances`

## Test strategy (MUST)
- Mock-only tests for:
  - listing pagination
  - large-file behavior (bounded)
  - error mapping (missing component, permission)

## Acceptance criteria
- Component discovery is reliable and does not require full-file downloads by default.

title: fcp.zendesk: Ticket CRUD Operations
description:
# fcp.zendesk: Ticket CRUD Operations (FCP2)

## Goal
Provide safe, typed ticket CRUD so agents can:
- create tickets
- read ticket details and thread metadata
- update status/priority/assignee/tags

Ticket content often contains PII; strict logging hygiene is required.

## Scope
- Create/get/update ticket.
- List/search tickets with filters and pagination.
- Soft-delete/archive (dangerous; optional).
- Attachments are handled as bounded downloads/uploads (may be separate surface).

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `zendesk.tickets.read`
- `zendesk.tickets.write` (dangerous-ish)
- Optional: `zendesk.tickets.delete` (dangerous)

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- NetworkConstraints pinned to the Zendesk subdomain host.
- PII hygiene:
  - do not log raw ticket bodies or requester emails
  - logs include only ticket ids and field names changed
- For writes: receipts + audit events required.

## Deliverables
- Operation schemas:
  - `zendesk.ticket.create`
  - `zendesk.ticket.get`
  - `zendesk.ticket.update`
  - `zendesk.ticket.search`
  - Optional: `zendesk.ticket.archive`

## Test strategy (MUST)
- Mock-only tests for:
  - CRUD flows
  - pagination
  - permission denied
  - receipts/audit for mutations
  - redaction

## Acceptance criteria
- Ticket mutations are mechanically authorized and auditable.
- No PII leaks into logs.

title: fcp.figma: Plugin-like operations via REST API
description:
# fcp.figma: Plugin-like operations via REST API (FCP2)

## Goal
Provide higher-level **macro operations** that feel like “plugin actions” but are implemented purely via the Figma REST API + connector-side processing.

Rationale:
- Figma’s public API is mostly read + comments/webhooks.
- Many real workflows want “do the thing” operations (extract, package, compare, annotate) without writing a custom plugin.

## Scope
### Macro operations (examples)
- `figma.macro.export_component_bundle`:
  - input: file_key + node_ids
  - output: a canonical `ComponentBundle` object containing:
    - minimal node sub-tree
    - rendered assets (optional, bounded)
    - extracted tokens (optional)
    - metadata (component ids, names)
- `figma.macro.design_audit`:
  - detect missing tokens, inconsistent styles, naming issues
  - output: structured findings (no human text required)
- `figma.macro.annotate_with_comments` (write):
  - create a constrained set of comments referencing findings

### Boundaries
- These macros must be **compositions** of already-defined safe primitives (file access, export, comments).
- No attempt to emulate full plugin execution or arbitrary code.

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `figma.files.read`
- `figma.export.read` (if bundling includes exports)
- `figma.tokens.read` (if bundling includes tokens)
- `figma.comments.write` (only for annotate macros)

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- NetworkConstraints pinned.
- Bounded outputs:
  - explicit max nodes per bundle
  - explicit max bytes for any embedded assets
- Structured logs include only IDs and counts (no raw design text).

## Deliverables
- Canonical types:
  - `ComponentBundle`
  - `DesignAuditFinding`
- Operation schemas:
  - `figma.macro.export_component_bundle`
  - `figma.macro.design_audit`
  - Optional: `figma.macro.annotate_with_comments`

## Test strategy (MUST)
- Mock-only tests for:
  - bundle construction determinism
  - bounds enforcement
  - comment annotation gating

## Acceptance criteria
- Macro ops are deterministic, bounded, and mechanically authorized.

title: fcp.sentry: Issue listing and advanced search
description:
# fcp.sentry: Issue listing and advanced search (FCP2)

## Goal
Provide efficient, correct access to Sentry **issue discovery** so agents can:
- list issues by project/environment
- search issues with filters (status, assignee, time range, error type)
- page reliably without missing/duplicating results

## Scope
### Read operations
- List issues for a project/org with:
  - status filters (unresolved/resolved/ignored)
  - environment filters (prod/staging)
  - time range filters
  - sort order (frequency, last seen, priority)
  - pagination (cursor-based)
- Optional: saved searches / query templates (connector-local, policy-owned)

### Output shaping
- Return **metadata** required for downstream workflows:
  - issue id
  - short title/message (PII risk: treat as tainted user content)
  - counts (events/users)
  - last_seen / first_seen
  - status/assignee
  - latest event id pointer (when provided)

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `sentry.issues.read`

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- NetworkConstraints pinned to the configured Sentry host.
- Treat issue titles/messages as **tainted** (they originate from external logs).
- Structured logs:
  - include org/project identifiers and query fingerprints
  - never log raw issue payloads in full

## Deliverables
- Operation schemas:
  - `sentry.issue.list`
  - `sentry.issue.search`
  - `sentry.issue.get_summary`
- Cursor-safe pagination helpers (bounded memory; no unbounded accumulation).

## Test strategy (MUST)
- Mock-only tests for:
  - pagination correctness (no dupes, no gaps)
  - filter correctness
  - rate limiting + retry/backoff
  - taint propagation (issue fields remain tainted)

## Acceptance criteria
- Search/list results are stable and deterministic across retries.
- No PII/secrets appear in logs, receipts, or errors.

title: fcp.jira: Tempo/time tracking integration
description:
# fcp.jira: Tempo/time tracking integration (FCP2)

## Goal
Add optional integration with **Tempo Timesheets** (and/or Jira-native worklogs where possible) to enable:
- time logging against issues
- retrieving timesheets/worklogs for reporting
- safe, auditable time entry automation

Tempo is common in enterprise Jira deployments; this bead isolates that surface because it often involves **additional APIs/hosts** and different auth.

## Zone model (mechanical)

<!-- fcp2-single-zone-note -->
**FCP2 single-zone binding note:** A connector instance binds to exactly one `ZoneId` for its entire lifetime.
The connector MUST NOT multiplex multiple zones internally.

Recommended deployment pattern: run separate connector instances in separate zones with different capability grants/policies.

## Scope
### Read
- List worklogs for an issue.
- Aggregate worklogs by user/sprint/project (where API supports).
- Retrieve Tempo account/category metadata (if used).

### Write
- Add/edit/delete worklog entries.
- Optional: “bulk log” flows (dangerous; approval gated).

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `jira.worklogs.read`
- `jira.worklogs.write` (dangerous-ish; affects reporting/billing)
- `jira.tempo.read` (if Tempo API is separate)
- `jira.tempo.write` (dangerous)

Policy guidance:
- In many orgs, time logging is sensitive; treat `*.write` as approval-gated.

## NetworkConstraints & auth
- Jira base hostname is pinned by the connector.
- If Tempo requires a separate host, it MUST be explicitly declared in NetworkConstraints (no implicit egress).
- Credentials are injected via `CredentialId`. Do not store API keys on disk.

## Deliverables
- Operation schemas:
  - `jira.worklog.list`
  - `jira.worklog.add`
  - `jira.worklog.update`
  - `jira.worklog.delete`
  - Optional Tempo-specific operations (only if installed/enabled):
    - `jira.tempo.timesheet.get`
    - `jira.tempo.accounts.list`
    - `jira.tempo.categories.list`
- Clear feature-detection behavior:
  - If Tempo is not available, return a typed “feature unavailable” error, not a generic failure.

## Test strategy (MUST)
### Unit/integration (mock-only)
- Mock Jira worklog endpoints.
- Mock Tempo endpoints (when enabled).
- Tests for:
  - correct permission failures
  - idempotency behavior for repeated “add worklog” attempts (where feasible)
  - redaction/no-PII logging

### Compliance
- Any write operation emits receipts + audit events including:
  - issue key
  - worklog id
  - time spent (duration only)
  - correlation id

## Acceptance criteria
- Time tracking operations are fully capability-gated and policy-configurable for approval.
- Connector correctly handles “Tempo not installed / not licensed” cases.
- No secrets/PII leak via logs, errors, or receipts.
