title: [FCP2] Full Profile: Advanced Mesh Hardening
description:
# [FCP2] Full Profile: Advanced Mesh Hardening

## Goal
Implement the *Full* conformance profile extensions after MVP is stable.

This epic is intentionally **post-MVP**. It hardens and scales the mesh, improves offline guarantees, and adds stronger post-compromise security options.

## Includes
- Threshold secrets (Shamir) + SecretAccessToken flows
- Source diversity enforcement (anti-sybil / anti-single-source symbol dependence)
- Gossip optimization (XOR filter + IBLT) for scalable dissemination
- Computation migration primitives and planner hooks
- Optional PCS zone mode via MLS/TreeKEM
- Advanced repair controller with SLO evaluation + adaptive placement/pre-staging

## Non-goals
- Backwards compatibility with any earlier protocol
- "Nice to have" connector features (connectors are a separate epic)

## Definition of Done
- Full-profile features are implemented behind explicit configuration, with conformance tests and benchmarks.
- No regressions to MVP latency/memory budgets.

## Success Criteria
- Full-profile features can be enabled per zone/policy without changing connector binaries.
- The conformance suite can distinguish MVP-only vs Full claims.

title: [FCP2] Threshold Secrets: Shamir Sharing + SecretAccessToken + Zeroize Discipline
description:
# [FCP2] Threshold Secrets: Shamir Sharing + SecretAccessToken + Zeroize Discipline

## Goal
Implement k-of-n threshold secrets such that no single device ever holds the whole secret at rest. This is DISTINCT from RaptorQ - secrets use real cryptographic secret sharing because RaptorQ symbols can leak structure.

## Background & Justification (V2 Spec §17.3)

The V2 spec explicitly states: "Secrets use real cryptographic secret sharing (Shamir), not just RaptorQ symbols. RaptorQ symbols are NOT a secret sharing scheme—a single symbol can leak structure."

Key differences from RaptorQ:
- RaptorQ symbols can leak structure (not semantically secure)
- Single RaptorQ symbol may reveal partial information
- Shamir shares reveal NOTHING until k shares collected
- Wrapped shares ensure a node cannot decrypt other nodes' shares

**Design Philosophy:** "Secrets are never complete anywhere"

## Normative Types (V2 Spec §17.3)

### SecretObject
```rust
pub struct SecretObject {
    pub header: ObjectHeader,
    pub secret_id: SecretId,        // Unique identifier
    pub zone_id: ZoneId,            // Zone binding
    pub k: u8,                      // Threshold (need k shares)
    pub n: u8,                      // Total shares distributed
    pub scheme: SecretSharingScheme,
    pub wrapped_shares: HashMap<TailscaleNodeId, Vec<u8>>,
    pub rotation: SecretRotationPolicy,
}
```

### SecretSharingScheme
```rust
pub enum SecretSharingScheme {
    ShamirGf256,  // Shamir's Secret Sharing over GF(2^8)
}
```

### SecretRotationPolicy
```rust
pub struct SecretRotationPolicy {
    pub rotate_after_secs: u64,    // Auto-rotate interval
    pub overlap_secs: u64,         // Both old and new valid during rotation
}
```

### SecretAccessToken
```rust
pub struct SecretAccessToken {
    pub jti: Uuid,                  // Unique token ID
    pub secret_id: SecretId,        // Which secret
    pub purpose: String,            // For audit trail
    pub requested_by: PrincipalId,  // Requester identity
    pub iat: u64,                   // Issued at
    pub exp: u64,                   // Expires at (short-lived!)
    pub signature: Signature,       // Approver signature
}
```

### Ephemeral Reconstruction (NORMATIVE)
```rust
impl SecretObject {
    pub async fn use_secret<F, R>(&self, access_token: &SecretAccessToken, f: F) -> Result<R>
    where F: FnOnce(&[u8]) -> R
    {
        // 1. Verify access token
        access_token.verify()?;
        
        // 2. Create audit event BEFORE reconstruction
        self.audit_secret_access(access_token).await?;
        
        // 3. Collect k wrapped shares from peers
        let shares = self.collect_k_wrapped_shares(access_token).await?;
        
        // 4. Reconstruct using Shamir
        let secret = reconstruct_shamir_secure(&shares)?;
        
        // 5. Execute closure with ephemeral secret
        let result = f(&secret);
        
        // 6. Zeroize IMMEDIATELY after use
        secure_zero(secret);
        
        Ok(result)
    }
}
```

## Requirements
- Use Shamir secret sharing over GF(2^8) with constant-time operations
- Shares are sealed to each node's X25519 key (HPKE)
- Access requires explicit SecretAccessToken (approval) + audit event
- Reconstruct in memory only; zeroize immediately after use
- Support configurable k-of-n thresholds
- Implement SecretRotationPolicy with overlap periods

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Shamir GF(2^8) implementation with constant-time polynomial evaluation
- [ ] SecretObject with k-of-n threshold configuration
- [ ] Per-node share wrapping using HPKE with node's X25519 key
- [ ] SecretAccessToken creation and validation (short-lived tokens)
- [ ] Ephemeral reconstruction with immediate zeroization
- [ ] SecretRotationPolicy with overlap period support
- [ ] Integration with CredentialObject for secret-backed credentials
- [ ] Comprehensive audit events for all secret operations
- [ ] Unit tests for share creation/reconstruction
- [ ] Negative tests: single share cannot reconstruct
- [ ] Property tests: k-1 shares reveal nothing

title: [FCP2] Source Diversity Enforcement (Anti-Single-Source Symbol Dependency)
description:
# [FCP2] Source Diversity Enforcement (Anti-Single-Source Symbol Dependency)

## Goal
Prevent availability and integrity from collapsing onto a single symbol source.

In practice: ensure object reconstruction (and ongoing repair) meets **source-diversity targets** so:
- one compromised/offline node cannot become the de-facto “single point of symbol truth”
- repair/availability remains robust under churn

This is a **Full Profile** hardening feature (Spec §17.2 “Source Diversity” + §25.0 Full Profile list).

## Why Users Care
- Offline resilience is meaningless if “offline recovery” silently depends on exactly one device.
- Security is weaker if an attacker can dominate reconstructed objects by being the only effective symbol provider.
- Deterministic enforcement makes the system predictable and explainable.

## Core Concept
Treat symbol sources as a measurable property of coverage, not just “do we have K symbols?”

For each object (or chunked object), track:
- `distinct_sources`: how many unique nodes contributed symbols used for reconstruction
- `max_concentration_bps`: max share of symbols contributed by any single node (basis points)

## Policy Model
Extend `ObjectPlacementPolicy` / coverage evaluation with diversity constraints:
- `min_distinct_sources: u16` (e.g., ≥ 2 or ≥ 3)
- `max_source_concentration_bps: u16` (e.g., ≤ 7000 bps = 70%)

These are evaluated alongside coverage ratio targets.

## Implementation Sketch
### A) Source tracking
Maintain a bounded per-object histogram:
- `SourceHistogram { top_k: Vec<(node_id, count)>, other_count: u32 }`
- Update on each accepted symbol receipt.
- Bound memory:
  - cap tracked sources per object
  - aggregate tail into `other_count`

### B) Enforcement points
- **Reconstruction**: when selecting symbols to decode, prefer symbol sets that satisfy diversity constraints.
- **Repair**: if diversity is below target, request symbols from additional nodes (targeted repair) to meet policy.
- **Explainability**: when failing due to insufficient diversity, emit a stable reason code and evidence:
  - required min sources / max concentration
  - observed histogram summary

### C) Interaction with byzantine assumptions
- Tailscale node IDs are authenticated, but nodes can still be faulty/malicious.
- Diversity enforcement is not a full Sybil defense, but it is a major reduction in single-source fragility.

### D) Bounds / DoS considerations
- Never keep unbounded per-object histograms.
- Prefer streaming aggregation and bounded heaps.
- Do not allow “symbol spam” to force per-object state growth.

## Dependencies
- `flywheel_connectors-1n78.15` (stores + placement/coverage evaluation)
- `flywheel_connectors-1n78.17` (mesh routing/repair plumbing)
- `flywheel_connectors-6o25` (Full Profile umbrella)

## Tests
### Unit
- histogram aggregation is bounded and deterministic
- concentration calculations are correct

### Simulation
- 3–5 node scenarios showing:
  - concentration collapse detected
  - repair selects additional sources
  - policy targets reached over time

### Adversarial
- single node attempts to dominate availability → enforcement triggers repair / denial

## Acceptance Criteria
- Diversity metrics are computed deterministically in basis points.
- Placement/repair can enforce `min_distinct_sources` and `max_source_concentration_bps`.
- Failures are explainable via reason codes and evidence.

title: TEST: Source Diversity Enforcement (Unit + Simulation + Adversarial)
description:
# TEST: Source Diversity Enforcement (Unit + Simulation + Adversarial)

## Goal
Prove `flywheel_connectors-6o25.2` is correct, bounded, and effective:
- diversity metrics are computed correctly
- enforcement triggers repair/denial deterministically
- storage/memory overhead stays bounded

## Test Categories
### Unit
- SourceHistogram aggregation:
  - bounded source tracking (cap works)
  - deterministic top-k selection
  - basis-points concentration computation
- Policy evaluation:
  - `min_distinct_sources` and `max_source_concentration_bps` checks

### Simulation (deterministic)
- 3-node mesh: one node holds most symbols initially → repair must bring in at least 1 more source
- 5-node mesh: concentration threshold forces diversification over time
- churn: one node disappears → policy re-satisfied via repair

### Adversarial
- malicious/single source attempts to dominate symbol responses
- ensure enforcement:
  - does not allocate unbounded per-object state
  - does not accept garbage to “satisfy” diversity without real distinct sources

## Logging Requirements
Per `flywheel_connectors-1n78.35`, emit structured JSON including:
- `object_id`, `zone_id`
- `distinct_sources_observed`, `max_concentration_bps_observed`
- `min_distinct_sources_required`, `max_concentration_bps_required`
- `repair_actions`, `result`

## Acceptance Criteria
- Deterministic simulations reproduce identical metrics and decisions in CI.
- Adversarial tests demonstrate bounded behavior and correct refusal/repair.

title: [FCP2] Gossip Optimization: XOR Filter + IBLT for Efficient Set Reconciliation
description:
# [FCP2] Gossip Optimization: XOR Filter + IBLT for Efficient Set Reconciliation

## Goal
Scale gossip beyond naïve “announce everything” by using set sketches:
- **XOR filters** for fast, compact membership tests
- **IBLTs** (Invertible Bloom Lookup Tables) for efficient set reconciliation when differences are small

This is a **Full Profile** scalability feature (Spec §25.0 Full Profile list).

## Why Users Care
- Lower background bandwidth → better battery life + less DERP usage.
- Faster convergence after partitions.
- Enables larger meshes without turning gossip into DoS.

## Background
The MVP gossip baseline (`flywheel_connectors-1n78.17.5`) can be correct but wasteful.

Full Profile adds *efficient summaries*:
- “I have these ObjectIds (approximately)…”
- “Here is a sketch to reconcile our differences…”

## Design / Deliverables
### A) Summary objects
Define canonical, size-bounded summary messages:
- `AvailabilitySummary`:
  - zone_id
  - checkpoint seq hints
  - XOR filter of known ObjectIds / symbol availability buckets
  - parameters + salt (domain separated)
- `ReconciliationSketch`:
  - IBLT table sized to expected diff
  - explicit bounds (max cells, max bytes)

### B) Protocol flow (high level)
1. Periodically exchange `AvailabilitySummary` with peers.
2. If summary indicates likely differences:
   - attempt IBLT reconciliation
   - if IBLT decode succeeds, request missing objects/symbols
   - if IBLT decode fails (diff too large), fall back to bounded explicit requests

### C) Security / DoS considerations
- XOR filters have false positives; never treat them as authoritative.
- IBLT decoding must be bounded:
  - max cells
  - max decode time
  - max retries
- All inbound summaries are subject to admission control budgets.

### D) Determinism requirements
- Use deterministic salts derived from zone_id + epoch/checkpoint to make tests reproducible.
- Ensure encoding/decoding is stable across platforms.

## Dependencies
- `flywheel_connectors-1n78.17` and `flywheel_connectors-1n78.17.5` (baseline gossip)
- `flywheel_connectors-1n78.15` (stores/availability model)
- `flywheel_connectors-6o25` (Full Profile umbrella)

## Tests
### Unit
- XOR filter build/query correctness (incl. false positive characterization)
- IBLT encode/decode for small diffs

### Simulation
- compare baseline vs optimized gossip bandwidth under:
  - small diffs
  - medium diffs
  - large diffs (forces fallback)

### Adversarial
- malformed/oversized summaries rejected
- decode-time bounds enforced

## Acceptance Criteria
- Convergence is correct (no missed required objects) under fallback paths.
- Optimized gossip reduces bandwidth measurably vs baseline in simulation.
- All decoding and memory usage is bounded.

title: TEST: Gossip Optimization (XOR Filter + IBLT)
description:
# TEST: Gossip Optimization (XOR Filter + IBLT)

## Goal
Validate the Full Profile gossip optimization (`flywheel_connectors-6o25.3`):

## Test Categories
### Unit

  - membership queries behave as expected

## Logging Requirements

- No unbounded allocations or panics on adversarial inputs.

title: [FCP2] Computation Migration: Checkpoints, Leases, and Safe Handoffs
description:
# [FCP2] Computation Migration: Checkpoints, Leases, and Safe Handoffs

## Goal
Implement Spec §16 computation migration so computations (including long-running connector work) can move between nodes **without duplicate side effects**.

This is a **Full Profile** feature: it builds on MVP correctness (leases, state objects, receipts/audit) and adds safe relocation under churn.

## Why This Matters
- Devices go offline, roam, and lose connectivity.
- Some computations are expensive (stateful streams, large sync jobs) and should resume rather than restart.
- Without a real migration protocol, “device-aware execution” becomes best-effort and can violate exactly-once semantics.

## Normative Alignment (Spec §16)
- Migration checkpoints MUST be **content-addressed mesh objects** distributed via the symbol layer.
- Execution leases MUST be transferred (fencing token changes) **before** resumption to prevent double execution.
- Migration state machine is explicit and auditable (Running → Suspended → Transferring → Running).

## Design / Deliverables
### A) MigratableComputation schema
Define a canonical schema that is sufficient for safe resume:
- `computation_id: ObjectId`
- `zone_id: ZoneId`
- `current_holder: TailscaleNodeId`
- `state: Running | Suspended | Completed | Failed`
- `checkpoint_object_id: Option<ObjectId>`
- `execution_lease_id: LeaseId`
- `lease_fencing_token: u64`
- `capability_context: { capability_token_jti, chk_id/chk_seq, aud_binary }` (minimal binding to authority)

### B) Checkpoint creation
- checkpoint bytes MUST be canonical (deterministic CBOR)
- checkpoints MUST be bounded and chunked when large (ChunkedObjectManifest)
- include integrity protection (ObjectHeader + signature where appropriate)

### C) Migration protocol
1. **Suspend**: holder transitions computation to Suspended and writes a checkpoint.
2. **Distribute**: ensure checkpoint is symbol-available to the target (may require targeted repair).
3. **Request**: holder sends a migration request to target (control plane).
4. **Lease handoff**: perform lease transfer so the target becomes the only valid executor.
5. **Resume**: target reconstructs checkpoint and resumes; emits audit/receipt events.

### D) Failure/partition handling
- network partition during migration MUST fail closed:
  - target cannot resume without the lease fencing token proving ownership
  - holder cannot resume once it has relinquished the lease
- concurrent migration attempts are resolved by lease/quorum rules

## Tests
### Unit
- checkpoint creation/restoration (roundtrip)
- migration state transitions (Running→Suspended→Running)
- lease fencing token monotonicity during transfer

### Integration
- full migration cycle between 2 nodes in the deterministic harness
- migration with partial symbol availability (requires repair)

### Adversarial
- partition during migration (split-brain prevention)
- corrupted checkpoint detection
- lease expiry mid-migration

## Acceptance Criteria
- Migration between devices is possible without duplicate execution.
- Resumption is impossible without lease ownership (fencing token).
- Migration emits audit events and (when side effects exist) OperationIntent/OperationReceipt evidence.

title: [FCP2] PCS Zones: Optional MLS/TreeKEM for Post-Compromise Security
description:
# [FCP2] PCS Zones: Optional MLS/TreeKEM for Post-Compromise Security

## Goal
Provide an optional **Post-Compromise Security (PCS)** mode for sensitive zones (e.g., `z:owner`, `z:private`) using MLS/TreeKEM-style group key agreement.

In PCS mode, *after a compromise is detected and recovered*, the system can regain forward security properties through group ratcheting.

This is a **Full Profile** hardening feature (Spec §25.0 Full Profile list).

## Why Users Care
- A single compromised device shouldn’t permanently poison a high-trust zone.
- Membership changes should trigger key updates with stronger security guarantees than “rewrap the same scheme.”

## Non-goals
- PCS is not required for MVP conformance.
- We are not designing a new group protocol; we adopt MLS/TreeKEM.

## Design Options (choose one; document the decision)
### Option A: MLS-derived ZoneKeyManifest keys
- MLS group state produces an epoch-sequenced shared secret.
- Derive `zone_key` material from MLS secret + epoch via HKDF.
- ZoneKeyManifest carries:
  - PCS mode flag
  - MLS commit references / group state object ids
  - deterministic epoch derivation parameters

### Option B: MLS used only for rekey distribution
- Keep the existing ZoneKeyManifest structure, but:
  - MLS group messages distribute/authorize new zone keys
  - ZoneKeyManifest points to the MLS commit that authorized the key

## Required Integration Points
- `flywheel_connectors-1n78.6` (ZoneKeyManifest + rotation): PCS mode must plug into the same key-selection/rotation plumbing.
- `flywheel_connectors-1n78.32` (enrollment/removal): membership changes drive MLS updates.
- `flywheel_connectors-1n78.25` (trust/quorum semantics): define which signatures/commit proofs are required.
- Observability: log and audit PCS rekeys without leaking secrets.

## Library Choice / Constraints
- Prefer a mature, audited Rust MLS implementation (e.g., `openmls`) if it meets:
  - no-unsafe project constraints (or clearly isolated/audited if unavoidable)
  - deterministic encoding for on-wire objects where needed
  - acceptable performance for small groups (personal mesh)

## Tests
### Unit
- deterministic derivation of epoch keys given MLS state + epoch
- membership-change triggers correct rekey

### Simulation
- compromise + recovery scenario:
  - before recovery: compromised node can decrypt
  - after PCS rekey: compromised node cannot decrypt future traffic

### Benchmarks
- key update latency for typical mesh sizes (n=3..10)
- memory impact of maintaining MLS state

## Acceptance Criteria
- PCS mode is opt-in per zone and coexists with non-PCS zones.
- Membership changes trigger PCS rekey with explicit audit evidence.
- Benchmarks and tests demonstrate feasibility for personal meshes.

title: TEST: PCS Zones (MLS/TreeKEM) Simulation + Benchmarks
description:
# TEST: PCS Zones (MLS/TreeKEM) Simulation + Benchmarks

## Goal
Validate the PCS zone mode (`flywheel_connectors-6o25.5`) is:
- correct (key updates work)
- secure (post-compromise properties improve)
- operationally feasible (performance and memory are acceptable for personal meshes)

## Test Categories
### Unit
- deterministic key derivation from MLS state + epoch
- membership change triggers rekey
- removed node cannot derive new keys

### Simulation
- scenario: compromise → removal → PCS rekey
  - confirm compromised/removed node cannot decrypt future epochs
- scenario: transient offline member rejoins
  - state reconciliation and commit application

### Benchmarks
- key update latency for n=3..10
- memory footprint of MLS state objects

## Logging Requirements
Per `flywheel_connectors-1n78.35`, emit structured JSON including:
- `zone_id`, `member_count`
- `rekey_ms`, `memory_bytes`
- `result` + `fcp_error_code` on failure

## Acceptance Criteria
- Tests are deterministic and pass in CI.
- Bench outputs are machine-readable and regressions are detectable.

title: [FCP2] Threshold Owner Signing: FROST Ed25519 (Recommended)
description:
# [FCP2] Threshold Owner Signing: FROST Ed25519 (Recommended)

## Goal
Implement threshold signing for the **owner root key** so no single leaked device key compromises the entire system.

The spec RECOMMENDS threshold owner signing; this is a core hardening step for z:owner / high-trust zones.

## Requirements
- Use a modern threshold Ed25519 scheme (e.g., FROST).
- Support:
  - distributed key generation (DKG) or secure key splitting
  - signing sessions with a threshold (t-of-n)
  - deterministic transcript binding (domain separation)
- Integrate with policy:
  - zones can require threshold owner signatures for specific object classes (ZoneKeyManifest, RevocationHead, AuditHead, ZoneCheckpoint)

## Deliverables
- Owner key material never exists as a single plaintext key on one device.
- A threshold-signature verifier that produces the same public verification key as the owner anchor.
- Operational ergonomics:
  - clear “needs quorum” UX
  - timeouts and retry semantics

## Tests
- Golden vectors for signature verification.
- Simulation tests for partial participant availability.

## Acceptance Criteria
- High-trust zones can be configured to require threshold signatures for critical objects.

title: TEST: Threshold Owner Signing (FROST) Vectors + Availability Simulation
description:
# TEST: Threshold Owner Signing (FROST) Vectors + Availability Simulation

## Goal
Validate `flywheel_connectors-6o25.6` with:
- golden vectors for verification
- deterministic simulations of partial signer availability
- failure-mode coverage (timeouts, missing shares, wrong participants)

## Test Categories
### Golden vectors
- signature verification vectors (threshold-produced signature verifies under owner public key)
- transcript binding / domain separation vectors

### Simulation
- n=3..10 participants, t-of-n signing
- missing participant scenarios (still succeed if ≥t available)
- reject if <t participants

### Adversarial

- replayed transcript
- malformed signature shares

## Logging Requirements
Per `flywheel_connectors-1n78.35`, emit structured JSON including:
- `threshold_t`, `threshold_n`, `participants_present`
- `result`, `duration_ms`, `fcp_error_code` on failure

## Acceptance Criteria
- Vectors pass deterministically across platforms.
- Simulations demonstrate availability behavior.

title: [FCP2] Advanced Repair Controller: SLO Evaluation + Adaptive Placement/Pre-staging
description:
# [FCP2] Advanced Repair Controller: SLO Evaluation + Adaptive Placement/Pre-staging

## Goal
Upgrade MVP repair/placement into an **SLO-driven, adaptive repair controller**:
- continuously evaluates offline/availability SLOs
- chooses repair actions that maximize resilience per unit cost
- integrates predictive pre-staging signals

This is a **Full Profile** refinement (Spec §25.0 Full Profile list: “advanced repair controller with SLO evaluation”).

## Why Users Care
- Battery and bandwidth are limited; repair must be smart, not brute-force.
- Users want predictable offline availability for important objects.
- The system should explain *why it repaired X instead of Y*.

## Inputs
- `ObjectPlacementPolicy` targets (coverage bps, concentration bps, min distinct nodes)
- Offline capability metrics (`flywheel_connectors-31c7`)
- Device profiles (storage/network constraints)
- Current symbol availability state from stores

## Controller Responsibilities
### A) SLO evaluation
Compute per-zone and per-policy metrics:
- `coverage_bps` distribution (p50/p90/p99 over tracked objects)
- `can_access` ratio for “hot” objects
- source diversity metrics (when enabled)

### B) Repair planning
- Prioritize repairs based on:
  - user importance (hotness / pinned objects)
  - SLO deficit (how far below target)
  - repair cost estimate (symbols to fetch, expected DERP penalty, expected decode CPU)
- Generate a bounded “repair plan” per cycle:
  - max repairs per cycle
  - max bytes per cycle
  - max decode budget per cycle

### C) Adaptive behavior
- Increase repair aggressiveness when:
  - SLO is below threshold
  - device is on mains power and has bandwidth
- Decrease repair when:
  - on battery / metered
  - DERP-only connectivity for high-cost repairs

### D) Explainability
- Emit a stable reason code for repair decisions:
  - `repair.policy_slo_deficit`
  - `repair.diversity_deficit`
  - `repair.hot_object_pre_stage`
  - `repair.deferred_power_budget`

## Dependencies
- `flywheel_connectors-1n78.15` (stores/placement/repair baseline)
- `flywheel_connectors-31c7` (offline capability + pre-staging signals)
- `flywheel_connectors-wwq8` (device profiles)
- `flywheel_connectors-1n78.28` (metrics/logging)

## Tests
### Unit
- deterministic repair prioritization for fixed inputs
- cost estimation sanity checks

### Simulation
- demonstrate SLO improvement over time under churn
- demonstrate adaptive behavior under battery/metered constraints

### Benchmarks
- planning overhead remains low (bounded time)

## Acceptance Criteria
- Repair planning is deterministic and bounded.
- Simulations show measurable SLO improvement vs MVP baseline.
- Logs/metrics make repair behavior explainable.

title: TEST: Advanced Repair Controller (Unit + Simulation + Bench)
description:
# TEST: Advanced Repair Controller (Unit + Simulation + Bench)

## Goal
Prove `flywheel_connectors-6o25.7` is correct, deterministic, and *actually improves* offline/availability SLOs without blowing budgets.

This test suite focuses on the **planning loop** (compute SLO → choose repairs → explain why) rather than low-level symbol plumbing.

## Test Categories

### Unit (deterministic)
- **SLO metrics:** given a fixed object set + symbol coverage state, compute:
  - coverage basis-points (bps) per object
  - p50/p90/p99 coverage over tracked sets
  - hot-object access ratio
- **Cost estimation sanity:** symbols-to-fetch, expected bytes, decode budget estimates are bounded and monotonic.
- **Planner determinism:** identical inputs produce identical repair plans (including tie-breaking).
- **Budget enforcement:** per-cycle limits are enforced:
  - max repairs
  - max bytes
  - max decode budget
- **Reason codes:** each planned repair includes a stable reason code:
  - `repair.policy_slo_deficit`
  - `repair.diversity_deficit`
  - `repair.hot_object_pre_stage`
  - `repair.deferred_power_budget`

### Simulation (deterministic)
- **Churn scenario:** nodes come/go; controller restores coverage toward policy targets.
- **Battery / metered scenario:** controller defers non-critical repairs and logs `repair.deferred_power_budget`.
- **DERP-only scenario:** controller prefers lower-cost repairs when DERP penalty is high.
- **Baseline comparison:** demonstrate measurable SLO improvement vs the MVP repair loop (same seed + topology).

### Benchmarks
- Planning overhead stays bounded under increasing object counts (e.g., 1k/10k/100k tracked objects).
- Verify stable runtime upper bounds per cycle (no unbounded scans).

## Logging Requirements
Per `flywheel_connectors-1n78.35`, emit structured JSON logs including:
- `zone_id`, `cycle_id`
- `policy_id`, `policy_targets` (coverage/diversity)
- `object_count_tracked`, `object_count_below_target`
- `budgets` and `budgets_used`
- per-action: `object_id`, `reason_code`, `estimated_bytes`, `estimated_decode_ms`, `selected_path` (if applicable)

## Acceptance Criteria
- Deterministic simulations reproduce identical plans/metrics in CI.
- Planner is explainable: logs make it obvious *why* a plan was chosen.
- Benchmarks confirm planning time is bounded and does not scale pathologically.

## Goal

title: fcp.arxiv: Reference extraction from paper content
description:
# fcp.arxiv: Reference extraction from paper content (FCP2)

## Goal
Extract structured references from paper PDFs/LaTeX to support:
- citation linking
- bibliography reconstruction
- cross-referencing with external indices

## External surface (NetworkConstraints)
Default deny.
- Network egress MUST be restricted per-operation via manifest `NetworkConstraints`.
- Allow only the configured service host(s); HTTPS-only where applicable; deny redirects by default.
- Bound timeouts + response sizes; treat all remote responses as untrusted input; never leak secrets/PII in logs or errors.

## Scope
- Parse references section from extracted text.
- Produce a normalized `ReferenceList`:
  - title (best-effort)
  - authors (best-effort)
  - venue/year (best-effort)
  - external identifiers when detectable (DOI/arXiv id)

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `arxiv.references.extract`

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- No network beyond pinned PDF hosts.
- Bounded processing:
  - cap pages/bytes parsed
  - cap number of extracted references

## Deliverables
- Operation schemas:
  - `arxiv.paper.references.extract`
- Canonical output type:
  - `ReferenceList`

## Test strategy (MUST)
- Fixture-based tests with known-paper PDFs.
- Golden extraction vectors for known reference formats.

## Acceptance criteria
- Reference extraction is deterministic and bounded.

title: TEST: Connector State Unit Tests (State Chain, Failover, Fork Detection, Adversarial)
description:
# TEST: Connector State Unit Tests

## Goal
Comprehensive tests verifying connector state persistence, failover, and fork detection.

## Test Categories

### 1. State Schema Tests
- ConnectorStateRoot schema validation
- ConnectorStateObject schema validation (incl. lease_seq, lease_object_id)
- ConnectorStateSnapshot schema validation
- Golden vectors for all state object types
- State schema versioning validation

### 2. State Chain Tests
- Append new state object to chain
- Verify chain integrity (hash linking)
- State lookup by cursor/position
- Chain traversal and iteration
- Compaction preserves chain integrity

### 3. Singleton-Writer Fencing Tests (NORMATIVE)
- State writes MUST include lease_seq and lease_object_id
- Stale lease holder write attempt (MUST be rejected deterministically)
- Valid lease holder can write
- Lease renewal during active writes
- ObjectHeader.refs MUST reference the Lease object

### 4. Failover Tests
- Failover resumes from last committed state
- No duplicate processing after failover
- State cursor preserved across restarts
- Graceful vs crash failover scenarios

### 5. Fork Detection Tests (CRITICAL)
- Two competing state objects with same prev = SAFETY INCIDENT
- Fork detection triggers pause + audit
- Fork audit event contains correct evidence
- Recovery path after fork detection

### 6. Snapshot Tests
- Snapshot creation at configured cadence
- Snapshot compaction rules
- Replay from snapshot + delta
- Snapshot integrity verification

### 7. Migration / Upgrade Tests (V2-only; NO backwards compatibility)
We do **not** support legacy/older state schema reads.

- State schema version migration hints exist and are **informational only** (NOT auto-executed).
- Fail-closed behavior for unknown/older state schema versions:
  - deterministic error code
  - AuditEvent emitted with evidence
- If/when a migration tool exists:
  - migrations must be explicit, deterministic, and produce new content-addressed objects
  - golden vectors cover upgrade paths

## Logging Requirements
- Structured JSON logs with:
  - `test_name`, `state_object_id`, `chain_height`
  - `lease_seq`, `writer_identity`
  - `expected_outcome`, `actual_outcome`
  - Fork detection events with full evidence

## Adversarial Tests
- Byzantine writer attempts (wrong lease, forged lease_seq)
- Replay attacks on state objects
- State object with invalid prev reference
- Concurrent fork attempts

## Acceptance Criteria
- All tests deterministic (no flaky behavior)
- Fork detection tests are thorough and documented
- Lease fencing is mechanically enforced
- Logging sufficient for post-mortem analysis
close_reason: Completed: 75 comprehensive tests for connector_state module covering CBOR golden vectors, state chain integrity, singleton-writer fencing, failover, fork detection, snapshots, CRDT deltas, and adversarial scenarios

title: fcp.sentry: Release tracking and deployment correlation
description:

title: fcp.openai - OpenAI Provider Connector
description:
# fcp.openai - OpenAI Provider Connector (FCP2)

## Goal
Provide an FCP2-compliant OpenAI provider connector (chat, embeddings, audio, images) with streaming support, usage/cost metrics (no embedded pricing tables), and strict single-zone + default-deny enforcement.

## Strategic Context

### Value Assessment
**Strategic Value Score: 94/100** — Critical Tier 1 connector (AI Provider family).

**Why Critical**: OpenAI offers the broadest suite of AI capabilities including chat completions, embeddings, vision, audio (Whisper, TTS), and image generation (DALL-E). Essential for multi-modal agent workflows.

### Priority Matrix Position
- **Category**: Strategic Investment (High Value + Foundation)
- **Build Phase**: Phase 1 Foundation (immediate)

---

## V2 Specification Compliance (NORMATIVE)

### ConnectorArchetype
```rust
archetypes: vec![ConnectorArchetype::Operational, ConnectorArchetype::Streaming]
```
- **Operational**: Standard request/response for chat, embeddings, images
- **Streaming**: SSE streaming for chat completions

### ConnectorStateModel
```rust
state_model: ConnectorStateModel::Stateless
```
- **Stateless**: No mesh-persisted state needed for most operations
- Assistants API threads are managed by OpenAI, not connector state
- Each request is independent

### ConnectorFormat
```rust
format: ConnectorFormat::Wasi
```
- **WASI recommended**: External API connector with credential handling
- Memory isolation for API key safety
- Cross-platform consistent behavior

### NetworkConstraints (NORMATIVE)
```rust
NetworkConstraints {
    host_allow: vec!["api.openai.com".into()],
    port_allow: vec![443],
    deny_localhost: true,
    deny_private_ranges: true,
    deny_tailnet_ranges: true,
    deny_ip_literals: true,
    require_sni: true,
    require_host_canonicalization: true,
}
```

### TaintFlags (NORMATIVE)
AI model outputs carry provenance metadata:
```rust
// Model outputs are internally generated
model_output.provenance.taint = TaintFlags::NONE;

// If output contains URLs:
if output.contains_urls {
    model_output.provenance.taint |= TaintFlags::UNVERIFIED_LINK;
}

// Outputs that will be interpreted by LLM:
if output.is_prompt_surface {
    model_output.provenance.taint |= TaintFlags::PROMPT_SURFACE;
}
```

### SafetyTier per Operation
| Operation | SafetyTier | Rationale |
|-----------|------------|-----------|
| `openai.chat.completions` | Safe | Read-only generation |
| `openai.chat.stream` | Safe | Read-only streaming |
| `openai.embeddings.create` | Safe | Read-only embedding |
| `openai.audio.transcription` | Safe | Read-only transcription |
| `openai.audio.speech` | Risky | Resource-intensive |
| `openai.images.generate` | Risky | High-cost, content risk |
| `openai.finetune.manage` | Dangerous | Resource-intensive, billing |

---

## Agent Capabilities (Concrete Use Cases)

### Text & Chat
- Chat completions (GPT-4, GPT-4o, etc.)
- Function calling / tool use
- Assistants API for stateful conversations
- JSON mode for structured outputs

### Embeddings
- Text embeddings for semantic search
- Document embedding for RAG pipelines
- Code embeddings

### Audio
- Whisper for transcription
- TTS for text-to-speech
- Voice mode integration

### Vision & Image
- Vision (images in prompts)
- DALL-E image generation
- Image editing

### Examples of Agent Workflows
```
"Transcribe this audio file"
"Generate embeddings for these documents"
"Create an image for this concept"
"Analyze this image and extract data"
"Convert this text to speech"
```

---

## Flywheel Ecosystem Synergies

### LLM Router Integration
- Part of the `fcp.llm-router` meta-connector strategy
- Fallback when Anthropic unavailable
- Different model strengths for different tasks

### CASS (Context-Aware Semantic Search)
- **Embeddings API is critical for CASS**
- Generate embeddings for semantic indexing
- Power vector search across Flywheel

### Whisper Connector Synergy
- Can use OpenAI Whisper API
- Or local Whisper model via fcp.whisper
- Consistent interface either way

### Agent Mail
- TTS for audio notifications
- Transcribe voice messages

---

## Technical Implementation Notes

### API Surface
- **Chat Completions** — Primary text generation
- **Embeddings** — Vector generation
- **Audio** — Whisper transcription, TTS
- **Images** — DALL-E generation/editing
- **Assistants** — Stateful conversation threads
- **Fine-tuning** — Model customization management

### Recommended Crates
- `reqwest` — HTTP client with streaming
- `async-sse` — SSE parsing for streaming
- `serde_json` — JSON handling
- `base64` — Audio/image encoding

### Streaming Implementation
Similar to Anthropic, uses SSE:
```rust
// data: {"choices":[{"delta":{"content":"token"}}]}
```

### Assistants API
- Threads maintain conversation state
- Runs execute assistant on thread
- File attachments for documents
- Code interpreter tool

---

## Zone Architecture

### Recommended Zones
| Zone | Description | Capabilities |
|------|-------------|--------------|
| `z:ai:openai:full` | Full access | All models, all capabilities |
| `z:ai:openai:gpt4` | GPT-4 access | GPT-4 models only |
| `z:ai:openai:gpt35` | GPT-3.5 access | Cost-effective option |
| `z:ai:openai:embeddings` | Embeddings only | No generation |
| `z:ai:openai:audio` | Audio only | Whisper + TTS |
| `z:ai:openai:images` | Images only | DALL-E |

---

## Manifest Archetypes (Closed Set)
- `operational` — Standard request/response
- `streaming` — SSE streaming for completions

---

## External Surface

### NetworkConstraints
Default-deny; allow only:
- `api.openai.com:443`

### Credential Injection
- API key via `CredentialId`
- Organization ID (optional) via config
- Never write credentials to disk

---

## Capability Model

### Text Generation
- `openai.chat.completions` — Chat completions
- `openai.chat.stream` — Streaming completions

### Embeddings
- `openai.embeddings.create` — Generate embeddings

### Audio
- `openai.audio.transcription` — Whisper transcription
- `openai.audio.translation` — Whisper translation
- `openai.audio.speech` — TTS generation

### Images (Dangerous - Cost)
- `openai.images.generate` — DALL-E generation
- `openai.images.edit` — Image editing
- `openai.images.variations` — Image variations

### Assistants
- `openai.assistants.manage` — Create/update assistants
- `openai.threads.manage` — Manage conversation threads
- `openai.runs.execute` — Execute assistant runs

### Fine-tuning (Dangerous)
- `openai.finetune.manage` — Manage fine-tuning jobs

---

## Operations (Representative)

### Chat Completions
```json
POST /chat/completions
{
  "model": "gpt-4o",
  "messages": [...],
  "tools": [...],
  "response_format": {"type": "json_object"},
  "stream": true
}
```

### Embeddings
```json
POST /embeddings
{
  "model": "text-embedding-3-small",
  "input": ["text to embed"]
}
```

### Audio Transcription
```json
POST /audio/transcriptions
{
  "model": "whisper-1",
  "file": <audio_file>,
  "response_format": "verbose_json"
}
```

### Image Generation
```json
POST /images/generations
{
  "model": "dall-e-3",
  "prompt": "...",
  "size": "1024x1024",
  "quality": "hd"
}
```

---

## Safety + Retries

### Rate Limits
- Different limits per model/capability
- Respect `retry-after` headers
- Implement token-bucket rate limiting

### Cost Control
- Track tokens per request
- Image generation is expensive
- Budget enforcement at zone level

---

## Tests

### Unit Tests (Mock-Only)
- Request construction for all API endpoints
- Response parsing (including streaming)
- Token counting
- Error handling

### Integration Tests
- wiremock-based API simulation
- Multi-modal scenarios (text + image)
- Embedding dimension verification

### E2E Compliance
- Validates default deny + NetworkConstraints
- Usage metrics accurate
- Cost tracking functional

---

## Acceptance Criteria
- Passes connector compliance runner (static + dynamic)
- No real OpenAI calls in unit tests
- All major APIs functional (chat, embeddings, audio, images)
- Streaming works correctly
- Tool use functions properly
- Usage metrics emitted
- All V2 NORMATIVE requirements satisfied

title: fcp.openai: Manifest + Capability Map (FCP2)
description:
# fcp.openai: Manifest + Capability Map (FCP2)

## Goal
Specify the OpenAI connector manifest contract:
- archetypes (`operational`, `streaming`)
- operation list + schema IDs
- capability families + per-operation required caps
- NetworkConstraints (default-deny; explicit allowlist)
- state model (likely stateless for most ops; stateful only where required)

## Key design choices to lock down
- How we represent “model identifier” in schemas and provenance.
- How we represent streaming responses (chunk schema, final summary schema).
- Which operations are considered side-effecting and require OperationIntent/Receipt.
- Which operations are Dangerous (fine-tuning, file writes) and require ApprovalToken `Execution` scope.

## Outputs
- Complete manifest section stored in this bead.
- Good/bad manifest examples for static compliance.

## Acceptance Criteria
- The functionality described in this bead is implemented with typed schemas + validation (no unstructured “stringly” interfaces).
- Errors map to the FCP error taxonomy with correct retry semantics and no secret/PII leakage.
- Mock-only unit/integration tests cover success paths and common failures and emit structured JSON logs per `flywheel_connectors-1n78.35`.
acceptance_criteria: - Manifest includes full operation list + schema IDs\n- Capability families map to operations; NetworkConstraints are default-deny\n- Includes at least 2 good and 2 bad manifest examples that the static compliance runner accepts/rejects deterministically

title: fcp.openai: Provisioning Automation (API Key + Deployment Profile)
description:

- Provisioning emits structured logs per `flywheel_connectors-1n78.35`.

# fcp.openai: Fine-tuning (policy-gated)

## Goal
Support fine-tuning job lifecycle operations behind strict policy.

title: [FCP2] Checkpoint/Frontier Management: Advancement Protocol, Fork Detection, Convergence
description:
# [FCP2] Checkpoint/Frontier Management: Advancement Protocol, Fork Detection, Convergence

## Goal
Define the protocol for checkpoint advancement, frontier management, and fork detection/resolution.

## Why This Matters
ZoneCheckpoints are the "heartbeat" of mesh security. Stale checkpoints mean stale revocation/audit enforcement. Without clear advancement rules, checkpoints become inconsistent.

## ZoneCheckpoint Structure (recap)
```
ZoneCheckpoint {
  zone_id: ZoneId,
  checkpoint_id: ObjectId,
  seq: u64,
  
  // Bound heads
  audit_head_id: ObjectId,
  audit_head_seq: u64,
  revocation_head_id: ObjectId,
  revocation_head_seq: u64,
  policy_head_id: ObjectId,
  config_head_id: ObjectId,
  
  // Quorum
  signatures: Vec<(NodeId, Ed25519Signature)>,
  timestamp: u64,
}
```

## Advancement Protocol (NORMATIVE)

### Trigger Conditions
New checkpoint SHOULD be issued when:
- Time since last checkpoint > checkpoint_interval (default: 60s)
- Audit chain has > N new events (default: 100)
- Revocation chain has any new events
- Policy or config changed

### Advancement Steps
1. **Coordinator Selection**: HRW hash over (zone_id, "checkpoint", epoch)
2. **Proposal**: Coordinator broadcasts CheckpointProposal
3. **Signature Collection**: Nodes sign if:
   - All referenced heads are known and valid
   - seq = prev_seq + 1
   - timestamp is within skew tolerance
4. **Finalization**: Once n-f signatures collected, checkpoint is published
5. **Propagation**: All nodes update their frontier

### Freshness Rules
- Token verification: `token.chk_seq <= local_checkpoint_seq` OR degraded mode
- Revocation verification: `local_revocation_head_seq >= policy_min_revocation_seq`

## Fork Detection (CRITICAL)

### Fork Condition
A fork exists when two checkpoints have:
- Same zone_id
- Same seq
- Different checkpoint_id

### Fork Response
1. **Immediate**: Halt checkpoint advancement
2. **Audit**: Emit ForkDetected audit event with both checkpoint IDs
3. **Alert**: Push alert to operator (cannot be auto-resolved)
4. **Safe Mode**: Operations requiring fresh checkpoint MUST fail

### Fork Prevention
- Coordinator election is deterministic
- Only coordinator can propose for given seq
- Nodes reject proposals from non-coordinator

## Convergence Protocol
After partition heals, nodes must converge:
1. Exchange frontier summaries
2. Identify highest common checkpoint
3. Replay missed checkpoints from peers
4. Resume normal advancement

## Tests
- Unit tests: checkpoint advancement with quorum
- Integration tests: partition → divergent checkpoints → heal → convergence
- Adversarial tests: fork injection detected and halts advancement
- Property tests: seq is always monotonic

## Acceptance Criteria
- Checkpoints advance reliably under normal conditions
- Forks are detected and halt advancement
- Convergence after partition works correctly
close_reason: Implemented checkpoint.rs with core types: CheckpointTrigger, CheckpointProposal, ForkEvidence, ForkDetectionResult, CheckpointAdvanceState, CheckpointValidationError, FreshnessResult. Added HRW coordinator selection. All 35 unit tests pass, clippy clean.

title: fcp.mcp-bridge: MCP Gateway Meta-Connector
description:
# fcp.mcp-bridge - MCP Gateway Meta-Connector (FCP2) [DEFERRED DESIGN]

## Goal
Investigate whether an MCP bridge can be made **mechanically safe** under FCP2’s requirements:
- deterministic manifest + interface_hash
- explicit capabilities (no “invoke anything” escape hatch)
- strict sandbox + NetworkConstraints
- single-zone binding
- no interpreted-runtime dependency in the connector distribution

## Why this is hard
MCP servers are often dynamic:
- tool sets can change at runtime
- schemas may be discovered dynamically

FCP2 requires a stable, verifiable contract:
- operations + schemas are part of the signed manifest
- conformance runner must be able to validate behavior mechanically

## Design constraints (non-negotiable)
- Single connector instance binds to exactly one `ZoneId`.
- The connector targets exactly one MCP server endpoint per instance.
- The manifest MUST enumerate the exposed tools/operations and schemas.
  - Dynamic “discover and expose new tools” is NOT allowed for production compliance.

## Allowed deployment modes (candidate)
- Remote MCP server over HTTP/SSE/WebSocket with explicit NetworkConstraints.
- Local stdio only if the MCP server is a policy-approved native executable (no Node/Python dependency implied by this connector).

## Proposed scope (if feasible)
- Provide a bridge for a *known* MCP server with a pinned tool schema set.
- Translate tool schemas to FCP operations at build time or install time and bind them into the manifest (signed).

## Outputs of this bead
- A clear “Go/No-Go” recommendation.
- If “Go”: a concrete design for manifest pinning + tool schema hashing + conformance strategy.
- If “No-Go”: document the exact spec conflicts and what would need to change.

## Acceptance Criteria
- The result is conclusive and actionable.

title: fcp.spotify: Playback Control
description:
# fcp.spotify: Playback Control (FCP2)

## Goal
Enable safe playback control for user devices:
- play/pause
- skip
- seek
- set volume/shuffle/repeat
- transfer playback between devices

Playback control is a real-world side effect and may require Spotify Premium.

## Scope
- Get current playback state and device list.
- Control playback on a specific device.

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `spotify.playback.read`
- `spotify.playback.control` (dangerous-ish)

Policy guidance:
- Some orgs may require approval for playback control in certain zones.

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- NetworkConstraints pinned.
- For control operations:
  - receipts + audit events include device id + action (no track names)
  - handle “Premium required” as a typed denial (not a generic error)

## Deliverables
- Operation schemas:
  - `spotify.playback.get_state`
  - `spotify.playback.devices.list`
  - `spotify.playback.play`
  - `spotify.playback.pause`
  - `spotify.playback.next/previous`
  - `spotify.playback.seek`
  - `spotify.playback.set_volume`
  - `spotify.playback.transfer`

## Test strategy (MUST)

  - control request formation
  - premium-required error mapping
  - audit/receipt emission

## Acceptance criteria
- Playback actions are safe, auditable, and do not leak listening content in logs.

title: TEST: Bootstrap/Genesis Unit Tests (First-Run, Owner Key Ceremony, Initial Enrollment)
description:
# TEST: Bootstrap/Genesis Unit Tests


## Goal
Validate first-run bootstrap/genesis flows are correct and safe (owner ceremony, enrollment, initial objects) with deterministic tests.

## Scope
Comprehensive tests for first-run mesh initialization and owner key ceremony.

## Test Categories

### Owner Key Generation
- [ ] Ed25519 keypair generation succeeds
- [ ] Key material never written unencrypted
- [ ] Public key fingerprint is stable
- [ ] Key import from external source
- [ ] Threshold key generation (FROST shares)

### Genesis Object Creation
- [ ] Genesis AuditEvent is self-referential (prev=self)
- [ ] Genesis RevocationHead has seq=0
- [ ] Genesis ZoneCheckpoint binds all heads
- [ ] All genesis objects are owner-signed
- [ ] Genesis objects are canonical CBOR

### First Device Enrollment
- [ ] Node keys generated correctly
- [ ] NodeKeyAttestation is owner-signed
- [ ] Node added to z:owner membership
- [ ] ZoneKeyManifest sealed to new node

### Zone Creation
- [ ] z:owner created as genesis zone
- [ ] Additional zones (private/work/community/public) created
- [ ] Zone policies correctly applied
- [ ] Cross-zone isolation verified

### Offline Bootstrap
- [ ] Genesis objects can be created air-gapped
- [ ] Import via file succeeds
- [ ] Chain integrity verified on import

## Golden Vectors
Location: `tests/vectors/bootstrap/`
- `genesis_audit_event.cbor`
- `genesis_revocation_head.cbor`
- `genesis_zone_checkpoint.cbor`
- `node_key_attestation.cbor`

## Logging Requirements
```json
{
  "timestamp": "RFC3339",
  "test_name": "test_genesis_creation",
  "phase": "execute",
  "correlation_id": "uuid",
  "genesis_objects": ["audit", "revocation", "checkpoint"],
  "owner_pubkey_fingerprint": "...",
  "result": "pass"
}
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- Single-node mesh can be initialized from scratch
- Second node can be enrolled
- All genesis objects pass verification

title: fcp.hubspot: Contact and company management
description:
# fcp.hubspot: Contact and company management (FCP2)

## Goal
Provide safe, typed access to HubSpot CRM **contacts** and **companies** so agents can:
- look up existing records
- create/update records with auditability
- search with filters without leaking PII

## Scope
### Contacts
- Create/get/update/archive contacts.
- Search by email/name and filter by properties.

### Companies
- Create/get/update/archive companies.
- Search by domain/name and filter by properties.

### Associations (minimum)
- Retrieve basic associations contact↔company.

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `hubspot.contacts.read`
- `hubspot.contacts.write` (dangerous-ish: modifies CRM)
- `hubspot.companies.read`
- `hubspot.companies.write`

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- NetworkConstraints pinned to HubSpot API host(s).
- PII hygiene:
  - email/phone/address fields are sensitive
  - avoid logging raw property values
  - structured logs should include only object ids and property names changed
- For writes: receipts + audit events required.

## Deliverables
- Operation schemas:
  - `hubspot.contact.get`
  - `hubspot.contact.search`
  - `hubspot.contact.create`
  - `hubspot.contact.update`
  - `hubspot.company.get`
  - `hubspot.company.search`
  - `hubspot.company.create`
  - `hubspot.company.update`
  - `hubspot.association.get`

## Test strategy (MUST)
- Mock-only tests for:
  - CRUD happy paths
  - search pagination
  - property update redaction in logs
  - capability gating + receipts/audit for writes

## Acceptance criteria
- Agents can safely manage contacts/companies without leaking PII.
- All mutations are explicitly capability gated and audited.

title: fcp.1password - 1Password Credential Management Connector
description:
# fcp.1password - 1Password Credential Management Connector (FCP2)

## Goal
Provide an FCP2-compliant 1Password connector for credential retrieval and safe secret usage with strict audit and secrets-never-touch-disk discipline.

## Zone model (mechanical)

<!-- fcp2-single-zone-note -->
**FCP2 single-zone binding note:** A connector instance binds to exactly one `ZoneId` for its entire lifetime.
The connector MUST NOT multiplex multiple zones internally.

Recommended deployment pattern: run separate connector instances in separate zones with different capability grants/policies.

## Strategic Context

### Value Assessment
**Strategic Value Score: 79/100** — Specialized Tier 3 connector (Security/Credentials family).

**Why Critical**: 1Password is the **most trusted enterprise password manager**. Enables agents to securely retrieve credentials for other connectors, manage secrets, and handle credential rotation. Essential infrastructure for secure autonomous operations.

### Priority Matrix Position
- **Category**: Specialized Investment (Security + Foundation)
- **Build Phase**: Phase 2 Productivity (but with extreme caution)

### Bitwarden Comparison
- **1Password**: Enterprise focus, better UX, higher cost
- **Bitwarden**: Open-source, self-hostable, lower cost
- Both needed for market coverage in credential management

---

## Agent Capabilities (Concrete Use Cases)

### Credential Retrieval
- Read passwords/secrets
- Access API keys
- Get secure notes
- Retrieve documents

### Vault Management
- List vaults
- Search items
- Read item metadata
- Access shared credentials

### Security Operations
- Credential rotation support
- Expiration tracking
- Access audit

### Examples of Agent Workflows
```
"Get the API key for Stripe"
"What credentials do we have for AWS?"
"Retrieve the database password"
"List all items in the DevOps vault"
"When does this credential expire?"
"Get the SSH key for production server"
```

---

## Flywheel Ecosystem Synergies

### ALL Other Connectors
**Central credential store:**
- 1Password is THE source for connector credentials
- API keys stored in 1Password
- OAuth tokens can be stored
- Credential injection flows through here

### Terraform/Kubernetes Integration
- Infrastructure secrets
- Service account keys
- TLS certificates

### Agent Mail Integration
- Credential sharing requests
- Access approval workflows
- Rotation notifications

### Security Operations
- Centralized secret management
- Audit trail for access
- Rotation automation

---

## Technical Implementation Notes

### API Surface
1Password offers multiple integration paths:

- **Connect Server** — Self-hosted API gateway (recommended)
- **CLI** — Command-line interface
- **Service Accounts** — Direct API access

### Connect Server Architecture
```
Agent → Connect Server → 1Password Cloud
           (self-hosted)
```

### Recommended Crates
- `reqwest` — HTTP client
- `serde_json` — JSON handling

### Item Types
| Type | Use Case |
|------|----------|
| Login | Username/password pairs |
| Password | Standalone passwords |
| API Credential | API keys/tokens |
| Secure Note | Text secrets |
| Document | File attachments |
| SSH Key | SSH credentials |

---

## Zone Architecture

### Recommended Zones
| Zone | Description | Capabilities |
|------|-------------|--------------|
| `z:secrets:1password:full` | Full access | All vaults |
| `z:secrets:1password:vault:<name>` | Vault-scoped | Single vault |
| `z:secrets:1password:readonly` | Read-only | No modifications |

### Security Tiers
- **EXTREME CAUTION** — This connector has access to all secrets
- Audit every access
- Minimal scope always
- Never cache credentials in memory longer than needed

---

## Manifest Archetypes (Closed Set)
- `operational` — REST API operations

---

## External Surface

### NetworkConstraints
- **Connect Server**: Self-hosted endpoint
- **1Password.com**: Cloud endpoints (if direct)

### Credential Injection
- Connect Server token via environment or secure injection
- Service account tokens via secure injection
- NEVER write 1Password credentials to disk
- Credentials retrieved here inject into other connectors

---

## Capability Model

### Read Operations
- `1password.vaults.list` — List accessible vaults
- `1password.items.list` — List items in vault
- `1password.items.read` — Get item details
- `1password.items.fields` — Read specific fields

### Write Operations (Very Dangerous)
- `1password.items.create` — Create items
- `1password.items.update` — Update items

### Administrative (Extremely Dangerous)
- `1password.items.delete` — Delete items

---

## Operations (Representative)

### List Vaults
```json
GET /v1/vaults
```

Response:
```json
{
  "vaults": [
    {"id": "abc123", "name": "DevOps", "type": "USER_CREATED"},
    {"id": "def456", "name": "Shared", "type": "SHARED"}
  ]
}
```

### List Items in Vault
```json
GET /v1/vaults/{vault_id}/items
```

### Get Item
```json
GET /v1/vaults/{vault_id}/items/{item_id}
```

Response:
```json
{
  "id": "item123",
  "title": "AWS API Key",
  "category": "API_CREDENTIAL",
  "vault": {"id": "abc123"},
  "fields": [
    {"id": "username", "type": "STRING", "value": "AKIAIOSFODNN7EXAMPLE"},
    {"id": "credential", "type": "CONCEALED", "value": "wJalrXUtnFEMI/K7MDENG/bPxRfiCYEXAMPLEKEY"}
  ]
}
```

### Search Items
```json
GET /v1/vaults/{vault_id}/items?filter=title co "stripe"
```

---

## Security Considerations

### CRITICAL SAFETY REQUIREMENTS

1. **Never Log Secrets**: Credential values must NEVER appear in logs
2. **Minimal Hold Time**: Clear credential from memory immediately after use
3. **Audit All Access**: Every credential read must be logged (without values)
4. **Scope Minimization**: Only grant access to specific vaults needed
5. **No Caching**: Never cache credentials beyond immediate use
6. **Encrypted Transit**: All communication must be TLS

### Access Pattern
```rust
// Correct pattern
let cred = get_credential("stripe-api-key")?;
let client = StripeClient::new(&cred);
drop(cred); // Clear immediately
// Use client...

// WRONG - holding credential
let cred = get_credential("stripe-api-key")?;
// ... lots of code ...
// cred still in memory ❌
```

### Audit Requirements
Every access logged:
```json
{
  "timestamp": "2024-01-15T10:30:00Z",
  "vault": "DevOps",
  "item": "stripe-api-key",
  "accessor": "agent-123",
  "action": "read",
  "fields_accessed": ["credential"]
}
```

---

## Credential Rotation Support

### Rotation Workflow
1. Agent detects credential near expiration
2. Requests new credential generation
3. Updates item in 1Password
4. Updates consuming services
5. Verifies new credential works
6. Archives old credential

### Expiration Tracking
- Custom fields for expiration dates
- Scheduled checks for approaching expiration
- Alert workflows for rotation needs

---

## Tests

### Unit Tests (Mock-Only)
- API request construction
- Response parsing
- Field extraction
- Vault enumeration

### Integration Tests
- Mock Connect Server
- Multi-vault scenarios
- Item type handling

### E2E Compliance
- Validates NetworkConstraints
- MANDATORY audit logging
- No credential leakage in logs

---

## Acceptance Criteria
- Passes connector compliance runner (static + dynamic)
- No real 1Password calls in unit tests
- Vault listing works
- Item retrieval functional
- NO credentials in ANY logs
- Audit trail for all access
- Immediate credential clearing

## Goal
Expose a tightly-controlled moderation surface for moderators:

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- NetworkConstraints pinned.
- For any moderation write:
  - require ApprovalToken when policy dictates (recommended default)
  - receipts + audit events include thing_id + action + reason (sanitized)
- Avoid logging raw user content.

title: fcp.kubernetes: Zone architecture for prod safety (dev/staging/prod isolation)
description:
# fcp.kubernetes: Zone architecture for prod safety (dev/staging/prod isolation) (FCP2)

## Goal
Define a safe-by-default zone strategy for Kubernetes operations, especially production.

Important: the connector instance is **single-zone bound**. “Dev/staging/prod isolation” is achieved by deploying separate connector instances bound to separate zones and pinned to separate cluster API hosts.

## External surface (NetworkConstraints)
Default deny.
- Network egress MUST be restricted per-operation via manifest `NetworkConstraints`.
- Allow only the configured service host(s); HTTPS-only where applicable; deny redirects by default.
- Bound timeouts + response sizes; treat all remote responses as untrusted input; never leak secrets/PII in logs or errors.

## Scope
- Recommended zone naming patterns (policy-owned):
  - `z:work:k8s:dev:<cluster>`
  - `z:work:k8s:staging:<cluster>`
  - `z:work:k8s:prod:<cluster>`
- Capability tiering guidance:
  - readonly vs deploy vs exec
  - forbid deletes in prod by default
- Approval guidance:
  - prod deploy and exec should require ApprovalToken

## Deliverables
- Documented default policy expectations (reason codes + deny-by-default rules) referenced by connector operations.
- Clear mapping between zone policy and Kubernetes RBAC contexts.

## Test strategy (MUST)
- Policy-oriented tests (mock-only) verifying:
  - prod zone denies mutations by default
  - approval gating required for exec/deploy

## Acceptance criteria
- A user can set up three connector instances and be mechanically confident prod is protected.

title: TEST: Enrollment Unit Tests (DeviceEnrollment, NodeKeyAttestation, Removal Workflow)
description:
# TEST: Enrollment Unit Tests

## Goal
Prove that device enrollment and removal work correctly and securely.

## Test Categories

### DeviceEnrollment Object
- [ ] Valid enrollment parses correctly
- [ ] Owner signature verifies
- [ ] Tailscale node_id binding correct
- [ ] Authorized tags match
- [ ] Expiry (if present) enforced
- [ ] Malformed enrollment rejected

### NodeKeyAttestation
- [ ] Attestation binds node_id to pubkeys
- [ ] signing_pubkey correctly attested
- [ ] encryption_pubkey correctly attested
- [ ] issuance_pubkey correctly attested
- [ ] KID mappings correct
- [ ] Owner signature verifies
- [ ] Attestation expiry enforced

### Enrollment Flow
- [ ] New node can enroll with valid enrollment object
- [ ] Enrolled node receives zone keys (ZoneKeyManifest)
- [ ] Enrolled node can participate in sessions
- [ ] Enrolled node appears in peer discovery

### Key Rotation
- [ ] Node can rotate its keys
- [ ] New attestation replaces old
- [ ] Old KIDs become invalid
- [ ] Sessions using old keys gracefully terminated

### Device Removal
- [ ] Removal revokes enrollment object
- [ ] Removal revokes attestation
- [ ] Removal revokes issuer keys
- [ ] Tokens from removed node rejected
- [ ] Zone keys rotated after removal
- [ ] Removed node cannot participate

### Attack Scenarios (Adversarial)
- [ ] Replay old enrollment: rejected (revoked or expired)
- [ ] Forge enrollment: invalid owner signature rejected
- [ ] Use removed node keys: rejected after revocation propagates
- [ ] Impersonate node_id: attestation signature check fails

## Golden Vectors
- Valid DeviceEnrollment bytes
- Valid NodeKeyAttestation bytes
- Removal workflow sequence

## Integration Tests
- [ ] Full enrollment → operation → removal cycle
- [ ] Multi-node enrollment
- [ ] Concurrent enrollment attempts

## Logging Requirements
```json
{
  "test_name": "...",
  "node_id": "...",
  "operation": "enroll|attest|rotate|remove",
  "result": "pass|fail",
  "reason_code": "..."
}
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- Enrollment flow works end-to-end
- Removal flow invalidates all node authority
- No stale credentials accepted after removal

title: fcp.kubernetes: Exec into pods for debugging and maintenance
description:
# fcp.kubernetes: Exec into pods for debugging and maintenance (FCP2)

## Goal
Provide a controlled exec surface for debugging:
- run a constrained command in a container

Exec is **high risk** (arbitrary code execution in prod). Must be approval gated and heavily audited.

## Scope
- Start an exec session with:
  - explicit namespace/pod/container
  - explicit command allowlist (policy-owned)
  - explicit timeout
- Capture session transcript metadata (not raw output by default).

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `k8s.exec` (critical)

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- NetworkConstraints pinned.
- Approval gating recommended default for exec.
- Audit:
  - emit OperationReceipt + AuditEvent including command hash + targets
  - never log secrets/output by default

## Deliverables
- Operation schemas:
  - `k8s.exec.start`
  - `k8s.exec.status`
  - `k8s.exec.cancel`
- Safety layer:
  - deny interactive shells by default
  - deny dangerous commands unless explicitly allowed

## Test strategy (MUST)
- Mock-only tests for:
  - allowlist enforcement
  - approval gating
  - audit/receipt emission

## Acceptance criteria
- Exec cannot run without explicit authorization and is fully auditable.

title: fcp.arxiv: Research Literature and Paper Access Connector
description:
# fcp.arxiv - Research Literature and Paper Access Connector (FCP2)

## Goal
Plan and implement an FCP2-compliant arXiv connector for literature search and paper retrieval (metadata + PDF) under safe NetworkConstraints and input validation.

## Zone model (mechanical)

<!-- fcp2-single-zone-note -->
**FCP2 single-zone binding note:** A connector instance binds to exactly one `ZoneId` for its entire lifetime.
The connector MUST NOT multiplex multiple zones internally.

Recommended deployment pattern: run separate connector instances in separate zones with different capability grants/policies.

## Strategic Context

### Value Assessment
**Strategic Value Score: 78/100** — Specialized Tier 3 connector (Research family).

**Why Critical**: ArXiv is the **primary preprint server for STEM research**, hosting 2M+ papers. Essential for research agents, AI/ML practitioners, and anyone needing access to cutting-edge scientific literature. Enables autonomous research workflows.

### Priority Matrix Position
- **Category**: Specialized Investment (Research + Domain Knowledge)
- **Build Phase**: Phase 3 Enterprise (weeks 9-12)

### Semantic Scholar Comparison
- **ArXiv**: Raw preprints, full PDF access, direct source
- **Semantic Scholar**: Citation graphs, abstracts, AI-enhanced search
- Both needed for comprehensive research access

---

## Agent Capabilities (Concrete Use Cases)

### Search & Discovery
- Query papers by topic, author, date
- Category-based filtering (cs.AI, cs.LG, etc.)
- Full-text search via abstract
- Citation tracking

### Content Access
- Download PDFs
- Access paper metadata
- Get LaTeX source (when available)
- Version history

### Research Workflows
- Literature review automation
- Citation network exploration
- Trend analysis across time
- New paper alerts

### Examples of Agent Workflows
```
"Find recent papers on transformer architectures"
"Download papers cited by this one"
"What's new in cs.AI this week?"
"Find all papers by this author"
"Summarize the abstract of this paper"
"Track citations for these foundational papers"
"Compare methods across these papers"
```

---

## Flywheel Ecosystem Synergies

### CASS (Context-Aware Semantic Search)
**Research knowledge base:**
- Index paper abstracts
- Semantic search over literature
- Build research corpus

### Vector DB Integration
- Paper embeddings for similarity search
- Find related work automatically
- Cluster papers by topic

### AI Provider Integration
- Summarize papers with LLMs
- Extract key findings
- Generate literature reviews

### Agent Mail Integration
- Research findings → agent threads
- Collaborative literature review
- Share paper recommendations

### Notion/Airtable Integration
- Track reading lists
- Annotate papers
- Organize research projects

---

## Technical Implementation Notes

### API Surface
ArXiv provides OAI-PMH and REST-like access:

- **Search API**: `export.arxiv.org/api/query`
- **OAI-PMH**: Metadata harvesting
- **PDF Access**: Direct download via arxiv.org

### Recommended Crates
- `reqwest` — HTTP client
- `quick-xml` — Atom/XML parsing
- `url` — URL construction
- `regex` — ArXiv ID parsing

### ArXiv ID Format
```
Old: hep-th/9901001
New: 2301.12345
Version: 2301.12345v2
```

### Response Format (Atom)
```xml
<entry>
  <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.12345v1</id>
  <title>Paper Title</title>
  <summary>Abstract text...</summary>
  <author><name>Author Name</name></author>
  <category term="cs.AI" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
  <published>2023-01-25T00:00:00Z</published>
</entry>
```

---

## Zone Architecture

### Recommended Zones
| Zone | Description | Capabilities |
|------|-------------|--------------|
| `z:research:arxiv:full` | Full access | Search and download |
| `z:research:arxiv:search` | Search only | Metadata access |
| `z:research:arxiv:category:<cat>` | Category-scoped | e.g., cs.AI only |

### Data Considerations
- Papers are public — low sensitivity
- Download volume should be respectful
- Bulk access has rate limits

---

## Manifest Archetypes (Closed Set)
- `operational` — REST API operations

---

## External Surface

### NetworkConstraints
Default-deny; allow only:
- `export.arxiv.org:443` (API)
- `arxiv.org:443` (PDF download)

### Credential Injection
- No authentication required
- Rate limiting is IP-based
- Respect robots.txt

---

## Capability Model

### Read Operations
- `arxiv.search` — Query papers
- `arxiv.metadata` — Get paper details
- `arxiv.pdf.download` — Download PDF
- `arxiv.source.download` — Download LaTeX source

### No Write Operations
ArXiv is read-only for consumers.

---

## Operations (Representative)

### Search Papers
```
GET /api/query?
  search_query=all:transformer+AND+cat:cs.AI
  &start=0
  &max_results=10
  &sortBy=submittedDate
  &sortOrder=descending
```

### Get Paper by ID
```
GET /api/query?id_list=2301.12345
```

### Download PDF
```
GET https://arxiv.org/pdf/2301.12345.pdf
```

### Category Codes
| Code | Field |
|------|-------|
| cs.AI | Artificial Intelligence |
| cs.LG | Machine Learning |
| cs.CL | Computation and Language (NLP) |
| cs.CV | Computer Vision |
| stat.ML | Statistics - ML |
| math.* | Mathematics |
| physics.* | Physics |

---

## Research Workflow Patterns

### Literature Review
1. Search for topic keywords
2. Retrieve top N papers
3. Extract abstracts
4. Use LLM to summarize findings
5. Identify citation chains
6. Build reading list

### New Paper Monitoring
1. Query recent submissions by category
2. Filter by keywords/authors
3. Generate daily digest
4. Track citation counts over time

### Citation Network Analysis
1. Start with seed papers
2. Extract references
3. Recursively fetch cited papers
4. Build citation graph
5. Identify influential works

---

## Rate Limiting

### ArXiv Policies
- 1 request per 3 seconds recommended
- Bulk downloads require coordination
- Respect robots.txt
- Consider using data dumps for large-scale analysis

### Implementation
```rust
// Rate limiter: max 20 requests per minute
let limiter = RateLimiter::new(20, Duration::from_secs(60));
```

---

## Tests

### Unit Tests (Mock-Only)
- Search query construction
- Atom feed parsing
- ArXiv ID validation
- Category handling

### Integration Tests
- wiremock-based API simulation
- Pagination testing
- Multi-paper fetch scenarios

### E2E Compliance
- Validates NetworkConstraints
- Rate limit enforcement
- Audit logging

---

## Acceptance Criteria
- Passes connector compliance runner (static + dynamic)
- No real ArXiv calls in unit tests
- Search queries functional
- PDF download works
- Atom response parsing correct
- Rate limiting implemented
- Category filtering works

## Success Criteria
- Connector epic is fully decomposed into implementable beads (manifest/cap map, provisioning, operations, tests, E2E compliance).
- All child beads are implemented and closed, and the connector passes the mechanical compliance runner + its E2E scenarios with structured JSON logs.
- Mechanical guarantees hold: single-zone binding, default-deny capabilities, and NetworkConstraints enforcement; no secret/PII leakage in logs.

title: fcp.arxiv: Manifest + Capability Map (FCP2)
description:
# fcp.arxiv: Manifest + Capability Map (FCP2)

## Goal
Define the arXiv connector’s **mechanical manifest contract** under FCP2.

## Required contents
- Manifest archetypes (closed set):
  - `knowledge` (search/retrieve papers)
  - `operational` (monitors/alerts configuration)
  - `streaming` (polling-backed event stream for new papers)
- Operation list + schema IDs.
- Capability families + per-operation required caps.
- NetworkConstraints:
  - pin arXiv API hosts
  - pin PDF download hosts
  - enforce strict rate limits to avoid bans
- State model declaration:
  - monitor cursors/checkpoints for polling
  - cached metadata rules (must be bounded)

## Acceptance criteria
- Another engineer can implement `--manifest` from this bead alone.

title: fcp.arxiv: Provisioning Automation (rate limits, monitors, optional enrichments)

# fcp.arxiv: Provisioning Automation (rate limits, monitors, optional enrichments)

## Goal
Automate arXiv connector onboarding with minimal human steps.

arXiv is mostly open-access, but provisioning still matters for:
- rate limiting configuration (avoid IP bans)
- monitor/alert setup
- optional enrichments (CASS indexing, semantic search)

## Requirements
- Configure and validate:
  - base API host(s)
  - strict rate limits (token bucket; 3 req/sec baseline)
- Monitor setup automation:
  - create/list/delete monitors
  - store polling checkpoints in connector state (if enabled)
- Optional enrichment hooks (policy-owned):
  - CASS indexing configuration
  - embedding provider selection for semantic search

## Acceptance criteria
- `fcp doctor` verifies readiness (host reachability + rate limiter sanity) without secrets.
- Mockable in CI.

title: fcp.terraform: State inspection and resource listing
description:
# fcp.terraform: State inspection and resource listing (FCP2)

## Goal
Provide safe state inspection so agents can:
- list resources
- show a resource
- read outputs

State contains sensitive infrastructure details; all access must be audited.

## Scope
- List resources in state.
- Show a specific resource.
- Read outputs.
- Optional: pull remote state for inspection (read-only).

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `terraform.state.read` (sensitive)

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- Sandbox profile must prevent arbitrary filesystem access.
- Audit:
  - every state read emits an audit event
- NetworkConstraints default deny unless backend requires explicit egress.

## Deliverables
- Operation schemas:
  - `terraform.state.list`
  - `terraform.state.show`
  - `terraform.output.read`
  - Optional: `terraform.state.pull`

## Test strategy (MUST)
- Unit tests with a terraform shim for:
  - correct arg formation
  - audit event emission
  - error mapping

## Acceptance criteria
- State access is safe, auditable, and bounded.

title: fcp.semanticscholar: Research Literature Connector
description:
## Overview
Academic research connector for Semantic Scholar API, providing semantic paper search, citation analysis, and author profiling to complement the arxiv connector.

## Core Capabilities

### Paper Search with Semantic Understanding
- Natural language query support
- Semantic similarity matching (not just keywords)
- Field-of-study filtering
- Publication date range filtering
- Venue and journal filtering
- Open access filter option

### Citation Graph and References
- Retrieve citing papers (who cited this)
- Retrieve referenced papers (bibliography)
- Citation context extraction
- Multi-hop citation traversal
- Co-citation analysis
- Bibliographic coupling detection

### Author Profiles and Metrics
- Author search by name and affiliation
- H-index and citation count retrieval
- Publication history timeline
- Co-author network mapping
- Author disambiguation
- ORCID linking where available

### Topic Classification
- Automatic topic/field assignment
- Hierarchical topic taxonomy
- Cross-disciplinary paper detection
- Emerging topic identification
- Topic trend analysis over time

### Open Access Paper Retrieval
- Identify open access versions
- Direct PDF URL when available
- Preprint linking (arxiv, bioRxiv, etc.)
- License information extraction
- Full text availability status

## Integration with Arxiv Connector
- Cross-reference arxiv IDs with S2 paper IDs
- Enrich arxiv results with citation data
- Use S2 for citation metrics, arxiv for full text
- Unified paper identifier mapping

## Implementation Notes
- Use Semantic Scholar Academic Graph API
- Respect rate limits (100 req/5min for unauthenticated)
- API key support for higher limits
- Batch request support for efficiency
- Handle partial data gracefully

## Testing Requirements
- Mock API responses for unit tests
- Rate limit handling tests
- Citation graph traversal tests
- Search relevance validation
