title: TEST: fcp-cli Unit/E2E Tests (All Commands, JSON Output, Snapshot Tests)
description:
# TEST: fcp-cli Unit/E2E Tests (All Commands, JSON Output, Snapshot Tests)

## Goal
Comprehensive tests for all fcp-cli commands ensuring correct behavior, stable output schemas, and excellent debugging experience.

## Recommended Test Stack (2025-2026)
| Purpose | Crate | Version | Notes |
|---------|-------|-------|-------|
| Snapshot testing | `insta` | 1.40+ | JSON + terminal output snapshots |
| Property testing | `proptest` | 0.11+ | Fuzzy input generation |
| CLI testing | `assert_cmd` | 2.0+ | Process spawning + assertions |
| Terminal testing | `strip-ansi-escapes` | 0.3+ | Clean output for snapshots |
| Mock HTTP | `wiremock` | 0.6+ | Async HTTP mocking |
| Temp dirs | `tempfile` | 3.14+ | Deterministic test isolation |
| Security audit | `cargo-audit` | CI | Dependency vulnerability scan |
| Coverage | `cargo-llvm-cov` | 0.6+ | LLVM-based coverage |

## Test Matrix

### Platform Coverage
| Platform | CI Runner | Notes |
|----------|-----------|-------|
| Linux x86_64 | ubuntu-latest | Primary platform |
| Linux aarch64 | ubuntu-24.04-arm | ARM64 testing |
| macOS x86_64 | macos-13 | Intel Mac |
| macOS aarch64 | macos-14 | Apple Silicon |
| Windows x64 | windows-latest | MSVC toolchain |

### Test Categories

#### 1. fcp install Tests
**Unit Tests:**
- [ ] Parse valid connector name patterns (`a-z0-9-`, 1-64 chars)
- [ ] Reject invalid connector names (special chars, too long, empty)
- [ ] Parse version constraints (exact, range, latest)
- [ ] Validate manifest TOML structure
- [ ] Verify checksum algorithms (SHA256, SHA512, BLAKE3)
- [ ] Verify signature algorithms (Ed25519)

**Integration Tests:**
- [ ] Install valid connector with verified manifest
- [ ] Install fails on invalid signature
- [ ] Install fails on checksum mismatch
- [ ] Install fails on policy requirement mismatch
- [ ] Install from local file path
- [ ] Install from remote registry (mocked)
- [ ] Mirror to mesh store verification
- [ ] Supply chain attestation verification (Sigstore)
- [ ] Offline install from pinned objects
- [ ] Concurrent install of same connector (idempotent)
- [ ] Install with progress indicator (TTY detection)
- [ ] Install with `--json` output

**E2E Tests:**
- [ ] Full install flow in deterministic harness
- [ ] Install → Verify → Uninstall cycle
- [ ] Install with network partition recovery

**Snapshot Tests:**
- [ ] JSON output schema for success
- [ ] JSON output schema for failure (each error code)
- [ ] Human-readable output (color-stripped)

**Property Tests:**
```rust
proptest! {
    #[test]
    fn install_rejects_invalid_names(name in "[^a-z0-9-]{1,100}") {
        let result = run_fcp(&["install", &name, "--json"]);
        prop_assert!(result.exit_code != 0);
    }
    
    #[test]
    fn install_accepts_valid_names(name in "[a-z][a-z0-9-]{0,62}[a-z0-9]?") {
        // Should parse name successfully (may fail on network)
        let result = run_fcp(&["install", &name, "--json", "--dry-run"]);
        let json: Value = serde_json::from_str(&result.stdout)?;
        prop_assert!(json["errors"].as_array().map(|a| a.is_empty()).unwrap_or(false) 
                     || json["errors"][0]["code"].as_str() != Some("FCP-0001"));
    }
}
```

#### 2. fcp doctor Tests
**Unit Tests:**
- [ ] Parse zone identifier formats
- [ ] Calculate checkpoint freshness thresholds
- [ ] Calculate revocation freshness thresholds
- [ ] Determine health state transitions

**Integration Tests:**
- [ ] Report checkpoint freshness (fresh/stale transitions)
- [ ] Report revocation freshness (fresh/stale)
- [ ] Report degraded-mode state
- [ ] Report transport policy state (DERP/Funnel)
- [ ] Zone-scoped doctor output
- [ ] Multi-zone doctor output
- [ ] Doctor with unreachable nodes (timeout)
- [ ] Doctor during network partition

**Exit Code Tests:**
| Scenario | Exit Code |
|----------|-----------|
| All healthy | 0 |
| Warnings present | 0 (with warning in output) |
| Checkpoint stale | 13 |
| Revocation stale | 12 |
| Network unreachable | 10 |
| Authentication error | 11 |

**Snapshot Tests:**
- [ ] JSON output schema for healthy state
- [ ] JSON output schema for degraded state
- [ ] JSON output schema for unhealthy state

#### 3. fcp explain Tests
**Unit Tests:**
- [ ] Parse DecisionReceipt structure
- [ ] Render reason codes to human-readable text
- [ ] Resolve ObjectId references to objects
- [ ] Format evidence chain

**Integration Tests:**
- [ ] Render DecisionReceipt for denial (missing capability)
- [ ] Render DecisionReceipt for denial (revoked token)
- [ ] Render DecisionReceipt for denial (taint without approval)
- [ ] Render DecisionReceipt for denial (zone policy ceiling)
- [ ] Include pointers to relevant objects
- [ ] Explain approval path (what would allow this)
- [ ] Explain with `--verbose` (full object dumps)
- [ ] Explain for non-existent receipt (error handling)

**Snapshot Tests:**
- [ ] JSON output for each denial reason code
- [ ] Human-readable output for each denial

#### 4. fcp audit tail Tests
**Unit Tests:**
- [ ] Parse AuditEvent structure
- [ ] Filter by trace correlation ID
- [ ] Filter by zone
- [ ] Filter by event type
- [ ] Filter by time range

**Integration Tests:**
- [ ] Tail AuditEvent stream (live)
- [ ] Tail with `--follow` (continuous)
- [ ] Trace correlation filtering
- [ ] Zone-scoped audit tail
- [ ] Event type filtering (`--type invoke,deny`)
- [ ] Time range filtering (`--since`, `--until`)
- [ ] Limit output (`--limit 100`)
- [ ] Output formatting (`--format compact|full`)
- [ ] Handle stream interruption (SIGINT)

**Snapshot Tests:**
- [ ] JSON output schema per event type
- [ ] Compact format output
- [ ] Full format output

#### 5. fcp repair status Tests
**Unit Tests:**
- [ ] Calculate coverage metrics (bps formula)
- [ ] Parse placement policy
- [ ] Calculate concentration metrics

**Integration Tests:**
- [ ] Report coverage metrics (bps, distinct nodes, max concentration)
- [ ] Report pending repair actions
- [ ] Report last repair actions (timestamp, nodes)
- [ ] Zone-scoped repair status
- [ ] Cross-zone repair status
- [ ] Report when below SLO threshold
- [ ] Report during active repair

**Snapshot Tests:**
- [ ] JSON output for healthy coverage
- [ ] JSON output for degraded coverage
- [ ] JSON output for repair in progress

#### 6. fcp bench Tests
**Unit Tests:**
- [ ] Parse benchmark configuration
- [ ] Calculate percentile statistics
- [ ] Format benchmark results

**Integration Tests:**
- [ ] Canonical CBOR encode/decode benchmark
- [ ] ObjectId derivation benchmark
- [ ] Token verify benchmark
- [ ] FCPS parse+verify benchmark
- [ ] RaptorQ decode benchmark
- [ ] invoke-local benchmark
- [ ] invoke-mesh benchmark
- [ ] Benchmark with warm-up iterations
- [ ] Benchmark with specific iteration count
- [ ] Benchmark result comparison (baseline)

**Snapshot Tests:**
- [ ] JSON output schema (all metrics)
- [ ] Human-readable table format

#### 7. Cross-Cutting Tests
**Output Mode Tests:**
- [ ] All commands support `--json` output
- [ ] JSON output goes to stdout, diagnostics to stderr
- [ ] `--no-color` disables ANSI codes
- [ ] Color auto-detection (TTY, NO_COLOR, FORCE_COLOR, CI)
- [ ] `--quiet` suppresses non-essential output
- [ ] `--verbose` increases output detail

**Error Handling Tests:**
- [ ] All commands use FCP-XXXX error codes
- [ ] Error codes documented in JSON schema
- [ ] Stack traces available with `RUST_BACKTRACE=1`
- [ ] Helpful error messages with suggestions

**Security Tests:**
- [ ] No commands print secrets (API keys, tokens)
- [ ] No commands print auth headers
- [ ] No commands log to world-readable files
- [ ] Credentials file has 0600 permissions

**Signal Handling Tests:**
- [ ] SIGINT (Ctrl+C) graceful shutdown
- [ ] SIGTERM graceful shutdown
- [ ] SIGHUP reload configuration (if applicable)

**Environment Tests:**
- [ ] `FCP_HOME` override
- [ ] `FCP_CONFIG` override
- [ ] `FCP_LOG` level override
- [ ] `NO_COLOR` respected
- [ ] `FORCE_COLOR` respected

**Config File Tests:**
- [ ] Load from `~/.config/fcp/config.toml`
- [ ] Load from `$FCP_CONFIG`
- [ ] Config file validation
- [ ] Config precedence: flags > env > file > defaults

## Snapshot Testing Strategy

### Directory Structure
```
tests/
├── snapshots/
│   ├── install/
│   │   ├── success.json.snap
│   │   ├── invalid_signature.json.snap
│   │   └── human_output.txt.snap
│   ├── doctor/
│   │   ├── healthy.json.snap
│   │   └── degraded.json.snap
│   └── ...
├── fixtures/
│   ├── manifests/
│   ├── receipts/
│   └── events/
└── e2e/
    ├── happy_path.rs
    └── denial_path.rs
```

### Snapshot Redaction Rules
```rust
/// Fields to redact for stable snapshots
const REDACT_FIELDS: &[&str] = &[
    "timestamp",
    "created_at",
    "updated_at",
    "trace_id",
    "correlation_id",
    "duration_ms",
    "node_id",      // May vary in tests
    "session_id",
];

fn redact_dynamic_fields(json: &mut Value) {
    for field in REDACT_FIELDS {
        if let Some(v) = json.get_mut(field) {
            *v = Value::String("[REDACTED]".to_string());
        }
    }
}
```

### Terminal Output Snapshots
```rust
#[test]
fn test_doctor_healthy_output() {
    let output = Command::new("fcp")
        .args(["doctor", "--no-color"])
        .output()
        .expect("failed to run");
    
    // Strip ANSI for deterministic snapshots
    let clean = strip_ansi_escapes::strip(&output.stdout)?;
    let text = String::from_utf8_lossy(&clean);
    
    // Redact timestamps and IDs
    let redacted = redact_terminal_output(&text);
    insta::assert_snapshot!(redacted);
}
```

## E2E Test Harness

### Harness Configuration
```rust
pub struct CliTestHarness {
    /// Temporary home directory
    temp_home: TempDir,
    /// Mock mesh server
    mock_server: MockServer,
    /// Environment overrides
    env: HashMap<String, String>,
    /// Captured output
    output_log: Vec<OutputEntry>,
}

impl CliTestHarness {
    pub fn new() -> Self {
        let temp_home = tempfile::tempdir().unwrap();
        let mock_server = MockServer::start().await;
        
        let mut env = HashMap::new();
        env.insert("FCP_HOME".into(), temp_home.path().display().to_string());
        env.insert("FCP_MESH_URL".into(), mock_server.uri());
        env.insert("NO_COLOR".into(), "1".into());
        
        Self { temp_home, mock_server, env, output_log: vec![] }
    }
    
    pub fn run(&mut self, args: &[&str]) -> CommandOutput {
        let output = Command::new(fcp_binary())
            .args(args)
            .envs(&self.env)
            .output()
            .expect("failed to run fcp");
        
        self.output_log.push(OutputEntry {
            args: args.iter().map(|s| s.to_string()).collect(),
            exit_code: output.status.code(),
            stdout: String::from_utf8_lossy(&output.stdout).to_string(),
            stderr: String::from_utf8_lossy(&output.stderr).to_string(),
        });
        
        CommandOutput::from(output)
    }
}
```

## Comprehensive Logging Requirements

### Test Log Format (Structured JSON)
```json
{
  "timestamp": "2026-01-16T14:30:00.123Z",
  "test_name": "fcp_cli::install::test_valid_manifest",
  "phase": "execute",
  "level": "DEBUG",
  "correlation_id": "test-abc123",
  "seed": 42,
  "message": "Running fcp install command",
  "command": {
    "binary": "fcp",
    "args": ["install", "test-connector", "--json"],
    "env": {"FCP_HOME": "/tmp/test-home-xyz"}
  },
  "output": {
    "exit_code": 0,
    "stdout_bytes": 1234,
    "stderr_bytes": 0,
    "duration_ms": 45
  }
}
```

### Log Capture Configuration
```rust
/// Configure test logging for comprehensive debugging
pub fn setup_test_logging() -> tracing::subscriber::DefaultGuard {
    let subscriber = tracing_subscriber::fmt()
        .with_env_filter("fcp_cli=debug,test=debug")
        .with_test_writer()
        .json()
        .flatten_event(true)
        .with_current_span(true)
        .with_span_list(true)
        .finish();
    
    tracing::subscriber::set_default(subscriber)
}
```

### CI Log Artifacts
```yaml
- name: Upload test logs on failure
  if: failure()
  uses: actions/upload-artifact@v4
  with:
    name: cli-test-logs-${{ matrix.os }}
    path: |
      target/test-logs/**/*.json
      target/test-logs/**/*.snap.new
    retention-days: 14
```

## CI Integration

### Full CI Workflow
```yaml
cli-tests:
  strategy:
    matrix:
      os: [ubuntu-latest, macos-14, windows-latest]
  runs-on: ${{ matrix.os }}
  steps:
    - uses: actions/checkout@v4
    
    - name: Install Rust
      uses: dtolnay/rust-toolchain@stable
    
    - name: Cache cargo
      uses: Swatinem/rust-cache@v2
    
    - name: Security audit
      run: cargo audit --deny warnings
    
    - name: Run unit tests
      run: cargo test --package fcp-cli --lib
      env:
        RUST_LOG: debug
        RUST_BACKTRACE: 1
    
    - name: Run integration tests
      run: cargo test --package fcp-cli --test integration
      env:
        E2E_SEED: 42
    
    - name: Check snapshots
      run: cargo insta test --check
    
    - name: Coverage report
      run: cargo llvm-cov --package fcp-cli --json --output-path coverage.json
    
    - name: Verify coverage threshold
      run: |
        COVERAGE=$(jq ".data[0].totals.lines.percent" coverage.json)
        if (( $(echo "$COVERAGE < 80" | bc -l) )); then
          echo "Coverage $COVERAGE% is below 80% threshold"
          exit 1
        fi
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] JSON output schemas are stable and versioned
- [ ] All commands testable without live mesh (mock/deterministic)
- [ ] Snapshot tests prevent accidental schema breaks
- [ ] E2E tests run in deterministic harness
- [ ] Property tests cover edge cases for all string inputs
- [ ] cargo-audit passes in CI
- [ ] Coverage >80% for all CLI code
- [ ] Tests run on Linux, macOS, and Windows
- [ ] All error codes have corresponding test cases
- [ ] Signal handling tests pass (SIGINT, SIGTERM)
close_reason: Added integration tests for fcp doctor (12 tests) and fcp bench (19 tests) commands using assert_cmd. Tests cover CLI argument parsing, JSON/human output, subcommand behavior, and placeholder benchmarks.

title: TEST: fcp new (scaffold/check) command
description:
# TEST: `fcp new` (scaffold/check) command

## Goal
Add dedicated tests for the `fcp new` developer command to ensure scaffolding is safe, deterministic, and produces compliant defaults.

## Why a separate test bead?
`fcp new` is a high-leverage DX feature for building many connectors, but it is not required for the operator MVP commands.
Keeping its tests separate prevents it from blocking MVP CLI validation while still enforcing correctness when we implement it.

## Test matrix

### 1) Scaffold creation
- Creates expected directory structure under `connectors/<name>/`.
- Emits a valid connector manifest with:
  - single-zone binding
  - default-deny NetworkConstraints
  - no secret material present
- Generates placeholder operations + schemas.

### 2) Safety / no-overwrite behavior
- Fails (or requires explicit `--force` if we add one) when target directory exists.
- Never deletes files (NO rm/unlink behaviors).
- `--dry-run` prints intended outputs without touching the filesystem.

### 3) `--check` validation
- Detects malformed manifest.
- Detects missing required template sections.
- Detects obvious secret anti-patterns (plaintext token examples, etc.).
- Emits actionable diagnostics with stable error codes.

### 4) Output + logging
- Supports `--json` with a stable output schema.
- Logs include correlation ids and do not leak secrets.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Tests run deterministically in CI.
- Passing tests prove:
  - safe scaffold behavior
  - manifest correctness defaults
  - no overwrites/deletions
  - `--json` schema stability

title: fcp.arxiv: Full text and PDF access for papers
description:
# fcp.arxiv: Full text and PDF access for papers (FCP2)

## Goal
Enable retrieval of paper content for summarization and indexing:
- fetch paper metadata
- download PDF (streamed)
- extract text/sections

## Scope
- Get paper metadata by arXiv id.
- Download PDF with strict bounds.
- Extract plain text and (optional) section segmentation.

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `arxiv.paper.read`
- `arxiv.pdf.download` (sensitive-ish: large IO)
- `arxiv.pdf.extract` (local processing)

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- NetworkConstraints pinned to API + PDF hosts.
- Strict rate limiting.
- Streaming + bounds:
  - max bytes per PDF
  - cap extraction output size

## Deliverables
- Operation schemas:
  - `arxiv.paper.get`
  - `arxiv.paper.pdf.download`
  - `arxiv.paper.pdf.extract_text`
  - Optional: `arxiv.paper.pdf.extract_sections`
- Canonical output types:
  - `PaperText`
  - `PaperSections`

## Test strategy (MUST)
- Fixture-based tests for PDF extraction (no network).
- Mock-only tests for download bounds and host pinning.

## Acceptance criteria
- PDF downloads/extraction are safe, bounded, and deterministic.

title: fcp.asana: Asana project management connector
description:
## Summary

The **fcp.asana** connector integrates with Asana's project management platform, providing comprehensive task management, project organization, and team collaboration capabilities. Asana is widely used for project tracking with rich features including sections, custom fields, portfolios, goals, timelines, and workload management.

## Value Assessment

- **Value Score**: 67/100 (Tier 4)
- **Market Position**: Major project management platform alongside Linear and Jira
- **Target Users**: Teams, enterprises, and organizations using Asana for project tracking
- **Integration Potential**: High - Asana's extensive feature set enables rich automation workflows

## Technical Architecture

### Archetype: Request-Response + Webhook

The connector implements a hybrid pattern combining synchronous REST API calls with asynchronous webhook event handling for real-time updates.

### Zone Architecture

**Zone 1: Task Read** (Low risk)
- List tasks, search tasks
- Get task details, subtasks
- Read comments, attachments
- View task followers, dependencies

**Zone 2: Task Write** (Medium risk)
- Create/update/delete tasks
- Manage subtasks
- Add/remove comments
- Upload/delete attachments
- Modify task followers, dependencies

**Zone 3: Project Admin** (High risk)
- Create/update/delete projects
- Manage sections
- Configure custom fields
- Portfolio management
- Goal configuration
- Timeline adjustments
- Workload settings
- Team/workspace administration

### Dependencies

```toml
[dependencies]
fcp-core = { path = "../fcp-core" }
fcp-oauth = { path = "../fcp-oauth" }
fcp-webhook = { path = "../fcp-webhook" }
fcp-ratelimit = { path = "../fcp-ratelimit" }
fcp-telemetry = { path = "../fcp-telemetry" }
```

## Operations

### Task Operations
- `task.list` - List tasks with filters (project, assignee, section, tags)
- `task.get` - Get task details including custom fields
- `task.create` - Create new task with all properties
- `task.update` - Update task fields
- `task.delete` - Delete task
- `task.search` - Search tasks across workspace
- `task.duplicate` - Duplicate task with options

### Subtask Operations
- `subtask.list` - List subtasks of a task
- `subtask.create` - Create subtask
- `subtask.convert` - Convert subtask to task or vice versa

### Project Operations
- `project.list` - List projects in workspace/team
- `project.get` - Get project details
- `project.create` - Create new project
- `project.update` - Update project settings
- `project.delete` - Delete project
- `project.duplicate` - Duplicate project with options

### Section Operations
- `section.list` - List sections in project
- `section.create` - Create section
- `section.update` - Update section name/position
- `section.delete` - Delete section
- `section.move_task` - Move task to section

### Custom Field Operations
- `custom_field.list` - List custom fields
- `custom_field.get` - Get custom field definition
- `custom_field.create` - Create custom field
- `custom_field.update` - Update custom field
- `custom_field.delete` - Delete custom field
- `custom_field.set_value` - Set custom field value on task

### Portfolio Operations
- `portfolio.list` - List portfolios
- `portfolio.get` - Get portfolio details
- `portfolio.create` - Create portfolio
- `portfolio.update` - Update portfolio
- `portfolio.add_item` - Add project to portfolio
- `portfolio.remove_item` - Remove project from portfolio

### Goal Operations
- `goal.list` - List goals
- `goal.get` - Get goal details
- `goal.create` - Create goal
- `goal.update` - Update goal progress
- `goal.add_supporting_work` - Link project/portfolio to goal

### Timeline Operations
- `timeline.get` - Get project timeline view
- `timeline.update_dates` - Bulk update task dates
- `timeline.set_dependencies` - Configure task dependencies

### Workload Operations
- `workload.get` - Get team workload view
- `workload.capacity` - Get/set user capacity
- `workload.effort` - Get/set task effort

### Comment Operations
- `comment.list` - List comments on task
- `comment.create` - Add comment
- `comment.update` - Edit comment
- `comment.delete` - Delete comment

### Attachment Operations
- `attachment.list` - List attachments
- `attachment.upload` - Upload attachment
- `attachment.download` - Download attachment
- `attachment.delete` - Delete attachment

### Webhook Operations
- `webhook.register` - Register webhook for events
- `webhook.list` - List registered webhooks
- `webhook.delete` - Remove webhook
- Events: task created/updated/deleted, comment added, project changes

## Implementation Details

### Authentication
- **OAuth 2.0** with PKCE flow
- Scopes: `default`, `openid`, `email`, `profile`
- Token refresh handling via fcp-oauth

### Rate Limiting
- 1,500 requests per minute per user
- Exponential backoff with jitter
- Rate limit headers: `X-Asana-*`

### Pagination
- Cursor-based pagination via `offset` parameter
- Default page size: 100, max: 100
- `next_page` object in response

### Webhook Implementation
- HMAC-SHA256 signature verification
- X-Hook-Secret handshake protocol
- Event types: task, project, section, story (comment)
- Webhook filters for specific projects/events

### Error Handling
- Standard HTTP error codes
- Asana-specific error objects with `errors` array
- Retry logic for 429 (rate limit) and 5xx errors

## Beads Sync Potential

The connector supports bidirectional sync with beads:
- Tasks map to beads with assignee, due date, priority
- Sections map to bead labels/categories
- Custom fields map to bead metadata
- Comments sync as bead notes
- Subtasks sync as child beads

## API Reference

- Base URL: `https://app.asana.com/api/1.0`
- Documentation: https://developers.asana.com/docs
- API Explorer: https://developers.asana.com/explorer

## Similar Connectors

- **fcp.linear**: Similar task/issue patterns, different API structure
- **fcp.jira**: Similar project management concepts, more enterprise-focused
- Both provide reference implementations for project management connectors

## Testing Strategy

- Unit tests with mock Asana responses
- Integration tests with Asana sandbox workspace
- Webhook simulation tests
- Rate limit handling verification
- OAuth flow testing

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] All CRUD operations for tasks, projects, sections implemented
- [ ] Custom field support with all field types
- [ ] Portfolio and goal management operations
- [ ] Timeline and workload read operations
- [ ] Webhook registration and event handling
- [ ] OAuth 2.0 authentication flow
- [ ] Rate limiting with proper backoff
- [ ] Comprehensive error handling
- [ ] Beads sync mapping documentation
- [ ] Integration tests passing

title: fcp.asana: Manifest + Capability Map (FCP2)
description:
## Goal
Produce the full FCP2 manifest and capability map for this connector.

This bead is where we translate the connector’s functional surface (operations) into a **mechanically checkable** contract:
- operation schemas + schema IDs
- capability families per operation
- per-operation NetworkConstraints (default deny)
- sandbox profile requirements
- declared state model (stateless / singleton_writer / crdt)

## Required content (must be explicit)
- Operation list is exhaustive and stable for the current phase.
- Capability IDs DO NOT encode hostnames/ports.
- NetworkConstraints are minimal and per-operation.
- Risk tier for each operation (Safe / Dangerous).
- Explicit bounds: timeouts, max response sizes, pagination limits.

## Tests
- Add good/bad manifest examples for the compliance runner.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Passes static checks in `flywheel_connectors-1n78.21.5`.
- Default-deny is enforced by manifest + capability requirements.

title: fcp.asana: Provisioning Automation
description:
## Goal
Automate provisioning and configuration with minimal human steps.

This bead owns:
- auth setup (OAuth / API keys / webhook secrets) via `CredentialObject`/`CredentialId` (egress proxy injection preferred)
- endpoint configuration
- `fcp doctor` readiness checks
- deterministic, mockable provisioning flows

## FCP2 requirements
- Secrets never touch disk.
- Provisioning is deterministic and testable.
- Error messages are actionable and do not leak secrets/PII.

## Acceptance Criteria
- No real external calls in unit tests.
- Provisioning emits structured logs per `flywheel_connectors-1n78.35`.

title: TEST: fcp.asana Unit/Integration Tests (mock-only)
description:
## Goal
Mock-only unit/integration tests for this connector.

## Required coverage
- schema validation (inputs + outputs)
- error taxonomy mapping (retry semantics)
- pagination and bounds
- rate limit behavior
- redaction (no token/secret/PII leakage)
- idempotency + receipts for Dangerous operations

## Logging
All tests emit structured JSON logs per `flywheel_connectors-1n78.35`.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Deterministic tests; no live external calls.
- Includes adversarial cases (timeouts, malformed responses, partial failures).

title: E2E: fcp.asana Connector Compliance Run
description:
## Goal
Run the shared connector compliance runner and capture an evidence bundle.

## Must validate
- handshake + introspection correctness
- default deny (no CapabilityToken → deny + DecisionReceipt)

## Acceptance Criteria

title: FCP Connector Portfolio: Strategic Prioritization Framework
description:
# FCP Connector Portfolio: Strategic Prioritization Framework

## Goal
Define and maintain a rigorous prioritization framework for the connector portfolio (value, risk, effort, dependencies) so roadmap decisions are coherent, explainable, and user-focused.

## Executive Summary

This document captures the strategic thinking, prioritization rationale, and implementation roadmap for the Flywheel Connector Platform (FCP) connector portfolio. The goal is to maximize agent autonomy and capability while building a sustainable, high-quality connector ecosystem.

---

## Strategic Vision

### The Flywheel Effect
Connectors create a flywheel of value:
1. **More connectors** → Agents can do more things
2. **More capable agents** → More users adopt the platform
3. **More users** → More demand for connectors
4. **More demand** → Justification for building more connectors

### Design Principles
- **Quality over quantity**: Each connector should be production-ready, not a proof-of-concept
- **Ecosystem coherence**: Connectors should work together, enabling cross-service workflows
- **Security by default**: Default-deny, capability-based permissions throughout
- **Future-proof**: FCP2 spec compliance ensures consistency and upgradeability

---

## Prioritization Framework

### Value Assessment Model
Each connector is scored on five dimensions:

| Dimension | Weight | Meaning |
|-----------|--------|---------|
| **User Reach** | 25% | How many users need this service |
| **Agent Autonomy** | 25% | How much more can agents do with this |
| **Flywheel Synergy** | 20% | Integration potential with other connectors |
| **Strategic Position** | 15% | Competitive differentiation |
| **Implementation Cost** | 15% | Effort vs. payoff ratio |

### Tier Definitions

#### Tier 1: Critical Infrastructure (Score 93-100)
**Build immediately. Foundation for everything else.**

These connectors either:
- Enable the core agent workflow loop
- Provide capabilities no other connector can substitute
- Have massive user reach (>50% of target users)

Connectors:
- `fcp.twitter` (98) — Real-time social layer, high visibility
- `fcp.linear` (97) — Modern issue tracking, Beads sync
- `fcp.stripe` (96) — Payments/billing, revenue operations
- `fcp.youtube` (95) — Video/transcript access, research
- `fcp.browser` (95) — Universal fallback, any website
- `fcp.plaid` (94) — Banking/financial data
- `fcp.anthropic` (94) — Core AI provider
- `fcp.openai` (94) — Broadest AI capabilities
- `fcp.google-ai` (94) — Massive context, multimodal
- `fcp.vectordb` (93) — Memory/search infrastructure

#### Tier 2: High-Value Productivity (Score 83-92)
**Build in phase 2. Major capability expansion.**

These connectors:
- Serve large user segments
- Enable important workflow categories
- Have strong synergies with Tier 1

Connectors:
- `fcp.microsoft365` (91) — Enterprise productivity suite
- `fcp.jira` (89) — Enterprise issue tracking
- `fcp.twilio` (88) — Communications infrastructure
- `fcp.hubspot` (87) — CRM/marketing automation
- `fcp.airtable` (86) — No-code database
- `fcp.figma` (85) — Design collaboration
- `fcp.sentry` (85) — Error tracking/debugging
- `fcp.datadog` (84) — Observability platform
- `fcp.grafana` (83) — Open-source observability

#### Tier 3: Specialized Value (Score 70-82)
**Build in phase 3. Domain-specific capabilities.**

These connectors:
- Serve specific user segments very well
- Enable specialized workflows
- May be safety-critical (credentials, infrastructure)

Connectors:
- `fcp.kubernetes` (82) — Container orchestration
- `fcp.s3` (81) — Object storage
- `fcp.terraform` (80) — Infrastructure as code
- `fcp.1password` (79) — Credential management
- `fcp.arxiv` (78) — Research papers
- `fcp.zendesk` (77) — Customer support
- `fcp.semanticscholar` (77) — Citation analysis
- `fcp.annas-archive` (76) — Book/document search
- `fcp.reddit` (76) — Community discussions
- `fcp.docusign` (75) — E-signatures
- `fcp.homeassistant` (74) — Home automation
- `fcp.spotify` (72) — Music/podcast

#### Meta-Connectors: Force Multipliers
**Build throughout. Infrastructure for the infrastructure.**

These aren't service connectors but platform capabilities:
- `fcp.webhook-receiver` (88) — Inbound event gateway
- `fcp.cron` (86) — Scheduled task runner
- `fcp.mcp-bridge` — MCP server passthrough

---

## Flywheel Ecosystem Synergies

### Synergy Map

```
                    Agent Mail (coordination hub)
                           ↑
         ┌─────────────────┼─────────────────┐
         ↓                 ↓                 ↓
    AI Providers     Data Sources      Communication
    (Anthropic,      (GitHub,          (Slack, Twilio,
     OpenAI,          Linear,           Discord,
     Google AI)       Stripe)           Email)
         ↓                 ↓                 ↓
         └─────────────────┼─────────────────┘
                           ↓
    ┌──────────────────────┼──────────────────────┐
    ↓                      ↓                      ↓
 Vector DB            CASS/CM                   BV
 (memory)          (search/memory)       (task tracking)
```

### Key Integration Patterns

#### 1. Development Workflow
```
GitHub PR → Linear issue → Agent investigates →
  → Sentry errors + Datadog metrics →
  → Agent proposes fix → PR merged → Linear updated
```

#### 2. Customer Success Workflow
```
Zendesk ticket → Agent analyzes →
  → Searches knowledge base → Drafts response →
  → If complex: creates Linear issue →
  → Updates HubSpot contact record
```

#### 3. Revenue Operations Workflow
```
Stripe payment event → Agent correlates →
  → Updates HubSpot deal → Sends Twilio notification →
  → If failed: creates Zendesk ticket →
  → Generates report in Airtable
```

#### 4. Research Workflow
```
User question → Agent searches ArXiv + Semantic Scholar →
  → Downloads papers → AI summarizes →
  → Stores in Vector DB → Returns synthesis
```

---

## Implementation Roadmap

### Phase 1: Foundation (Weeks 1-4)
**Focus: Core agent capabilities**

- AI Providers: Anthropic, OpenAI, Google AI
- Meta: Webhook Receiver, Cron
- Critical: Twitter, Linear, GitHub
- Storage: Vector DB, S3

### Phase 2: Productivity (Weeks 5-8)
**Focus: Business workflows**

- Enterprise: Microsoft 365, Jira
- Communication: Twilio, Slack
- CRM: HubSpot
- Observability: Sentry, Datadog, Grafana
- No-code: Airtable
- Design: Figma
- Payments: Stripe, Plaid

### Phase 3: Specialization (Weeks 9-12)
**Focus: Domain expertise**

- Infrastructure: Kubernetes, Terraform
- Research: ArXiv, Semantic Scholar, Anna's Archive
- Support: Zendesk
- Legal: DocuSign
- Security: 1Password

### Phase 4: Expansion (Weeks 13+)
**Focus: Long-tail value**

- Social: Reddit
- Media: Spotify, YouTube
- Home: Home Assistant
- Additional based on demand

---

## Quality Standards

### Every Connector Must:
1. **Pass FCP2 compliance runner** — Static and dynamic checks
2. **Have no real API calls in tests** — Mock-only unit tests
3. **Implement proper zones** — Capability-based security
4. **Support audit logging** — All operations tracked
5. **Handle rate limits** — Respect service quotas
6. **Document synergies** — Integration patterns explicit

### Bead Standards
Each connector bead must include:
- Strategic value score with justification
- Concrete agent use cases (not abstract)
- Flywheel synergies with specific connectors
- Zone architecture recommendations
- Capability model (read/write/admin)
- Representative operations with examples
- Testing approach
- Acceptance criteria

---

## Risk Considerations

### API Stability
- Services may change APIs
- Version pinning where possible
- Deprecation monitoring needed

### Rate Limits
- Different per service
- Budget enforcement at zone level
- Queue management for bursts

### Security
- Credentials never written to disk
- 1Password as credential source
- Audit trails mandatory

### Cost
- Some APIs charge per call
- AI providers charge per token
- Budget controls essential

---

## Success Metrics

### Coverage Metrics
- % of target workflows enabled
- # of connectors at each tier
- Cross-connector workflow coverage

### Quality Metrics
- FCP2 compliance rate
- Test coverage per connector
- API error rates

### Usage Metrics
- Operations per connector
- Workflow completion rates
- User satisfaction scores

---

## Appendix: Connector Index by Category

### AI Providers
- fcp.anthropic, fcp.openai, fcp.google-ai

### Communication
- fcp.slack, fcp.discord, fcp.telegram, fcp.twilio

### Development
- fcp.github, fcp.linear, fcp.jira

### Observability
- fcp.sentry, fcp.datadog, fcp.grafana

### Productivity
- fcp.microsoft365, fcp.notion, fcp.airtable

### CRM/Sales
- fcp.hubspot, fcp.stripe

### Financial
- fcp.plaid, fcp.stripe

### Research
- fcp.arxiv, fcp.semanticscholar, fcp.annas-archive

### Infrastructure
- fcp.kubernetes, fcp.terraform, fcp.s3

### Social
- fcp.twitter, fcp.reddit, fcp.youtube

### Support
- fcp.zendesk, fcp.intercom

### Security
- fcp.1password, fcp.bitwarden

### Design
- fcp.figma

### Legal
- fcp.docusign, fcp.pandadoc

### Personal
- fcp.spotify, fcp.homeassistant

### Meta-Connectors
- fcp.webhook-receiver, fcp.cron, fcp.browser

## Success Criteria
- A stable scoring model exists (value, risk, effort, dependencies) and is applied consistently across the connector list.
- Tiering/prioritization outputs are actionable: they produce concrete connector epic work with dependencies that align to the FCP2 platform build order.
- The framework can be updated incrementally without losing rationale (future maintainers can understand why rankings changed).
close_reason: Framework complete: scoring model (5 dimensions with weights), tier definitions (93-100, 83-92, 70-82), flywheel synergies map, and 4-phase implementation roadmap all documented in bead description. Framework is stable and can be updated incrementally.

title: fcp.homeassistant: Event subscription and real-time updates
description:
# fcp.homeassistant: Event subscription and real-time updates (FCP2)

## Goal
Provide streaming access to Home Assistant’s event bus via WebSocket:
- state_changed
- call_service
- custom events

## Scope
- Establish websocket session and authenticate.
- Subscribe to events with filters (domain/entity allowlists).
- Deliver events as FCP2 event envelopes with:
  - stable event IDs
  - correlation IDs

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `ha.events.subscribe` (sensitive)

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- NetworkConstraints pinned (WS + HTTPS to HA host only).
- Streaming must be bounded/backpressured:
  - cap queue depth
  - drop/deny with explicit reason codes when overloaded
- Taint:
  - event payloads are tainted external input

## Deliverables
- Operation schema:
  - `ha.events.subscribe`
- Event envelope types:
  - `ha.event.state_changed`
  - `ha.event.call_service`

## Test strategy (MUST)
- Mock-only tests for:
  - reconnect + resubscribe
  - bounds/backpressure behavior
  - taint propagation

## Acceptance criteria
- Event streaming is reliable under reconnects and never causes unbounded memory growth.

title: TEST: Offline Capability Unit Tests (Availability Tracking, Pre-staging, Coverage Metrics)
description:
# TEST: Offline Capability Unit Tests

## Goal
Comprehensive unit tests for offline capability tracking from V2 spec section 21.

## Test Categories

### OfflineAccess Tests
- can_access() returns true when local_symbols >= k
- can_access() returns false when local_symbols < k
- coverage() calculates correct ratio (local_symbols / k)
- Edge cases: k=0, local_symbols=0, overflow

### OfflineCapability Tests
- Accessible map tracks multiple objects correctly
- Object removal updates capability state
- Query by zone returns correct subset
- Memory efficient for large object counts

### Pre-staging Tests
- Access pattern tracking updates correctly
- Frequent objects prioritized for pre-staging
- Pre-staging respects device storage limits
- Stale access patterns decay appropriately
- Pre-staging triggers before predicted access

### Integration with Stores
- Symbol store updates reflect in OfflineAccess
- Symbol eviction updates can_access() correctly
- Repair loop improves coverage metrics

## Golden Vectors
- Location: tests/golden/offline_capability/
- Include: OfflineAccess serialization, coverage calculations

## Logging Requirements (per 1n78.35)
All tests emit structured JSON:
{
  "timestamp": "RFC3339",
  "test": "can_access_sufficient_symbols",
  "object_id": "...",
  "local_symbols": 60,
  "k": 50,
  "expected_can_access": true,
  "result": "pass|fail"
}

## Fuzz Targets
- OfflineAccess from arbitrary symbol counts
- Pre-staging priority calculation

## Acceptance Criteria
- All can_access/coverage calculations correct
- Pre-staging improves offline availability
- Integration with stores is consistent
close_reason: 26 comprehensive unit tests covering all requirements: OfflineAccess, OfflineCapability, AccessPatternTracker with edge cases

title: fcp.reddit: User Posting and Commenting
description:
# fcp.reddit: User Posting and Commenting (FCP2)

## Goal
Enable controlled Reddit participation:
- submit posts
- submit comments
- edit/delete own content

These are real-world side effects and must be tightly capability scoped.

## Scope
- Submit post to a subreddit (text/link).
- Submit comment.
- Edit content.
- Delete content.

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `reddit.post.write` (dangerous)
- `reddit.comment.write` (dangerous)
- `reddit.content.edit` (dangerous)

Policy guidance:
- Posting should often require ApprovalToken depending on zone policy.

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- NetworkConstraints pinned.
- Content safety:
  - outbound content must be treated as a “publication” action
  - receipts + audit events include subreddit + post/comment id
  - never log post bodies

## Deliverables
- Operation schemas:
  - `reddit.post.submit`
  - `reddit.comment.submit`
  - `reddit.content.edit`
  - `reddit.content.delete`

## Test strategy (MUST)
- Mock-only tests for:
  - request formation
  - approval gating
  - audit/receipt emission
  - error mapping (subreddit rules, forbidden)

## Acceptance criteria
- Write operations are mechanically authorized, explainable, and auditable.

title: TEST: Computation Migration Unit Tests (Checkpoint, Lease Transfer, Resume)
description:
# TEST: Computation Migration Unit Tests

## Goal
Comprehensive unit and integration tests for computation migration from V2 spec section 16.

## Test Categories

### Checkpoint Tests
- Checkpoint creation serializes all computation state
- Checkpoint is content-addressed ObjectId
- Checkpoint can be reconstructed from symbols
- Large checkpoint is chunked correctly

### Lease Transfer Tests
- Execution lease transfers atomically during migration
- Duplicate execution prevented during migration window
- Lease transfer fails gracefully on network partition
- Fencing token is updated after transfer

### Resume Tests
- Target device reconstructs checkpoint correctly
- Computation resumes from checkpoint progress
- State transitions: Suspended -> Running are audited
- Failed resume transitions to Failed state correctly

### Adversarial Tests
- Migration during network partition (split brain prevention)
- Concurrent migrations of same computation (conflict resolution)
- Checkpoint corruption detection
- Lease expiry during migration

## Golden Vectors
- Location: tests/golden/computation_migration/
- Include: checkpoint serialization, lease transfer messages, resume protocol

## Logging Requirements (per 1n78.35)
All tests emit structured JSON:
{
  "timestamp": "RFC3339",
  "test": "checkpoint_creation",
  "computation_id": "...",
  "checkpoint_size": 1234,
  "result": "pass|fail",
  "error": "optional error message"
}

## Fuzz Targets
- Checkpoint deserialization (arbitrary bytes)
- Migration request parsing
- Lease transfer message validation

## Acceptance Criteria
- All checkpoint creation/restoration tests pass
- Lease transfer is atomic (no duplicate execution)
- Adversarial scenarios handled correctly

title: fcp.airtable: Attachment upload and download handling
description:
# fcp.airtable: Attachment Upload and Download Handling

## Goal
Handle Airtable attachments safely under strict sandboxing.

## Zone model (mechanical)

<!-- fcp2-single-zone-note -->
**FCP2 single-zone binding note:** A connector instance binds to exactly one `ZoneId` for its entire lifetime.
The connector MUST NOT multiplex multiple zones internally.

Recommended deployment pattern: run separate connector instances in separate zones with different capability grants/policies.

## Scope
Operations (representative):
- `airtable.attachments.upload`
- `airtable.attachments.get` (fetch attachment metadata/URL)
- optional: `airtable.attachments.download` (if we choose to implement actual download)

## Key requirements
- Capability gated:
  - read vs write separated
- NetworkConstraints:
  - Airtable API host(s) allowed
  - attachment download hosts must be explicitly enumerated/pinned
  - validate URLs are HTTPS and match allowlist
- Data handling:
  - attachments move as **ObjectId references** (no local disk persistence)
  - enforce size limits and streaming bounds
- Logging:
  - never log attachment contents
  - URLs may contain opaque tokens; treat as sensitive

## Tests
- Allow/deny matrix for attachment URL hosts.
- Size limit and timeout tests.
- Redaction tests.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Attachment flows are safe-by-default and deterministic.
- Non-allowed hosts are blocked by Network Guard.

title: fcp.airtable: Full CRUD operations on records
description:
# fcp.airtable: Full CRUD Operations on Records

## Goal
Implement record CRUD with batching, pagination, and strict safety controls.

## External surface (NetworkConstraints)
Default deny.
- Network egress MUST be restricted per-operation via manifest `NetworkConstraints`.
- Allow only the configured service host(s); HTTPS-only where applicable; deny redirects by default.
- Bound timeouts + response sizes; treat all remote responses as untrusted input; never leak secrets/PII in logs or errors.

## Zone model (mechanical)

<!-- fcp2-single-zone-note -->
**FCP2 single-zone binding note:** A connector instance binds to exactly one `ZoneId` for its entire lifetime.
The connector MUST NOT multiplex multiple zones internally.

Recommended deployment pattern: run separate connector instances in separate zones with different capability grants/policies.

## Scope
Operations (representative):
- `airtable.records.list` (pagination, filter/sort)
- `airtable.records.get`
- `airtable.records.create` / `airtable.records.create_batch`
- `airtable.records.update` / `airtable.records.update_batch`
- `airtable.records.upsert`
- `airtable.records.delete` / `airtable.records.delete_batch` (Dangerous)

## Key requirements
- Capability gated:
  - read vs write vs delete are separate capabilities
- Rate limiting and backpressure are mechanical.
- Pagination:
  - support continuation tokens
  - bound page sizes
- Batch operations:
  - handle partial failures deterministically
  - stable error mapping per record
- Idempotency / retries:
  - upsert is preferred for retry-safe workflows
  - deletes and schema writes must be treated as Dangerous (policy + receipts)

## Tests
- Mock-only tests cover:
  - pagination edge cases
  - batch partial failure semantics
  - upsert conflict handling
  - redaction: never log record bodies by default

## Acceptance Criteria
- CRUD operations behave deterministically under retries.
- Dangerous operations are properly gated and audited.

title: TEST: Integration Scenarios (Partition Recovery, Node Failure, Concurrent Conflicts)
description:
# TEST: Integration Scenarios (Partition Recovery, Node Failure, Concurrent Conflicts)

## Goal
Define explicit integration test scenarios that verify the system behaves correctly under adverse conditions.

## Why This Matters
Unit tests and E2E "happy path" tests are not sufficient. The system must be tested under realistic failure modes.

## Scenario Categories

### Network Partition Recovery
- [ ] **Partition-Heal**: 3-node mesh, partition node C from A+B for 60s, heal, verify:
  - All nodes converge on same AuditHead
  - No duplicate operations executed
  - Gossip reconciliation completes
- [ ] **Split-Brain Prevention**: Both partitions attempt quorum ops, only one succeeds
- [ ] **Stale Node Rejoins**: Node offline for longer than revocation freshness window must catch up before accepting operations

### Node Failure and Recovery
- [ ] **Graceful Shutdown**: Node announces shutdown, leases transferred, no operation loss
- [ ] **Crash Recovery**: Node killed mid-operation, restart, verify:
  - Incomplete OperationIntent is detected
  - No duplicate side effects
  - Lease is released after timeout
- [ ] **Multi-Node Failure**: Lose f nodes (within quorum tolerance), operations continue
- [ ] **Quorum Loss**: Lose more than f nodes, operations fail closed with clear error

### Concurrent Operation Conflicts
- [ ] **Lease Contention**: Two nodes attempt same operation lease simultaneously
  - Only one succeeds
  - Loser gets FCP-4320 (LeaseConflict)
  - Winner produces receipt
- [ ] **State Fork Detection**: Two nodes write connector state without proper lease
  - Fork is detected
  - Audit event emitted
  - Operations paused pending resolution
- [ ] **Revocation Race**: Token used while revocation propagating
  - Operation allowed if checkpoint valid at token issuance time
  - Subsequent operations rejected

### Revocation Propagation
- [ ] **Issuer Key Revocation**: Revoke issuer key, verify:
  - Existing tokens from that issuer rejected within freshness window
  - New tokens cannot be issued
  - Audit trail shows revocation
- [ ] **Capability Revocation**: Revoke capability object, verify:
  - Tokens referencing revoked grant rejected
  - DecisionReceipt cites revocation as reason
- [ ] **Node Removal**: Remove node, verify:
  - Zone keys rotated
  - Removed node cannot issue tokens
  - Removed node cannot participate in gossip

### Zone Key Rotation Under Load
- [ ] **Hot Rotation**: Rotate zone key while operations in flight
  - In-flight operations complete with old key
  - New operations use new key
  - No operation loss
- [ ] **Multi-Zone Rotation**: Rotate keys in multiple zones simultaneously
  - Cross-zone operations handle transition correctly

### Symbol Availability and Repair
- [ ] **Degraded Availability**: Reduce symbol availability below threshold
  - Operations that need those symbols report partial availability
  - Repair loop activates and improves coverage
- [ ] **Single-Source Prevention**: Block symbols from all but one source
  - Diversity enforcement triggers
  - Operations wait for diverse sources

## Test Infrastructure Requirements
- Deterministic clock control
- Network fault injection (partitions, latency, packet loss)
- Node lifecycle control (start, stop, crash, restart)
- Structured log collection across all nodes

## Logging Requirements
Each scenario produces:
```json
{
  "scenario": "partition-heal",
  "phase": "partition | heal | verify",
  "nodes": ["A", "B", "C"],
  "timestamp": "...",
  "assertion": "audit_heads_equal",
  "result": "pass|fail",
  "evidence": {...}
}
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- All scenarios have automated tests
- Tests run in CI with reasonable duration (<5min per scenario)
- Failures produce actionable logs

title: [FCP2] Rate Limiting: ThrottleViolation, Backpressure Signals, Quota Enforcement
description:
# [FCP2] Rate Limiting: ThrottleViolation, Backpressure Signals, Quota Enforcement

## Goal
Implement rate limiting at multiple layers: per-connector, per-operation, per-zone, and mesh-wide.

## Why This Matters
Without rate limiting:
- A runaway connector can exhaust external API quotas
- A compromised node can DoS the mesh
- Resource exhaustion becomes undetectable until failure

## Rate Limit Layers

### Layer 1: Connector Manifest Limits
Declared in connector manifest:
```toml
[rate_limits]
requests_per_minute = 60
requests_per_hour = 1000
concurrent_operations = 5
```

### Layer 2: Zone Policy Limits
```
ZonePolicy.rate_limits {
  per_connector_rpm: u32,
  per_zone_rpm: u32,
  burst_allowance: f32,  // multiplier for burst
}
```

### Layer 3: Capability Limits
Capabilities can include rate constraints:
```
CapabilityGrant.constraints.rate_limit {
  max_per_minute: 10,
  max_concurrent: 2,
}
```

### Layer 4: MeshNode Admission Control
Global limits per peer node (covered in admission control bead).

## ThrottleViolation Object
When rate limit is exceeded:
```
ThrottleViolation {
  violation_id: ObjectId,
  timestamp: u64,
  zone_id: ZoneId,
  connector_id: Option<ConnectorId>,
  operation_id: Option<SchemaId>,
  limit_type: LimitType,  // RPM, Concurrent, Burst, Quota
  limit_value: u32,
  current_value: u32,
  retry_after_ms: u64,
}
```

ThrottleViolation is:
- Recorded in audit chain
- Returned in InvokeResponse error
- Triggers backpressure signals

## Backpressure Protocol
When approaching limits:
1. **Warning Zone (80%)**: Emit metric, log warning
2. **Soft Limit (95%)**: Return `retry_after_ms` in responses
3. **Hard Limit (100%)**: Reject with FCP-4290 (RateLimited)

For streaming operations:
- Flow control via FCPC backpressure frames
- Connector can request pause/resume

## Token Bucket Implementation
Use token bucket algorithm with:
- `capacity`: max burst size
- `refill_rate`: tokens per second
- `current_tokens`: available tokens

Tokens are consumed per-operation based on:
- Base cost (1 token)
- Size cost (for data transfer)
- Compute cost (for expensive operations)

## Tests
- Unit tests: token bucket refill and consumption
- Property tests: rate limit never exceeds declared max
- Integration tests: concurrent requests properly limited
- Adversarial tests: burst exhaustion followed by gradual recovery
- E2E tests: ThrottleViolation appears in audit chain

## Acceptance Criteria
- Rate limits are enforced at all layers
- ThrottleViolation objects are recorded for audit
- Backpressure signals enable graceful degradation
notes:
Progress: implemented core rate-limit artifacts + enforcement primitives.

- fcp-core: added ThrottleViolation (+ ThrottleViolationInput), LimitType, BackpressureLevel/Signal; extended FcpError::RateLimited to carry optional boxed ThrottleViolation and include it in structured error details.
- fcp-ratelimit: added FCP glue (config_from_core, enforce() -> EnforcementOutcome w/ backpressure + violation); token cost model (base + bytes ceil-div + compute); ConcurrencyLimiter with try_acquire_or_violation(); RateLimiter::try_acquire_n and atomic multi-permit TokenBucket consumption.
- Tests: new unit tests for backpressure thresholds, violation propagation into FcpErrorResponse.details, token cost, concurrency limiter, and atomic multi-permit consumption.
- Quality gates: cargo fmt/check/clippy/test all green.

Remaining (blocked by other beads): integrate with policy engine + audit chain storage, and mesh-wide admission control + E2E scenarios.

title: fcp.hubspot: Pipeline analytics and reporting
description:
# fcp.hubspot: Pipeline analytics and reporting (FCP2)

## Goal
Expose HubSpot reporting surfaces needed for:
- pipeline health dashboards
- stage conversion analysis
- activity/velocity metrics

This is primarily read-only but may include access to sensitive business data.

## Scope
### Read
- Retrieve pipeline definitions (stages, probabilities).
- Fetch metrics:
  - counts by stage
  - conversion rates
  - time-in-stage
  - win/loss trends
- Support time window filters and stable pagination.

### Output shaping
- Prefer aggregate metrics and IDs over raw deal details where possible.

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `hubspot.analytics.read`
- `hubspot.pipelines.read`

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- NetworkConstraints pinned.
- Avoid logging raw deal contents.

## Deliverables
- Operation schemas:
  - `hubspot.pipeline.list`
  - `hubspot.pipeline.metrics`
  - `hubspot.pipeline.stage_metrics`
- Consistent metric naming + units.

## Test strategy (MUST)
- Mock-only tests for:
  - time window handling
  - pagination
  - error mapping

## Acceptance criteria
- Agents can answer “how is the pipeline doing?” without exposing raw CRM PII in logs.

title: fcp.arxiv: Category and topic classification system
description:
# fcp.arxiv: Category and topic classification system (FCP2)

## Goal
Provide structured topic/category classification to support:
- monitors by topic
- clustering and trend analysis
- downstream indexing (CASS/CM)

## External surface (NetworkConstraints)
Default deny.
- Network egress MUST be restricted per-operation via manifest `NetworkConstraints`.
- Allow only the configured service host(s); HTTPS-only where applicable; deny redirects by default.
- Bound timeouts + response sizes; treat all remote responses as untrusted input; never leak secrets/PII in logs or errors.

## Scope
- List arXiv categories and metadata.
- Extract topics/keywords from:
  - title + abstract (minimum)
  - optional full text (when enabled)
- Provide a deterministic `TopicProfile` object:
  - categories
  - keywords
  - confidence

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `arxiv.categories.read`
- `arxiv.topics.extract`

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- If full text is used, it must come from bounded extraction (`flywheel_connectors-ehu`).
- Deterministic output (no hidden model randomness inside connector unless explicitly configured).

## Deliverables
- Operation schemas:
  - `arxiv.categories.list`
  - `arxiv.paper.topics.extract`
- Canonical output type:
  - `TopicProfile`

## Test strategy (MUST)
- Golden fixtures for topic extraction.
- Verify deterministic ordering and bounds.

## Acceptance criteria
- Topic extraction is deterministic, bounded, and useful for monitoring/indexing.

title: fcp.kubernetes connector - Container orchestration integration
description:
# fcp.kubernetes - Container Orchestration Integration Connector (FCP2)

## Goal
Deliver the FCP2 Kubernetes connector epic plan for safe cluster introspection and controlled mutations under strict NetworkConstraints, credential handling, and policy-gated dangerous operations.

## Zone model (mechanical)

<!-- fcp2-single-zone-note -->
**FCP2 single-zone binding note:** A connector instance binds to exactly one `ZoneId` for its entire lifetime.
The connector MUST NOT multiplex multiple zones internally.

Recommended deployment pattern: run separate connector instances in separate zones with different capability grants/policies.

## Strategic Context

### Value Assessment
**Strategic Value Score: 82/100** — Important Tier 3 connector (Infrastructure family).

**Why Critical**: Kubernetes is the **dominant container orchestration platform**, running production workloads at most tech companies. Enables agents to manage deployments, investigate pod issues, scale services, and automate DevOps workflows. Essential for cloud-native operations.

### Priority Matrix Position
- **Category**: Specialized Investment (Infrastructure + High Complexity)
- **Build Phase**: Phase 3 Enterprise (weeks 9-12)

---

## Agent Capabilities (Concrete Use Cases)

### Workload Management
- Deploy and update applications
- Scale deployments
- Rollback deployments
- Restart pods

### Investigation
- Pod logs access
- Event monitoring
- Resource status checks
- Container exec (with restrictions)

### Configuration
- ConfigMap management
- Secret access (controlled)
- Service and ingress inspection
- Namespace operations

### Examples of Agent Workflows
```
"What pods are crashing in production?"
"Scale the API deployment to 5 replicas"
"Show logs from the failing pod"
"Rollback the frontend to previous version"
"What's using the most memory?"
"Check events for this deployment"
"Apply this manifest to staging"
```

---

## Flywheel Ecosystem Synergies

### Grafana/Datadog Integration
**Full observability stack:**
- K8s metrics via Prometheus
- Pod logs via Loki/Datadog
- Container traces
- Agent correlates infrastructure state with metrics

### Sentry Integration
- Link crashes to pod restarts
- Correlate errors with deployments
- Resource exhaustion → error patterns

### GitHub Integration
**GitOps workflows:**
- Git changes → K8s manifests
- ArgoCD/Flux integration
- Deployment tracking

### Terraform Integration
- Cluster infrastructure via Terraform
- Workloads via Kubernetes connector
- Full infrastructure automation

### Agent Mail Integration
- Incident alerts → agent investigation
- Deployment coordination
- On-call handoff workflows

---

## Technical Implementation Notes

### API Surface
- **Core API** — Pods, Services, ConfigMaps, Secrets
- **Apps API** — Deployments, StatefulSets, DaemonSets
- **Batch API** — Jobs, CronJobs
- **Networking API** — Ingress, NetworkPolicies

### Authentication Modes
| Mode | Use Case |
|------|----------|
| Kubeconfig | Local/development |
| ServiceAccount | In-cluster |
| OIDC | Enterprise SSO |
| Cloud Provider | EKS/GKE/AKS auth |

### Recommended Crates
- `kube` — Kubernetes client for Rust
- `k8s-openapi` — Type-safe K8s API bindings
- `tokio` — Async runtime

### Resource Hierarchy
```
Namespace
├── Deployment/StatefulSet/DaemonSet
│   └── ReplicaSet
│       └── Pod
│           └── Container
├── Service
├── ConfigMap
├── Secret
└── Ingress
```

---

## Zone Architecture

### Recommended Zones
| Zone | Description | Capabilities |
|------|-------------|--------------|
| `z:infra:k8s:full` | Full cluster access | All operations |
| `z:infra:k8s:readonly` | Read-only | Queries and logs |
| `z:infra:k8s:namespace:<name>` | Namespace-scoped | Single namespace |
| `z:infra:k8s:deploy` | Deployment only | Scale, rollback |

### Safety Tiers
- **Read**: Logs, status, events — low risk
- **Deploy**: Scale, rollback — moderate risk
- **Write**: Apply manifests — high risk
- **Exec**: Container access — very high risk

---

## Manifest Archetypes (Closed Set)
- `operational` — API operations
- `streaming` — Watch events, log streaming

---

## External Surface

### NetworkConstraints
Varies by deployment:
- In-cluster: `kubernetes.default.svc:443`
- Cloud: EKS/GKE/AKS API endpoints
- Self-hosted: configured API server

### Credential Injection
- Kubeconfig via file reference
- ServiceAccount token via mounted secret
- Cloud credentials via `CredentialId`
- Never write credentials to disk

---

## Capability Model

### Read Operations
- `k8s.pods.read` — List/get pods
- `k8s.pods.logs` — Stream logs
- `k8s.deployments.read` — Deployment status
- `k8s.events.read` — Cluster events
- `k8s.services.read` — Service info
- `k8s.configmaps.read` — Config data
- `k8s.secrets.read` — Secret metadata (not values by default)

### Write Operations
- `k8s.deployments.scale` — Scale replicas
- `k8s.deployments.rollback` — Rollback version
- `k8s.pods.delete` — Restart pods
- `k8s.configmaps.write` — Update configs

### Administrative (Dangerous)
- `k8s.manifests.apply` — Apply arbitrary YAML
- `k8s.pods.exec` — Execute in container
- `k8s.secrets.values` — Read secret values
- `k8s.namespaces.delete` — Delete namespace

---

## Operations (Representative)

### List Pods
```rust
let pods: Api<Pod> = Api::namespaced(client, "production");
let list = pods.list(&ListParams::default()).await?;
```

### Get Pod Logs
```rust
let pods: Api<Pod> = Api::namespaced(client, "production");
let logs = pods.logs("api-pod-abc123", &LogParams {
    container: Some("api".into()),
    tail_lines: Some(100),
    ..Default::default()
}).await?;
```

### Scale Deployment
```rust
let deployments: Api<Deployment> = Api::namespaced(client, "production");
let patch = json!({
    "spec": {
        "replicas": 5
    }
});
deployments.patch_scale("api", &PatchParams::default(), &Patch::Merge(&patch)).await?;
```

### Watch Events
```rust
let events: Api<Event> = Api::all(client);
let watcher = watcher(events, Config::default());
// Stream events as they occur
```

---

## Safety Considerations

### Blast Radius Control
- Prefer namespace-scoped access
- Avoid cluster-admin by default
- Rate limit write operations

### Sensitive Operations
| Operation | Risk | Mitigation |
|-----------|------|------------|
| `exec` | Very High | Disabled by default, audit all uses |
| `delete namespace` | High | Require explicit confirmation |
| `apply manifest` | Medium | Validate against schema |
| `read secrets` | Medium | Mask values, log access |

### Audit Requirements
- All K8s API calls logged
- Secret access specially flagged
- exec sessions recorded

---

## Tests

### Unit Tests (Mock-Only)
- API request construction
- Resource type handling
- Watch event parsing
- Log streaming

### Integration Tests
- k3s or kind for local cluster simulation
- Namespace isolation scenarios
- RBAC enforcement testing

### E2E Compliance
- Validates NetworkConstraints
- RBAC boundaries respected
- Audit logging for all operations

---

## Acceptance Criteria
- Passes connector compliance runner (static + dynamic)
- No real cluster calls in unit tests
- Pod listing and logs functional
- Deployment scale/rollback works
- Event watching operational
- Namespace isolation enforced
- Proper RBAC integration

## Success Criteria
- Connector epic is fully decomposed into implementable beads (manifest/cap map, provisioning, operations, tests, E2E compliance).
- All child beads are implemented and closed, and the connector passes the mechanical compliance runner + its E2E scenarios with structured JSON logs.
- Mechanical guarantees hold: single-zone binding, default-deny capabilities, and NetworkConstraints enforcement; no secret/PII leakage in logs.

title: fcp.kubernetes: Manifest + Capability Map (FCP2)
description:
# fcp.kubernetes: Manifest + Capability Map (FCP2)

## Goal
Define the Kubernetes connector’s **mechanical manifest contract** under FCP2.

Kubernetes is safety-critical; the manifest must make dangerous operations mechanically obvious.

## Required contents
- Manifest archetypes (closed set):
  - `operational` (CRUD, deploy, config)
  - `streaming` (watch/events/log streams)
- Operation list + schema IDs.
- Capability families + per-operation required caps.
- NetworkConstraints:
  - pin the configured Kubernetes API server host(s)
  - restrict any exec/log streaming endpoints to that host
- Sandbox profile:
  - strict filesystem allowlist
  - kubeconfig handling policy
- State model declaration:
  - watch cursors/resourceVersions (if persisted)

## Acceptance criteria
- Another engineer can implement `--manifest` from this bead alone.

title: fcp.kubernetes: Provisioning Automation (kubeconfig, service accounts, RBAC)
description:
# fcp.kubernetes: Provisioning Automation (kubeconfig, service accounts, RBAC)

## Goal
Automate Kubernetes connector onboarding with minimal human steps while keeping credentials zone-scoped.

- Mockable in CI.

## Goal
Mock-only tests for fcp.kubernetes focusing on request construction, capability gating, and streaming behavior.

title: E2E: Kubernetes Connector Compliance Run
description:

## Goal
Run the shared Mechanical Connector Compliance Runner against fcp.kubernetes.

## Must verify

- NetworkConstraints enforcement (pinned API server host).
- Receipts/audit for write/dangerous ops.
