title: TEST: Connector Performance Benchmark Suite
description:
# TEST: Connector Performance Benchmark Suite (FCP2)


## Goal
Establish a benchmark suite to measure and guard connector performance budgets (latency, memory, allocations) with regression tracking.

## Overview
Performance benchmarks ensuring the platform meets the README/spec targets.

Benchmarks must be:
- repeatable
- machine-readable
- diagnostic (logs + environment metadata)

## Benchmarks (README-aligned)
### `fcp bench connector-activate`
- cold start time (p50/p99)
- warm start time (optional)

### `fcp bench invoke-local`
- end-to-end invoke latency when caller/executor are the same node

### `fcp bench invoke-mesh --path=direct|derp`
- end-to-end invoke latency across the mesh for:
  - direct/LAN
  - DERP

### `fcp bench raptorq --size=1mb`
- encode/decode throughput and wall time
- memory high-water mark if available

### `fcp bench secrets --k=3 --n=5`
- secret reconstruction wall time + overhead

### Microbenches (hot primitives)
- canonical CBOR encode/decode
- ObjectId derivation
- CapabilityToken verify
- FCPS frame parse + session MAC verify

## Output
- JSON results with:
  - benchmark name + parameters
  - p50/p90/p99
  - environment (os/arch/cpu)
  - versions + commit hash
- Regression detection policy:
  - start with “report-only”
  - later enforce thresholds once baselines stabilize

## Logging Requirements
Per `flywheel_connectors-1n78.35`, logs must include:
- bench name/params
- sample counts
- any detected outliers

## Acceptance Criteria
- Suite produces stable JSON shapes suitable for snapshot testing.
- Results are reproducible enough to catch real regressions (not noise).
close_reason:
Completed benchmark suite implementation:

IMPLEMENTED:
- Core benchmark runner with statistical analysis (percentiles, outlier detection)
- CBOR benchmarks: schema-hash, serialize, deserialize (small/medium objects)
- Primitive benchmarks: ObjectId derivation, capability verification, session MAC, FCPS frame parse
- RaptorQ encode/decode benchmarks
- JSON and human-readable output formats
- Environment metadata collection (OS, arch, CPU, git commit, rustc version)
- Target threshold tracking with pass/fail determination

PLACEHOLDERS (awaiting dependencies):
- connector-activate (needs fcp-sdk)
- invoke-local (needs fcp-mesh)
- invoke-mesh (needs fcp-mesh)
- secrets reconstruction (needs fcp-crypto Shamir)

All tests pass. Benchmarks produce stable JSON suitable for regression tracking.

title: STANDARD: Connector Testing Requirements and Quality Gates
description:
# STANDARD: Connector Testing Requirements and Quality Gates

## Goal
Define mandatory connector testing quality gates (mock-only unit tests + E2E compliance runs) so every connector is mechanically verifiable.

## Overview
Defines mandatory testing requirements and quality gates that ALL FCP connectors must pass before release.

This standard is connector-focused and builds on the platform-wide test/logging standard `flywheel_connectors-1n78.35`.

## Recommended Testing Stack (2025-2026)

| Category | Tool | Version | Notes |
|----------|------|---------|-------|
| Unit framework | `cargo test` | built-in | Standard Rust testing |
| Snapshot | `insta` | 1.40+ | JSON + terminal snapshots |
| Property | `proptest` | 0.11+ | Invariant/fuzzy testing |
| Mutation | `cargo-mutants` | 25.1+ | Mutation coverage |
| Fuzzing | `cargo-fuzz` | 0.12+ | Fuzz targets for parsing |
| HTTP mock | `wiremock` | 0.6+ | Async HTTP mocking |
| Assertions | `assert2` | 0.3+ | Better error messages |
| Coverage | `cargo-llvm-cov` | 0.6+ | LLVM-based coverage |
| Security | `cargo-audit` | 0.21+ | Dependency audit |
| Benchmarks | `criterion` | 0.6+ | Statistical benchmarks |

## Unit Test Requirements

### Coverage Thresholds
- Overall: >80% line coverage
- Critical paths: >95% coverage
- Security code: >98% coverage
- **Mutation score**: >70% (cargo-mutants)

### Required Test Categories
- [ ] All connector standard methods (`--manifest`, handshake/describe/introspect/capabilities/configure/invoke/health/shutdown)
- [ ] Configuration validation (valid/invalid)
- [ ] Handshake success/failure scenarios
- [ ] Capability token validation
- [ ] Each operation (success, common errors, edge cases)
- [ ] Rate limit handling
- [ ] Timeout behavior
- [ ] Error recovery
- [ ] **Property tests**: Random inputs for all string/struct parsing

### Mocking Requirements
- NEVER make real API calls in unit tests
- Use wiremock or similar for HTTP mocking
- Mock external service responses
- Test error injection (network, auth, rate limit)

### Property Testing Patterns
```rust
proptest\! {
    #[test]
    fn parse_config_doesnt_panic(input in ".*") {
        // Should never panic, only return Ok/Err
        let _ = ConnectorConfig::parse(&input);
    }
    
    #[test]
    fn roundtrip_serialization(config in arb_connector_config()) {
        let serialized = serde_json::to_string(&config)?;
        let deserialized: ConnectorConfig = serde_json::from_str(&serialized)?;
        prop_assert_eq\!(config, deserialized);
    }
}
```

## Fuzz Testing Requirements (Security-Critical)

### Required Fuzz Targets
Every connector MUST have fuzz targets for:
- [ ] Configuration parsing
- [ ] Protocol message parsing
- [ ] Credential/token handling
- [ ] Event payload parsing

### Fuzz Target Template
```rust
#\![no_main]
use libfuzzer_sys::fuzz_target;

fuzz_target\!(|data: &[u8]| {
    // Should never panic, only return valid error
    let _ = connector::parse_message(data);
});
```

### CI Fuzz Integration
```yaml
- name: Fuzz for 60s per target
  run: cargo +nightly fuzz run --release --sanitizer=address -- -max_total_time=60
```

## Integration Test Requirements
- [ ] Real handshake flow (with test credentials) OR fully deterministic harness
- [ ] Basic operation execution
- [ ] Event subscription lifecycle
- [ ] Reconnection handling

## E2E Test Requirements (Mechanical Compliance)
Every connector MUST pass the platform E2E/compliance harness:
- [ ] Mechanical compliance runner (static + dynamic)
- [ ] Zone binding enforcement
- [ ] Default deny (no cap token → denial + DecisionReceipt)
- [ ] No secret leakage in logs
- [ ] Sandbox/network constraints enforced
- [ ] **Tool descriptor validation** (SEP-1382 compliance)

## Security Testing Requirements

### cargo-audit Gate
```yaml
- name: Security audit
  run: cargo audit --deny warnings --ignore RUSTSEC-XXXX
```

### Secret Leakage Detection
```rust
#[test]
fn no_secrets_in_logs() {
    let logs = capture_connector_logs();
    assert\!(\!logs.contains("api_key="));
    assert\!(\!logs.contains("Authorization:"));
    assert\!(\!logs.contains("Bearer "));
}
```

### Zeroize Verification
```rust
#[test]
fn credentials_are_zeroized_on_drop() {
    let cred = Credential::new("secret");
    let ptr = cred.as_ptr();
    drop(cred);
    // Memory should be zeroed
    unsafe { assert\!(std::slice::from_raw_parts(ptr, 6).iter().all(|&b| b == 0)); }
}
```

## Quality Gates (CI/CD)
1. `cargo check --all-targets` - No errors
2. `cargo clippy --all-targets -- -D warnings` - No warnings
3. `cargo fmt --check` - Properly formatted
4. `cargo test` - All tests pass
5. `cargo test --release` - Release tests pass
6. Coverage threshold met (>80%)
7. `cargo audit --deny warnings` - Security scan clean
8. `cargo mutants --timeout-multiplier=2` - Mutation score >70%
9. Fuzz targets run without crash

## Connector Plan Template
For connector planning/bead structure (manifest/provisioning/tests/e2e), use:
- `flywheel_connectors-lszk.5` — STANDARD: Connector Spec Template (FCP2)

## CRITICAL: Detailed Logging Requirements

### All Tests MUST Include Comprehensive Logging

#### Log Levels by Test Phase
- **Setup**: INFO - test initialization, mock configuration
- **Execution**: DEBUG - every significant action
- **Assertions**: INFO - expected vs actual values
- **Teardown**: DEBUG - cleanup operations
- **Errors**: ERROR with full context

#### Required Log Fields (Structured JSON)
Every log entry MUST include:
- `timestamp` - ISO 8601 with milliseconds
- `test_name` - Full test path (module::test_fn)
- `phase` - setup|execute|assert|teardown
- `correlation_id` - Unique per test run
- `duration_ms` - Time since test start
- `operation` - Current operation being tested

When applicable, also include:
- `connector_id`, `zone_id`, `session_id`
- `decision`, `reason_code`, and evidence object IDs for denials

#### Log Format Example
```json
{
  "timestamp": "2026-01-11T12:00:00.123Z",
  "test_name": "discord::gateway::test_heartbeat_mechanism",
  "phase": "execute",
  "correlation_id": "a1b2c3d4",
  "duration_ms": 45,
  "operation": "send_heartbeat",
  "level": "DEBUG",
  "message": "Sending heartbeat frame",
  "details": {
    "sequence": 42,
    "interval_ms": 41250,
    "last_ack_at": "2026-01-11T11:59:58.500Z"
  }
}
```

#### Test Output Capture
- All tests run with `--nocapture` in CI for full visibility
- Failed tests include complete log history in reports
- Logs retained for 30 days for debugging
- Performance metrics extracted from logs for trending

## Documentation Requirements
- [ ] All public APIs documented
- [ ] AI hints for each operation
- [ ] Configuration schema documented
- [ ] Error codes documented

## Acceptance Criteria
- CI enforces the quality gates.
- The E2E compliance harness rejects non-compliant connectors.
- Mutation testing catches weak test suites.
- Fuzz testing runs on every merge to main.

title: fcp.arxiv: Paper search with semantic and keyword modes
description:
# fcp.arxiv: Paper search with semantic and keyword modes (FCP2)

## Goal
Provide high-quality discovery of arXiv papers:
- keyword/fielded search (official arXiv API)
- optional semantic search (requires embeddings + indexed corpus)

## Scope
### Keyword/fielded search
- Support arXiv query syntax with filters:
  - categories
  - author
  - title/abstract
  - date range
- Pagination and sorting.

### Semantic search (optional)
- If enabled, search a local/indexed corpus (e.g., CASS-backed) using embeddings.
- Must be bounded and deterministic.

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `arxiv.search.keyword`
- `arxiv.search.semantic` (optional)

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- NetworkConstraints pinned to arXiv API host(s).
- Strict rate limiting to avoid bans.

## Deliverables
- Operation schemas:
  - `arxiv.search.keyword`
  - `arxiv.search.advanced`
  - Optional: `arxiv.search.semantic`
- Canonical output types:
  - `ArxivSearchResult`

## Test strategy (MUST)
- Mock-only tests for:
  - query parsing/validation
  - pagination
  - rate limiter behavior

## Acceptance criteria
- Search results are stable, paginated, and policy-respecting.

title: fcp.cron: Scheduled Task Runner
description:
# Scheduled Task Runner Meta-Connector

**Force Multiplier:** Time-based automation for FCP zones.

## Overview

Many automation workflows require scheduled execution: daily reports, periodic syncs, cleanup jobs, reminder systems. This meta-connector provides a robust scheduling infrastructure that triggers FCP actions on time-based schedules.

## Core Components

### 1. Cron Expression Scheduling
- Standard cron syntax (5-field and 6-field)
- Extended syntax with seconds precision
- Timezone-aware scheduling
- Named schedules for common patterns
- Cron expression validation and preview

```
# Standard patterns
@hourly    = 0 * * * *
@daily     = 0 0 * * *
@weekly    = 0 0 * * 0
@monthly   = 0 0 1 * *

# Custom patterns
*/15 * * * *     = Every 15 minutes
0 9 * * 1-5      = 9 AM on weekdays
0 0 1,15 * *     = 1st and 15th of month
```

### 2. One-Time Scheduled Tasks
- Schedule task for specific datetime
- Support for relative scheduling ("in 30 minutes")
- Cancellation before execution
- Rescheduling capability
- Batch scheduling (multiple one-time tasks)

### 3. Interval-Based Triggers
- Fixed interval execution (every N minutes/hours/days)
- Sliding window intervals
- Jitter support for load distribution
- Minimum interval enforcement
- Pause/resume capability

### 4. Task History and Logs
- Complete execution history
- Stdout/stderr capture
- Execution duration tracking
- Success/failure status
- Searchable log storage
- Log retention policies

### 5. Failure Alerting
- Configurable alert channels (email, Slack, PagerDuty)
- Alert on:
  - Task failure
  - Task timeout
  - Consecutive failures
  - Missed schedules
- Alert suppression/snooze
- Escalation policies

## Configuration Example

```toml
[[schedules]]
name = "daily-backup"
cron = "0 2 * * *"
timezone = "America/New_York"
action = "zone.backup.run_backup"
params = { full = true }
timeout = "1h"
alert_on_failure = true

[[schedules]]
name = "hourly-sync"
interval = "1h"
jitter = "5m"
action = "zone.sync.pull_updates"
retry_on_failure = 3

[[one_time]]
name = "migration-task"
run_at = "2024-02-01T03:00:00Z"
action = "zone.db.run_migration"
params = { version = "v2.0" }
```

## Task State Machine

```
PENDING → RUNNING → COMPLETED
              ↓
           FAILED → RETRYING → COMPLETED/FAILED
              ↓
         DEAD (max retries exceeded)
```

## Dashboard Features

- Calendar view of scheduled tasks
- Next N upcoming executions
- Recent execution history
- Live execution monitoring
- Manual trigger capability
- Bulk operations (pause all, resume all)

## Success Criteria

- [ ] Sub-second scheduling precision
- [ ] Support 1000+ concurrent schedules
- [ ] Missed task detection and alerting
- [ ] Distributed execution (no single point of failure)
- [ ] Complete audit trail
- [ ] Hot-reload of schedule configurations

## Dependencies

- Persistent storage for schedules and history
- Time synchronization (NTP)
- Alert channel integrations
- Zone action invocation system

## Considerations

- Handle daylight saving time transitions
- Cluster-safe (only one instance executes)
- Graceful shutdown (complete running tasks)
- Clock skew tolerance
- Long-running task support
close_reason: Duplicate of flywheel_connectors-hiu (fcp.cron: Scheduled Task Runner Connector)

title: Threshold Secrets (Shamir Secret Sharing)
description:
## Overview

Implement cryptographic threshold secret sharing using Shamir's Secret Sharing Scheme (SSS) over GF(2^8) as mandated by V2 spec §17.3. This is a DISTINCT system from RaptorQ symbol distribution - secrets use real cryptographic secret sharing because RaptorQ symbols can leak structure.

## Background & Justification

**Why This Matters:**
The V2 spec explicitly states: "Secrets use real cryptographic secret sharing (Shamir), not just RaptorQ symbols. RaptorQ symbols are NOT a secret sharing scheme—a single symbol can leak structure."

Key differences from RaptorQ:
- RaptorQ symbols can leak structure (not semantically secure)
- Single RaptorQ symbol may reveal partial information
- Shamir shares reveal NOTHING until k shares collected
- Wrapped shares ensure a node cannot decrypt other nodes' shares

**Design Philosophy:**
"Secrets are never complete anywhere" - the secret is only reconstructed ephemerally during use and immediately zeroized. No single device ever stores the complete secret.

## Normative Types (V2 Spec §17.3)

### SecretObject
```rust
pub struct SecretObject {
    pub header: ObjectHeader,
    pub secret_id: SecretId,        // Unique identifier
    pub zone_id: ZoneId,            // Zone binding
    pub k: u8,                      // Threshold (need k shares)
    pub n: u8,                      // Total shares distributed
    pub scheme: SecretSharingScheme,
    pub wrapped_shares: HashMap<TailscaleNodeId, Vec<u8>>,
    pub rotation: SecretRotationPolicy,
}
```

### SecretSharingScheme
```rust
pub enum SecretSharingScheme {
    ShamirGf256,  // Shamir's Secret Sharing over GF(2^8)
}
```

### SecretRotationPolicy
```rust
pub struct SecretRotationPolicy {
    pub rotate_after_secs: u64,    // Auto-rotate interval
    pub overlap_secs: u64,         // Both old and new valid
}
```

### SecretAccessToken
```rust
pub struct SecretAccessToken {
    pub jti: Uuid,                  // Unique token ID
    pub secret_id: SecretId,        // Which secret
    pub purpose: String,            // For audit trail
    pub requested_by: PrincipalId,  // Requester identity
    pub iat: u64,                   // Issued at
    pub exp: u64,                   // Expires at (short-lived!)
    pub signature: Signature,       // Approver signature
}
```

## Implementation Requirements

### 1. Shamir Secret Sharing Implementation
- Implement Shamir SSS over GF(2^8) with constant-time operations
- Support configurable k-of-n thresholds
- Each share MUST be wrapped (encrypted) so nodes cannot decrypt other nodes' shares
- Use per-node Tailscale keys for share wrapping

### 2. SecretObject Management
- Create/store secrets with proper threshold configuration
- Distribute wrapped shares to mesh peers
- Track share locations for reconstruction
- Implement zone-scoped access control

### 3. Secret Reconstruction (Ephemeral)
```rust
impl SecretObject {
    pub async fn use_secret<F, R>(&self, access_token: &SecretAccessToken, f: F) -> Result<R>
    where F: FnOnce(&[u8]) -> R
    {
        // 1. Verify access token
        access_token.verify()?;
        
        // 2. Create audit event BEFORE reconstruction
        self.audit_secret_access(access_token).await?;
        
        // 3. Collect k wrapped shares from peers
        let shares = self.collect_k_wrapped_shares(access_token).await?;
        
        // 4. Reconstruct using Shamir
        let secret = reconstruct_shamir_secure(&shares)?;
        
        // 5. Execute closure with ephemeral secret
        let result = f(&secret);
        
        // 6. Zeroize IMMEDIATELY after use
        secure_zero(secret);
        
        Ok(result)
    }
}
```

### 4. SecretAccessToken Workflow
- Token issuance requires owner or delegated approver signature
- Tokens MUST be short-lived (minutes, not hours)
- Purpose field required for audit trail
- Verify before any secret operation

### 5. Secret Rotation
- Implement automatic rotation based on SecretRotationPolicy
- Support overlap period where both old and new secrets valid
- Coordinate rotation across mesh peers
- Maintain audit trail of rotation events

### 6. Integration with Credentials
The CredentialObject (§10.4) references secrets via SecretId:
- CredentialObject.secret_ref: Option<SecretId>
- Secret materialization requires SecretAccessToken
- Audit every secret access for credential injection

## Security Considerations

1. **Constant-time operations**: All Shamir math MUST be constant-time to prevent timing attacks
2. **Zeroization**: Use zeroize crate; secrets never persist in memory longer than closure execution
3. **Share isolation**: Wrapped shares use per-node keys; compromise of one node doesn't leak other shares
4. **Audit trail**: Every secret access creates AuditEvent BEFORE reconstruction
5. **Token validation**: SecretAccessToken signature and expiry verified before any operation

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Shamir GF(2^8) implementation with constant-time polynomial evaluation
- [ ] SecretObject with k-of-n threshold configuration
- [ ] Per-node share wrapping using Tailscale node keys
- [ ] SecretAccessToken creation and validation
- [ ] Ephemeral reconstruction with immediate zeroization
- [ ] SecretRotationPolicy with overlap period support
- [ ] Integration with CredentialObject for secret-backed credentials
- [ ] Comprehensive audit events for all secret operations
- [ ] Unit tests for Shamir math, threshold edge cases, rotation
- [ ] Integration tests for multi-node secret reconstruction

## Dependencies

This feature depends on:
- Core Types (ObjectHeader, ZoneId, etc.)
- Zone Architecture (zone-scoped access)
- Capability System (for SecretAccessToken authorization)
- MeshNode (for peer share collection)
- Observability (for audit events)
close_reason: Duplicate of 6o25.1 (enhanced with detailed V2 spec content)

title: fcp.linear - Linear Issue Tracking Connector
description:
# fcp.linear - Linear Issue Tracking Connector (FCP2)

## Goal
Provide an FCP2-compliant Linear connector for issue/project automation (and optional bidirectional Beads sync) with deterministic, idempotent, auditable behavior.

## Strategic Context

### Value Assessment
**Strategic Value Score: 97/100** — Critical Tier 1 connector.

**Why Critical**: Linear is the dominant issue tracker for modern engineering teams. Direct integration enables seamless human↔agent task handoff and creates the bridge between "human project management" and "agent task execution." This is the task coordination backbone.

### Priority Matrix Position
- **Category**: Strategic Investment (High Value + Moderate Effort)
- **Build Phase**: Phase 1 Foundation (immediate)

---

## V2 Specification Compliance (NORMATIVE)

### ConnectorArchetype
```rust
archetypes: vec\![
    ConnectorArchetype::Operational,
    ConnectorArchetype::Streaming,
    ConnectorArchetype::Bidirectional
]
```
- **Operational**: GraphQL CRUD operations
- **Streaming**: Webhook event ingestion
- **Bidirectional**: If Beads↔Linear sync implemented

### ConnectorStateModel
```rust
state_model: ConnectorStateModel::SingletonWriter
```
- **SingletonWriter**: Required for bidirectional sync and webhook dedupe
- State tracked: `{ sync_cursor: Option<SyncToken>, webhook_event_ids: Vec<EventId> }`
- Lease required for writer fencing during sync operations

### ConnectorFormat
```rust
format: ConnectorFormat::Wasi
```
- **WASI recommended**: External API connector with OAuth credentials
- Memory isolation prevents token extraction
- Cross-platform consistent behavior

### NetworkConstraints (NORMATIVE)
```rust
NetworkConstraints {
    host_allow: vec\![
        "api.linear.app".into(),
        "linear.app".into(),
    ],
    port_allow: vec\![443],
    deny_localhost: true,
    deny_private_ranges: true,
    deny_tailnet_ranges: true,
    deny_ip_literals: true,
    require_sni: true,
    require_host_canonicalization: true,
}
```

### TaintFlags (NORMATIVE)
Issue tracking data handling:
```rust
// Webhook events are externally sourced
webhook_event.provenance.taint = TaintFlags::EXTERNAL_INPUT;

// Issue content may contain user-supplied data
issue_content.provenance.taint = TaintFlags::USER_SUPPLIED;

// If issues contain URLs:
if issue.contains_urls {
    issue_content.provenance.taint |= TaintFlags::UNVERIFIED_LINK;
}
```

### SafetyTier per Operation
| Operation | SafetyTier | Rationale |
|-----------|------------|-----------|
| `linear.issues.read` | Safe | Read-only listing |
| `linear.comments.read` | Safe | Read-only data |
| `linear.projects.read` | Safe | Read-only data |
| `linear.issues.write` | Risky | Creates/modifies work items |
| `linear.comments.write` | Risky | Public communication |
| `linear.webhooks.manage` | Dangerous | Inbound vector config |
| `linear.beads.sync` | Dangerous | Bidirectional data sync |

---

## Agent Capabilities (Concrete Use Cases)

### Issue Management
- Full issue CRUD with metadata (priority, labels, assignees)
- Comment threads and discussions
- Label and status automation
- Team workload visibility
- Sprint/cycle management

### Project & Roadmap
- Project and roadmap access
- Milestone tracking
- Team capacity planning
- Cross-project dependency tracking

### Webhook Events
- Real-time event processing for automation triggers
- Status change notifications
- Assignment alerts

### Examples of Agent Workflows
```
"Create a Linear issue for this bug I found"
"Whats blocking the current sprint?"
"Assign this task to the frontend team"
"Update issue status when PR is merged"
"Generate weekly sprint summary"
"Auto-triage incoming issues using BV algorithms"
```

---

## Flywheel Ecosystem Synergies

### BV (Beads Viewer) — Bidirectional Sync
**This is the killer feature.**
- Linear issues ↔ Beads (agent-native tasks)
- Sync status, priority, and dependencies bidirectionally
- Use BV's graph algorithms for Linear triage:
  - PageRank for issue importance
  - Critical path analysis
  - Blocker detection

### Agent Mail Integration
- Auto-assign issues based on file reservations
- Route issue updates as mail notifications
- Thread Linear comments with agent discussions

### NTM (Neural Task Manager)
- Spawn agents for Linear issues automatically
- Break down Linear epics into agent-executable subtasks
- Report progress back to Linear

### CASS (Context-Aware Semantic Search)
- Link code sessions to Linear issues
- Semantic search across issue history
- Learn from resolution patterns

### UBS (Ultimate Bug Scanner)
- Create Linear issues from UBS findings automatically
- Link bug reports to specific code locations
- Track fix status through issue lifecycle

---

## Automation Unlocks

### Auto-Triage Pipeline
```
UBS finding → Create Linear issue → BV ranks priority → Agent Mail assigns → Agent works → PR links back
```

### Implementation Plan Generation
```
Linear issue description → Agent generates implementation plan → Creates subtasks → Links to codebase
```

### Status Sync
```
Git commit → Linked issue → Update Linear status → Notify stakeholders
```

---

## Technical Implementation Notes

### API Surface
- **GraphQL API** with full query/mutation support
- **Subscription support** for real-time updates (optional)
- **Webhook handler** for event-driven automation

### Recommended Crates
- `graphql_client` or `cynic` — GraphQL client
- `reqwest` — HTTP transport
- `serde_json` — JSON handling
- `tokio` — Async runtime

### Bidirectional Beads Sync Protocol
If enabled, this is a high-risk side effect requiring:
- Explicit capability token
- OperationIntent/Receipt to avoid duplicate writes
- AuditEvents for every sync operation
- Stable reason codes on denials
- Conflict resolution strategy (last-write-wins or manual)

---

## Zone Architecture

### Recommended Zones
| Zone | Description | Capabilities |
|------|-------------|--------------|
| `z:work:linear:<workspace>` | Full workspace access | All CRUD operations |
| `z:project:<name>:linear` | Project-scoped access | Issues in specific project |
| `z:work:linear:readonly` | Read-only monitoring | List/get only |

### Single-Zone Binding
- One connector instance binds to exactly one `ZoneId`
- Cross-workspace sync requires separate instances
- Beads sync is per-zone; cannot sync across workspaces

---

## Manifest Archetypes (Closed Set)
- `operational` — GraphQL CRUD operations
- `streaming` — Webhook/event ingestion (if enabled)
- `bidirectional` — If Beads↔Linear sync implemented

---

## External Surface

### NetworkConstraints
Default-deny; allow only:
- `api.linear.app:443`
- `linear.app:443` (OAuth flows)

### Credential Injection
- API key via `CredentialId` (simpler, personal use)
- OAuth token via `CredentialId` (team/workspace access)
- Never write credentials to disk

---

## Capability Model

### Read Operations
- `linear.issues.read` — List, get, search issues
- `linear.comments.read` — Read issue comments
- `linear.projects.read` — List projects, roadmaps
- `linear.teams.read` — Team information
- `linear.users.read` — User profiles

### Write Operations
- `linear.issues.write` — Create, update, move, assign
- `linear.comments.write` — Create, update, delete comments
- `linear.projects.write` — Modify project settings
- `linear.labels.write` — Manage labels

### Dangerous Operations
- `linear.webhooks.manage` — Webhook configuration
- `linear.beads.sync` — Bidirectional Beads sync (if enabled)

---

## Operations (Representative)

### Issue Operations
- `issue.create` — Create new issue
- `issue.update` — Update issue fields
- `issue.get` — Get issue by ID
- `issue.list` — List issues with filters
- `issue.search` — Full-text search
- `issue.move` — Move between projects/teams
- `issue.assign` — Assign to user
- `issue.relations` — Manage issue relationships

### Comment Operations
- `comment.create` — Add comment to issue
- `comment.update` — Edit comment
- `comment.delete` — Remove comment
- `comment.list` — List issue comments

### Project/Cycle Operations
- `project.list` — List projects
- `project.get` — Get project details
- `cycle.list` — List sprints/cycles
- `cycle.get` — Get cycle details

### Optional: Beads Sync
- `beads.sync.pull` — Import Linear issues to Beads
- `beads.sync.push` — Export Beads to Linear
- `beads.sync.bidirectional` — Full two-way sync

---

## Tests

### Unit Tests (Mock-Only)
- GraphQL query construction
- Response parsing
- Sync conflict resolution logic
- Rate limit handling

### Integration Tests
- wiremock-based GraphQL simulation
- Webhook event simulation
- Bidirectional sync scenarios

### E2E Compliance
- Validates default deny + NetworkConstraints
- Verifies receipts for write operations
- Confirms audit trail for sync operations

---

## Acceptance Criteria
- Passes connector compliance runner (static + dynamic)
- Deterministic tests; no live Linear calls in unit tests
- GraphQL operations work correctly
- Webhook events processed reliably (if enabled)
- Beads sync maintains data integrity (if enabled)
- All V2 NORMATIVE requirements satisfied

# fcp.linear: Webhook Event Ingestion (optional)

## Goal
If enabled, ingest Linear webhooks as an FCP2 streaming source.

## Requirements
- Connector does not expose inbound ports.
- `fcp-host` owns ingress and forwards verified payloads over FCPC.
- Events emitted as EventEnvelopes with correct topics/taints.

## Acceptance Criteria
- The functionality described in this bead is implemented with typed schemas + validation (no unstructured “stringly” interfaces).
- Errors map to the FCP error taxonomy with correct retry semantics and no secret/PII leakage.
- Mock-only unit/integration tests cover success paths and common failures and emit structured JSON logs per `flywheel_connectors-1n78.35`.

title: fcp.hubspot: HubSpot CRM & Marketing Platform Connector
description:
# fcp.hubspot - HubSpot CRM & Marketing Platform Connector (FCP2)

## Success Criteria
- `flywheel_connectors-hy8v.1` (Manifest + Capability Map) is complete and passes static validation (IDs, schemas, NetworkConstraints, safety tiers).
- `flywheel_connectors-hy8v.2` (Provisioning Automation) is complete, minimizes human prompts, and is fully mockable for tests.
- `flywheel_connectors-hy8v.3` (Unit/Integration Tests) are mock-only, include success + denial paths, and assert log redaction (no secrets/PII).
- `flywheel_connectors-hy8v.4` (E2E Compliance Run) passes the shared compliance runner and emits an evidence bundle (logs + receipts + audit checks).
- Connector is V2-only: single-zone binding, default deny, constrained egress, audited risky/dangerous ops.

## Strategic Context

### Value Assessment
**Strategic Value Score: 87/100** — High priority Tier 2 connector (CRM family).

**Why Critical**: HubSpot is the **leading mid-market CRM and marketing platform**. Enables agents to manage sales pipelines, automate marketing, and handle customer relationships. Essential for revenue operations automation.

### Priority Matrix Position
- **Category**: Strategic Investment (High Value + Revenue Operations)
- **Build Phase**: Phase 2 Productivity (weeks 5-8)

---

## V2 Specification Compliance (NORMATIVE)

### ConnectorArchetype
```rust
archetypes: vec\![
    ConnectorArchetype::Operational,  // CRM CRUD operations
    ConnectorArchetype::Streaming,    // Webhook events
]
```
- **Operational**: Contact/company/deal CRUD, marketing actions
- **Streaming**: Webhooks for CRM events, form submissions

### ConnectorStateModel
```rust
state_model: ConnectorStateModel::SingletonWriter
```
- **SingletonWriter**: Sync cursors for incremental updates
- State tracked: `{ sync_cursors: HashMap<ObjectType, Cursor>, webhook_state: WebhookState }`
- Lease required for writer fencing

### ConnectorFormat
```rust
format: ConnectorFormat::Wasi
```
- **WASI recommended**: Handles OAuth tokens, PII data
- Memory isolation for credential protection
- Capability-gated hostcalls

### NetworkConstraints (NORMATIVE)
```rust
NetworkConstraints {
    // HubSpot API endpoints
    host_allow: vec\![
        "api.hubapi.com".into(),
        "api.hubspot.com".into(),
        "app.hubspot.com".into(),  // OAuth
    ],
    port_allow: vec\![443],
    deny_localhost: true,
    deny_private_ranges: true,
    deny_tailnet_ranges: true,
    deny_ip_literals: true,
    require_sni: true,
    require_host_canonicalization: true,
}
```

### TaintFlags (NORMATIVE)
```rust
// Contact data contains PII
contact_data.provenance.taint = TaintFlags::USER_SUPPLIED;

// Form submissions are external input
form_submission.provenance.taint = TaintFlags::EXTERNAL_INPUT
    | TaintFlags::USER_SUPPLIED;

// Email content is user-generated
email_content.provenance.taint = TaintFlags::USER_SUPPLIED
    | TaintFlags::PROMPT_SURFACE;
```

### SafetyTier per Operation
| Operation | SafetyTier | Rationale |
|-----------|------------|-----------|
| `hubspot.contacts.read` | Risky | PII data |
| `hubspot.companies.read` | Safe | Business data |
| `hubspot.deals.read` | Safe | Sales data |
| `hubspot.contacts.write` | Risky | Creates PII records |
| `hubspot.deals.write` | Risky | Modifies pipeline |
| `hubspot.email.send` | Dangerous | External communication |
| `hubspot.contacts.delete` | Dangerous | Irreversible |
| `hubspot.marketing.manage` | Dangerous | Campaign automation |

---

## Agent Capabilities (Concrete Use Cases)

### Contact & Company Management
- Create/update contacts and companies
- Association management (contacts ↔ companies ↔ deals)
- Custom property handling
- List segmentation

### Deal Pipeline
- Create and update deals
- Pipeline stage progression
- Revenue forecasting data
- Deal associations

### Marketing Automation
- Email campaign management
- Form submission handling
- Landing page data
- Marketing analytics

### Examples of Agent Workflows
```
"Create a contact for this new lead"
"Update the deal stage to Closed Won"
"Find all contacts at this company"
"Add this lead to the nurture campaign"
"Get pipeline value for this quarter"
"Log this email to the contact record"
```

---

## Flywheel Ecosystem Synergies

### Stripe Integration
**Revenue operations:**
- Payment data → deal updates
- Subscription status → contact records
- Revenue attribution

### Slack/Teams Integration
- Deal notifications to sales channel
- Lead alerts
- Pipeline updates

### Agent Mail Integration
- CRM notifications → agent threads
- Customer context in conversations

---

## Technical Implementation Notes

### API Surface
- **CRM API v3**: Primary CRUD operations
- **Marketing API**: Campaigns, forms
- **Webhooks**: Event notifications

### Recommended Crates
- `reqwest` — HTTP client
- `serde_json` — JSON handling
- `oauth2` — Authentication

### Authentication
| Mode | Use Case |
|------|----------|
| Private App | Internal integrations |
| OAuth 2.0 | External integrations |
| API Key | Legacy (deprecated) |

---

## Zone Architecture

### Recommended Zones
| Zone | Description | Capabilities |
|------|-------------|--------------|
| `z:work:hubspot:full` | Full access | All CRM + marketing |
| `z:work:hubspot:crm` | CRM only | Contacts, deals |
| `z:work:hubspot:readonly` | Read-only | Safe operations |

---

## Manifest Archetypes (Closed Set)
- `operational` — CRM CRUD
- `streaming` — Webhook events

---

## External Surface

### NetworkConstraints
Default-deny; allow only:
- `api.hubapi.com:443`
- `api.hubspot.com:443`

### Credential Injection
- OAuth tokens via egress proxy
- Private app tokens via CredentialId

---

## Capability Model

### CRM Read Operations
- `hubspot.contacts.read` — Contact data (Risky/PII)
- `hubspot.companies.read` — Company data
- `hubspot.deals.read` — Deal data

### CRM Write Operations
- `hubspot.contacts.write` — Create/update contacts
- `hubspot.companies.write` — Create/update companies
- `hubspot.deals.write` — Create/update deals

### Marketing Operations
- `hubspot.email.send` — Send email (Dangerous)
- `hubspot.marketing.manage` — Campaign management (Dangerous)

### Admin Operations
- `hubspot.contacts.delete` — Delete contacts (Dangerous)

---

## Operations (Representative)

### Create Contact
```json
POST /crm/v3/objects/contacts
{
  "properties": {
    "email": "user@example.com",
    "firstname": "John",
    "lastname": "Doe"
  }
}
```

### Search Contacts
```json
POST /crm/v3/objects/contacts/search
{
  "filterGroups": [{
    "filters": [{
      "propertyName": "company",
      "operator": "EQ",
      "value": "Acme Inc"
    }]
  }]
}
```

### Update Deal Stage
```json
PATCH /crm/v3/objects/deals/{dealId}
{
  "properties": {
    "dealstage": "closedwon"
  }
}
```

---

## Tests

### Unit Tests (Mock-Only)
- Request construction
- Response parsing
- Search query building
- Error handling

### Integration Tests
- Mock HubSpot API responses
- CRM workflow scenarios
- Error recovery

### E2E Compliance
- Validates NetworkConstraints
- Dangerous operation approval flow
- PII handling audit

---

## Acceptance Criteria
- Passes connector compliance runner (static + dynamic)
- No real HubSpot API calls in unit tests
- Contact/company/deal CRUD works
- Search functionality works
- Association management works
- All V2 NORMATIVE requirements satisfied

title: fcp.slack: Slack Workspace Integration Connector
description:
# fcp.slack - Slack Workspace Integration Connector (FCP2)

## Strategic Context

### Value Assessment
**Strategic Value Score: 92/100** — Critical Tier 1 connector (Communication family).

**Why Critical**: Slack is **the dominant enterprise messaging platform**. Enables agents to participate in team conversations, automate workflows, and bridge communication across tools. Essential for enterprise agent deployments.

### Priority Matrix Position
- **Category**: Strategic Investment (Communication + Automation)
- **Build Phase**: Phase 1 Foundation (immediate)

---

## V2 Specification Compliance (NORMATIVE)

### ConnectorArchetype
```rust
archetypes: vec\![
    ConnectorArchetype::Bidirectional,  // Send + receive messages
    ConnectorArchetype::Streaming,      // Real-time events via Socket Mode
    ConnectorArchetype::Operational,    // Web API actions
]
```
- **Bidirectional**: Two-way messaging in channels/DMs
- **Streaming**: Real-time event subscription (Socket Mode preferred)
- **Operational**: CRUD on channels, users, files

### ConnectorStateModel
```rust
state_model: ConnectorStateModel::SingletonWriter
```
- **SingletonWriter**: Event cursor for Socket Mode or pagination state
- State tracked: `{ cursor: Option<String>, last_event_ts: Timestamp }`
- Lease required for writer fencing

### ConnectorFormat
```rust
format: ConnectorFormat::Wasi
```
- **WASI**: Contains Dangerous operations (channel archive, DM access)
- Memory isolation for token handling
- Capability-gated hostcalls

### NetworkConstraints (NORMATIVE)
```rust
NetworkConstraints {
    // Slack API endpoints
    host_allow: vec\![
        "slack.com".into(),
        "api.slack.com".into(),
        "files.slack.com".into(),
        "wss-primary.slack.com".into(),  // Socket Mode
    ],
    port_allow: vec\![443],
    deny_localhost: true,
    deny_private_ranges: true,
    deny_tailnet_ranges: true,
    deny_ip_literals: true,
    require_sni: true,
    require_host_canonicalization: true,
}
```

### TaintFlags (NORMATIVE)
```rust
// All Slack messages are adversarial prompt surfaces
message.provenance.taint = TaintFlags::EXTERNAL_INPUT
    | TaintFlags::PROMPT_SURFACE
    | TaintFlags::USER_SUPPLIED;

// URLs in messages are unverified
if message.contains_urls() {
    message.provenance.taint |= TaintFlags::UNVERIFIED_LINK;
}

// File attachments need scanning
file.provenance.taint = TaintFlags::EXTERNAL_INPUT
    | TaintFlags::UNVERIFIED_LINK;
```

### SafetyTier per Operation
| Operation | SafetyTier | Rationale |
|-----------|------------|-----------|
| `slack.messages.read` | Safe | Read-only |
| `slack.channels.read` | Safe | Read-only listing |
| `slack.users.read` | Risky | Contains PII |
| `slack.messages.send` | Risky | Creates content |
| `slack.channels.write` | Dangerous | Org-level changes |
| `slack.files.write` | Dangerous | Data upload |
| `slack.search.read` | Dangerous | Broad data access |

---

## Agent Capabilities (Concrete Use Cases)

### Messaging Operations
- Send/update/delete messages
- React with emoji
- Reply in threads
- Schedule messages

### Channel Management
- List/create channels
- Archive/rename channels
- Set topic/purpose
- Manage membership

### User Information
- List workspace users
- Get user profiles
- Check presence status

### File Operations
- Upload/download files
- Share files in channels
- List file history

### Examples of Agent Workflows
```
"Post a summary in #team-updates"
"Reply to this thread with the analysis"
"Create a channel for this project"
"Search for messages about the deployment"
"Upload this report to #reports"
"Notify @oncall about the incident"
```

---

## Flywheel Ecosystem Synergies

### Agent Mail Integration
- Slack threads ↔ Agent Mail threads
- Cross-platform notifications
- Unified conversation history

### GitHub/Linear Integration
- PR/issue notifications to channels
- Command-triggered workflows
- Status updates on commits

### Sentry/Datadog Integration
- Alerts routed to Slack
- Incident channels auto-created
- On-call notifications

### HubSpot Integration
- Deal updates in sales channels
- Customer mentions trigger CRM lookup

---

## Technical Implementation Notes

### API Surface
- **Web API**: CRUD operations
- **Socket Mode**: Real-time events (recommended)
- **Events API**: Webhook-based events (fallback)

### Recommended Crates
- `slack_morphism` — Slack API client
- `reqwest` — HTTP client
- `tokio-tungstenite` — WebSocket for Socket Mode
- `hmac` / `sha2` — Request signing

### Authentication Modes
| Mode | Use Case | Recommendation |
|------|----------|----------------|
| Bot Token | Standard automation | **Preferred** |
| User Token | User-delegated access | Limited use |
| App-Level Token | Socket Mode | Required for events |

---

## Zone Architecture

### Recommended Zones
| Zone | Description | Capabilities |
|------|-------------|--------------|
| `z:work:slack:<workspace>` | Workspace-scoped | Full workspace access |
| `z:work:slack:readonly` | Read-only | Safe operations only |
| `z:project:<name>:slack` | Channel-scoped | Limited channels |

### Threat Model
- Slack messages are adversarial prompt surfaces
- DMs contain sensitive enterprise data
- No token/PII leakage in logs

---

## Manifest Archetypes (Closed Set)
- `bidirectional` — Send + receive messages
- `streaming` — Real-time event ingestion
- `operational` — Web API actions

---

## External Surface

### NetworkConstraints
Default-deny; allow only:
- `api.slack.com:443`
- `files.slack.com:443`
- `wss-primary.slack.com:443` (Socket Mode)

### Credential Injection
- Bot token via egress proxy
- App-level token for Socket Mode
- Signing secret for Events API

---

## Capability Model

### Read Operations
- `slack.messages.read` — Read messages
- `slack.channels.read` — List channels
- `slack.users.read` — User info (PII)
- `slack.files.read` — File access

### Write Operations
- `slack.messages.send` — Post messages
- `slack.channels.write` — Create/modify channels
- `slack.files.write` — Upload files

### Admin Operations
- `slack.search.read` — Workspace-wide search (Dangerous)
- `slack.interactive.manage` — Modals/actions (Dangerous)

---

## Operations (Representative)

### Post Message
```json
POST /chat.postMessage
{
  "channel": "C1234567890",
  "text": "Hello from the agent\!",
  "thread_ts": "1234567890.123456"
}
```

### List Channels
```
GET /conversations.list?types=public_channel,private_channel
```

### Get User Info
```
GET /users.info?user=U1234567890
```

### Upload File
```
POST /files.upload
(multipart form with file + channel)
```

---

## Tests

### Unit Tests (Mock-Only)
- API request construction
- Response parsing
- Socket Mode event handling
- Rate limit handling
- Signing verification

### Integration Tests
- Mock Slack API responses
- Multi-step workflows
- Socket Mode connection simulation

### E2E Compliance
- Validates NetworkConstraints
- Dangerous operation approval flow
- Audit logging for writes

---

## Acceptance Criteria
- Passes connector compliance runner (static + dynamic)
- No real Slack API calls in unit tests
- Socket Mode connection functional
- All message operations work
- Channel CRUD functional
- File upload/download works
- All V2 NORMATIVE requirements satisfied

title: fcp.mailchimp: Email Marketing Platform Connector
description:
## Goal
Provide an FCP2-compliant Mailchimp connector for email marketing automation (campaigns/lists/segments) with strict capabilities and auditability.

## External surface (NetworkConstraints)
Default deny.
- Network egress MUST be restricted per-operation via manifest `NetworkConstraints` (defined in the connector’s manifest/cap map bead if present).
- Allow only the configured service host(s); HTTPS-only where applicable; deny redirects by default.
- Bound timeouts + response sizes; treat all remote responses as untrusted input; never leak secrets/PII in logs or errors.

## Manifest archetypes (closed set)

- `operational`
- `streaming`

> Interaction patterns (non-archetype): Request/Response + Webhook

## Summary
Implement FCP connector for Mailchimp Marketing API - an email marketing automation platform. This connector enables audience/list management, campaign creation, template management, automation workflows, and analytics reporting.

## Value Assessment
- **Value Score**: 59/100 (Tier 4)
- **Archetype**: Request-Response + Webhook
- **Priority**: P3

## API Integration
- **Primary API**: Mailchimp Marketing API v3
- **Base URL**: https://{dc}.api.mailchimp.com/3.0/
- **Authentication**: OAuth 2.0 (API key also supported)
- **Rate Limits**: 10 concurrent connections, varies by plan

## Operations

### Audience Management
- List/create/update/delete audiences (lists)
- Manage audience members (subscribers)
- Batch subscribe/unsubscribe operations
- Member activity and history
- Interest categories and interests
- Merge fields management

### Campaign Management
- Create/send/schedule campaigns
- Campaign content editing
- A/B testing campaigns
- Campaign reports and analytics
- Replicate campaigns
- Pause/resume sending

### Templates
- List/create/update templates
- Template folders
- Default content blocks

### Automations
- List automation workflows
- Start/pause automations
- Automation emails and queues
- Subscriber workflow management

### Segments & Tags
- Create/manage segments
- Segment conditions and logic
- Tag management
- Batch tagging operations

### Reports & Analytics
- Campaign reports
- Open/click reports
- Subscriber activity
- E-commerce reports
- Automation reports
- Comparative reports

## Zone Architecture

### Zone 1: Audience Read (Low Risk)
- Read audience/list information
- Get subscriber data
- View segments and tags
- Access reports and analytics

### Zone 2: Campaign Management (Medium Risk)
- Create and edit campaigns
- Manage templates
- Configure automations
- Manage segments

### Zone 3: Admin (High Risk)
- Send campaigns
- Delete audiences/subscribers
- Modify automation workflows
- Batch operations

## Dependencies
- fcp-core: Core connector framework
- fcp-oauth: OAuth 2.0 authentication flow
- fcp-webhook: Real-time event notifications
- fcp-ratelimit: Rate limiting and throttling
- fcp-telemetry: Observability and metrics

## Webhook Events
- Subscribe events
- Unsubscribe events
- Profile updates
- Email sent/opened/clicked
- Campaign events
- Cleaned (bounced) emails

## Data Models
- Audience (List)
- Member (Subscriber)
- Campaign
- Template
- Automation
- Segment
- Tag
- Report

## Implementation Notes
- Mailchimp uses data center-specific URLs (us1, us2, etc.)
- API key contains datacenter suffix (key-dc)
- Batch operations available for bulk subscriber management
- Webhook verification via secret key
- Pagination uses offset/count pattern
- Some endpoints have specific rate limits

## Testing Strategy
- Unit tests for data transformations
- Integration tests with Mailchimp sandbox
- Webhook signature verification tests
- Rate limit handling tests

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] OAuth 2.0 authentication working
- [ ] All CRUD operations for audiences
- [ ] Campaign creation and sending
- [ ] Template management
- [ ] Automation workflow support
- [ ] Segment and tag operations
- [ ] Webhook event handling
- [ ] Report/analytics retrieval
- [ ] Rate limiting compliance
- [ ] Comprehensive error handling

title: Revocation System (RevocationObject/Registry/Chain)
description:
## Overview

Implement the revocation system as specified in V2 spec §14.3. This is CRITICAL security infrastructure - the spec explicitly states: "Without revocation, 'compromised device' recovery is mostly imaginary."

Revocations are mesh objects distributed like any other object and MUST be enforced before use.

## Background & Justification

When a device is compromised or a key is leaked, the mesh MUST be able to:
1. Revoke capabilities issued to that device
2. Revoke the device's issuer key (can no longer mint tokens)
3. Remove the device from the mesh entirely
4. Revoke compromised connector binaries
5. Force zone key rotation

Without revocation, security incidents cannot be recovered from.

## Normative Types (V2 Spec §14.3)

### RevocationObject
```rust
pub struct RevocationObject {
    pub header: ObjectHeader,
    /// ObjectIds being revoked
    pub revoked: Vec<ObjectId>,
    /// Scope of revocation
    pub scope: RevocationScope,
    /// Human-readable reason
    pub reason: String,
    /// When revocation becomes effective
    pub effective_at: u64,
    /// Optional expiry (None = permanent)
    pub expires_at: Option<u64>,
    /// Owner signature (revocations MUST be owner-signed)
    pub signature: Signature,
}
```

### RevocationScope
```rust
pub enum RevocationScope {
    /// Revoke capability objects/tokens
    Capability,
    /// Revoke issuer keys (node can no longer mint tokens)
    IssuerKey,
    /// Revoke node attestation (removes device from mesh)
    NodeAttestation,
    /// Revoke zone key (forces rotation)
    ZoneKey,
    /// Revoke connector binary (supply chain response)
    ConnectorBinary,
}
```

### RevocationEvent (Chain Node)
```rust
/// Hash-linked chain for revocation freshness
pub struct RevocationEvent {
    pub header: ObjectHeader,
    pub revocation_object_id: ObjectId,
    pub prev: Option<ObjectId>,
    /// Monotonic chain sequence number (NORMATIVE)
    /// Enables O(1) freshness comparison: seq_a > seq_b ⟹ a is fresher than b
    pub seq: u64,
    pub occurred_at: u64,
    pub signature: Signature,
}
```

### RevocationHead (Checkpoint)
```rust
/// Enables freshness semantics: tokens bound to a rev_head, verifiers MUST
/// have revocation state >= that head before accepting the token
pub struct RevocationHead {
    pub header: ObjectHeader,
    pub zone_id: ZoneId,
    pub head_event: ObjectId,
    /// Sequence number of head_event (NORMATIVE)
    /// Enables O(1) freshness comparison without chain traversal
    pub head_seq: u64,
    pub epoch_id: EpochId,
    pub quorum_signatures: Vec<(TailscaleNodeId, Signature)>,
}
```

### RevocationRegistry
```rust
pub struct RevocationRegistry {
    revocations: HashMap<ObjectId, RevocationObject>,
    bloom_filter: BloomFilter,  // Fast negative lookup
    /// Latest revocation head known for this zone
    pub head: Option<ObjectId>,
}

impl RevocationRegistry {
    /// Check if object is revoked (MUST be called before use)
    pub fn is_revoked(&self, object_id: &ObjectId) -> bool {
        // Fast path: bloom filter definitely-not check
        if !self.bloom_filter.might_contain(object_id.as_bytes()) {
            return false;
        }
        self.revocations.contains_key(object_id)
    }
}
```

## Implementation Requirements

### 1. RevocationObject Creation and Signing
- Owner-only signing (revocations are critical operations)
- Support all RevocationScope variants
- Validate effective_at is in future or now
- Propagate via mesh gossip immediately

### 2. RevocationEvent Chain
- Hash-linked for integrity
- Monotonic seq for O(1) freshness comparison
- Each new revocation creates new chain node
- Support chain traversal for full audit

### 3. RevocationHead Quorum
- Requires quorum signatures from mesh nodes
- Binds capability tokens to revocation state
- Verifiers MUST check token.rev_head <= local.head
- Enables freshness guarantees

### 4. Bloom Filter Optimization
- Fast negative lookup for non-revoked objects
- Size tuned for expected revocation volume
- Rebuild on restart from persistent store

### 5. Revocation Enforcement Points

EVERY capability verification MUST include:
```rust
fn verify_capability_token(&self, token: &CapabilityToken) -> Result<()> {
    // MANDATORY: Check revocation before any other validation
    if self.revocation_registry.is_revoked(&token.object_id) {
        return Err(Error::Revoked);
    }
    
    // Check revocation freshness
    if let Some(token_rev_head) = token.rev_head {
        if !self.revocation_registry.is_at_least(token_rev_head)? {
            return Err(Error::RevocationStateStale);
        }
    }
    
    // Continue with normal verification...
}
```

### 6. Revocation Propagation
- High-priority gossip (revocations supersede other traffic)
- Persist to local store immediately
- Trigger re-evaluation of cached capability decisions

## Use Cases by Scope

### Capability Revocation
- Revoke specific capability tokens (e.g., leaked token)
- Immediate effect on all nodes

### IssuerKey Revocation  
- Node can no longer mint new tokens
- Existing tokens remain valid until they expire
- Used for semi-trusted devices

### NodeAttestation Revocation
- Complete device removal from mesh
- All capabilities issued TO and BY this node revoked
- Used for compromised devices

### ZoneKey Revocation
- Forces zone key rotation
- All zone members must re-enroll
- Used for catastrophic key compromise

### ConnectorBinary Revocation
- Specific binary hash revoked
- Connectors using that binary MUST stop
- Used for supply chain incidents

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] RevocationObject with all scope variants
- [ ] Owner-only signature validation
- [ ] RevocationEvent hash-linked chain
- [ ] Monotonic seq numbers for O(1) freshness
- [ ] RevocationHead with quorum signatures
- [ ] RevocationRegistry with bloom filter
- [ ] is_revoked() check at all enforcement points
- [ ] Revocation freshness comparison
- [ ] High-priority gossip propagation
- [ ] Persistent storage with crash recovery
- [ ] Audit events for all revocation operations

## Dependencies

- Core Types (ObjectHeader, ObjectId, etc.)
- Zone Architecture (zone-scoped revocations)
- Capability System (enforcement points)
- MeshNode (gossip propagation)
- Observability (audit events)
close_reason: Duplicate of 1n78.9 (enhanced with detailed V2 spec content)

title: TEST: Error Taxonomy Unit Tests (FCP-XXXX Codes, Retry Semantics, AI Hints)
description:
# TEST: Error Taxonomy Unit Tests


## Goal
Validate the error taxonomy is stable, code-complete, and machine-actionable (retry semantics + hints) with golden vectors.

## Scope
Comprehensive tests for error code system and recovery hints.

## Test Categories

### Error Code Ranges
- [ ] FCP-1xxx (protocol errors) mapped correctly
- [ ] FCP-2xxx (auth/capability errors) mapped correctly
- [ ] FCP-3xxx (zone errors) mapped correctly
- [ ] FCP-4xxx (store/mesh errors) mapped correctly
- [ ] FCP-5xxx (connector errors) mapped correctly
- [ ] FCP-9xxx (internal errors) mapped correctly

### Error Structure
- [ ] All errors have stable `code` string
- [ ] All errors have human-readable `message`
- [ ] All errors have `retryable` flag
- [ ] Retryable errors have `retry_after_ms`
- [ ] Errors include `details` when applicable

### AI Recovery Hints
- [ ] Top 20 failure modes have ai_recovery_hint
- [ ] Hints are actionable and specific
- [ ] Hints don't leak secrets
- [ ] Hints are stable across versions

### Error Serialization
- [ ] Errors serialize to canonical CBOR
- [ ] Errors deserialize correctly
- [ ] Unknown error codes handled gracefully
- [ ] Forward compatibility for new codes

### Retry Semantics
- [ ] Retryable errors retry correctly
- [ ] Non-retryable errors fail immediately
- [ ] Retry budget is respected
- [ ] Exponential backoff applied

## Golden Vectors
Location: `tests/vectors/errors/`
- `error_protocol.cbor`
- `error_auth.cbor`
- `error_zone.cbor`
- `error_retryable.cbor`

## Logging Requirements
```json
{
  "timestamp": "RFC3339",
  "test_name": "test_error_taxonomy",
  "phase": "execute",
  "correlation_id": "uuid",
  "error_code": "FCP-2101",
  "retryable": false,
  "ai_hint_present": true,
  "result": "pass"
}
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- All error codes are tested
- AI hints exist for common failures
- Error serialization is stable
close_reason: Error Taxonomy Unit Tests complete: 50+ tests covering all FCP error code ranges (1xxx-9xxx), error structure, AI recovery hints (all_errors_have_ai_hints, ai_hints_are_actionable), error serialization roundtrips, retry semantics, and golden vector tests. Tests are inline in fcp-core/src/error.rs. All 204 tests pass.

title: fcp.figma: Image export (PNG, SVG, PDF formats)
description:
# fcp.figma: Image export (PNG, SVG, PDF formats) (FCP2)

## Goal
Export design assets from Figma safely:
- render nodes/frames to PNG/SVG/PDF
- download rendered assets with strict bounds

## Scope
- Request render URLs for one or more node IDs.
- Download rendered assets (streamed).
- Enforce size and host constraints:
  - bounded max bytes
  - allowlist content-types
  - deny redirects to new hosts

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `figma.export.read`

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- NetworkConstraints must explicitly allow:
  - Figma API host(s)
  - the specific export CDN host(s) if distinct
- Avoid logging URLs/tokens embedded in export links.

## Deliverables
- Operation schemas:
  - `figma.export.render`
  - `figma.export.download`
- Streaming download implementation with hash computation for evidence.

## Test strategy (MUST)
- Mock-only tests for:
  - render request formation
  - download bounds + early abort
  - host pinning and redirect refusal
  - content-type allowlist

## Acceptance criteria
- Asset export is safe-by-default and does not allow arbitrary egress.

title: fcp.browser - Headless Browser Automation Connector
description:
# fcp.browser - Headless Browser Automation Connector (FCP2)

## Strategic Context

### Value Assessment
**Strategic Value Score: 95/100** — Critical Tier 1 meta-connector.

**Why Critical**: This is the **"UNIVERSAL ADAPTER"** that lets agents interact with ANY web service, even those without APIs. Combined with vision models, this enables true general-purpose web automation. When there is no API, the browser connector is the fallback.

### Priority Matrix Position
- **Category**: Strategic Investment (High Value + Foundation)
- **Build Phase**: Phase 1 Foundation (immediate)

---

## V2 Specification Compliance (NORMATIVE)

### ConnectorArchetype
```rust
archetypes: vec\![ConnectorArchetype::Operational]
```
- **Operational**: Navigates, extracts, interacts with web pages

### ConnectorStateModel
```rust
state_model: ConnectorStateModel::SingletonWriter
```
- **SingletonWriter**: Browser session state, cookies, auth tokens
- State tracked: `{ session_id: String, cookies: CookieJar, auth_state: Option<AuthState> }`
- Lease required for session fencing

### ConnectorFormat
```rust
format: ConnectorFormat::Native
```
- **Native MANDATORY**: Requires OS-level process spawning for browser
- Sandboxed via seccomp/landlock
- Browser runs in separate process sandbox
- Note: WASI does not support browser automation

### NetworkConstraints (NORMATIVE)
```rust
NetworkConstraints {
    // DYNAMIC: host_allow populated from policy allowlist
    host_allow: vec\![/* policy-defined allowlist */],
    port_allow: vec\![80, 443],
    deny_localhost: true,
    deny_private_ranges: true,
    deny_tailnet_ranges: true,
    deny_ip_literals: true,
    require_sni: true,
    require_host_canonicalization: true,
}
```
**Note**: Browser navigation is ONLY permitted to explicitly allowlisted hosts.

### TaintFlags (NORMATIVE)
```rust
// ALL web content is adversarial
page_content.provenance.taint = TaintFlags::PUBLIC_INPUT
    | TaintFlags::EXTERNAL_INPUT
    | TaintFlags::PROMPT_SURFACE
    | TaintFlags::UNVERIFIED_LINK;

// Form inputs submitted by agent
form_data.provenance.taint = TaintFlags::USER_SUPPLIED;

// Extracted data inherits source taint
extracted_data.provenance.taint = page_content.provenance.taint;
```

### SafetyTier per Operation
| Operation | SafetyTier | Rationale |
|-----------|------------|-----------|
| `browser.navigate` | Risky | Visits external sites |
| `browser.screenshot` | Safe | Read-only capture |
| `browser.extract` | Safe | Read-only extraction |
| `browser.click` | Risky | Triggers actions |
| `browser.fill` | Risky | Submits data |
| `browser.submit` | Dangerous | Form submission |
| `browser.authenticate` | Dangerous | Credential handling |
| `browser.execute_js` | Dangerous | Arbitrary code execution |

---

## Agent Capabilities (Concrete Use Cases)

### Universal Web Access
- Navigate any allowlisted website
- Fill forms and submit data
- Extract structured data (scraping)
- Handle authentication flows
- Screenshot and visual verification
- PDF generation from web pages

### Automation Superpowers
- **Covers EVERY service without a dedicated connector**
- Handles legacy systems with only web UI
- Enables agents to do anything a human can do online
- Future-proof: works with any new website automatically

### Examples of Agent Workflows
```
"Log into this legacy system and export the report"
"Fill out this government form with the provided data"
"Screenshot the competitor pricing page daily"
"Extract product data from this e-commerce site"
"Complete this multi-step web workflow"
"Check if this website is accessible"
"Generate PDF invoice from this web portal"
```

---

## Flywheel Ecosystem Synergies

### ALL Other Connectors
**Universal fallback:**
- When no API exists, use browser
- Legacy system integration
- Complex web workflows

### Google AI/Vision Integration
- Screenshot → vision model analysis
- Visual understanding of pages
- Layout comprehension

### Vector DB Integration
- Scraped content → embeddings
- Web page indexing
- Content similarity search

### Agent Mail Integration
- Web form results → agent threads
- Screenshot reports
- Workflow status notifications

---

## Technical Implementation Notes

### Architecture
```
FCP Connector
      ↓
Browser Controller
      ↓
Chromium/Playwright
      ↓
Web (allowlisted hosts only)
```

### Recommended Crates
- `chromiumoxide` — Chrome DevTools Protocol
- `fantoccini` — WebDriver client
- `headless_chrome` — Chrome automation
- `image` — Screenshot handling

### Browser Options
| Engine | Recommendation |
|--------|----------------|
| Chromium | **Preferred** |
| Firefox | Supported |
| WebKit | Limited support |

### Security Hardening
- Browser runs with minimal permissions
- No extension installation
- Disk access disabled
- Network restricted to allowlist

---

## Zone Architecture

### Recommended Zones
| Zone | Description | Capabilities |
|------|-------------|--------------|
| `z:web:browser:allowlist` | Allowlisted sites | Navigate + extract |
| `z:web:browser:auth` | Auth-enabled | Can handle login |
| `z:web:browser:restricted` | Minimal | Screenshot only |

### Security Considerations
- EVERY navigated URL is adversarial
- Content extraction requires sanitization
- Form submission is high-risk
- JavaScript execution is DANGEROUS

---

## Manifest Archetypes (Closed Set)
- `operational` — Web interactions

---

## External Surface

### NetworkConstraints
Default-deny; DYNAMIC allowlist:
- Policy specifies permitted hosts
- No implicit wildcards
- Subdomain matching explicit

### Credential Injection
- Site credentials via egress proxy
- Session cookies managed securely
- Never persist login state

---

## Capability Model

### Navigation Operations
- `browser.navigate` — Load URL (allowlisted)
- `browser.back` / `browser.forward` — History navigation
- `browser.refresh` — Reload page

### Extraction Operations
- `browser.screenshot` — Capture page
- `browser.extract` — DOM extraction
- `browser.pdf` — Generate PDF

### Interaction Operations
- `browser.click` — Click element
- `browser.fill` — Fill form field
- `browser.submit` — Submit form (Dangerous)
- `browser.authenticate` — Login flow (Dangerous)

### Advanced Operations
- `browser.execute_js` — Run JavaScript (Dangerous)
- `browser.wait` — Wait for condition
- `browser.scroll` — Scroll page

---

## Operations (Representative)

### Navigate to URL
```json
{
  "operation": "browser.navigate",
  "url": "https://allowlisted-site.com/page",
  "wait_for": "networkidle"
}
```

### Take Screenshot
```json
{
  "operation": "browser.screenshot",
  "selector": "#main-content",
  "format": "png",
  "full_page": false
}
```

### Extract Data
```json
{
  "operation": "browser.extract",
  "selectors": {
    "title": "h1.title",
    "price": ".price-value",
    "description": ".product-desc"
  }
}
```

### Fill Form
```json
{
  "operation": "browser.fill",
  "fields": [
    {"selector": "#email", "value": "test@example.com"},
    {"selector": "#message", "value": "Hello"}
  ]
}
```

---

## Tests

### Unit Tests (Mock-Only)
- Command serialization
- Response parsing
- Selector validation
- Allowlist enforcement

### Integration Tests
- Mock browser responses
- Multi-step navigation
- Form interaction simulation
- Error handling

### E2E Compliance
- Validates NetworkConstraints (allowlist only)
- Dangerous operation approval flow
- Content taint propagation
- Audit logging

---

## Acceptance Criteria
- Passes connector compliance runner (static + dynamic)
- No real web navigation in unit tests
- URL allowlist enforced
- Screenshot capture functional
- DOM extraction works
- Form filling works
- JavaScript execution requires approval
- All V2 NORMATIVE requirements satisfied

# fcp.google-calendar - Google Calendar API Connector (FCP2)

## Goal
Provide an FCP2-compliant Google Calendar connector for scheduling and availability with strict zone isolation.

## Manifest archetypes (closed set)
- `operational`
- `streaming` (optional: watch/push or polling-driven event stream)

## Zone model
- Single-zone bound: one connector instance ↔ one `ZoneId`.
- Calendar data is private and sensitive; enforce strict capability gating.

## External surface
### NetworkConstraints
Default-deny; allow only Google Calendar API endpoints and OAuth refresh endpoints required by the configured auth mode.

### Credential injection
- OAuth tokens or service account credentials via `CredentialId`.

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `calendar.events.read` / `calendar.events.write`
- `calendar.freebusy.read`
- `calendar.calendars.read` / `calendar.calendars.write`
- `calendar.acl.manage` (Dangerous)
- `calendar.watch.manage` (Dangerous)

## Operations (representative)
- events CRUD + instances
- freebusy queries
- calendars + calendarlist
- ACL management (Dangerous)

## State model
- Persist syncToken cursor for incremental sync.
- Advance cursor under singleton-writer lease.

## Tests
- Mock-only unit/integration tests with wiremock.
- Deterministic syncToken simulation.
- E2E compliance run validates default deny + NetworkConstraints + cursor behavior.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Passes connector compliance runner.
- Deterministic tests; no live Calendar calls in unit tests.

title: [FCP2] fcp-cli: Developer + Operator CLI
CLI: fcp install (verify + mirror)
description:
# CLI: `fcp install` (verify + mirror)

## Goal
Implement `fcp install` as the user-facing entrypoint for installing a connector safely.

## Behavior
- Fetch or load a connector manifest + binary.
- Run the full verification chain (policy-controlled):
  - manifest signature(s)
  - binary checksum and signature
  - platform/arch compatibility
  - policy requirements (transparency/attestations when required)
- Mirror/pin connector objects into the mesh store for offline installs.
- Emit audit events describing what was installed (by object id).

## Output
- Human mode: concise success/failure.
- `--json` mode: machine-readable result including installed object ids.

## Tests
- Integration tests with a mock registry:
  - install success
  - bad signature rejected
  - checksum mismatch rejected
  - missing attestation rejected when policy requires
- Snapshot tests for `--json` output.

## Acceptance Criteria
- A connector cannot be installed if verification fails.
- CLI never prints secrets.
close_reason: Implemented fcp install command with full verification chain (stub), JSON output, and comprehensive tests. All 59 tests pass.

title: CLI: fcp doctor (freshness + degraded mode)
description:
# CLI: `fcp doctor` (freshness + degraded mode)

## Goal
Implement `fcp doctor --zone <zone>` to report the current safety posture of a zone.

## Behavior
Report, at minimum:
- latest pinned ZoneCheckpoint id + checkpoint_seq + age
- revocation/audit head freshness state
- whether the system is in degraded mode for this zone and why
- transport policy settings (DERP/Funnel allowed?)
- store coverage summary for key roots (checkpoint, policy heads)

## Output
- Human mode: clear OK/WARN/FAIL summary with reason codes.
- `--json` mode: full structured state for automation.

## Tests
- E2E harness scenarios:
  - fresh checkpoint -> OK
  - stale checkpoint -> WARN/FAIL depending on policy
  - missing checkpoint -> degraded mode report

## Acceptance Criteria
- Output is sufficient to decide whether Risky/Dangerous operations should be allowed.

title: CLI: fcp explain (DecisionReceipt renderer)
description:
# CLI: `fcp explain` (DecisionReceipt renderer)

## Goal
Implement `fcp explain --request <objectid>` to render the *mechanical evidence* behind an allow/deny.

## Behavior
- Load the DecisionReceipt for the request (or explain why it is missing).
- Render:
  - decision (allow/deny)
  - reason_code
  - evidence object ids and a short description of each (token, grants, checkpoint, approvals, policy head)
  - optional human message if present

## Output
- Human mode: readable explanation.
- `--json` mode: fully structured output for tooling.

## Tests
- Snapshot tests for representative deny reason codes.
- E2E: invoke a request that is denied and ensure `fcp explain` matches the DecisionReceipt.

## Acceptance Criteria
- A user can understand why a denial happened without guessing or disabling security.
close_reason: Implemented fcp explain command with human-readable and JSON output modes. Includes types, rendering, validation, demo data for testing, and 18 unit tests.

title: CLI: fcp new <name> (Connector scaffold + compliance precheck)
description:
# CLI: `fcp new <name>` (Connector scaffold + compliance precheck)

## Goal
Make it fast and safe to create a new **FCP2-compliant** connector crate by generating a correct skeleton (manifest + SDK surface + tests) and running mechanical prechecks.

## Context
We will build many connectors (Telegram, Discord, etc.). The highest leverage DX improvement is a generator that enforces:
- single-zone binding,
- default-deny NetworkConstraints,
- secretless operation by default (no secrets on disk; no logging secrets),
- structured JSON logging,
- unit test + E2E scaffolding,
- and a clear “what you must fill in” checklist.

This command is **developer tooling**. It must not weaken production security assumptions.

## Scope
In scope:
- Create a new connector crate with a minimal-but-correct FCP2 skeleton.
- Emit a default manifest with placeholder capabilities, sandbox profile, and NetworkConstraints.
- Emit placeholder operations and the correct receipts / error taxonomy wiring.
- Create deterministic unit test scaffolding and an E2E script skeleton.
- Run mechanical validation checks and print actionable diagnostics.

Out of scope:
- Any compatibility shim for legacy FCP1 protocols.
- Generating real credentials or storing secrets.

## Command UX (proposal)

### Basic usage
```bash
fcp new fcp.myservice
```

### Optional flags
- `--archetype request-response|streaming|bidirectional|polling|webhook|queue|file|database|cli|browser`
- `--zone z:project:<name>` (default: `z:project:default` or prompt)
- `--no-e2e` (if generating only unit test scaffolding)
- `--dry-run` (print planned files without writing)
- `--check` (validate an existing connector directory)

### Outputs
- Prints:
  - created file list
  - next steps
  - compliance precheck results (pass/fail with reasons)
- Supports `--json` output like the rest of `fcp-cli`.

## Skeleton contents (must generate)

### 1) Cargo crate
- Path: `connectors/<name>/`
- Library crate (or bin, depending on repo conventions) with:
  - minimal `Cargo.toml`
  - dependency on `fcp-sdk`
  - `#![forbid(unsafe_code)]`

### 2) Manifest
Generate an initial FCP2 manifest that is:
- syntactically valid TOML
- references:
  - connector id
  - version
  - zone binding (single-zone)
  - capabilities list
  - sandbox profile
  - NetworkConstraints (default deny)

### 3) Operations + schemas
- Provide placeholder operations that demonstrate:
  - typed input/output schemas
  - error taxonomy usage (FCP-XXXX)
  - receipt emission
  - tracing fields (`correlation_id`, `zone_id`, `connector_id`, `operation_id`)

### 4) Tests
- Unit test scaffold:
  - a “happy path” operation test using a mock transport
  - negative tests for missing capability / denied NetworkConstraints
  - redaction test: assert secrets are never logged

- E2E scaffold:
  - a script or harness integration that:
    - installs the connector
    - invokes an operation
    - verifies DecisionReceipt / AuditEvent shape
    - exercises default-deny failure path

## Mechanical prechecks (must run)
At creation time (and for `--check`), run:
- Manifest validation
- Connector compliance checklist (structure + fields)
- NetworkConstraints default-deny invariant
- “no secrets on disk” lint (no examples with plaintext tokens)

These checks should reuse the platform’s mechanical compliance runner where possible.

## Acceptance Criteria
- `fcp new <name>` creates a connector skeleton that builds in the workspace.
- Generated connector starts V2-only and includes no FCP1 language or compatibility shims.
- Generated manifest includes single-zone binding + default-deny NetworkConstraints.
- Generated tests include at least:
  - happy path
  - default deny
  - redaction
- `fcp new --check` produces actionable diagnostics and supports `--json`.

title: fcp.reddit: Messaging
description:
# fcp.reddit: Messaging (FCP2)

## Goal
Support Reddit inbox and direct messaging to enable:
- receiving replies/mentions
- sending messages to users (when permitted)

Messaging is privacy sensitive.

## Scope
- Fetch inbox (unread, mentions, messages) with pagination.
- Mark as read (optional; dangerous-ish).
- Send a message.

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `reddit.messages.read`
- `reddit.messages.send` (dangerous)

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- NetworkConstraints pinned.
- PII hygiene:
  - never log message bodies or usernames
- For sends:
  - receipts + audit events include recipient hash + message id

## Deliverables
- Operation schemas:
  - `reddit.inbox.list`
  - `reddit.inbox.unread.list`
  - `reddit.message.send`
  - Optional: `reddit.inbox.mark_read`

## Test strategy (MUST)
- Mock-only tests for:
  - pagination
  - send request formation
  - redaction
  - audit/receipt on send

## Acceptance criteria
- Messaging operations are safe, auditable, and privacy-preserving.
