title: fcp.twilio: Verify 2FA authentication service
description:
# fcp.twilio: Verify 2FA authentication service (FCP2)

## Goal
Expose Twilio Verify to support 2FA/verification workflows:
- send verification codes
- check verification codes

This surface is security-sensitive and must be tightly capability scoped.

## Scope
- Create a verification (send code via SMS/call/etc).
- Check a verification (validate code).
- Optional: cancel verification.

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `twilio.verify.send` (dangerous-ish: sends messages)
- `twilio.verify.check` (auth-sensitive)
- Optional: `twilio.verify.cancel`

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- NetworkConstraints pinned.
- PII hygiene:
  - phone numbers are sensitive (never log)
  - verification codes are secrets (never log)
- For sends:
  - receipts/audit events include verification SID and destination hash only

## Deliverables
- Operation schemas:
  - `twilio.verify.send`
  - `twilio.verify.check`
  - Optional: `twilio.verify.cancel`
- Strict validation:
  - code length/format
  - channel allowlist

## Test strategy (MUST)
- Mock-only tests for:
  - send/check flows
  - redaction (no codes/numbers in logs)
  - error mapping (invalid code, expired, rate limited)

## Acceptance criteria
- Verify operations are mechanically authorized, safe, and do not leak secrets.

title: fcp.sentry: Issue assignment and status management
description:
# fcp.sentry: Issue assignment and status management (FCP2)

## Goal
Allow safe, auditable manipulation of Sentry issue workflow state:
- assign/unassign
- resolve/unresolve
- ignore/unignore
- set priority (if supported)

These are write operations that can affect on-call workflows.

## Scope
### Write operations
- `sentry.issue.assign`
- `sentry.issue.resolve`
- `sentry.issue.ignore`
- `sentry.issue.update_priority`

### Read support
- fetch minimal issue metadata required for optimistic concurrency (if available).

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `sentry.issues.write`

Policy guidance:
- Some orgs may require approvals for resolving/ignoring issues.

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- NetworkConstraints pinned.
- For every write:
  - emit OperationReceipt + AuditEvent
  - include issue id + action + correlation id
  - never include raw issue payloads in logs

## Deliverables
- Operation schemas:
  - `sentry.issue.assign`
  - `sentry.issue.set_status` (resolve/ignore/unresolve)
  - `sentry.issue.set_priority`
- Denial reason codes for policy engine.

## Test strategy (MUST)
- Mock-only tests for:
  - capability gating
  - approval gating (when policy requires)
  - error mapping (permission denied, conflict)
  - audit/receipt emission

## Acceptance criteria
- Issue workflow actions are safe, explainable, and auditable.

title: fcp.gmail: Google Gmail API Connector
description:
# fcp.gmail - Gmail API Connector (FCP2)

## Goal
Provide an FCP2-compliant Gmail connector for email automation with strict zone isolation, sandboxing, and mechanical authorization.

## Manifest archetypes (closed set)
- `operational`
- `streaming` (optional: watch/push or polling-driven event stream)

## Zone model

<!-- fcp2-single-zone-note -->
**FCP2 single-zone binding note:** A connector instance binds to exactly one `ZoneId` for its entire lifetime.
The *"zones"* described in this section are a **recommended deployment pattern** (run separate connector instances in separate zones with different capability grants/policies) and/or conceptual risk tiers.
The connector MUST NOT multiplex multiple zones internally.

- Single-zone bound: one connector instance ↔ one `ZoneId`.
- Recommended: `z:private:gmail:<account>` (policy-owned naming).

## External surface
### NetworkConstraints
Default-deny; allow only the Gmail/Google API endpoints required by:
- Gmail API
- OAuth token refresh (if used by the OAuth library)

### Credential injection
- OAuth2 refresh/access tokens via `CredentialId`.
- Never persist tokens to disk.

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `gmail.messages.read`
- `gmail.messages.send`
- `gmail.messages.modify` (labels/trash)
- `gmail.threads.read` / `gmail.threads.modify`
- `gmail.labels.manage`
- `gmail.settings.manage` (Dangerous)

## Operations (representative)
- messages: get/list/send/reply/forward/modify/trash/delete
- threads: get/list/modify/trash
- labels: list/create/update/delete
- drafts: create/get/list/update/send/delete

## Eventing (optional)
If we support push/watch:
- connector must not expose inbound ports directly
- integrate through `fcp-host` controlled ingress (or deterministic polling)

## State model
- Stateless for simple reads.
- For incremental sync (historyId), persist cursor in connector state and advance under a singleton-writer lease.

## Tests
- Mock-only unit/integration tests with wiremock.
- Deterministic historyId/poll simulation.
- E2E compliance run validates default deny + NetworkConstraints + state/cursor behavior.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Passes connector compliance runner.
- Deterministic tests; no live Gmail calls in unit tests.

fcp.kubernetes: ConfigMap and Secret management
description:
# fcp.kubernetes: ConfigMap and Secret management (FCP2)

## Goal
Provide safe management of configuration resources:
- ConfigMaps
- Secrets (with strict redaction)

## Scope
### Read
- Get/list ConfigMaps.
- Get/list Secret metadata.
  - default: do not return secret values unless explicitly requested and authorized

### Write (dangerous)
- Create/update ConfigMaps.
- Create/update Secrets (critical).
- Delete (policy-controlled; often forbidden in prod).

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `k8s.configmaps.read`
- `k8s.configmaps.write` (dangerous)
- `k8s.secrets.read` (sensitive)
- `k8s.secrets.write` (critical)

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- NetworkConstraints pinned.
- Secret hygiene:
  - never log secret values
  - default to returning key names only
  - require explicit capability and approval for secret value reads/writes
- Receipts/audit for all mutations.

## Deliverables
- Operation schemas:
  - `k8s.configmap.get/list/apply/delete`
  - `k8s.secret.get_metadata/list`
  - Optional (policy-gated): `k8s.secret.get_values`
  - `k8s.secret.apply/delete`

## Test strategy (MUST)
- Mock-only tests for:
  - redaction behavior
  - approval gating for secret operations
  - audit/receipt emission

## Acceptance criteria
- Secrets are protected by default and cannot leak through logs.

title: fcp.homeassistant
description:
# fcp.homeassistant - Home Automation Platform Connector (FCP2)

## Goal
Deliver the FCP2 Home Assistant connector epic plan for safe smart-home automation with strict zone-based safety gating and auditable actuation.

## Zone model (mechanical)

<!-- fcp2-single-zone-note -->
**FCP2 single-zone binding note:** A connector instance binds to exactly one `ZoneId` for its entire lifetime.
The connector MUST NOT multiplex multiple zones internally.

Recommended deployment pattern: run separate connector instances in separate zones with different capability grants/policies.

## Strategic Context

### Value Assessment
**Strategic Value Score: 74/100** — Specialized Tier 3 connector (IoT/Home Automation family).

**Why Critical**: Home Assistant is the **leading open-source home automation platform**, with 500K+ active installations. Enables agents to control smart home devices, automate routines, and integrate physical world with digital workflows. Unique capability for personal productivity agents.

### Priority Matrix Position
- **Category**: Specialized Investment (IoT + Personal Automation)
- **Build Phase**: Phase 4 Advanced (weeks 13+)

---

## Agent Capabilities (Concrete Use Cases)

### Device Control
- Turn devices on/off
- Adjust settings (brightness, temperature)
- Trigger scenes
- Lock/unlock doors

### State Monitoring
- Read sensor values
- Track device states
- Monitor energy usage
- Get climate data

### Automation Management
- Trigger automations
- Enable/disable automations
- Read automation history
- Manage schedules

### Examples of Agent Workflows
```
"Turn off all lights in the house"
"What's the temperature in the living room?"
"Set the thermostat to 72°F"
"Lock the front door"
"Start the 'Movie Time' scene"
"Is the garage door closed?"
"Turn on office lights at 9am"
"Alert me if motion detected while away"
```

---

## Flywheel Ecosystem Synergies

### Calendar Integration
**Time-aware automation:**
- Calendar events → home state changes
- "Meeting mode" activations
- Presence-based scheduling

### Agent Mail Integration
- Home alerts → agent notifications
- Coordinate with family members
- Security event escalation

### Twilio Integration
- SMS alerts for security events
- Voice notifications
- Emergency contact automation

### Weather API Integration
- Weather-based automations
- Climate control optimization
- Energy efficiency

### Spotify Integration
- Music as part of scenes
- Voice-controlled playback
- Mood-based automation

---

## Technical Implementation Notes

### API Surface
- **REST API** — Full device control
- **WebSocket API** — Real-time state updates
- **Long-lived Access Tokens** — Authentication

### Recommended Crates
- `reqwest` — HTTP client
- `tokio-tungstenite` — WebSocket client
- `serde_json` — JSON handling

### Entity Model
```
Domain.entity_id = service target
Examples:
  light.living_room
  switch.coffee_maker
  climate.thermostat
  lock.front_door
  sensor.temperature
  binary_sensor.motion
```

### Service Calls
```json
POST /api/services/{domain}/{service}
{
  "entity_id": "light.living_room",
  "brightness": 255,
  "color_temp": 400
}
```

---

## Zone Architecture

### Recommended Zones
| Zone | Description | Capabilities |
|------|-------------|--------------|
| `z:home:ha:full` | Full access | All devices and services |
| `z:home:ha:readonly` | Read-only | State monitoring only |
| `z:home:ha:lights` | Lights only | Light control |
| `z:home:ha:climate` | Climate only | Thermostat control |
| `z:home:ha:security` | Security | Locks, alarms, cameras |

### Safety Tiers
- **Lights/Media**: Low risk — comfort only
- **Climate**: Medium risk — affects comfort/cost
- **Locks/Security**: High risk — physical safety
- **Garage/Entry**: Very high risk — security critical

---

## Manifest Archetypes (Closed Set)
- `operational` — REST API operations
- `streaming` — WebSocket state subscriptions

---

## External Surface

### NetworkConstraints
Self-hosted platform:
- Local: `homeassistant.local:8123` or IP
- Remote: Nabu Casa (*.ui.nabu.casa:443)

### Credential Injection
- Long-lived access token via `CredentialId`
- Never write credentials to disk

---

## Capability Model

### Read Operations
- `ha.states.read` — Get entity states
- `ha.history.read` — Historical data
- `ha.config.read` — Configuration info
- `ha.automations.read` — Automation list

### Write Operations
- `ha.services.call` — Call any service
- `ha.lights.control` — Light operations
- `ha.climate.control` — Thermostat control
- `ha.switches.control` — Switch operations
- `ha.scenes.activate` — Trigger scenes

### Security Operations (Dangerous)
- `ha.locks.control` — Lock/unlock
- `ha.covers.control` — Garage doors, blinds
- `ha.alarms.control` — Arm/disarm

### Administrative (Dangerous)
- `ha.automations.manage` — Enable/disable automations
- `ha.scripts.execute` — Run scripts

---

## Operations (Representative)

### Get All States
```json
GET /api/states
```

Response:
```json
[{
  "entity_id": "light.living_room",
  "state": "on",
  "attributes": {
    "brightness": 200,
    "color_temp": 400,
    "friendly_name": "Living Room Light"
  },
  "last_changed": "2024-01-15T10:30:00Z"
}]
```

### Get Single Entity State
```json
GET /api/states/{entity_id}
```

### Call Service
```json
POST /api/services/light/turn_on
{
  "entity_id": "light.living_room",
  "brightness_pct": 75,
  "transition": 2
}
```

### Common Services
| Domain | Service | Effect |
|--------|---------|--------|
| light | turn_on/turn_off | Light control |
| switch | turn_on/turn_off | Switch control |
| climate | set_temperature | Thermostat |
| lock | lock/unlock | Door locks |
| scene | turn_on | Activate scene |
| automation | trigger | Run automation |

### WebSocket Subscription
```json
{"type": "subscribe_events", "event_type": "state_changed"}
```

---

## Safety Considerations

### Physical Safety
- Lock/security operations require confirmation
- Emergency contacts for critical alerts
- Fail-safe defaults for security devices

### Privacy
- Camera feeds are highly sensitive
- Motion data reveals presence patterns
- Energy data reveals behavior

### Rate Limiting
- Local API generally unlimited
- Don't spam device commands
- Respect device response times

---

## Tests

### Unit Tests (Mock-Only)
- Service call construction
- State parsing
- Entity ID validation
- WebSocket message handling

### Integration Tests
- Mock Home Assistant server
- State change scenarios
- Service call verification

### E2E Compliance
- Validates NetworkConstraints
- Security operation logging
- Audit trail for all commands

---

## Acceptance Criteria
- Passes connector compliance runner (static + dynamic)
- No real HA calls in unit tests
- State reading works
- Service calls functional
- WebSocket subscription works
- Security operations require confirmation
- Proper entity ID validation

## Success Criteria
- Connector epic is fully decomposed into implementable beads (manifest/cap map, provisioning, operations, tests, E2E compliance).
- All child beads are implemented and closed, and the connector passes the mechanical compliance runner + its E2E scenarios with structured JSON logs.
- Mechanical guarantees hold: single-zone binding, default-deny capabilities, and NetworkConstraints enforcement; no secret/PII leakage in logs.

title: fcp.kubernetes: Resource CRUD for pods, deployments, and services
description:
# fcp.kubernetes: Resource CRUD for pods, deployments, and services (FCP2)

## Goal
Provide safe, typed CRUD for core Kubernetes resources:
- pods
- deployments
- services

## Scope
### Read
- Get/list resources with namespace scoping and label selectors.

### Write (dangerous)
- Create/update resources.
- Delete resources (policy-controlled; often forbidden in prod).
- Scale deployments.

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `k8s.read`
- `k8s.write` (dangerous)
- `k8s.delete` (critical)
- `k8s.deploy.scale` (dangerous-ish)

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- NetworkConstraints pinned to the cluster API server host.
- Namespace isolation:
  - operations must enforce namespace allowlists
- For mutations:
  - receipts + audit events include kind/namespace/name + action

## Deliverables
- Operation schemas:
  - `k8s.pod.get/list/create/delete`
  - `k8s.deployment.get/list/apply/scale/delete`
  - `k8s.service.get/list/apply/delete`

## Test strategy (MUST)
- Mock-only tests for:
  - namespace allowlist enforcement
  - apply/patch correctness
  - deny-by-default deletes in prod policy

## Acceptance criteria
- CRUD operations are safe-by-default, policy-driven, and auditable.

title: fcp.twilio: Communication Infrastructure Connector (SMS, Voice, WhatsApp)
description:
# fcp.twilio - Communication Infrastructure Connector (FCP2)

## Success Criteria
- `flywheel_connectors-otqy.1` (Manifest + Capability Map) is complete and passes static validation (IDs, schemas, NetworkConstraints, safety tiers).
- `flywheel_connectors-otqy.2` (Provisioning Automation) is complete, minimizes human prompts, and is fully mockable for tests.
- `flywheel_connectors-otqy.3` (Unit/Integration Tests) are mock-only, include success + denial paths, and assert log redaction (no secrets/PII).
- `flywheel_connectors-otqy.4` (E2E Compliance Run) passes the shared compliance runner and emits an evidence bundle (logs + receipts + audit checks).
- Connector is V2-only: single-zone binding, default deny, constrained egress, audited risky/dangerous ops.

## Strategic Context

### Value Assessment
**Strategic Value Score: 88/100** — High priority Tier 2 connector.

**Why Critical**: Twilio is the **dominant programmable communications platform**. Enables agents to communicate via SMS, voice calls, and WhatsApp — essential for customer-facing automation, alerting, and multi-channel engagement workflows.

### Priority Matrix Position
- **Category**: Strategic Investment (High Value + Communication Infrastructure)
- **Build Phase**: Phase 2 Productivity (weeks 5-8)

---

## V2 Specification Compliance (NORMATIVE)

### ConnectorArchetype
```rust
archetypes: vec\![
    ConnectorArchetype::Bidirectional,  // Send/receive messages
    ConnectorArchetype::Operational,    // Call initiation, config
    ConnectorArchetype::Streaming,      // Webhook events
]
```
- **Bidirectional**: SMS/WhatsApp send and receive
- **Operational**: Voice calls, TwiML, phone numbers
- **Streaming**: Webhooks for delivery status, inbound messages

### ConnectorStateModel
```rust
state_model: ConnectorStateModel::SingletonWriter
```
- **SingletonWriter**: Message delivery tracking, call state
- State tracked: `{ pending_messages: HashMap<MessageSid, Status>, call_state: HashMap<CallSid, CallState> }`
- Lease required for writer fencing

### ConnectorFormat
```rust
format: ConnectorFormat::Wasi
```
- **WASI recommended**: Handles API credentials, PII (phone numbers)
- Memory isolation for credential protection
- Capability-gated hostcalls

### NetworkConstraints (NORMATIVE)
```rust
NetworkConstraints {
    // Twilio API endpoints
    host_allow: vec\![
        "api.twilio.com".into(),
        "verify.twilio.com".into(),
        "lookups.twilio.com".into(),
        // Media URLs for MMS
        "api.twilio.com/2010-04-01/Accounts/*/Messages/*/Media/*".into(),
    ],
    port_allow: vec\![443],
    deny_localhost: true,
    deny_private_ranges: true,
    deny_tailnet_ranges: true,
    deny_ip_literals: true,
    require_sni: true,
    require_host_canonicalization: true,
}
```

### TaintFlags (NORMATIVE)
```rust
// Inbound messages are external/adversarial
inbound_message.provenance.taint = TaintFlags::EXTERNAL_INPUT
    | TaintFlags::PROMPT_SURFACE
    | TaintFlags::USER_SUPPLIED;

// Phone numbers are PII - handle carefully
phone_number.provenance.taint = TaintFlags::USER_SUPPLIED;

// Outbound content may contain user data
outbound_message.provenance.taint = TaintFlags::USER_SUPPLIED;
```

### SafetyTier per Operation
| Operation | SafetyTier | Rationale |
|-----------|------------|-----------|
| `twilio.messages.read` | Risky | Contains PII |
| `twilio.calls.read` | Risky | Call history |
| `twilio.lookups.phone` | Risky | Phone number info |
| `twilio.messages.send` | Dangerous | External communication |
| `twilio.calls.initiate` | Dangerous | Real-world call |
| `twilio.verify.send` | Dangerous | Sends verification |
| `twilio.numbers.purchase` | Dangerous | Financial transaction |
| `twilio.numbers.release` | Dangerous | Releases resource |

---

## Agent Capabilities (Concrete Use Cases)

### SMS Operations
- Send individual and bulk SMS messages
- Receive and process inbound SMS
- MMS with media attachments
- Short code and toll-free support

### Voice Calls
- Initiate outbound calls
- TwiML for call flow control
- Conference calling
- Call recording and transcription

### WhatsApp Business
- Send template messages
- Handle conversations
- Media messages

### Verification
- Send verification codes
- Phone number validation
- 2FA support

### Examples of Agent Workflows
```
"Send an SMS alert to the on-call engineer"
"Notify customers about their order status"
"Initiate a call to this number"
"Verify this phone number"
"Send a WhatsApp message with the invoice"
"Check delivery status of sent messages"
```

---

## Flywheel Ecosystem Synergies

### Stripe Integration
**Payment notifications:**
- SMS receipts
- Payment failure alerts
- Subscription reminders

### Sentry/Datadog Integration
- Alert escalation via SMS/call
- On-call notifications
- Incident updates

### Agent Mail Integration
- SMS threads → agent mail
- Voice transcripts
- Delivery confirmations

### HubSpot Integration
- Customer communication tracking
- Contact engagement

---

## Technical Implementation Notes

### API Surface
- **REST API**: Primary interface
- **TwiML**: Voice call scripting
- **Webhooks**: Event delivery

### Recommended Crates
- `twilio-rs` — Twilio API client
- `reqwest` — HTTP client
- `hmac` / `sha1` — Webhook validation

### Authentication
```rust
// Basic auth with Account SID and Auth Token
Authorization: Basic {base64(account_sid:auth_token)}
```

### Rate Limits
```rust
RateLimits {
    sms_per_second: 1,      // Per phone number
    mps_rate: 400,          // High-throughput
    api_requests: 100,      // Per second
}
```

---

## Zone Architecture

### Recommended Zones
| Zone | Description | Capabilities |
|------|-------------|--------------|
| `z:comm:twilio:full` | Full access | All operations |
| `z:comm:twilio:sms` | SMS only | Message send/receive |
| `z:comm:twilio:voice` | Voice only | Call operations |
| `z:comm:twilio:readonly` | Read-only | Status checks |

### Security Considerations
- Phone numbers are PII
- Never log full phone numbers
- Message content is sensitive
- Audit all sends

---

## Manifest Archetypes (Closed Set)
- `bidirectional` — SMS/WhatsApp send/receive
- `operational` — Voice calls, configuration
- `streaming` — Webhook events

---

## External Surface

### NetworkConstraints
Default-deny; allow only:
- `api.twilio.com:443`
- `verify.twilio.com:443`
- `lookups.twilio.com:443`

### Credential Injection
- Account SID + Auth Token via egress proxy
- API keys for limited access
- Webhook validation secret

---

## Capability Model

### Messaging Operations
- `twilio.messages.send` — Send SMS/MMS (Dangerous)
- `twilio.messages.read` — Get message status (Risky)
- `twilio.whatsapp.send` — Send WhatsApp (Dangerous)

### Voice Operations
- `twilio.calls.initiate` — Start call (Dangerous)
- `twilio.calls.read` — Call status (Risky)
- `twilio.calls.update` — Modify call

### Verification Operations
- `twilio.verify.send` — Send code (Dangerous)
- `twilio.verify.check` — Verify code
- `twilio.lookups.phone` — Phone lookup (Risky)

### Admin Operations
- `twilio.numbers.purchase` — Buy number (Dangerous)
- `twilio.numbers.release` — Release number (Dangerous)

---

## Operations (Representative)

### Send SMS
```json
POST /2010-04-01/Accounts/{AccountSid}/Messages
{
  "To": "+1234567890",
  "From": "+0987654321",
  "Body": "Your order has shipped\!"
}
```

### Initiate Call
```json
POST /2010-04-01/Accounts/{AccountSid}/Calls
{
  "To": "+1234567890",
  "From": "+0987654321",
  "Url": "https://example.com/twiml/welcome"
}
```

### Send Verification
```json
POST /v2/Services/{ServiceSid}/Verifications
{
  "To": "+1234567890",
  "Channel": "sms"
}
```

---

## Log Redaction (NORMATIVE)
```rust
// NEVER log full phone numbers
log_phone("+1234567890") → "+1***890"

// NEVER log message content in full
log_message("Hello world") → "Hello ***"

// NEVER log auth tokens
log_token("SK123...") → "SK***"
```

---

## Tests

### Unit Tests (Mock-Only)
- Request construction
- Response parsing
- Webhook signature validation
- Phone number formatting

### Integration Tests
- Mock Twilio API responses
- Multi-channel workflows
- Error handling

### E2E Compliance
- Validates NetworkConstraints
- Dangerous operation approval flow
- Log redaction verification
- Audit logging

---

## Acceptance Criteria
- Passes connector compliance runner (static + dynamic)
- No real Twilio API calls in unit tests
- SMS send/receive works
- Voice call initiation works
- Webhook handling functional
- Phone number redaction in logs
- All V2 NORMATIVE requirements satisfied

title: fcp.twilio: Manifest + Capability Map (FCP2)
description:
# fcp.twilio: Manifest + Capability Map (FCP2)

## Goal
Define the Twilio connector’s **mechanical manifest contract** so it can be sandboxed, authorized, and tested deterministically under FCP2.

## Required contents
- Manifest archetypes (closed set):
  - `operational` (send messages / create calls / manage resources)
  - `streaming` (webhook/event ingestion; optional media streaming)
  - `bidirectional` (two-way messaging/voice flows)
- Operation list + schema IDs.
- Capability families + per-operation required caps.
- NetworkConstraints:
  - allow Twilio API host(s) and webhook signature validation surface
  - explicitly enumerate/pin any media/recording download hosts
  - HTTPS-only; deny redirects by default
- State model declaration:
  - webhook subscription state (if any)
  - message/event idempotency keys (if persisted)

## Output artifacts
- Complete manifest spec stored in this bead.
- Good/bad manifest examples for static compliance (especially NetworkConstraints + dangerous ops).

## Acceptance Criteria
- Another engineer can implement `--manifest` from this bead alone.
- Static compliance can reject:
  - capability IDs that embed hostnames/ports
  - overly-broad NetworkConstraints

title: fcp.twilio: Provisioning Automation (auth, webhooks, numbers)
description:
# fcp.twilio: Provisioning Automation (auth, webhooks, numbers)

## Goal
Automate Twilio onboarding with **minimal human steps** while keeping all secrets zone-scoped and never written to disk.

## Requirements
- Supported auth strategies (policy-owned):
  - Account SID + Auth Token (`CredentialId`)
  - API Key + API Secret (`CredentialId`)
  - Subaccount support (optional)
- Webhook setup automation:
  - configure inbound SMS webhook endpoints
  - configure voice webhook endpoints (TwiML / status callbacks)
  - validate webhook signature verification configuration
- Number configuration automation:
  - list owned numbers
  - configure number webhook URLs
  - purchasing numbers is **dangerous** and must be explicitly capability + approval gated

## Safety rules
- Validate credentials using safe read-only calls.
- Validate NetworkConstraints pinning before declaring connector “ready”.
- Never log or echo secrets.

## Acceptance Criteria
- `fcp doctor` can verify readiness (auth + webhook reachability) without leaking secrets.
- Fully mockable for unit tests (no real Twilio calls in CI).

title: TEST: Twilio Connector Unit/Integration Tests (mock-only)
description:
# TEST: Twilio Connector Unit/Integration Tests (mock-only)

## Goal
Provide comprehensive mock-only tests for Twilio connector behavior, with structured JSON logs suitable for debugging and compliance evidence.

## Requirements
- No real external API calls in unit/integration tests.
- Use mock HTTP servers for Twilio REST API + webhook callbacks.
- Test coverage must include:
  - auth header formation (multiple auth modes)
  - request/response parsing
  - idempotency behavior for sends
  - webhook signature validation
  - rate limit handling + retry/backoff
  - dangerous operations require ApprovalToken (purchase numbers, delete recordings, etc.)

## Acceptance Criteria
- Tests are deterministic and run in CI.
- Logs include correlation_id and stable reason codes for denial paths.

title: E2E: Twilio Connector Compliance Run
description:
# E2E: Twilio Connector Compliance Run

## Goal
Run the shared Mechanical Connector Compliance Runner against fcp.twilio and capture evidence artifacts.

## What this must verify
- Default deny: all operations require explicit CapabilityTokens.
- NetworkConstraints enforcement (deny unexpected egress).
- Receipts + audit events produced for all writes/dangerous ops.
- Structured logs:
  - JSON
  - correlation IDs
  - reason codes

## Evidence artifacts
- Runner output bundle (logs + decision receipts + manifest validation report).
- A minimal “happy path” scenario set:
  - send SMS (mock)
  - receive webhook (mock)
  - denied send without capability
  - denied dangerous op without approval

## Acceptance Criteria
- Compliance runner is green for fcp.twilio.
- Failures are explainable and actionable from logs alone.

title: fcp.sentry: Alert rule configuration and management
description:
# fcp.sentry: Alert rule configuration and management (FCP2)

## Goal
Provide controlled access to Sentry alert rule configuration so agents can help maintain:
- issue alerts
- performance alerts
- notification routing

This is **dangerous** (high blast radius). Must be approval-gated by policy.

## Scope
### Read
- List alert rules (project/org scope where available).
- Get rule definition + current enabled/disabled state.

### Write (dangerous)
- Create/update/delete alert rules.
- Enable/disable rule.

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `sentry.alerts.read`
- `sentry.alerts.write` (dangerous; requires approval)

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- NetworkConstraints pinned.
- For any write:
  - require ApprovalToken when policy dictates (recommended default)
  - emit OperationReceipt + AuditEvent with:
    - rule id
    - structural hash of rule definition
    - correlation id

## Deliverables
- Operation schemas:
  - `sentry.alert.list`
  - `sentry.alert.get`
  - `sentry.alert.create`
  - `sentry.alert.update`
  - `sentry.alert.enable`
  - `sentry.alert.disable`
  - `sentry.alert.delete`
- Safe rule templates:
  - avoid arbitrary code/script injection
  - prefer constrained rule DSL + parameterization

## Test strategy (MUST)
- Mock-only tests for:
  - CRUD flows
  - validation failures
  - approval gating
  - audit/receipt emission

## Acceptance criteria
- Alert rule changes are mechanically gated, auditable, and reversible.

title: TEST: Rate Limiting Unit Tests (ThrottleViolation, Backpressure, Quota Enforcement)
description:
# TEST: Rate Limiting Unit Tests


## Goal
Validate rate limiting / backpressure behaviors (quota, throttling, time-bounds) are correct and produce explainable denials.

## Scope
Comprehensive tests for rate limiting and quota enforcement.

## Test Categories

### ThrottleViolation Detection
- [ ] Requests exceeding rate produce ThrottleViolation
- [ ] Violation includes retry_after_ms
- [ ] Violation includes quota details
- [ ] Violation is logged to audit

### Backpressure Signals
- [ ] Backpressure signal sent when approaching limit
- [ ] Client respects backpressure hint
- [ ] Gradual backoff before hard rejection
- [ ] Backpressure clears when load drops

### Quota Enforcement
- [ ] Per-connector quotas enforced
- [ ] Per-zone quotas enforced
- [ ] Per-operation quotas enforced
- [ ] Quota reset on time window
- [ ] Quota pooling across operations

### Burst Handling
- [ ] Token bucket allows bursts
- [ ] Burst capacity is configurable
- [ ] Burst doesn't exceed hard limits
- [ ] Burst refill rate is correct

### Distributed Rate Limiting
- [ ] Quotas shared across mesh nodes
- [ ] Quota sync is eventually consistent
- [ ] No double-spending on quota
- [ ] Partition handling for quotas

## Golden Vectors
Location: `tests/vectors/rate_limiting/`
- `throttle_violation.cbor`
- `backpressure_signal.cbor`
- `quota_state.cbor`

## Logging Requirements
```json
{
  "timestamp": "RFC3339",
  "test_name": "test_quota_enforcement",
  "phase": "execute",
  "correlation_id": "uuid",
  "connector_id": "...",
  "quota_used": 95,
  "quota_limit": 100,
  "throttled": false,
  "result": "pass"
}
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- Rate limits are enforced correctly
- Quotas prevent resource exhaustion
- Audit trail for all throttle events
close_reason: Completed: Added 19 comprehensive rate limiting unit tests covering ThrottleViolation detection, backpressure signals, per-zone/connector/operation quota enforcement, burst handling, and concurrency limiting. All tests pass against current fcp-ratelimit implementation.

title: fcp.anthropic - Anthropic AI Provider Connector
description:
# FCP Anthropic Connector - Anthropic AI Provider (LEGACY / SUPERSEDED)

> NOTE (2026-01-15): This bead predates the current **FCP2 connector model** and is kept only for historical context of an earlier prototype.
> 
> The active, FCP2-compliant Anthropic plan is: `flywheel_connectors-lszk.4` (and its child beads). Use that as the source of truth.

## Overview
A comprehensive connector for Anthropic's Claude API, enabling agents to leverage Claude models for complex reasoning, tool use, vision capabilities, and batch processing with built-in usage tracking and budget enforcement.

## Priority: P1 (Critical Infrastructure)

## Core Capabilities

### 1. Messages API
- Send messages to Claude models
- Streaming responses for real-time output
- Multi-turn conversations
- System prompts
- Model selection (claude-opus-4-5-20251101, claude-sonnet-4-20250514, claude-haiku, etc.)
- Temperature and sampling controls
- Max tokens configuration
- Stop sequences

### 2. Tool Use Support
- Define tools with JSON schema
- Handle tool_use responses
- Execute tools and return results
- Multi-tool conversations
- Parallel tool execution
- Tool choice forcing (auto, any, specific)

### 3. Vision Capabilities
- Images in prompts (base64 or URL)
- Multiple images per message
- Image analysis and description
- Document/screenshot understanding
- Chart and diagram interpretation

### 4. Prompt Caching
- Cache system prompts
- Cache large context documents
- Cache tool definitions
- Automatic cache management
- Cache hit/miss tracking
- Usage/cost savings can be computed from tracked usage deltas

### 5. Batch API
- Submit batch requests
- Track batch status
- Retrieve batch results
- Cancel batches
- Batch pricing can change; treat billing as provider- or policy-owned (do not hardcode discounts)

### 6. Usage Tracking & Budget Enforcement
- Per-request usage calculation (tokens, images, audio seconds, etc.)
- Running total tracking
- Budget limits per agent/session/day
- Alerts at thresholds
- Automatic cutoff at budget limit
- Usage attribution and reporting

## FCP Integration

### Manifest Structure
```toml
[connector]
name = "fcp.anthropic"
version = "0.1.0"
description = "Anthropic Claude API integration with usage tracking"

[capabilities]
messages = { risk = "medium", description = "Send messages to Claude" }
streaming = { risk = "medium", description = "Stream responses" }
tool_use = { risk = "medium", description = "Use tools in conversations" }
vision = { risk = "medium", description = "Process images" }
batch = { risk = "low", description = "Submit batch requests" }

[trust_zones]
default = "z:ai:inference"

[resources]
rate_limit_rpm = 1000
rate_limit_tpm = 100000
default_timeout_ms = 120000

[billing]
track_costs = true
budget_enforcement = true
```

### Tool Definitions
```yaml
tools:
  - name: anthropic_message
    description: Send a message to Claude
    parameters:
      model:
        type: string
        enum: [claude-opus-4-5-20251101, claude-sonnet-4-20250514, claude-3-5-haiku-20241022]
        required: true
      messages:
        type: array
        items:
          type: object
          properties:
            role: { type: string, enum: [user, assistant] }
            content: { type: string }
        required: true
      system: { type: string }
      max_tokens: { type: integer, default: 4096 }
      temperature: { type: number, default: 1.0, min: 0, max: 1 }
      stream: { type: boolean, default: false }

  - name: anthropic_message_with_tools
    description: Send a message with tool definitions
    parameters:
      model: { type: string, required: true }
      messages: { type: array, required: true }
      tools:
        type: array
        items:
          type: object
          properties:
            name: { type: string }
            description: { type: string }
            input_schema: { type: object }
      tool_choice:
        type: object
        properties:
          type: { type: string, enum: [auto, any, tool] }
          name: { type: string }

  - name: anthropic_message_with_vision
    description: Send a message with images
    parameters:
      model: { type: string, required: true }
      messages:
        type: array
        items:
          type: object
          properties:
            role: { type: string }
            content:
              type: array
              items:
                oneOf:
                  - type: object
                    properties:
                      type: { const: text }
                      text: { type: string }
                  - type: object
                    properties:
                      type: { const: image }
                      source:
                        type: object
                        properties:
                          type: { enum: [base64, url] }
                          media_type: { type: string }
                          data: { type: string }

  - name: anthropic_batch_create
    description: Create a batch request
    parameters:
      requests:
        type: array
        items:
          type: object
          properties:
            custom_id: { type: string }
            params: { type: object }
        required: true

  - name: anthropic_batch_status
    description: Get batch status
    parameters:
      batch_id: { type: string, required: true }

  - name: anthropic_batch_results
    description: Get batch results
    parameters:
      batch_id: { type: string, required: true }

  - name: anthropic_get_usage
    description: Get current usage metrics (currency cost is policy/ops-owned)
    parameters:
      period: { type: string, enum: [session, day, month] }
```

## Usage / Cost Tracking (NO hard-coded pricing)

### Why we do NOT embed pricing tables
Provider pricing changes frequently. Hard-coding a “pricing model” table in a connector/spec becomes incorrect quickly.

### What we track instead (stable)
- provider-reported usage fields (when present)
- token counts (input/output/cache)
- image counts/size classes
- audio seconds

### Budget enforcement
Budgets can be enforced in two stable ways:
1. **Usage budgets** (preferred): token/image/second limits per request/session/day.
2. **Currency budgets** (optional): computed by an external, versioned “pricing catalog” object owned by policy/ops (not embedded in the connector).

### Attribution
- Track usage per agent
- Track usage per task/session
- Track usage per operation/tool
- Generate reports

## Prompt Caching Strategy
- System prompts > 1024 tokens: Always cache
- Tool definitions: Cache when > 5 tools
- Large documents: Cache with TTL
- Cache warming on connector init

## Error Handling
- Rate limit (429): Exponential backoff
- Overloaded (529): Queue and retry
- Invalid request (400): Parse and report
- Auth failure (401): Refresh credentials
- Context length exceeded: Truncation strategy

## Dependencies
- anthropic-rs or custom HTTP client
- reqwest (HTTP)
- tokio (async)
- serde (serialization)
- async-stream (streaming)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Send basic message and receive response
- [ ] Stream response tokens in real-time
- [ ] Use tools in conversation
- [ ] Process images in prompts
- [ ] Submit and retrieve batch jobs
- [ ] Track usage accurately per request
- [ ] Enforce budget limits
- [ ] Handle rate limits gracefully
- [ ] Utilize prompt caching
close_reason: Implemented Anthropic Claude API connector with Messages API, streaming support, cost tracking, and unit tests

title: fcp.zendesk - Zendesk Support Connector
description:
# fcp.zendesk - Zendesk Support Platform Connector (FCP2)

## Goal
Deliver the FCP2 Zendesk connector epic plan for tickets/comments/KB workflows with careful PII handling and audit for writes.

## Zone model (mechanical)

<!-- fcp2-single-zone-note -->
**FCP2 single-zone binding note:** A connector instance binds to exactly one `ZoneId` for its entire lifetime.
The connector MUST NOT multiplex multiple zones internally.

Recommended deployment pattern: run separate connector instances in separate zones with different capability grants/policies.

## Strategic Context

### Value Assessment
**Strategic Value Score: 77/100** — Specialized Tier 3 connector (Support/CRM family).

**Why Critical**: Zendesk is a **leading customer support platform**, used by 100K+ companies. Enables agents to manage support tickets, automate responses, analyze customer issues, and improve support efficiency. Essential for customer success automation.

### Priority Matrix Position
- **Category**: Specialized Investment (Support + Customer Success)
- **Build Phase**: Phase 3 Enterprise (weeks 9-12)

### Intercom Comparison
- **Zendesk**: Traditional ticketing, enterprise support
- **Intercom**: Modern messaging, product-led
- Different market segments — both valuable

---

## Agent Capabilities (Concrete Use Cases)

### Ticket Management
- Create and update tickets
- Assign and prioritize
- Add internal notes
- Merge duplicate tickets

### Customer Interaction
- Send replies
- Read ticket history
- Access user information
- Track satisfaction

### Support Operations
- Categorize and tag
- Apply macros
- Set SLA status
- Route to teams

### Examples of Agent Workflows
```
"What are the open P1 tickets?"
"Reply to this support request"
"Assign this ticket to the billing team"
"Find similar tickets to this issue"
"What's our average response time today?"
"Escalate this to engineering"
"Generate weekly support report"
```

---

## Flywheel Ecosystem Synergies

### Sentry Integration
**Bug-to-ticket correlation:**
- Sentry error → Zendesk ticket
- Link customer reports to errors
- Track fix status bidirectionally

### HubSpot/Salesforce Integration
- Support context for sales
- Customer health scores
- Upsell opportunity identification

### Linear/Jira Integration
- Feature requests → backlog items
- Bug reports → engineering issues
- Status sync between systems

### Agent Mail Integration
- Support threads → agent coordination
- Internal escalation workflows
- Cross-team collaboration

### Slack/Teams Integration
- Support alerts in channels
- Quick internal discussions
- Agent assistance requests

---

## Technical Implementation Notes

### API Surface
- **Support API** — Tickets, users, organizations
- **Help Center API** — Knowledge base articles
- **Search API** — Full-text search
- **Webhooks** — Real-time ticket events

### Recommended Crates
- `reqwest` — HTTP client
- `serde_json` — JSON handling
- `oauth2` — OAuth handling

### Authentication
- API token (email/token pair)
- OAuth 2.0 (for apps)
- Basic auth (legacy)

### Data Model
```
Organization
└── User
    └── Ticket
        ├── Comments (public/private)
        ├── Tags
        └── Custom Fields
```

---

## Zone Architecture

### Recommended Zones
| Zone | Description | Capabilities |
|------|-------------|--------------|
| `z:support:zendesk:full` | Full access | All operations |
| `z:support:zendesk:agent` | Agent access | Handle tickets |
| `z:support:zendesk:readonly` | Read-only | View and search |
| `z:support:zendesk:group:<id>` | Group-scoped | Single team |

### Data Sensitivity
- Tickets may contain customer PII
- Internal notes are confidential
- Customer issues reveal product problems

---

## Manifest Archetypes (Closed Set)
- `operational` — REST API operations
- `streaming` — Webhook event ingestion

---

## External Surface

### NetworkConstraints
Default-deny; allow only:
- `{subdomain}.zendesk.com:443`

### Credential Injection
- API token via `CredentialId`
- OAuth tokens via `CredentialId`
- Never write credentials to disk

---

## Capability Model

### Read Operations
- `zendesk.tickets.read` — View tickets
- `zendesk.tickets.search` — Search tickets
- `zendesk.users.read` — User information
- `zendesk.organizations.read` — Organization info

### Write Operations
- `zendesk.tickets.create` — Create tickets
- `zendesk.tickets.update` — Update tickets
- `zendesk.tickets.comment` — Add comments
- `zendesk.tickets.assign` — Assign tickets

### Administrative (Dangerous)
- `zendesk.tickets.delete` — Delete tickets
- `zendesk.users.admin` — User management

---

## Operations (Representative)

### List Tickets
```json
GET /api/v2/tickets.json
Query params:
  sort_by: updated_at
  sort_order: desc
```

### Search Tickets
```json
GET /api/v2/search.json
Query params:
  query: status<solved type:ticket priority:urgent
```

### Get Ticket
```json
GET /api/v2/tickets/{id}.json
```

Response:
```json
{
  "ticket": {
    "id": 123,
    "subject": "Help with billing",
    "description": "...",
    "status": "open",
    "priority": "high",
    "requester_id": 456,
    "assignee_id": 789,
    "tags": ["billing", "subscription"]
  }
}
```

### Create Ticket
```json
POST /api/v2/tickets.json
{
  "ticket": {
    "subject": "Issue with login",
    "comment": {"body": "Customer cannot access their account..."},
    "priority": "high",
    "requester_id": 456
  }
}
```

### Update Ticket (Add Comment)
```json
PUT /api/v2/tickets/{id}.json
{
  "ticket": {
    "status": "pending",
    "comment": {
      "body": "We're investigating this issue.",
      "public": true
    }
  }
}
```

### Add Internal Note
```json
PUT /api/v2/tickets/{id}.json
{
  "ticket": {
    "comment": {
      "body": "Escalated to engineering team.",
      "public": false
    }
  }
}
```

---

## Support Automation Patterns

### Auto-Triage
1. New ticket arrives
2. Agent analyzes content
3. Assigns priority and category
4. Routes to appropriate team
5. Sends initial acknowledgment

### Knowledge Base Deflection
1. Analyze ticket content
2. Search help center articles
3. Suggest relevant articles
4. Auto-respond if high confidence
5. Escalate if no match

### SLA Monitoring
1. Track response/resolution times
2. Alert on approaching breaches
3. Escalate stale tickets
4. Generate SLA reports

---

## Tests

### Unit Tests (Mock-Only)
- Ticket construction
- Search query building
- Comment formatting
- Status transitions

### Integration Tests
- wiremock-based API simulation
- Multi-ticket workflows
- Webhook handling

### E2E Compliance
- Validates NetworkConstraints
- Permission enforcement
- Audit logging

---

## Acceptance Criteria
- Passes connector compliance runner (static + dynamic)
- No real Zendesk calls in unit tests
- Ticket CRUD functional
- Search works
- Comment operations work
- Webhook events processed
- Status transitions handled

## Success Criteria
- Connector epic is fully decomposed into implementable beads (manifest/cap map, provisioning, operations, tests, E2E compliance).
- All child beads are implemented and closed, and the connector passes the mechanical compliance runner + its E2E scenarios with structured JSON logs.
- Mechanical guarantees hold: single-zone binding, default-deny capabilities, and NetworkConstraints enforcement; no secret/PII leakage in logs.

title: fcp.zendesk: Manifest + Capability Map (FCP2)
description:
# fcp.zendesk: Manifest + Capability Map (FCP2)

## Goal
Define the Zendesk connector’s **mechanical manifest contract** under FCP2.

## Required contents
- Manifest archetypes (closed set):
  - `operational` (ticket CRUD, macros)
  - `streaming` (webhooks/events)
  - `knowledge` (KB reads/search)
- Operation list + schema IDs.

## Acceptance criteria

title: TEST: Trust/Quorum Model Unit Tests (n/f Assumptions, Threshold Rules, Degraded Mode)
description:
# TEST: Trust/Quorum Model Unit Tests


## Goal
Validate trust/quorum and degraded-mode policy rules so the mesh behaves predictably under partial failure/byzantine assumptions.

## Scope
Comprehensive tests for Byzantine fault tolerance model and quorum rules.

## Test Categories

### n/f Assumptions
- [ ] 3-node mesh tolerates 0 Byzantine faults
- [ ] 4-node mesh tolerates 1 Byzantine fault
- [ ] 7-node mesh tolerates 2 Byzantine faults
- [ ] f < n/3 invariant enforced
- [ ] Quorum size = n - f calculated correctly

### Threshold Rules
- [ ] Zone operations require 2f+1 signatures
- [ ] Checkpoint advancement requires quorum
- [ ] Key rotation requires quorum
- [ ] Revocation propagation requires quorum
- [ ] Threshold signature verification

### Degraded Mode Semantics
- [ ] Degraded mode triggers at f failures
- [ ] Operations pause when quorum lost
- [ ] Clear error codes for degraded state
- [ ] Recovery path when nodes return
- [ ] Degraded mode logged/alerted

### Safety Tier Quorums
- [ ] Safe operations: single node
- [ ] Risky operations: 2f+1 quorum
- [ ] Dangerous operations: higher quorum
- [ ] Critical operations: owner quorum

### Split-Brain Prevention
- [ ] Only one partition can make progress
- [ ] Minority partition refuses writes
- [ ] Majority partition continues
- [ ] Merge after heal

## Golden Vectors
Location: `tests/vectors/quorum/`
- `quorum_3_of_3.cbor`
- `quorum_3_of_5.cbor`
- `degraded_state.cbor`

## Logging Requirements
```json
{
  "timestamp": "RFC3339",
  "test_name": "test_quorum_threshold",
  "phase": "execute",
  "correlation_id": "uuid",
  "n": 5,
  "f": 1,
  "quorum_size": 4,
  "signatures_collected": 4,
  "result": "pass"
}
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- Quorum calculations are correct
- Degraded mode is reliable
- Split-brain is prevented
close_reason: All tests implemented and passing (63 tests), golden vectors generated

title: fcp.grafana: Open-Source Observability Connector
description:
## Overview
Comprehensive observability connector for Grafana ecosystem, enabling AI agents to query metrics, analyze logs, inspect traces, and manage dashboards.

## Core Capabilities

### Metrics Querying (PromQL)
- Execute PromQL queries against Prometheus datasources
- Time range selection with relative and absolute times
- Aggregation and transformation functions
- Multi-datasource queries
- Query result formatting (tables, time series)

### Dashboard Access and Rendering
- List available dashboards by folder/tag
- Retrieve dashboard JSON definitions
- Render dashboard panels as images
- Variable interpolation for dynamic dashboards
- Export dashboards for backup/migration

### Alert Management
- List active and silenced alerts
- Query alert history and state transitions
- Create and modify alert rules
- Manage silence rules
- Acknowledge and annotate alerts

### Log Search (Loki Integration)
- LogQL query execution
- Log stream discovery
- Label-based filtering
- Pattern matching and parsing
- Log context retrieval around events

### Trace Inspection (Tempo Integration)
- Trace ID lookup and visualization
- Service map generation
- Span analysis and timing breakdown
- Cross-service correlation
- Trace-to-log linking

## Deployment Support

### Self-Hosted
- Direct API authentication
- Custom SSL/TLS configuration
- On-premise datasource access
- Air-gapped environment support

### Grafana Cloud
- Cloud API token authentication
- Stack management
- Usage metrics and billing info
- Multi-tenant organization support

## Implementation Notes
- Use Grafana HTTP API
- Support API key and OAuth authentication
- Handle rate limiting gracefully
- Cache frequently accessed dashboards

## Testing Requirements
- Mock Grafana server for unit tests
- Integration tests with test instance
- Performance tests for large queries
- Compatibility tests across Grafana versions

title: fcp.youtube - YouTube Data & Studio API Connector
description:
# fcp.youtube - YouTube Data & Studio API Connector (FCP2)

## Strategic Context

### Value Assessment
**Strategic Value Score: 95/100** — Critical Tier 1 connector.

**Why Critical**: YouTube is the world's second-largest search engine and a massive knowledge repository. **Transcript access alone makes this invaluable for research agents.** Video content is one of the richest information sources available.

### Priority Matrix Position
- **Category**: Quick Wins (High Value + Moderate Effort)
- **Build Phase**: Phase 1 Foundation (immediate)

---

## V2 Specification Compliance (NORMATIVE)

### ConnectorArchetype
```rust
archetypes: vec\![
    ConnectorArchetype::Knowledge,    // Video/transcript search
    ConnectorArchetype::Operational,  // Channel management
]
```
- **Knowledge**: Video discovery, transcript retrieval, search
- **Operational**: Upload, publish, comment management

### ConnectorStateModel
```rust
state_model: ConnectorStateModel::SingletonWriter
```
- **SingletonWriter**: Upload state, comment sync cursors
- State tracked: `{ upload_progress: HashMap<VideoId, Progress>, sync_cursors: HashMap<ChannelId, Cursor> }`
- Lease required for upload operations

### ConnectorFormat
```rust
format: ConnectorFormat::Wasi
```
- **WASI recommended**: Handles OAuth credentials
- Memory isolation for token protection
- Capability-gated hostcalls

### NetworkConstraints (NORMATIVE)
```rust
NetworkConstraints {
    // YouTube Data API v3
    host_allow: vec\![
        "www.googleapis.com".into(),
        "youtube.googleapis.com".into(),
        "oauth2.googleapis.com".into(),
        // For video upload
        "upload.youtube.com".into(),
    ],
    port_allow: vec\![443],
    deny_localhost: true,
    deny_private_ranges: true,
    deny_tailnet_ranges: true,
    deny_ip_literals: true,
    require_sni: true,
    require_host_canonicalization: true,
}
```

### TaintFlags (NORMATIVE)
```rust
// Video content is external/public
video_content.provenance.taint = TaintFlags::PUBLIC_INPUT
    | TaintFlags::EXTERNAL_INPUT;

// Transcripts may contain errors
transcript.provenance.taint = TaintFlags::EXTERNAL_INPUT;

// Comments are adversarial
comment.provenance.taint = TaintFlags::EXTERNAL_INPUT
    | TaintFlags::PROMPT_SURFACE
    | TaintFlags::USER_SUPPLIED;

// URLs in content are unverified
if content.contains_urls() {
    content.provenance.taint |= TaintFlags::UNVERIFIED_LINK;
}
```

### SafetyTier per Operation
| Operation | SafetyTier | Rationale |
|-----------|------------|-----------|
| `youtube.videos.search` | Safe | Read-only search |
| `youtube.videos.get` | Safe | Read-only metadata |
| `youtube.captions.get` | Safe | Read-only transcripts |
| `youtube.channels.get` | Safe | Read-only |
| `youtube.comments.read` | Risky | Adversarial content |
| `youtube.videos.upload` | Dangerous | Creates public content |
| `youtube.videos.update` | Dangerous | Modifies public content |
| `youtube.videos.delete` | Dangerous | Irreversible |
| `youtube.comments.write` | Dangerous | Public interaction |

---

## Agent Capabilities (Concrete Use Cases)

### Research & Knowledge Extraction
- Video metadata extraction and search
- **Transcript retrieval** (auto-generated + manual captions)
- Video summarization via transcript
- Topic research across video content

### Channel Management
- Channel analytics and insights
- Video upload and publish automation
- Comment management and moderation
- Playlist management

### Content Discovery
- Search videos by topic, channel, or criteria
- Find relevant tutorials and explanations
- Monitor competitor channels
- Track trending content

### Examples of Agent Workflows
```
"Summarize this YouTube video" → Fetch transcript → Process
"Find videos about {topic}" → Search + metadata extraction
"What are people saying about this video?" → Comment analysis
"Monitor competitor channels for new content"
"Schedule video posts" → Content calendar management
"Extract code examples from this tutorial video"
"What are the key points from this conference talk?"
```

---

## Flywheel Ecosystem Synergies

### CASS (Context-Aware Semantic Search)
- Index video transcripts
- Semantic video search
- Knowledge graph from video content

### Google AI/Gemini Integration
- Native video understanding
- Multimodal analysis
- Long video processing

### Vector DB Integration
- Transcript embeddings
- Video similarity search
- Topic clustering

### Agent Mail Integration
- Video notifications → agent threads
- Content updates
- Research findings

---

## Technical Implementation Notes

### API Surface
- **YouTube Data API v3**: Primary interface
- **YouTube Analytics API**: Channel insights
- **YouTube Reporting API**: Bulk data

### Recommended Crates
- `google-youtube3` — YouTube API client
- `reqwest` — HTTP client
- `serde_json` — JSON handling
- `tokio` — Async runtime

### Quota Management
YouTube API has strict quotas:
```rust
QuotaLimits {
    daily_quota: 10000,  // Units per day
    // search.list: 100 units
    // videos.list: 1 unit
    // captions.download: 200 units
    // videos.insert: 1600 units
}
```

### Authentication
| Mode | Use Case |
|------|----------|
| API Key | Public data (search, metadata) |
| OAuth2 | Private data, uploads |
| Service Account | Server-to-server |

---

## Zone Architecture

### Recommended Zones
| Zone | Description | Capabilities |
|------|-------------|--------------|
| `z:media:youtube:full` | Full access | All operations |
| `z:media:youtube:read` | Read-only | Search, metadata, transcripts |
| `z:media:youtube:manage` | Management | Upload, update, delete |

### Security Considerations
- Quota exhaustion is a concern
- Public content creation is high-risk
- Comments are adversarial

---

## Manifest Archetypes (Closed Set)
- `knowledge` — Video/transcript search
- `operational` — Channel management

---

## External Surface

### NetworkConstraints
Default-deny; allow only:
- `www.googleapis.com:443`
- `youtube.googleapis.com:443`
- `upload.youtube.com:443`

### Credential Injection
- API key via egress proxy (public data)
- OAuth2 tokens via CredentialId
- Never persist credentials

---

## Capability Model

### Read Operations
- `youtube.videos.search` — Search videos
- `youtube.videos.get` — Video metadata
- `youtube.captions.get` — Transcripts
- `youtube.channels.get` — Channel info
- `youtube.playlists.get` — Playlist info

### Write Operations
- `youtube.videos.upload` — Upload video (Dangerous)
- `youtube.videos.update` — Update metadata (Dangerous)
- `youtube.playlists.write` — Manage playlists
- `youtube.comments.write` — Post comments (Dangerous)

### Admin Operations
- `youtube.videos.delete` — Delete video (Dangerous)
- `youtube.channels.update` — Channel settings (Dangerous)

---

## Operations (Representative)

### Search Videos
```
GET /youtube/v3/search?part=snippet&q={query}&type=video
```

### Get Video Details
```
GET /youtube/v3/videos?part=snippet,contentDetails&id={video_id}
```

### Get Captions/Transcript
```
GET /youtube/v3/captions?part=snippet&videoId={video_id}
GET /youtube/v3/captions/{caption_id}?tfmt=srt
```

### Upload Video
```json
POST /upload/youtube/v3/videos?part=snippet,status
{
  "snippet": {
    "title": "Video Title",
    "description": "Description",
    "tags": ["tag1", "tag2"]
  },
  "status": {
    "privacyStatus": "private"
  }
}
```

---

## Tests

### Unit Tests (Mock-Only)
- API request construction
- Response parsing
- Quota tracking
- Transcript parsing
- Error handling

### Integration Tests
- Mock YouTube API responses
- Multi-step workflows
- Quota exhaustion scenarios

### E2E Compliance
- Validates NetworkConstraints
- Dangerous operation approval flow
- Quota enforcement
- Audit logging

---

## Acceptance Criteria
- Passes connector compliance runner (static + dynamic)
- No real YouTube API calls in unit tests
- Video search functional
- Transcript retrieval works
- Quota tracking accurate
- Upload flow works
- All V2 NORMATIVE requirements satisfied

title: TEST: Connector SDK Unit Tests (Standard Methods, Typed Schemas, State Model)
description:
# TEST: Connector SDK Unit Tests


## Goal
Validate the connector SDK standard-method surface is correct and ergonomic via a comprehensive test suite (schemas, state, streaming).

## Scope
Comprehensive tests for connector SDK APIs and patterns.

## Test Categories

### Standard Methods
- [ ] invoke() method signature correct
- [ ] simulate() method signature correct (preflight; no side effects)
- [ ] subscribe() method signature correct
- [ ] get_state() method signature correct
- [ ] set_state() method signature correct
- [ ] introspect() returns correct schema

### Simulate / CostEstimate / Availability (Spec-aligned)
- [ ] SimulateRequest/SimulateResponse canonical encoding round-trip
- [ ] `estimate_cost=true` populates `CostEstimate` deterministically when supported
- [ ] `check_availability=true` populates `ResourceAvailability` deterministically when supported
- [ ] missing capability reporting is stable (ordering + content)
- [ ] simulate MUST NOT call write paths in the test connector (mock-enforced)
- [ ] simulate timeouts are enforced and do not leak secrets in error strings/logs

### Typed Schemas
- [ ] Operation schema generation
- [ ] Event schema generation
- [ ] State schema generation
- [ ] Schema validation at runtime
- [ ] Schema evolution rules (V2-only; fail-closed + explicit migration)
  - unknown schema hashes rejected deterministically
  - interface_hash changes are detectable and surfaced via introspection
  - migrations (if any) are explicit and produce new content-addressed objects

### State Model
- [ ] State read/write round-trip
- [ ] State versioning works
- [ ] State conflict detection
- [ ] State snapshot creation
- [ ] State restore from snapshot

### Error Handling
- [ ] SDK errors use error taxonomy
- [ ] Errors include ai_recovery_hint
- [ ] Panic recovery in connector code
- [ ] Timeout handling

### Trait Implementations
- [ ] FcpConnector trait defaults work
- [ ] Capability checking helpers
- [ ] Audit event helpers
- [ ] Receipt creation helpers

## Golden Vectors
Location: `tests/vectors/sdk/`
- `operation_schema.json`
- `event_schema.json`
- `state_snapshot.cbor`
- `simulate_request.cbor`
- `simulate_response.cbor`

## Logging Requirements
```json
{
  "timestamp": "RFC3339",
  "test_name": "test_sdk_invoke",
  "phase": "execute",
  "correlation_id": "uuid",
  "operation_id": "...",
  "connector_id": "...",
  "result": "pass"
}
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- All SDK methods tested
- State model is reliable
- Error handling is consistent

title: fcp.terraform — Infrastructure as Code Connector
description:
# fcp.terraform - Infrastructure as Code Connector (FCP2)

## Goal
Deliver the FCP2 Terraform connector epic plan for IaC workflows with strict sandboxing, plan/diff safety, and policy-gated apply (dangerous).

## Zone model (mechanical)

<!-- fcp2-single-zone-note -->
**FCP2 single-zone binding note:** A connector instance binds to exactly one `ZoneId` for its entire lifetime.
The connector MUST NOT multiplex multiple zones internally.

Recommended deployment pattern: run separate connector instances in separate zones with different capability grants/policies.

## Strategic Context

### Value Assessment
**Strategic Value Score: 80/100** — Important Tier 3 connector (Infrastructure family).

**Why Critical**: Terraform is the **dominant Infrastructure-as-Code tool**, managing cloud resources across AWS, GCP, Azure, and 1000+ providers. Enables agents to provision infrastructure, review plans, and automate cloud operations. Essential for autonomous DevOps.

### Priority Matrix Position
- **Category**: Specialized Investment (Infrastructure + Safety Critical)
- **Build Phase**: Phase 3 Enterprise (weeks 9-12)

### Pulumi Comparison
- **Terraform**: HCL-based, mature ecosystem, state management
- **Pulumi**: General-purpose languages, same cloud targets
- Both needed for full IaC coverage

---

## Agent Capabilities (Concrete Use Cases)

### Plan & Apply
- Generate infrastructure plans
- Review change diffs
- Apply approved changes
- Destroy resources (controlled)

### State Management
- Read current state
- Import existing resources
- State drift detection
- Resource inventory

### Workspace Management
- List workspaces
- Switch workspaces
- Lock/unlock state

### Examples of Agent Workflows
```
"What will this change affect?"
"Show me the current infrastructure state"
"Apply the approved changes"
"What resources exist in production?"
"Has any infrastructure drifted?"
"Import this existing S3 bucket"
"Create a new staging workspace"
```

---

## Flywheel Ecosystem Synergies

### Kubernetes Connector Synergy
**Full stack automation:**
- Terraform provisions clusters
- K8s connector manages workloads
- Agent handles both layers

### GitHub Integration
**GitOps workflows:**
- PR triggers terraform plan
- Agent reviews plan safety
- Merge triggers apply

### Datadog/Grafana Integration
- Infrastructure metrics correlation
- Provisioning impacts on observability
- Cost monitoring integration

### Agent Mail Integration
- Plan review requests → agent threads
- Apply approval workflows
- Drift notifications

### Stripe Integration
- Cloud cost correlation
- Resource provisioning → billing impact
- Budget enforcement

---

## Technical Implementation Notes

### Execution Modes

#### Terraform CLI Wrapper
- Execute `terraform` commands via subprocess
- Parse plan/apply output
- Handle state file operations

#### Terraform Cloud/Enterprise API
- REST API for cloud workspaces
- Remote state management
- Run management

### Recommended Crates
- `tokio::process` — Command execution
- `serde_json` — JSON output parsing
- `reqwest` — Terraform Cloud API

### Core Operations
```
init → plan → apply
         ↓
      state operations
```

---

## Zone Architecture

### Recommended Zones
| Zone | Description | Capabilities |
|------|-------------|--------------|
| `z:infra:terraform:full` | Full access | All operations including apply |
| `z:infra:terraform:plan` | Plan only | Plan and state read |
| `z:infra:terraform:readonly` | Read-only | State inspection only |
| `z:infra:terraform:workspace:<name>` | Workspace-scoped | Single workspace |

### Safety Boundaries
- Apply is **safety-critical** — requires explicit approval
- Destroy is **highest risk** — double confirmation
- Plan is safe — read-only simulation

---

## Manifest Archetypes (Closed Set)
- `operational` — CLI execution / API calls

---

## External Surface

### NetworkConstraints
Varies by mode:
- **CLI**: Cloud provider APIs (AWS, GCP, Azure endpoints)
- **Terraform Cloud**: `app.terraform.io:443`

### Credential Injection
- Cloud provider credentials via environment
- TFE token via `CredentialId`
- Never write credentials to disk

---

## Capability Model

### Read Operations
- `terraform.state.read` — Read current state
- `terraform.state.list` — List resources
- `terraform.workspaces.read` — List workspaces
- `terraform.plan.read` — View existing plans

### Write Operations
- `terraform.plan.create` — Run terraform plan
- `terraform.apply.execute` — Apply changes (Dangerous)
- `terraform.state.import` — Import resources

### Administrative (Dangerous)
- `terraform.destroy` — Destroy infrastructure
- `terraform.state.remove` — Remove from state
- `terraform.workspaces.delete` — Delete workspace

---

## Operations (Representative)

### Terraform Plan
```bash
terraform plan -out=tfplan -json
```

Parsed output:
```json
{
  "resource_changes": [{
    "address": "aws_instance.web",
    "change": {
      "actions": ["create"],
      "before": null,
      "after": {
        "instance_type": "t3.medium",
        "ami": "ami-12345678"
      }
    }
  }]
}
```

### Terraform Apply
```bash
terraform apply tfplan -json
```

### Read State
```bash
terraform show -json
```

### Terraform Cloud Run (API)
```json
POST /api/v2/runs
{
  "data": {
    "type": "runs",
    "attributes": {
      "message": "Deploy API changes"
    },
    "relationships": {
      "workspace": {
        "data": {"type": "workspaces", "id": "ws-123abc"}
      }
    }
  }
}
```

---

## Safety Considerations

### Plan Review Protocol
1. Agent generates plan
2. Plan must show all changes
3. Human/policy approval required
4. Only then can apply proceed

### Dangerous Operations
| Operation | Risk | Mitigation |
|-----------|------|------------|
| `apply` | High | Require prior plan approval |
| `destroy` | Very High | Double confirmation, no auto-approve |
| `state rm` | High | Audit log, confirmation |
| Import | Medium | Validation of resource match |

### Drift Detection
- Periodic state refresh
- Compare plan output
- Alert on unexpected changes

---

## Terraform Cloud Integration

### Benefits
- Remote state management
- Team collaboration
- Policy enforcement (Sentinel)
- VCS integration

### API Capabilities
- Workspace management
- Run triggering and monitoring
- Variable management
- State version access

---

## Tests

### Unit Tests (Mock-Only)
- Plan output parsing
- State JSON handling
- Change detection logic
- Workspace management

### Integration Tests
- Local terraform with mock providers
- State file operations
- Plan/apply workflow simulation

### E2E Compliance
- Validates NetworkConstraints
- Apply requires approval
- Audit logging complete

---

## Acceptance Criteria
- Passes connector compliance runner (static + dynamic)
- No real infrastructure changes in tests
- Plan generation works
- State reading functional
- Apply requires explicit approval
- Terraform Cloud API works
- Proper audit trail maintained

## Success Criteria
- Connector epic is fully decomposed into implementable beads (manifest/cap map, provisioning, operations, tests, E2E compliance).
- All child beads are implemented and closed, and the connector passes the mechanical compliance runner + its E2E scenarios with structured JSON logs.
- Mechanical guarantees hold: single-zone binding, default-deny capabilities, and NetworkConstraints enforcement; no secret/PII leakage in logs.

title: fcp.terraform: Manifest + Capability Map (FCP2)
description:
# fcp.terraform: Manifest + Capability Map (FCP2)

## Goal
Define the Terraform connector’s **mechanical manifest contract** under FCP2.

Terraform is safety-critical; the manifest must make dangerous operations mechanically obvious.

## Required contents
- Manifest archetypes (closed set):
  - `operational` (CLI invocation; plan/apply/state)
- Operation list + schema IDs.
- Capability families + per-operation required caps.
- NetworkConstraints:
  - default deny
  - explicitly allow only the minimal outbound hosts required for the configured backends/providers
  - optionally require “offline mode” for plan-only environments
- Sandbox profile:
  - strict filesystem allowlist
  - explicit binary allowlist (terraform + minimal helpers)
- State model declaration:
  - plan artifact references + hashes (if persisted)
  - drift checkpoints (if persisted)

## Acceptance criteria
- Another engineer can implement `--manifest` from this bead alone.
- Static compliance can reject:
  - overly-broad egress
  - unsafe filesystem profiles

title: fcp.terraform: Provisioning Automation (terraform binary, backend creds, safety mode)
description:
# fcp.terraform: Provisioning Automation (terraform binary, backend creds, safety mode)

## Goal
Automate Terraform connector onboarding with minimal human steps while keeping all credentials zone-scoped and never written to disk.

## Requirements
- Detect/verify Terraform binary:
  - version constraints
  - hash/publisher verification if required by policy
- Backend credential injection via `CredentialId`:
  - AWS creds for S3 backend
  - GCP creds for GCS backend
  - etc.
- Safety mode configuration:
  - default: plan-only
  - apply requires explicit approval gating
  - destroy is disabled unless explicitly enabled by policy
- Validate sandbox filesystem constraints:
  - only allow configured workspace paths

## Acceptance criteria
- `fcp doctor` verifies readiness without leaking secrets.
- Mockable in CI (no real terraform needed for unit tests).

title: fcp.dropbox: Dropbox file storage connector
description:
## Goal
Provide an FCP2-compliant Dropbox connector for file storage operations under strict sandboxing, NetworkConstraints, and safe sharing controls.

## Manifest archetypes (closed set)

- `storage`
- `operational`

> Interaction patterns (non-archetype): Request/Response

## Overview

Implement the Flywheel Connector Platform (FCP) connector for Dropbox, a leading file storage and collaboration platform. This connector enables file CRUD operations, folder management, sharing capabilities, search functionality, Paper document handling, and team administration through Dropbox API v2.

## Value Assessment

- **Value Score**: 70/100 (Tier 4)
- **Priority**: P3
- **Archetype**: Request-Response + Webhook

Dropbox serves as a critical file storage connector alongside fcp.s3 and fcp.onedrive, providing cloud file storage capabilities for the FCP ecosystem.

## Technical Architecture

### API Integration
- **API Version**: Dropbox API v2
- **Authentication**: OAuth 2.0 with PKCE
- **Base URL**: https://api.dropboxapi.com/2/
- **Content URL**: https://content.dropboxapi.com/2/

### Zone Architecture

<!-- fcp2-single-zone-note -->
**FCP2 single-zone binding note:** A connector instance binds to exactly one `ZoneId` for its entire lifetime.
The *"zones"* described in this section are a **recommended deployment pattern** (run separate connector instances in separate zones with different capability grants/policies) and/or conceptual risk tiers.
The connector MUST NOT multiplex multiple zones internally.

The connector operates across three distinct zones:

1. **Personal Files Zone**
   - User's personal file storage
   - Individual file/folder operations
   - Personal sharing settings

2. **Shared Files Zone**
   - Team shared folders
   - Collaborative workspaces
   - Shared links management

3. **Team Admin Zone**
   - Team member management
   - Group administration
   - Team-wide policies and settings
   - Storage quota management

### Dependencies
- `fcp-core`: Core connector traits and types
- `fcp-oauth`: OAuth 2.0 authentication flow
- `fcp-webhook`: Webhook handling for file change notifications
- `fcp-ratelimit`: Rate limiting (Dropbox uses sliding window limits)
- `fcp-telemetry`: Observability and metrics

## Operations

### File Operations
- `files.upload` - Upload files (chunked for large files)
- `files.download` - Download file content
- `files.get_metadata` - Get file/folder metadata
- `files.delete` - Delete files/folders
- `files.copy` - Copy files/folders
- `files.move` - Move/rename files/folders
- `files.search` - Search for files by name/content
- `files.list_folder` - List folder contents
- `files.get_thumbnail` - Get image thumbnails
- `files.get_preview` - Get file previews

### Folder Operations
- `folders.create` - Create new folders
- `folders.delete` - Delete folders recursively
- `folders.copy` - Copy folder structure
- `folders.move` - Move/rename folders

### Sharing Operations
- `sharing.create_shared_link` - Create shareable links
- `sharing.list_shared_links` - List existing shared links
- `sharing.revoke_shared_link` - Revoke shared links
- `sharing.add_folder_member` - Add members to shared folders
- `sharing.remove_folder_member` - Remove folder members
- `sharing.list_folder_members` - List shared folder members
- `sharing.update_folder_member` - Update member permissions

### Paper Documents
- `paper.docs.create` - Create Paper documents
- `paper.docs.update` - Update Paper content
- `paper.docs.download` - Export Paper documents
- `paper.docs.list` - List Paper documents
- `paper.docs.archive` - Archive Paper documents

### Team Administration
- `team.members.list` - List team members
- `team.members.add` - Add team members
- `team.members.remove` - Remove team members
- `team.members.suspend` - Suspend team members
- `team.groups.list` - List team groups
- `team.groups.create` - Create groups
- `team.groups.members.add` - Add members to groups
- `team.info` - Get team information
- `team.features` - Get team features/quotas

### Webhook Events
- `file.change` - File added/modified/deleted
- `folder.change` - Folder structure changes
- `sharing.change` - Sharing settings modified
- `team.member.change` - Team membership changes

## Implementation Notes

### Rate Limiting
Dropbox uses per-app and per-user rate limits:
- Standard endpoints: 1000 requests/minute
- Content endpoints: Variable based on operation
- Implement exponential backoff with jitter

### Large File Handling
- Files > 150MB require chunked upload sessions
- Session-based uploads with `upload_session/start`, `append`, `finish`
- Support for resumable uploads

### Cursor-Based Pagination
- Use cursors for `list_folder` continuation
- Implement `list_folder/continue` for large directories
- Handle cursor expiration (reset after ~4 hours)

### Namespace Handling
- Support both root namespace (team) and member namespaces
- Handle namespace routing via `Dropbox-API-Path-Root` header

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] OAuth 2.0 flow with refresh token support
- [ ] Full file CRUD operations
- [ ] Folder management with recursive operations
- [ ] Sharing link creation and management
- [ ] Team member and group administration
- [ ] Paper document support
- [ ] Search functionality across files
- [ ] Webhook integration for change notifications
- [ ] Chunked upload for large files (>150MB)
- [ ] Proper rate limit handling with backoff
- [ ] Cursor-based pagination for large result sets
- [ ] Comprehensive error handling for Dropbox error codes
- [ ] Unit and integration tests

## Similar Connectors

Reference implementations for patterns:
- `fcp.s3` - File storage operations, chunked uploads
- `fcp.onedrive` - Microsoft Graph patterns, sharing model
- `fcp.google-drive` - OAuth patterns, folder hierarchy

## Resources

- [Dropbox API v2 Documentation](https://www.dropbox.com/developers/documentation/http/documentation)
- [Dropbox OAuth Guide](https://www.dropbox.com/developers/reference/oauth-guide)
- [Dropbox Webhooks](https://www.dropbox.com/developers/reference/webhooks)

title: fcp.dropbox: Manifest + Capability Map (FCP2)
description:
