title: TEST: Telegram Connector Integration Tests
description:
# TEST: Telegram Connector Integration Tests (Deterministic)


## Goal
Validate Telegram connector integration flows (updates, sends, webhook/polling harness) with deterministic tests and mocks.

## External surface (NetworkConstraints)
Default deny.
- Network egress MUST be restricted per-operation via manifest `NetworkConstraints`.
- Allow only the configured service host(s); HTTPS-only where applicable; deny redirects by default.
- Bound timeouts + response sizes; treat all remote responses as untrusted input; never leak secrets/PII in logs or errors.

## Zone model (mechanical)

<!-- fcp2-single-zone-note -->
**FCP2 single-zone binding note:** A connector instance binds to exactly one `ZoneId` for its entire lifetime.
The connector MUST NOT multiplex multiple zones internally.

Recommended deployment pattern: run separate connector instances in separate zones with different capability grants/policies.

## Purpose
Integration tests for `fcp.telegram` that validate **real connector behavior** against a **deterministic fake Telegram Bot API** (wiremock or a purpose-built in-process server).

These tests are NOT allowed to call the real Telegram API.

## What this test suite must prove
### 1) Bot API correctness (request/response)
- getUpdates long-poll semantics (timeout handling is bounded)
- update offset advancement and persistence
- sendMessage / sendMedia request formation
- file download URL handling (if supported)

### 2) Cursor + singleton-writer correctness
- only the lease-holder advances the update cursor
- restart behavior: resume from persisted cursor
- duplicate update defense (idempotent event emission)

### 3) FCP2 connector contract (integration-level)
- standard method surface works end-to-end (handshake/describe/introspect/capabilities/configure/invoke/health/shutdown)
- capability gating is mechanical:
  - no token → deny + DecisionReceipt
  - valid token → allow
- streaming/event emission:
  - events emitted as EventEnvelopes with correct topic
  - inbound data is tainted as external input

### 4) Error and adversity handling
- rate limits (429) and Retry-After
- invalid token (401) fail-closed
- network timeouts and bounded retries
- malformed update payloads (reject + audit, never panic)

## Required scenarios (minimum)
- scripted update stream: new message → edit → member join → member leave
- concurrent start attempt:
  - second instance denied/fenced by lease
- send operation with simulated timeout-after-send:
  - verify fail-closed behavior to avoid duplicate messages

## Logging requirements
- Structured JSON logs with: `test_name`, `phase`, `correlation_id`, `duration_ms`.
- For denials: `decision=deny`, `reason_code`, `evidence` (object IDs).
- Never log bot tokens or raw message bodies by default.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Runs deterministically in CI.
- Produces a clear, searchable log trail on failure.
- Integrates cleanly with the shared E2E/compliance framework (no bespoke harness logic that can’t be reused).

title: fcp.github: GitHub API Connector
description:
# fcp.github - GitHub API Connector (FCP2)

## Strategic Context

### Value Assessment
**Strategic Value Score: 95/100** — Critical Tier 1 connector (Development family).

**Why Critical**: GitHub is **the dominant code hosting platform**. Enables agents to manage repositories, issues, PRs, CI/CD workflows, and code search. Essential for any software development automation.

### Priority Matrix Position
- **Category**: Critical Infrastructure (Development + Automation)
- **Build Phase**: Phase 1 Foundation (immediate)

---

## V2 Specification Compliance (NORMATIVE)

### ConnectorArchetype
```rust
archetypes: vec\![
    ConnectorArchetype::Operational,  // REST/GraphQL actions
    ConnectorArchetype::Streaming,    // Webhook event ingestion
]
```
- **Operational**: CRUD on repos, issues, PRs, workflows
- **Streaming**: Webhook events (push, PR, issue updates)

### ConnectorStateModel
```rust
state_model: ConnectorStateModel::SingletonWriter
```
- **SingletonWriter**: Cursor/sync state for webhook event processing
- State tracked: `{ last_event_ids: HashMap<RepoId, Vec<EventId>> }`
- Lease required for writer fencing

### ConnectorFormat
```rust
format: ConnectorFormat::Wasi
```
- **WASI**: Contains Dangerous operations (repo delete, workflow dispatch)
- Memory isolation for credential handling
- Capability-gated hostcalls

### NetworkConstraints (NORMATIVE)
```rust
NetworkConstraints {
    // GitHub.com API
    host_allow: vec\!["api.github.com".into()],
    // GitHub Enterprise: configured hostname added dynamically
    port_allow: vec\![443],
    deny_localhost: true,
    deny_private_ranges: true,
    deny_tailnet_ranges: true,
    deny_ip_literals: true,
    require_sni: true,
    require_host_canonicalization: true,
}
```

### TaintFlags (NORMATIVE)
```rust
// User inputs (issue bodies, PR descriptions) are tainted
user_content.provenance.taint = TaintFlags::USER_SUPPLIED
    | TaintFlags::PROMPT_SURFACE;

// Webhook payloads are external
webhook_event.provenance.taint = TaintFlags::EXTERNAL_INPUT;

// URLs in content are unverified
if content.contains_urls() {
    content.provenance.taint |= TaintFlags::UNVERIFIED_LINK;
}
```

### SafetyTier per Operation
| Operation | SafetyTier | Rationale |
|-----------|------------|-----------|
| `github.repos.read` | Safe | Read-only listing |
| `github.issues.read` | Safe | Read-only |
| `github.pulls.read` | Safe | Read-only |
| `github.search.read` | Safe | Code/issue search |
| `github.issues.write` | Risky | Creates/modifies issues |
| `github.pulls.write` | Risky | Creates/modifies PRs |
| `github.repos.write` | Risky | Modifies repo settings |
| `github.actions.dispatch` | Dangerous | Triggers CI/CD workflows |
| `github.webhooks.manage` | Dangerous | Modifies event routing |
| `github.repos.delete` | Dangerous | Irreversible deletion |

---

## Agent Capabilities (Concrete Use Cases)

### Repository Operations
- List/create/update repositories
- Manage branches and tags
- Access file contents
- Configure settings

### Issue Management
- Create and update issues
- Add comments and labels
- Assign users
- Link to PRs

### Pull Request Workflows
- Create and review PRs
- Request/submit reviews
- Merge strategies
- Check status

### CI/CD Integration
- List workflow runs
- Dispatch workflows
- Cancel/rerun jobs
- Access logs

### Code Search
- Search code across repos
- Search issues and PRs
- Advanced query syntax

### Examples of Agent Workflows
```
"Create an issue for this bug"
"Open a PR with these changes"
"Merge the PR after checks pass"
"Search for usages of this function"
"Trigger the deployment workflow"
"List all open PRs for review"
"Add labels to issues matching criteria"
```

---

## Flywheel Ecosystem Synergies

### Linear Integration
**Issue bidirectional sync:**
- GitHub issues ↔ Linear issues
- PR references in Linear
- Coordinated status updates

### Agent Mail Integration
- PR review requests → agent threads
- Issue assignments trigger workflows
- CI/CD notifications routed

### Sentry Integration
- Error events create GitHub issues
- Stack traces linked to code
- Release tracking

### Datadog/Grafana Integration
- Deployment events correlated
- Performance metrics linked to commits
- Incident → PR correlation

---

## Technical Implementation Notes

### API Surface
- **REST API v3**: Primary CRUD operations
- **GraphQL API v4**: Efficient queries, mutations
- **Webhooks**: Event delivery

### Recommended Crates
- `octocrab` — GitHub API client
- `reqwest` — HTTP client
- `graphql_client` — GraphQL queries
- `hmac` / `sha2` — Webhook signature validation

### Authentication Modes
| Mode | Use Case | Recommendation |
|------|----------|----------------|
| GitHub App | Organization automation | **Preferred** |
| OAuth App | User-delegated access | Good |
| PAT | Personal use | Discouraged |

---

## Zone Architecture

### Recommended Zones
| Zone | Description | Capabilities |
|------|-------------|--------------|
| `z:work:github:<org>` | Organization-scoped | Full org access |
| `z:project:<name>:github` | Repo-scoped | Single repo |
| `z:work:github:readonly` | Read-only | Safe operations only |

### Security Considerations
- Org-level access is high trust
- Repo-scoped tokens preferred
- Webhook secrets per installation

---

## Manifest Archetypes (Closed Set)
- `operational` — REST/GraphQL actions
- `streaming` — Webhook event ingestion

---

## External Surface

### NetworkConstraints
Default-deny; allow only:
- `api.github.com:443` (GitHub.com)
- Enterprise: configured hostname

### Credential Injection
- GitHub App private key + installation token
- OAuth tokens via egress proxy
- Webhook secrets for signature validation

---

## Capability Model

### Read Operations
- `github.repos.read` — List/get repositories
- `github.issues.read` — List/get issues
- `github.pulls.read` — List/get PRs
- `github.actions.read` — Workflow/run status
- `github.search.read` — Code/issue search

### Write Operations
- `github.repos.write` — Update repo settings
- `github.issues.write` — Create/update issues
- `github.pulls.write` — Create/update PRs
- `github.actions.write` — Cancel/rerun jobs

### Admin Operations
- `github.repos.delete` — Delete repository (Dangerous)
- `github.actions.dispatch` — Trigger workflows (Dangerous)
- `github.webhooks.manage` — Configure webhooks (Dangerous)

---

## Operations (Representative)

### List Repositories
```
GET /orgs/{org}/repos
GET /user/repos
```

### Create Issue
```json
POST /repos/{owner}/{repo}/issues
{
  "title": "Bug: login fails",
  "body": "Steps to reproduce...",
  "labels": ["bug", "priority:high"]
}
```

### Create Pull Request
```json
POST /repos/{owner}/{repo}/pulls
{
  "title": "Fix login bug",
  "head": "fix-login",
  "base": "main",
  "body": "Fixes #123"
}
```

### Dispatch Workflow
```json
POST /repos/{owner}/{repo}/actions/workflows/{workflow_id}/dispatches
{
  "ref": "main",
  "inputs": {"environment": "staging"}
}
```

### Search Code
```
GET /search/code?q=function+repo:owner/repo
```

---

## Tests

### Unit Tests (Mock-Only)
- API request construction
- Response parsing
- Webhook signature validation
- Rate limit handling
- Error responses

### Integration Tests
- Mock GitHub API responses
- Multi-step workflows (create PR → review → merge)
- Webhook event processing

### E2E Compliance
- Validates NetworkConstraints (api.github.com only)
- Dangerous operation approval flow
- Audit logging for writes

---

## Acceptance Criteria
- Passes connector compliance runner (static + dynamic)
- No real GitHub API calls in unit tests
- All CRUD operations functional
- Webhook signature validation works
- Rate limiting respected
- GraphQL queries supported
- All V2 NORMATIVE requirements satisfied

## External surface (NetworkConstraints)

- Network egress MUST be restricted per-operation via manifest `NetworkConstraints`.
- Allow only the configured service host(s); HTTPS-only where applicable; deny redirects by default.
- Bound timeouts + response sizes; treat all remote responses as untrusted input; never leak secrets/PII in logs or errors.

## Zone model (mechanical)

<!-- fcp2-single-zone-note -->
**FCP2 single-zone binding note:** A connector instance binds to exactly one `ZoneId` for its entire lifetime.
The connector MUST NOT multiplex multiple zones internally.

Recommended deployment pattern: run separate connector instances in separate zones with different capability grants/policies.

title: fcp.docusign: Download Signed Documents
description:
# fcp.docusign: Download Signed Documents (FCP2)

## Goal
Allow retrieval of completed, signed documents safely:
- list documents in an envelope
- download document bytes (streamed, bounded)

Signed documents may contain highly sensitive data.

## Scope
- List envelope documents (metadata).
- Download a document.
- Optional: download combined document bundle.

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `docusign.documents.read` (dangerous; sensitive content)

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- NetworkConstraints pinned.
- Strict IO bounds:
  - max bytes
  - streaming download
  - hash computation for evidence
- Never log document contents.

## Deliverables
- Operation schemas:
  - `docusign.document.list`
  - `docusign.document.download`

## Test strategy (MUST)
- Mock-only tests for:
  - download bounds
  - host pinning
  - hash correctness

## Acceptance criteria
- Document downloads are safe-by-default and do not allow unbounded memory usage.

title: TEST: fcp-oauth Unit Test Suite
description:
# TEST: fcp-oauth Unit Test Suite

## Scope
Comprehensive unit tests for the OAuth2/OAuth1 authentication library.

## Test Categories

### OAuth 2.0 Authorization Code Flow
- [ ] Authorization URL generation with state/PKCE
- [ ] Token exchange with valid/invalid codes
- [ ] Refresh token flow
- [ ] Token expiration handling

### OAuth 2.0 Client Credentials Flow

### OAuth 1.0a Flow (Twitter/legacy)

- [ ] Access token exchange

### Token Management

- [ ] Revoked tokens
- [ ] Network failures

## Mocking Strategy
- Use wiremock to mock OAuth provider endpoints
- Test against mock Google, GitHub, Twitter, Slack endpoints

## Coverage Target: >90%
close_reason: OAuth functionality is connector-specific, not a platform crate. OAuth testing belongs in individual connector test suites.

title: fcp.airtable: Flexible Database and Spreadsheet Connector
description:
# fcp.airtable - Flexible Database and Spreadsheet Connector (FCP2)

## Success Criteria
- `flywheel_connectors-soft.1` (Manifest + Capability Map) is complete and passes static validation (IDs, schemas, NetworkConstraints, safety tiers).
- `flywheel_connectors-soft.2` (Provisioning Automation) is complete, minimizes human prompts, and is fully mockable for tests.
- `flywheel_connectors-soft.3` (Unit/Integration Tests) are mock-only, include success + denial paths, and assert log redaction (no secrets/PII).
- `flywheel_connectors-soft.4` (E2E Compliance Run) passes the shared compliance runner and emits an evidence bundle (logs + receipts + audit checks).
- Connector is V2-only: single-zone binding, default deny, constrained egress, audited risky/dangerous ops.

## Strategic Context

### Value Assessment
**Strategic Value Score: 86/100** — High priority Tier 2 connector.

**Why Critical**: Airtable is the **leading no-code database platform**, bridging spreadsheets and databases. Widely used by operations teams, PMs, and non-technical users. Enables agents to work with structured data managed by business users.

### Priority Matrix Position
- **Category**: Strategic Investment (High Value + Business User Data)
- **Build Phase**: Phase 2 Productivity (weeks 5-8)

---

## V2 Specification Compliance (NORMATIVE)

### ConnectorArchetype
```rust
archetypes: vec\![
    ConnectorArchetype::Storage,      // Record storage
    ConnectorArchetype::Operational,  // CRUD operations
    ConnectorArchetype::Streaming,    // Webhook events
]
```
- **Storage**: Record storage and retrieval
- **Operational**: CRUD, filtering, sorting
- **Streaming**: Webhooks for record changes

### ConnectorStateModel
```rust
state_model: ConnectorStateModel::SingletonWriter
```
- **SingletonWriter**: Pagination cursors, sync state
- State tracked: `{ offsets: HashMap<TableId, Offset>, webhook_state: WebhookState }`
- Lease required for writer fencing

### ConnectorFormat
```rust
format: ConnectorFormat::Wasi
```
- **WASI recommended**: Handles API tokens
- Memory isolation for credential protection
- Capability-gated hostcalls

### NetworkConstraints (NORMATIVE)
```rust
NetworkConstraints {
    // Airtable API endpoints
    host_allow: vec\![
        "api.airtable.com".into(),
        // For file attachments
        "dl.airtable.com".into(),
    ],
    port_allow: vec\![443],
    deny_localhost: true,
    deny_private_ranges: true,
    deny_tailnet_ranges: true,
    deny_ip_literals: true,
    require_sni: true,
    require_host_canonicalization: true,
}
```

### TaintFlags (NORMATIVE)
```rust
// Record data may contain user input
record_data.provenance.taint = TaintFlags::USER_SUPPLIED;

// Attachment URLs are external
attachment.provenance.taint = TaintFlags::UNVERIFIED_LINK;

// Webhook payloads are external
webhook_event.provenance.taint = TaintFlags::EXTERNAL_INPUT;
```

### SafetyTier per Operation
| Operation | SafetyTier | Rationale |
|-----------|------------|-----------|
| `airtable.records.read` | Safe | Read-only |
| `airtable.schema.read` | Safe | Metadata only |
| `airtable.records.create` | Risky | Creates data |
| `airtable.records.update` | Risky | Modifies data |
| `airtable.records.delete` | Dangerous | Irreversible |
| `airtable.tables.create` | Dangerous | Schema changes |
| `airtable.webhooks.manage` | Dangerous | Event routing |

---

## Agent Capabilities (Concrete Use Cases)

### Data Operations
- CRUD on records across bases and tables
- Complex filtering and sorting
- Field type handling (attachments, linked records, formulas)
- View-based data access

### Schema Operations
- Read table/field schemas
- Understand relationships between tables
- Access formula field definitions

### Automation Support
- Webhook triggers on record changes
- Bulk record operations
- Sync with external systems

### Examples of Agent Workflows
```
"Add this item to the inventory table"
"Find all tasks due this week"
"Update the status of this record"
"Get all records linked to this project"
"Export data from this view"
"Create a new record with attachments"
```

---

## Flywheel Ecosystem Synergies

### Stripe/Plaid Integration
**Financial tracking:**
- Transaction records in Airtable
- Budget tracking
- Invoice management

### Linear/Jira Integration
- Task mirroring
- Cross-platform project tracking

### Agent Mail Integration
- Record updates → agent threads
- Data change notifications

---

## Technical Implementation Notes

### API Surface
- **REST API**: Primary CRUD operations
- **Metadata API**: Schema information
- **Webhooks**: Change notifications

### Recommended Crates
- `reqwest` — HTTP client
- `serde_json` — JSON handling

### Authentication
| Mode | Use Case |
|------|----------|
| Personal Access Token | Individual access |
| OAuth 2.0 | Integration apps |

### Rate Limits
```rust
RateLimits {
    requests_per_second: 5,
    // Per base limits
}
```

---

## Zone Architecture

### Recommended Zones
| Zone | Description | Capabilities |
|------|-------------|--------------|
| `z:data:airtable:base:<id>` | Base-scoped | Single base |
| `z:data:airtable:full` | Full access | All bases |
| `z:data:airtable:readonly` | Read-only | Safe operations |

---

## Manifest Archetypes (Closed Set)
- `storage` — Record storage
- `operational` — CRUD operations
- `streaming` — Webhook events

---

## External Surface

### NetworkConstraints
Default-deny; allow only:
- `api.airtable.com:443`
- `dl.airtable.com:443` (attachments)

### Credential Injection
- API tokens via egress proxy
- OAuth tokens via CredentialId

---

## Capability Model

### Read Operations
- `airtable.records.read` — List/get records
- `airtable.schema.read` — Table/field metadata
- `airtable.views.read` — View data

### Write Operations
- `airtable.records.create` — Create records
- `airtable.records.update` — Update records

### Admin Operations
- `airtable.records.delete` — Delete records (Dangerous)
- `airtable.tables.create` — Create tables (Dangerous)
- `airtable.webhooks.manage` — Configure webhooks (Dangerous)

---

## Operations (Representative)

### List Records
```
GET /v0/{baseId}/{tableIdOrName}?filterByFormula={status}="Active"
```

### Create Record
```json
POST /v0/{baseId}/{tableIdOrName}
{
  "fields": {
    "Name": "New Item",
    "Status": "Active",
    "Due Date": "2024-01-15"
  }
}
```

### Update Record
```json
PATCH /v0/{baseId}/{tableIdOrName}/{recordId}
{
  "fields": {
    "Status": "Completed"
  }
}
```

### Delete Record
```
DELETE /v0/{baseId}/{tableIdOrName}/{recordId}
```

---

## Field Type Handling

### Supported Types
- Text, Number, Date
- Single/Multiple Select
- Linked Records
- Attachments
- Formulas (read-only)
- Rollups (read-only)

### Attachment Handling
```json
{
  "Attachments": [
    {
      "url": "https://dl.airtable.com/...",
      "filename": "document.pdf"
    }
  ]
}
```

---

## Tests

### Unit Tests (Mock-Only)
- Request construction
- Response parsing
- Filter formula building
- Field type handling

### Integration Tests
- Mock Airtable API responses
- Multi-table scenarios
- Error handling

### E2E Compliance
- Validates NetworkConstraints
- Dangerous operation approval flow
- Audit logging

---

## Acceptance Criteria
- Passes connector compliance runner (static + dynamic)
- No real Airtable API calls in unit tests
- Record CRUD works
- Filter formulas work
- Linked records handled
- Attachments work
- All V2 NORMATIVE requirements satisfied

title: fcp.airtable: Manifest + Capability Map (FCP2)
description:
# fcp.airtable: Manifest + Capability Map (FCP2)

## Goal
Lock down the Airtable connector’s **mechanical contract** so the platform can sandbox, authorize, and test it deterministically.

## Required contents
- Manifest archetypes: `storage`, `operational`, `streaming`.
- Operation list + schema IDs.
- Capability families + per-operation required caps.
- NetworkConstraints:
  - allow Airtable API host(s)
  - explicitly handle attachment download hosts (enumerate/pin; HTTPS-only; bounded)
- State model declaration for webhooks (if webhook cursors/subscription state is persisted).

## Outputs
- Complete manifest spec stored in this bead.
- Good/bad manifest examples for static compliance.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Another engineer can implement `--manifest` from this bead alone.
- Static compliance runner has enough detail to reject unsafe NetworkConstraints.

title: fcp.homeassistant: Integration aggregation layer for 2000+ device types
description:
# fcp.homeassistant: Integration aggregation layer for 2000+ device types (FCP2)

## Goal
Provide a unified, typed abstraction over Home Assistant’s entity/service model so the connector can support thousands of device integrations without bespoke code for each.

## Scope
- Entity registry discovery:
  - list entities with domain/area/device metadata
  - expose stable identifiers
- Domain capability mapping:
  - map entity domains to capability families (read vs write vs security-adjacent)
- Normalized “device control” schema:
  - a small set of generic operations covers most integrations

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `ha.entities.read`
- `ha.entities.write` (dangerous-ish)
- `ha.services.call` (dangerous-ish)

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- NetworkConstraints pinned to configured HA host.
- Strict safety for security-adjacent domains (locks, alarms) must be policy-owned and approval gated.

## Deliverables
- Canonical types:
  - `HaEntityRef`, `HaEntityState`, `HaServiceCall`
- Operation schemas:
  - `ha.entity.list`
  - `ha.entity.get`
  - `ha.entity.capabilities.get`

## Test strategy (MUST)
- Mock-only tests for:
  - entity registry parsing
  - domain mapping correctness
  - redaction of sensitive attributes

## Acceptance criteria
- The connector can support new HA integrations without adding new per-device code paths.

title: fcp.sentry: Auto-create Beads from Sentry issues
description:
# fcp.sentry - Error Tracking & Performance Monitoring Connector (FCP2)

## Strategic Context

### Value Assessment
**Strategic Value Score: 85/100** — Important Tier 2 connector (Observability family).

**Why Critical**: Sentry is the **leading application error tracking platform**. Enables agents to monitor application health, diagnose errors, and automatically create actionable work items from production issues. Essential for autonomous debugging workflows.

### Priority Matrix Position
- **Category**: Strategic Investment (High Value + Debugging Automation)
- **Build Phase**: Phase 2 Productivity (weeks 5-8)

---

## V2 Specification Compliance (NORMATIVE)

### ConnectorArchetype
```rust
archetypes: vec\![
    ConnectorArchetype::Operational,  // Issue management, alerts
    ConnectorArchetype::Streaming,    // Webhook events
]
```
- **Operational**: Issue CRUD, alert configuration, release tracking
- **Streaming**: Webhooks for new issues, regressions, alerts

### ConnectorStateModel
```rust
state_model: ConnectorStateModel::SingletonWriter
```
- **SingletonWriter**: Webhook deduplication, issue sync state
- State tracked: `{ processed_events: HashSet<EventId>, sync_cursors: HashMap<ProjectId, Cursor> }`
- Lease required for writer fencing

### ConnectorFormat
```rust
format: ConnectorFormat::Wasi
```
- **WASI recommended**: Handles API tokens
- Memory isolation for credential protection
- Capability-gated hostcalls

### NetworkConstraints (NORMATIVE)
```rust
NetworkConstraints {
    // Sentry API endpoints
    host_allow: vec\![
        "sentry.io".into(),
        "*.sentry.io".into(),
        // Self-hosted: explicitly configured
    ],
    port_allow: vec\![443],
    deny_localhost: true,
    deny_private_ranges: true,  // Override for self-hosted
    deny_tailnet_ranges: true,
    deny_ip_literals: true,
    require_sni: true,
    require_host_canonicalization: true,
}
```

### TaintFlags (NORMATIVE)
```rust
// Stack traces may contain sensitive data
stack_trace.provenance.taint = TaintFlags::EXTERNAL_INPUT;

// User context in errors is PII
user_context.provenance.taint = TaintFlags::USER_SUPPLIED;

// Webhook payloads are external
webhook_event.provenance.taint = TaintFlags::EXTERNAL_INPUT;

// URLs in breadcrumbs are unverified
if breadcrumb.contains_urls() {
    breadcrumb.provenance.taint |= TaintFlags::UNVERIFIED_LINK;
}
```

### SafetyTier per Operation
| Operation | SafetyTier | Rationale |
|-----------|------------|-----------|
| `sentry.issues.read` | Safe | Read-only |
| `sentry.events.read` | Safe | Read-only |
| `sentry.projects.read` | Safe | Metadata |
| `sentry.issues.update` | Risky | Status changes |
| `sentry.issues.assign` | Risky | Routing changes |
| `sentry.alerts.manage` | Dangerous | Alert configuration |
| `sentry.issues.delete` | Dangerous | Irreversible |
| `sentry.projects.admin` | Dangerous | Project settings |

---

## Agent Capabilities (Concrete Use Cases)

### Issue Management
- List and search issues
- View event details and stack traces
- Update issue status (resolve, ignore, unresolve)
- Assign issues to team members
- Add tags and annotations

### Event Analysis
- Inspect error events
- View breadcrumbs and context
- Analyze stack traces
- Correlate with releases

### Alerting & Monitoring
- Configure alert rules
- Manage notification channels
- View alert history

### Beads Integration
- Auto-create Beads from Sentry issues
- Sync issue status
- Link Beads to releases

### Examples of Agent Workflows
```
"Show me the top errors this week"
"Resolve all issues fixed in this release"
"Create a Bead for this critical error"
"Find errors related to this stack trace"
"Set up an alert for high error rates"
"Assign this issue to the backend team"
```

---

## Flywheel Ecosystem Synergies

### GitHub Integration
**Error-to-code linking:**
- Stack trace → source code
- Issue → PR reference
- Release correlation

### Linear/Jira Integration
- Error → issue creation
- Status sync
- Triage workflows

### Slack Integration
- Alert notifications
- Issue escalation

### Datadog/Grafana Integration
- Error rate metrics
- Performance correlation
- Unified observability

---

## Technical Implementation Notes

### API Surface
- **REST API**: Primary CRUD operations
- **Webhooks**: Event notifications

### Recommended Crates
- `reqwest` — HTTP client
- `serde_json` — JSON handling

### Authentication
| Mode | Use Case |
|------|----------|
| Auth Token | User-based access |
| DSN | Event ingestion (not for connector) |
| Internal Integration | Org-wide access |

### Rate Limits
```rust
RateLimits {
    requests_per_second: 10,
    // Concurrent request limits apply
}
```

---

## Zone Architecture

### Recommended Zones
| Zone | Description | Capabilities |
|------|-------------|--------------|
| `z:ops:sentry:full` | Full access | All projects |
| `z:ops:sentry:project:<slug>` | Project-scoped | Single project |
| `z:ops:sentry:readonly` | Read-only | Safe operations |

---

## Manifest Archetypes (Closed Set)
- `operational` — Issue management, alerts
- `streaming` — Webhook events

---

## External Surface

### NetworkConstraints
Default-deny; allow only:
- `sentry.io:443`
- `*.sentry.io:443`
- Self-hosted: configured hostname

### Credential Injection
- Auth tokens via egress proxy
- Webhook secrets for validation

---

## Capability Model

### Read Operations
- `sentry.issues.read` — List/get issues
- `sentry.events.read` — Event details
- `sentry.projects.read` — Project info

### Write Operations
- `sentry.issues.update` — Status changes
- `sentry.issues.assign` — Assignment

### Admin Operations
- `sentry.alerts.manage` — Alert rules (Dangerous)
- `sentry.issues.delete` — Delete issues (Dangerous)
- `sentry.projects.admin` — Project settings (Dangerous)

---

## Operations (Representative)

### List Issues
```
GET /api/0/projects/{org_slug}/{project_slug}/issues/
```

### Get Issue Details
```
GET /api/0/issues/{issue_id}/
```

### Update Issue Status
```json
PUT /api/0/issues/{issue_id}/
{
  "status": "resolved"
}
```

### List Events for Issue
```
GET /api/0/issues/{issue_id}/events/
```

---

## Beads Auto-Creation

### Trigger Sources
- New high-severity issue
- Issue regression
- Alert triggered
- Elevated error rate on release

### Mapping
```
Bead title: Sentry issue title (tainted)
Bead body: sanitized summary + links
Labels: project/environment/severity
```

### Deduplication
- Same Sentry issue ID → single Bead
- Idempotent webhook handling

---

## Tests

### Unit Tests (Mock-Only)
- Request construction
- Response parsing
- Webhook signature validation
- Issue status mapping

### Integration Tests
- Mock Sentry API responses
- Beads creation workflow
- Error handling

### E2E Compliance
- Validates NetworkConstraints
- Dangerous operation approval flow
- Audit logging

---

## Acceptance Criteria
- Passes connector compliance runner (static + dynamic)
- No real Sentry API calls in unit tests
- Issue listing and details work
- Status updates work
- Webhook handling functional
- Beads auto-creation works
- All V2 NORMATIVE requirements satisfied

title: fcp.jira: Comment and attachment handling
description:
# fcp.jira: Comment and attachment handling (FCP2)

## Goal
Add first-class support for Jira issue **comments** and **attachments**, including safe upload/download flows that preserve FCP2 security invariants.

Comments and attachments are high-leverage for real workflows, but they also carry:
- PII risk
- large binary payload risk
- data exfil risk

## Scope
### Comments
- List comments for an issue (pagination).
- Create/update/delete comments (with visibility rules when supported).
- Convert between:
  - Jira Cloud ADF (Atlassian Document Format)
  - a canonical connector representation (e.g., markdown + structured spans)

### Attachments
- List attachments for an issue (metadata only).
- Download attachment content (streamed; size limits; hash).
- Upload attachment (streamed; content-type allowlist; filename sanitization).
- Delete attachment (dangerous; approval-gated).

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `jira.comments.read`
- `jira.comments.write`
- `jira.attachments.read`
- `jira.attachments.write` (dangerous: data egress into Jira)
- `jira.attachments.delete` (dangerous)

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- NetworkConstraints pinned to Jira base hostname and any attachment host if distinct.
- No secrets in logs.
- **Binary safety**:
  - enforce max download size; abort early
  - enforce max upload size; abort early
  - compute content hash for receipts/audit evidence
- **Taint model**:
  - comment bodies and attachment filenames are tainted inputs
  - do not allow tainted text to trigger dangerous operations without approval

## Deliverables
- Operation schemas:
  - `jira.comment.list`
  - `jira.comment.create`
  - `jira.comment.update`
  - `jira.comment.delete`
  - `jira.attachment.list`
  - `jira.attachment.download`
  - `jira.attachment.upload`
  - `jira.attachment.delete`
- Streaming download/upload helpers compatible with sandboxed IO.

## Test strategy (MUST)
### Unit/integration (mock-only)
- ADF ↔ markdown conversion golden tests.
- Upload tests:
  - filename normalization
  - content-type allowlist
  - size limits
- Download tests:
  - streaming behavior
  - early abort on oversized content
  - hash correctness

### Compliance
- Any write/delete emits OperationReceipt + AuditEvent with:
  - issue key
  - comment id / attachment id
  - content hash (never raw content)

## Acceptance criteria
- Comments round-trip through conversion without losing critical structure.
- Attachment IO is streaming + bounded (no unbounded buffering).
- Dangerous operations are capability + (policy) approval gated and audited.

title: FIX: connector_target_from_env_matches_runtime test arch normalization
description:
## Bug Summary

The test `connector_target_from_env_matches_runtime` was failing because it compared `ConnectorTarget::from_env().arch` directly with `std::env::consts::ARCH`.

However, `ConnectorTarget::from_env()` intentionally normalizes architecture names for OCI/Docker compatibility:
- `x86_64` → `amd64`
- `aarch64` → `arm64`

## Fix

Updated the test to expect the normalized arch value by using the same mapping logic that `from_env()` uses.

## Files Changed

- `crates/fcp-registry/src/lib.rs`: Fixed test assertion to account for arch normalization

## Verification

- All 48 fcp-registry tests pass
- Full workspace tests pass
- No clippy warnings introduced
close_reason: Closed

title: fcp.twilio: SMS sending and receiving
description:
# fcp.twilio: SMS sending and receiving (FCP2)

## Goal
Provide core SMS/MMS capabilities:
- send outbound SMS (and MMS when enabled)
- read message status/history
- support inbound SMS via webhook-driven event flow (ingest handled in `flywheel_connectors-ugp`)

## Scope
### Outbound
- Send SMS to a single destination.
- Optional: bulk send with batching + rate limiting.
- Support idempotency keys to prevent duplicate sends.

### Status / history
- Get message details by SID.
- List messages with filters (date range, to/from).

### Media (MMS)
- List/download media attachments (bounded + host pinned).

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `twilio.sms.send`
- `twilio.sms.read`
- `twilio.sms.media.read`

Policy guidance:
- Outbound send is a real-world side effect; many orgs require approval for certain destinations.

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- NetworkConstraints pinned to Twilio API host(s) and explicit media hosts.
- For sends:
  - receipts + audit events with message SID + to/from hashes (never raw phone numbers in logs)
  - strict log redaction for phone numbers and message bodies
- Taint model:
  - inbound message bodies are tainted by default

## Deliverables
- Operation schemas:
  - `twilio.sms.send`
  - `twilio.sms.get`
  - `twilio.sms.list`
  - `twilio.sms.media.list`
  - `twilio.sms.media.download`
- Idempotency strategy:
  - stable client idempotency key → dedupe cache/state

## Test strategy (MUST)
- Mock-only tests for:
  - send request formation
  - idempotency behavior
  - status polling
  - media download size limits
  - secret/PII redaction in logs

## Acceptance criteria
- Duplicate sends are mechanically prevented via idempotency.
- Logs and receipts never leak phone numbers or message bodies.

title: TEST: Revocation System Unit/Integration Tests
description:
## Overview

Comprehensive test suite for Revocation System (i4zm). This is CRITICAL security testing.

## Test Categories

### 1. RevocationObject Tests
- **Creation**: Valid revocation with owner signature
- **Signature validation**: Only owner can sign revocations
- **Scope variants**: Test all RevocationScope types
- **Effective timing**: effective_at in past/present/future
- **Expiry handling**: Temporary vs permanent revocations

### 2. RevocationEvent Chain Tests
- **Chain integrity**: Hash links verified
- **Monotonic seq**: seq always increases
- **Chain traversal**: Full history retrievable
- **Concurrent additions**: No forks in chain

### 3. RevocationHead Tests
- **Quorum validation**: Requires N-of-M signatures
- **Freshness comparison**: head_seq comparison works
- **Head updates**: New events create new heads
- **Cross-zone heads**: Separate chains per zone

### 4. RevocationRegistry Tests
- **Bloom filter accuracy**: No false negatives
- **is_revoked() correctness**: True positives work
- **Fast path performance**: Bloom filter ~O(1)
- **Registry persistence**: Survives restart
- **Registry rebuild**: Reconstruct from chain

### 5. Enforcement Point Tests
- **Capability verification**: Revoked tokens rejected
- **Freshness check**: Stale revocation state detected
- **All scopes enforced**: Each scope type enforced correctly
- **Timing edge cases**: effective_at boundary conditions

### 6. Propagation Tests
- **Gossip priority**: Revocations propagate quickly
- **Network partition**: Revocations merge after heal
- **Duplicate handling**: Same revocation received twice
- **Order independence**: Out-of-order delivery handled

### 7. Use Case Tests
- **Capability revocation**: Token revoke → immediate rejection
- **IssuerKey revocation**: Node can't mint new tokens
- **NodeAttestation revocation**: Complete device removal
- **ZoneKey revocation**: Forces key rotation
- **ConnectorBinary revocation**: Binary hash blocked

## Logging Requirements

All tests emit structured JSON:
```json
{
  "test": "test_revocation_enforcement",
  "scope": "Capability",
  "revoked_object_id": "objectid:...",
  "enforcement_point": "verify_capability_token",
  "result": "rejected_as_expected",
  "timing_us": 45
}
```

## Security-Focused Tests

- **Replay attacks**: Old revocation can't un-revoke
- **Signature bypass**: Unsigned revocations rejected
- **Scope escalation**: Capability scope can't revoke zone key
- **Clock attacks**: Manipulated timestamps detected

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] All RevocationScope variants tested
- [ ] Chain integrity verified
- [ ] Quorum signatures tested
- [ ] All enforcement points verified
- [ ] Propagation tested
- [ ] Use cases validated
- [ ] Security tests comprehensive
- [ ] Structured JSON logging in all tests
close_reason: Duplicate of 36x3 which is already comprehensive

## Goal

- `knowledge`
- `storage`
- `operational`

## External surface
### NetworkConstraints
Default-deny; allow only `api.notion.com:443` (and any additional Notion endpoints required by the chosen auth mode).

- databases: create/get/update/query, items create/update
- blocks: get/update/delete, children list/append
- search

- Writes emit receipts/audit.

- E2E compliance run validates default deny + NetworkConstraints + receipts.

title: TEST: Provenance/Taint Unit Tests (Label Propagation, Approval Enforcement, Sanitizer Receipts)
description:
# TEST: Provenance/Taint Unit Tests

## Goal
Prove that information flow controls work correctly and cannot be bypassed.

## Test Categories

### Provenance Field Handling
- [ ] origin_zone correctly tracked
- [ ] current_zone updated on zone crossing
- [ ] integrity_label correctly propagated
- [ ] confidentiality_label correctly propagated
- [ ] taints accumulated correctly

### Taint Flags
- [ ] PUBLIC_INPUT flag applied to public data
- [ ] EXTERNAL_INPUT flag applied to external API responses
- [ ] UNVERIFIED_LINK flag applied to unverified references
- [ ] USER_SUPPLIED flag applied to user inputs
- [ ] PROMPT_SURFACE flag applied to data reaching prompts
- [ ] Flags accumulate (union) correctly

### Label Merge Rules
- [ ] integrity = MIN(input_integrities) - verified
- [ ] confidentiality = MAX(input_confidentialities) - verified
- [ ] Property tests: merge is associative and commutative
- [ ] Edge cases: empty inputs, single input, many inputs

### Integrity Flow (Biba Model)
- [ ] Down-flow (high→low integrity): allowed without approval
- [ ] Up-flow (low→high integrity): requires Elevation approval
- [ ] Missing elevation approval → rejection with reason_code
- [ ] Valid elevation approval → allow

### Confidentiality Flow (Bell-LaPadula Model)
- [ ] Up-flow (low→high confidentiality): allowed without approval
- [ ] Down-flow (high→low confidentiality): requires Declassification approval
- [ ] Missing declassification approval → rejection
- [ ] Valid declassification approval → allow

### ApprovalToken Verification
- [ ] scope = Elevation: validates integrity transition
- [ ] scope = Declassification: validates confidentiality transition
- [ ] from_label/to_label binding enforced
- [ ] Time validity (iat/exp) enforced
- [ ] Signature verification succeeds/fails correctly

### SanitizerReceipt Verification
- [ ] Receipt covers input object IDs
- [ ] Receipt from authorized sanitizer
- [ ] Receipt within validity period
- [ ] Taint flags correctly reduced after sanitization
- [ ] Partial sanitization (some taints remain) handled

### Cross-Zone Operations
- [ ] Zone crossing requires appropriate approvals
- [ ] Labels adjusted correctly on zone entry
- [ ] DecisionReceipt captures zone crossing denial

### Attack Scenarios (Adversarial)
- [ ] Taint laundering: attempt to remove taint without receipt → rejected
- [ ] Elevation bypass: low-integrity data to high-integrity zone without approval → rejected
- [ ] Declassification leak: high-confidentiality data to low-confidentiality sink → rejected
- [ ] Forged sanitizer receipt: invalid signature → rejected
- [ ] Stale approval: expired ApprovalToken → rejected

## Golden Vectors
- Provenance merge scenarios with expected output
- ApprovalToken for elevation and declassification
- SanitizerReceipt format and verification

## Property Tests
- Merge rule properties (associative, commutative)
- No taint reduction without valid receipt
- Labels never increase integrity / decrease confidentiality without approval

## Logging Requirements
```json
{
  "test_name": "...",
  "flow_type": "integrity|confidentiality",
  "from_label": "...",
  "to_label": "...",
  "approval_present": true,
  "result": "pass|fail",
  "reason_code": "..."
}
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- All label propagation paths tested
- Approval enforcement verified
- No taint bypass possible
notes:
Added 10 property tests for provenance merge invariants:
- property_merge_commutativity
- property_merge_associativity
- property_merge_integrity_is_minimum
- property_merge_confidentiality_is_maximum
- property_merge_taint_accumulation
- property_merge_single_preserves_labels
- property_merge_empty_returns_zone_defaults
- property_taint_flags_merge_commutativity
- property_taint_flags_merge_associativity
- property_taint_flags_merge_identity

All tests use rand crate with deterministic seed for reproducibility.
close_reason: 35 comprehensive tests covering provenance fields, ApprovalToken scopes, SanitizerReceipt zone authority, taint accumulation, label merge rules, flow checks, and adversarial scenarios. All tests pass.

title: fcp.trello: Trello Kanban Board Connector
description:
# fcp.trello Connector


## Goal
Provide an FCP2-compliant Trello connector for boards/cards automation with strict capabilities and webhook ingestion.

Flywheel Connector Protocol implementation for Trello - the popular kanban board platform for project management and team collaboration.

## External surface (NetworkConstraints)
Default deny.
- Network egress MUST be restricted per-operation via manifest `NetworkConstraints` (defined in the connector’s manifest/cap map bead if present).
- Allow only the configured service host(s); HTTPS-only where applicable; deny redirects by default.
- Bound timeouts + response sizes; treat all remote responses as untrusted input; never leak secrets/PII in logs or errors.

## Manifest archetypes (closed set)

- `operational`
- `streaming`

> Interaction patterns (non-archetype): Request/Response + Webhook

## Overview

- **Value Score**: 63/100 (Tier 4)
- **Archetype**: Request-Response + Webhook
- **Platform**: Trello REST API
- **Model**: Simple kanban (boards, lists, cards)

## Operations

### Board Management
- Create, read, update, delete boards
- Board settings and preferences
- Board backgrounds and power-ups
- Board templates

### List Management
- Create, read, update, archive lists
- List positioning and ordering
- Move lists between boards

### Card Operations (CRUD)
- Create, read, update, delete cards
- Card positioning within lists
- Move cards between lists/boards
- Card due dates and reminders
- Card cover images

### Checklists
- Create, read, update, delete checklists
- Checklist items management
- Item completion tracking
- Copy checklists between cards

### Labels
- Create, read, update, delete labels
- Assign/remove labels from cards
- Custom label colors and names

### Attachments
- Upload attachments to cards
- Link external URLs
- Delete attachments
- Attachment previews

### Members
- List board members
- Add/remove members from boards
- Assign/unassign members to cards
- Member permissions

## Zone Architecture

<!-- fcp2-single-zone-note -->
**FCP2 single-zone binding note:** A connector instance binds to exactly one `ZoneId` for its entire lifetime.
The *"zones"* described in this section are a **recommended deployment pattern** (run separate connector instances in separate zones with different capability grants/policies) and/or conceptual risk tiers.
The connector MUST NOT multiplex multiple zones internally.


### Zone: board_read
- Read board details and settings
- List boards for user
- Read lists and list positions
- Read cards and card details
- Read checklists and items
- Read labels and attachments
- Read member information

### Zone: card_write
- Create/update/delete cards
- Manage card positions
- Create/update/delete checklists
- Manage checklist items
- Add/remove labels from cards
- Upload/delete attachments
- Assign/unassign members to cards

### Zone: board_admin
- Create/update/delete boards
- Create/update/delete lists
- Create/update/delete labels
- Add/remove board members
- Manage board settings
- Archive/unarchive boards

## Dependencies

- `fcp-core`: Core FCP types and traits
- `fcp-oauth`: OAuth 1.0a authentication (Trello uses OAuth 1.0a)
- `fcp-webhook`: Real-time webhook handling for board/card events
- `fcp-ratelimit`: Rate limiting (Trello: 100 requests/10s per token, 300/10s per key)
- `fcp-telemetry`: Metrics and tracing

## Technical Details

### Authentication
- OAuth 1.0a flow
- API Key + Token authentication
- Token expiration handling

### Rate Limits
- 100 requests per 10 seconds per token
- 300 requests per 10 seconds per API key
- Rate limit headers: `X-RateLimit-Limit`, `X-RateLimit-Remaining`

### Webhook Events
- Card created/updated/deleted
- Card moved between lists
- Checklist item completed
- Member added/removed
- Board updated
- List created/archived

### API Considerations
- Nested resources (board > list > card > checklist)
- Batch operations support
- Field selection for response optimization
- Pagination via `limit` and `before`/`since` parameters

## Implementation Plan

1. **Phase 1**: Core board and list operations
2. **Phase 2**: Card CRUD and positioning
3. **Phase 3**: Checklists and labels
4. **Phase 4**: Attachments and members
5. **Phase 5**: Webhook integration

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Full board CRUD operations
- [ ] Complete list management
- [ ] Card operations with positioning
- [ ] Checklist and label support
- [ ] Attachment upload/management
- [ ] Member management
- [ ] Webhook event handling
- [ ] Rate limit compliance
- [ ] OAuth 1.0a authentication flow
- [ ] Zone-based permission model
- [ ] Comprehensive test coverage

title: fcp.twilio: Webhook handling for incoming messages
description:
# fcp.twilio: Webhook handling for incoming messages (FCP2)

## Goal
Safely ingest Twilio webhooks for:
- inbound SMS/MMS
- delivery status updates
- voice call status events (if configured)

Webhooks are a primary streaming surface and must be treated as **tainted untrusted input**.

## Scope
### Webhook ingestion
- Validate `X-Twilio-Signature` (or equivalent) against the configured webhook secret.
- Parse form-encoded payloads into typed event objects.
- Emit connector events with:
  - stable event IDs
  - correlation_id linkage

### Idempotency and replay safety
- Deduplicate repeated webhook deliveries.
- Handle out-of-order status callbacks safely.

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `twilio.webhook.ingest`

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- Default deny: webhook ingestion itself is capability gated.
- Taint:
  - all inbound content (message body, sender number, media URLs) is tainted by default
- NetworkConstraints:
  - do not follow arbitrary media URLs unless pinned/allowed

## Deliverables
- Operation schema:
  - `twilio.webhook.ingest`
- Event envelopes:
  - `twilio.sms.incoming`
  - `twilio.sms.status`
  - `twilio.voice.status` (optional)
- Dedup state model:
  - store webhook delivery IDs / message SIDs / call SIDs as needed

## Test strategy (MUST)
- Mock-only tests for:
  - signature validation (golden vectors)
  - taint propagation
  - dedupe/out-of-order handling
  - refusal on invalid signature

## Acceptance criteria
- Invalid signatures are rejected with a clear reason code.
- Webhook replays do not create duplicate downstream events.

title: TEST: Audit Chain Unit Tests (Hash Linking, Checkpoints, DecisionReceipts, Fork Detection)
description:
# TEST: Audit Chain Unit Tests

## Goal
Prove that the audit chain provides tamper-evident history with explainable decisions.

## Test Categories

### AuditEvent Chain
- [ ] Events hash-linked correctly (prev_hash binding)
- [ ] Monotonic seq enforced
- [ ] Event types correctly discriminated
- [ ] Timestamp ordering reasonable (within skew)
- [ ] Zone binding correct
- [ ] Event payload schema-validated

### AuditHead
- [ ] Quorum signatures required (n-f for CriticalWrite)
- [ ] Insufficient signatures rejected
- [ ] Signature from non-member rejected
- [ ] Signature set canonicalized (sorted by node_id)
- [ ] AuditHead references correct chain tip

### ZoneCheckpoint
- [ ] Binds audit_head correctly (id + seq)
- [ ] Binds revocation_head correctly (id + seq)
- [ ] Binds policy_head correctly
- [ ] Binds config_head correctly
- [ ] Quorum signatures valid
- [ ] seq is monotonic

### DecisionReceipt
- [ ] Content-addressed (stable ObjectId)
- [ ] reason_code is stable and enumerable
- [ ] evidence ObjectIds are present and resolvable
- [ ] Denied operations produce DecisionReceipt
- [ ] DecisionReceipt is in audit chain

### Fork Detection
- [ ] Same seq, different id → fork detected
- [ ] Fork detection halts checkpoint advancement
- [ ] Fork emits audit event
- [ ] Fork requires manual intervention
- [ ] No auto-resolution of forks

### TraceContext Propagation
- [ ] trace_id preserved through invoke → receipt → audit
- [ ] span_id correctly propagated
- [ ] Missing trace_id handled gracefully

### Explainability (fcp explain)
- [ ] DecisionReceipt can be fetched by operation_id
- [ ] Evidence chain can be traversed
- [ ] Reason code maps to human explanation
- [ ] AI recovery hints available where applicable

## Golden Vectors
- Valid AuditEvent chain segment
- AuditHead with quorum signatures
- ZoneCheckpoint binding all heads
- DecisionReceipt with evidence

## Property Tests
- Seq is always monotonic
- Hash linking is consistent
- No event can be removed without detection

## Fuzz Targets
- AuditEvent parsing
- AuditHead signature verification
- DecisionReceipt parsing

## Logging Requirements
```json
{
  "test_name": "...",
  "chain_seq": 123,
  "event_type": "...",
  "checkpoint_seq": 456,
  "result": "pass|fail",
  "reason_code": "..."
}
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- Chain integrity verified
- Fork detection works
- DecisionReceipts are explainable
close_reason: Added 55 comprehensive unit tests for audit chain primitives (AuditEvent, AuditHead, ZoneCheckpoint, DecisionReceipt, fork detection, TraceContext, golden vectors). All tests pass, clippy clean.

title: Study: Clawdbot Discord Connector Implementation
description:
# Study: Clawdbot Discord Connector Implementation


## Goal
Study Clawdbot Discord connector implementation to extract edge cases, performance pitfalls, and security lessons for FCP2.

## External surface (NetworkConstraints)
Default deny.
- Network egress MUST be restricted per-operation via manifest `NetworkConstraints`.
- Allow only the configured service host(s); HTTPS-only where applicable; deny redirects by default.
- Bound timeouts + response sizes; treat all remote responses as untrusted input; never leak secrets/PII in logs or errors.

## Zone model (mechanical)

<!-- fcp2-single-zone-note -->
**FCP2 single-zone binding note:** A connector instance binds to exactly one `ZoneId` for its entire lifetime.
The connector MUST NOT multiplex multiple zones internally.

Recommended deployment pattern: run separate connector instances in separate zones with different capability grants/policies.

## Objective

Research and document the existing clawdbot Discord connector implementation to extract patterns, learnings, and reusable components for building FCP connectors.

## Research Areas

### 1. Architecture Overview
- [ ] Overall connector structure
- [ ] Module organization
- [ ] Dependency graph
- [ ] Configuration management
- [ ] Entry point and initialization

### 2. Discord API Integration
- [ ] Gateway connection handling
- [ ] REST API usage patterns
- [ ] Rate limiting implementation
- [ ] Retry logic and backoff
- [ ] Error handling strategies

### 3. Event Handling
- [ ] Event subscription model
- [ ] Event parsing and validation
- [ ] Event dispatching mechanism
- [ ] Event filtering capabilities
- [ ] Async event processing

### 4. Authentication & Security
- [ ] Token management
- [ ] Permission handling
- [ ] Credential storage patterns
- [ ] Security best practices used

### 5. Message Processing
- [ ] Message parsing
- [ ] Command extraction
- [ ] Response formatting
- [ ] Attachment handling
- [ ] Embed construction

### 6. State Management
- [ ] Guild/server state tracking
- [ ] User session management
- [ ] Cache strategies
- [ ] Persistence patterns

### 7. Testing Approach
- [ ] Unit test patterns
- [ ] Integration test setup
- [ ] Mock strategies for Discord API
- [ ] Test coverage areas

## Deliverables

1. **Architecture Diagram** - Visual representation of connector structure
2. **Pattern Catalog** - Documented patterns that can be reused
3. **Anti-Pattern Notes** - What to avoid based on learnings
4. **Reusable Components List** - Code/patterns that can be extracted
5. **Recommendations** - Suggestions for FCP connector design

## Questions to Answer

- How does clawdbot handle Discord's rate limits?
- What reconnection strategy is used for the gateway?
- How are slash commands registered and handled?
- How is state synchronized across restarts?
- What logging/observability patterns are used?

## Resources

- Clawdbot repository
- Discord.js/Discord.py documentation (for comparison)
- Discord API documentation
- Existing connector documentation

## Time Estimate

- Research: 4-6 hours
- Documentation: 2-3 hours
- Total: 6-9 hours

## Acceptance Criteria
- Runs deterministically in CI (no flake due to timing/network).
- Uses mocks only (no real external network).
- Emits structured JSON logs per `flywheel_connectors-1n78.35` with stable `test_name` identifiers.

title: fcp.jira: Automation rule management
description:
# fcp.jira: Automation rule management (FCP2)

## Goal
Support Jira Automation ("Automation for Jira") rule management for organizations that want:
- agent-assisted creation of automation rules
- safe enable/disable workflows
- auditing of automation changes

Automation configuration is **admin-level** and can have broad blast radius. This bead is explicitly treated as *dangerous*.

## Scope
### Read
- List automation rules (project-scoped / global-scoped where allowed).
- Get rule definition + status (enabled/disabled).

### Write (dangerous; approval-gated)
- Create rule (from a constrained schema).
- Update rule.
- Enable/disable rule.
- Delete rule.

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `jira.automation.read`
- `jira.automation.write` (dangerous)
- `jira.admin` (dangerous; optional umbrella)

Policy guidance:
- Require ApprovalToken for any write.
- Include a two-person rule if the org policy requires it.

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- NetworkConstraints pinned.
- Receipts + audit events for all writes with:
  - rule id
  - project id
  - diff summary (structural; no secrets)

## Deliverables
- Operation schemas:
  - `jira.automation.rule.list`
  - `jira.automation.rule.get`
  - `jira.automation.rule.create`
  - `jira.automation.rule.update`
  - `jira.automation.rule.enable`
  - `jira.automation.rule.disable`
  - `jira.automation.rule.delete`
- A constrained rule representation:
  - avoid arbitrary script injection
  - prefer templates + parameterization

## Test strategy (MUST)
### Unit/integration (mock-only)
- Rule CRUD happy paths.
- Permission denied.
- Validation failures (unsafe actions rejected).
- Idempotency: repeated enable/disable does not drift.

### Compliance
- Ensure all write ops require appropriate capabilities + approval.
- Ensure audit evidence includes a stable structural hash of the rule definition.

## Acceptance criteria
- Connector can manage automation rules without enabling arbitrary code execution.
- All writes are approval-gated and produce receipts/audit events.

title: fcp-webhook: Shared Webhook Handling Library
description:
# fcp-webhook: Shared Webhook Handling Library

## Overview
Production webhook handling library supporting signature verification, event routing, and delivery management for inbound webhooks.

## Signature Verification
- HMAC-SHA256 (Stripe, GitHub, Slack)
- HMAC-SHA1 (legacy)
- Ed25519 signatures
- Timestamp validation (replay prevention)
- Multiple algorithm support per provider

## Provider Support
- GitHub (X-Hub-Signature-256)
- Stripe (Stripe-Signature with timestamp)
- Slack (X-Slack-Signature)
- Linear (Linear-Signature)
- Discord (Ed25519)
- Custom providers via configuration

## Event Processing
- Event type routing
- Payload parsing (JSON, form-encoded)
- Event filtering and subscription
- Priority queue processing

## Delivery Management
- Idempotency (deduplication by event ID)
- At-least-once delivery guarantee
- Retry scheduling for failures
- Dead letter queue
- Delivery status tracking

## Security
- IP allowlist verification
- Request size limits
- Timeout enforcement
- TLS certificate validation

## Observability
- Delivery metrics
- Latency tracking
- Error categorization
- Audit logging

## Dependencies
- hmac, sha2, ed25519-dalek
- serde_json, chrono
- fcp-core, fcp-telemetry
close_reason: Implemented fcp-webhook crate with HMAC/Ed25519 signature verification, provider handlers (GitHub, Stripe, Slack, Linear), event routing, idempotency, and dead letter queue. All 18 tests passing.

title: fcp.zendesk: Auto-Categorize Incoming Tickets
description:
# fcp.zendesk: Auto-Categorize Incoming Tickets (FCP2)

## Goal
Provide an automation pipeline that turns inbound tickets into structured, actionable metadata:
- category labels
- priority suggestions
- macro suggestions
- escalation flags (SLA risk, sentiment)

This bead must be **safe-by-default**: it may *recommend* actions, but must not silently mutate tickets without explicit capability + (policy) approval.

## Trigger sources
- Ticket-created / ticket-updated webhooks (tainted input).

## Scope
### Classification (suggest-only)
- Produce a `TicketClassification` object:
  - category (billing/tech/account/etc)
  - priority suggestion
  - confidence
  - recommended macros
  - recommended routing queue

### Optional apply step (dangerous)
- Apply tags/fields/macro to a ticket **only** when explicitly invoked and authorized.

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `zendesk.webhook.ingest`
- `zendesk.tickets.read`
- `zendesk.classify` (produces suggestions)
- `zendesk.tickets.write` (dangerous; for applying results)

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- NetworkConstraints pinned.
- Taint:
  - ticket bodies and requester text are tainted
  - suggestions derived from tainted inputs must carry provenance/taint metadata
- For any mutation:
  - receipts + audit events
  - approval gating recommended

## Deliverables
- Event ingestion schema:
  - `zendesk.webhook.ticket_ingest`
- Operation schemas:
  - `zendesk.ticket.classify`
  - Optional: `zendesk.ticket.apply_classification`
- State:
  - webhook delivery dedupe
  - last-classified fingerprint to avoid repeated work

## Test strategy (MUST)
- Mock-only tests for:
  - webhook replay/idempotency
  - classification object schema stability
  - deny-by-default for mutation without capability/approval

## Acceptance criteria
- Inbound tickets can be categorized deterministically with clear evidence.
- No automatic mutations occur without explicit authorization.

title: fcp.zendesk: Macro/Canned Response Management
description:
# fcp.zendesk: Macro/Canned Response Management (FCP2)

## Goal
Enable safe use of Zendesk macros/canned responses to:
- retrieve available macros
- apply macros to tickets (with controlled variable substitution)
- optionally manage macros (admin-only; dangerous)

## Scope
### Read
- List macros.
- Get macro details (actions/conditions).

### Write
- Apply macro to a ticket (dangerous-ish: mutates ticket state / adds comments).
- Optional: create/update/delete macros (dangerous; admin).

## Capability model (illustrative)
- `zendesk.macros.read`
- `zendesk.macros.apply` (dangerous-ish)
- Optional: `zendesk.macros.write` (dangerous)

## FCP2 requirements
- Single-zone binding.
- NetworkConstraints pinned.
- For macro apply:
  - receipts + audit events include ticket id + macro id
  - never log macro-expanded ticket content

## Deliverables
- Operation schemas:
  - `zendesk.macro.list`
  - `zendesk.macro.get`
  - `zendesk.macro.apply`
  - Optional: `zendesk.macro.create/update/delete`
- Safe template handling:
  - restrict which fields can be mutated
  - sanitize substitutions

## Test strategy (MUST)
- Mock-only tests for:
  - apply macro happy path
  - variable substitution safety
  - receipts/audit for apply

## Acceptance criteria
- Macros can be applied safely without content leakage.
- Admin macro management (if enabled) is approval gated.

title: fcp.figma: Design Collaboration and Asset Extraction Connector
description:
# fcp.figma - Design Collaboration and Asset Extraction Connector (FCP2)

## Success Criteria
- `flywheel_connectors-vuwy.1` (Manifest + Capability Map) is complete and passes static validation (IDs, schemas, NetworkConstraints, safety tiers).
- `flywheel_connectors-vuwy.2` (Provisioning Automation) is complete, minimizes human prompts, and is fully mockable for tests.
- `flywheel_connectors-vuwy.3` (Unit/Integration Tests) are mock-only, include success + denial paths, and assert log redaction (no secrets/PII).
- `flywheel_connectors-vuwy.4` (E2E Compliance Run) passes the shared compliance runner and emits an evidence bundle (logs + receipts + audit checks).
- Connector is V2-only: single-zone binding, default deny, constrained egress, audited risky/dangerous ops.

## Strategic Context

### Value Assessment
**Strategic Value Score: 85/100** — High priority Tier 2 connector.

**Why Critical**: Figma is the **dominant collaborative design platform** (~80% market share in product design). Enables agents to access design specs, extract assets, automate design-to-code workflows, and bridge design-development collaboration.

### Priority Matrix Position
- **Category**: Strategic Investment (High Value + Design-Dev Bridge)
- **Build Phase**: Phase 2 Productivity (weeks 5-8)

---

## V2 Specification Compliance (NORMATIVE)

### ConnectorArchetype
```rust
archetypes: vec\![
    ConnectorArchetype::Knowledge,    // Design file introspection
    ConnectorArchetype::Operational,  // Asset extraction
    ConnectorArchetype::Streaming,    // Webhook events
]
```
- **Knowledge**: Design file reading, component discovery
- **Operational**: Asset export, comment management
- **Streaming**: Webhooks for file updates

### ConnectorStateModel
```rust
state_model: ConnectorStateModel::Stateless
```
- **Stateless**: Each request is independent
- Version info fetched on demand
- No sync cursors needed

### ConnectorFormat
```rust
format: ConnectorFormat::Wasi
```
- **WASI recommended**: Handles OAuth tokens
- Memory isolation for credential protection
- Capability-gated hostcalls

### NetworkConstraints (NORMATIVE)
```rust
NetworkConstraints {
    // Figma API endpoints
    host_allow: vec\![
        "api.figma.com".into(),
        "www.figma.com".into(),
        // For image exports
        "figma-alpha-api.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com".into(),
        "s3-alpha-sig.figma.com".into(),
    ],
    port_allow: vec\![443],
    deny_localhost: true,
    deny_private_ranges: true,
    deny_tailnet_ranges: true,
    deny_ip_literals: true,
    require_sni: true,
    require_host_canonicalization: true,
}
```

### TaintFlags (NORMATIVE)
```rust
// Design content is user-generated
design_content.provenance.taint = TaintFlags::USER_SUPPLIED;

// Comments are external input
comment.provenance.taint = TaintFlags::EXTERNAL_INPUT
    | TaintFlags::USER_SUPPLIED;

// Export URLs are external
export_url.provenance.taint = TaintFlags::UNVERIFIED_LINK;
```

### SafetyTier per Operation
| Operation | SafetyTier | Rationale |
|-----------|------------|-----------|
| `figma.files.read` | Safe | Read-only |
| `figma.components.read` | Safe | Read-only |
| `figma.styles.read` | Safe | Design tokens |
| `figma.images.export` | Safe | Asset generation |
| `figma.comments.read` | Safe | Read-only |
| `figma.comments.write` | Risky | Creates content |
| `figma.versions.read` | Safe | History |
| `figma.webhooks.manage` | Dangerous | Event routing |

---

## Agent Capabilities (Concrete Use Cases)

### Design Access
- Read file and component information
- Access design tokens and styles
- Navigate frame/component hierarchy
- Get version history

### Asset Extraction
- Export images (PNG, JPG, SVG, PDF)
- Extract component assets
- Batch export multiple nodes
- Get image fills

### Design System Integration
- Read component library info
- Access shared styles
- Get variable collections (design tokens)

### Examples of Agent Workflows
```
"Export all icons from this file as SVGs"
"Get the design specs for this component"
"Find all text styles used in the file"
"List components in the design system"
"Extract color tokens from this file"
"Get comments on this design"
```

---

## Flywheel Ecosystem Synergies

### Linear/Jira Integration
**Design-task linking:**
- Link designs to issues
- Design review workflows

### GitHub Integration
- Design → code references
- PR design previews

### Slack Integration
- Design update notifications
- Review request routing

### Agent Mail Integration
- Design comments → agent threads
- Version update notifications

---

## Technical Implementation Notes

### API Surface
- **REST API**: File reading, exports
- **Webhooks**: File change events

### Recommended Crates
- `reqwest` — HTTP client
- `serde_json` — JSON handling
- `oauth2` — Authentication

### Authentication
| Mode | Use Case |
|------|----------|
| Personal Access Token | Individual access |
| OAuth 2.0 | Integration apps |

### Rate Limits
```rust
RateLimits {
    requests_per_minute: 720,
    // Per-file export limits apply
}
```

---

## Zone Architecture

### Recommended Zones
| Zone | Description | Capabilities |
|------|-------------|--------------|
| `z:design:figma:full` | Full access | All files |
| `z:design:figma:team:<id>` | Team-scoped | Team files |
| `z:design:figma:readonly` | Read-only | No comments |

---

## Manifest Archetypes (Closed Set)
- `knowledge` — Design file reading
- `operational` — Asset extraction
- `streaming` — Webhook events

---

## External Surface

### NetworkConstraints
Default-deny; allow only:
- `api.figma.com:443`
- `s3-alpha-sig.figma.com:443` (exports)

### Credential Injection
- OAuth tokens via egress proxy
- Personal tokens via CredentialId

---

## Capability Model

### Read Operations
- `figma.files.read` — File structure
- `figma.components.read` — Component info
- `figma.styles.read` — Design tokens
- `figma.versions.read` — Version history
- `figma.comments.read` — Comments

### Export Operations
- `figma.images.export` — Generate images

### Write Operations
- `figma.comments.write` — Post comments

### Admin Operations
- `figma.webhooks.manage` — Configure webhooks (Dangerous)

---

## Operations (Representative)

### Get File
```
GET /v1/files/{file_key}
```

### Get File Components
```
GET /v1/files/{file_key}/components
```

### Export Images
```
GET /v1/images/{file_key}?ids={node_ids}&format=svg&scale=2
```

Response:
```json
{
  "images": {
    "node_id_1": "https://s3-alpha-sig.figma.com/...",
    "node_id_2": "https://s3-alpha-sig.figma.com/..."
  }
}
```

### Get Comments
```
GET /v1/files/{file_key}/comments
```

### Post Comment
```json
POST /v1/files/{file_key}/comments
{
  "message": "Review feedback here",
  "client_meta": {"x": 100, "y": 200}
}
```

---

## Design System Access

### Component Libraries
```
GET /v1/teams/{team_id}/components
```

### Styles
```
GET /v1/files/{file_key}/styles
```

### Variables (Design Tokens)
```
GET /v1/files/{file_key}/variables/local
```

---

## Tests

### Unit Tests (Mock-Only)
- Request construction
- Response parsing
- Node tree traversal
- Export URL handling

### Integration Tests
- Mock Figma API responses
- Multi-file scenarios
- Export workflows

### E2E Compliance
- Validates NetworkConstraints
- Export URL handling
- Audit logging

---

## Acceptance Criteria
- Passes connector compliance runner (static + dynamic)
- No real Figma API calls in unit tests
- File reading works
- Component discovery works
- Asset export works (PNG, SVG, PDF)
- Design tokens extraction works
- All V2 NORMATIVE requirements satisfied

title: fcp.figma: Manifest + Capability Map (FCP2)
description:
# fcp.figma: Manifest + Capability Map (FCP2)

## Goal
Define the Figma connector’s **mechanical manifest contract** so the platform can sandbox, authorize, and mechanically test it under FCP2.

## Required contents
- Manifest archetypes (closed set):
  - `knowledge` (read designs, metadata, versions)
  - `operational` (comments, webhooks management)
  - `streaming` (webhook/event ingestion)
- Operation list + schema IDs.
- Capability families + per-operation required caps.
- NetworkConstraints:
  - pin Figma API host(s)
  - pin image export hosts / CDN hosts if distinct
  - deny broad egress; deny redirects by default
- State model declaration:
  - webhook subscription state
  - optional cache keys (must be bounded)

## Output artifacts
- Full manifest spec stored here.
- Good/bad examples for static compliance (especially export/download constraints).

## Acceptance Criteria
- Another engineer can implement `--manifest` from this bead alone.
- Static compliance can mechanically reject:
  - overly-broad export/download egress
  - host/port-encoded capability IDs

title: fcp.figma: Provisioning Automation (OAuth, webhooks, scopes)
description:
# fcp.figma: Provisioning Automation (OAuth, webhooks, scopes)

## Goal
Automate Figma onboarding with minimal human steps, while keeping secrets zone-scoped and never written to disk.

## Requirements
- OAuth2 (PKCE) flow support via provisioning recipes.
- Optional: Personal Access Token support (policy-gated).
- Scope selection:
  - minimal viable scopes for read operations
  - separate scopes/capabilities for comment writes and webhook management
- Webhook registration automation:
  - create/list/delete webhooks
  - verify webhook secret configuration

## Safety rules
- Validate credentials with safe read-only calls.
- Validate NetworkConstraints before declaring readiness.
- Never log access tokens.

## Acceptance Criteria
- `fcp doctor` verifies readiness (scopes + webhook reachability) without leaking secrets.
- Fully mockable for unit tests.

title: TEST: Figma Connector Unit/Integration Tests (mock-only)
description:

description:
# Study: Clawdbot Telegram Connector Implementation


## Goal
Study Clawdbot Telegram connector implementation to extract edge cases, rate-limit behaviors, and security lessons for FCP2.

## External surface (NetworkConstraints)
Default deny.
- Network egress MUST be restricted per-operation via manifest `NetworkConstraints`.
- Allow only the configured service host(s); HTTPS-only where applicable; deny redirects by default.
- Bound timeouts + response sizes; treat all remote responses as untrusted input; never leak secrets/PII in logs or errors.

## Zone model (mechanical)

<!-- fcp2-single-zone-note -->
**FCP2 single-zone binding note:** A connector instance binds to exactly one `ZoneId` for its entire lifetime.
The connector MUST NOT multiplex multiple zones internally.

Recommended deployment pattern: run separate connector instances in separate zones with different capability grants/policies.

## Objective

Research and document the existing clawdbot Telegram connector implementation to extract patterns, learnings, and reusable components for building FCP connectors.
